('14', 57, 1, 2, 119264) 53. THE IMMIGRATION ACT
('14', 57, 2, 3, 119288) The interpretation of this Act daily presents new difficulties.
('14', 57, 2, 4, 119352) The latest is Justice Broome’s decision in the matter of Dawad Ismail and Daya Purshotam against the Immigration Officer.
('14', 57, 2, 5, 119474) According to Justice Broome’s interpretation of the Act, the Supreme Court may not even grant an interdict against that officer, acting under the Act of last year, in respect of persons seeking to re enter the Union as was the case in the matter we are discussing.
('14', 57, 2, 6, 119739) Thus the Supreme Court will be powerless, if Justice Broome’s decision holds good, to prevent a manifest miscarriage of justice, as happened in this case, through the stupidity of the under officials.
('14', 57, 2, 7, 119940) As Justice Broome himself remarked, here the ends of justice were not defeated only because the aid of the Court was improperly invoked and as improperly given by the Court granting the interdict.
('14', 57, 2, 8, 120137) If such is the correct reading of the law, every Indian is entirely at the mercy of Immigration Officers.
('14', 57, 2, 9, 120243) The only comfort that the Court could give to the parties grossly injured was that they had not to bear the costs of crown although the proceedings were irregularly brought by them.
('14', 57, 2, 10, 120425) It is true that the Court came most reluctantly to the decision it did.
('14', 57, 2, 11, 120497) But we cannot eternally live on sympathy unless it leads to useful action.
('14', 57, 2, 12, 120572) This case is merely a sample of several others like it.
('14', 57, 2, 13, 120628) Every section of the Act—even the protective sections—seems to have been designed, wittingly or unwittingly, to harass the resident Indian population.
('14', 57, 2, 14, 120779) So that the law not only prohibits Indian immigration in practice, but it materially interferes with the liberty and the free movement, within the law, of the resident Indian population of the Union.
('14', 57, 2, 15, 120979) Take, again, the case recently decided by the now defunct Appellate Board, appointed for Natal under the Act.
('14', 57, 2, 16, 121089) There, Mr. Binns, delivering the judgment of the Board, reluctantly granted relief to a man who possessed a domicile certificate issued under the old Act and with which certificate he was completely identified.
('14', 57, 2, 17, 121300) Why was there this reluctance?
('14', 57, 2, 18, 121331) Why should an Indian be called upon to tax his memory as to what happened fifteen years ago?
('14', 57, 2, 19, 121424) The title deeds of property once granted cannot be questioned.
('14', 57, 2, 20, 121487) They are conclusive proof of title.
('14', 57, 2, 21, 121523) Why should a domicile certificate be treated differently?
('14', 57, 2, 22, 121581) These certificates were granted after due and exhaustive—and in many cases vexatious—inquiry.
('14', 57, 2, 23, 121675) By what right are they now questioned?
('14', 57, 2, 24, 121714) If the Act
('14', 58, 0, 1, 121725) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 59
('14', 58, 1, 2, 121769) gives such powers to Immigration Officers, the sooner it is amended the better it will be for both the Government and the people affected by the Act.
('14', 58, 1, 3, 121919) What is, however, perhaps more ominous even than the above mentioned legal proceedings is the severe administration of the Act.
('14', 58, 1, 4, 122047) It is clear that, had the officers done their duty by the persons who were seeking re entry—not those who were seeking to immigrate into the Union—the cases need never have arisen.
('14', 58, 1, 5, 122228) The officials are certainly going mad over their administration of the Act against persons in the Cape and Basutoland who have continually to pass through the Free State on their way to the other Provinces.
('14', 58, 1, 6, 122435) To expect them each time to take out temporary permits is to put an unwarranted tax upon their purses and is an unnecessary annoyance to the men who have to apply for permits.
('14', 58, 1, 7, 122611) The old practice of letting Indian passengers go through unchallenged never caused the slightest difficulty to the administra tion and it ought to be continued.The case of a boy that has happened in Pretoria is also of the same type.
('14', 58, 1, 8, 122845) Surely the child, whatever may be the meaning of the Act, is entitled to enter the Transvaal, seeing that he is the son beyond doubt of his father and that his mother is dead.
('14', 58, 1, 9, 123021) Indeed, the Government have practically bound themselves to recognize at least administratively the right of such children to join their parents who may be in South Africa.
('14', 58, 1, 10, 123194) But in the Pretoria case, the Appellate Board has interpreted the Act, too, in favour of the Indian applicant.
('14', 58, 1, 11, 123305) Yet the Government are not satisfied.
('14', 58, 1, 12, 123343) They must seek to upset the finding of the Appellate Board which is appointed by them and whichhas powers given largely to protect the administration rather than the persons coming under its lash.
('14', 58, 1, 13, 123540) The fact that the Government are challenging the liberal interpretation of the Act shows that they want it to be interpreted as strictly as it is administered.
('14', 58, 1, 14, 123700) It is against this wretched spirit that we must wage war, if we are to live in this country as men.
('14', 58, 2, 15, 123800) Indian Opinion, 11 2 1914
('14', 59, 0, 1, 123826) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 59, 1, 2, 123867) 54. REQUEST TO LEADERS
('14', 59, 2, 3, 123890) We have carefully studied the evidence given by Mr. Anglia and Mr. Dada Osman and it is our considered view that both the leaders have done harm to the community.
('14', 59, 2, 4, 124053) That the Commissioners pay compliments to them is of no account.
('14', 59, 2, 5, 124118) Their evidence seems to suggest that our only grievances about licences and immigration are those that they mentioned.
('14', 59, 2, 6, 124237) By giving the evidence that they did, they set a limit [to what we could demand].
('14', 59, 2, 7, 124319) It happens, however, that theirs is not the last word on behalf of the community.
('14', 59, 2, 8, 124401) Even if their demands are accepted, much will remain and, so long as this is not settled, there will always remain the possibility of the Indian community resuming satyagraha.
('14', 59, 2, 9, 124577) If they were bent on giving evidence, it was their duty to put it all together and have it formulated by a reliable lawyer before presenting it.
('14', 59, 2, 10, 124722) It was their primary duty to the community to have accepted the resolution passed by thousands of people to boycott the Commission and to have remained silent.
('14', 59, 2, 11, 124882) If, however, they wished to give evidence, they should have been more careful.
('14', 59, 2, 12, 124961) Their evidence has had the unhappy result of provoking the thoroughly hostile evidence of Mr. Wincall against us.
('14', 59, 2, 13, 125075) If Mr. Wincall were right in his facts, there would have been nothing that we could do.
('14', 59, 2, 14, 125163) But we know that his evidence is not factually true, and that he has made many statements which are altogether false.
('14', 59, 2, 15, 125281) Those who claim to be leaders should have a better sense of their duty.
('14', 59, 2, 16, 125353) If they were keen on tendering evidence, they should have produced a number of witnesses and not behaved with the utmost irresponsibility, as Mr. Sooker did, just when the Commission’s sittings were coming to a close.
('14', 59, 2, 17, 125571) They had known for a month that the Commission would be sitting and should have started preparing well beforehand so that they could give evidence which would be sound.
('14', 59, 2, 18, 125740) We therefore believe that these two leaders, instead of doing their duty by the community, have done it harm.
('14', 59, 2, 19, 125850) Having said this, we also thank them for having refrained from washing the dirty linen of the community before the Commission.
('14', 59, 2, 20, 125977) Mr. Anglia stated that he could speak with authority on behalf of all the Indians of established standing and reputation.
('14', 59, 2, 21, 126099) Who are these Indians on whose behalf he was speaking?
('14', 59, 2, 22, 126154) If Mr. Anglia’s claim is right, we pity these well established Indians and feel sorry for them.
('14', 59, 2, 23, 126250) We hold that Mr. Anglia has erred in making such a statement
('14', 60, 0, 1, 126311) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 61
('14', 60, 1, 2, 126355) and has failed to pay due regard to his position and the responsibility that rests on him.
('14', 60, 1, 3, 126446) About Mr. Sooker, we simply refuse to comment.
('14', 60, 1, 4, 126493) The youngman is carried away by pride.
('14', 60, 1, 5, 126532) As regards Mr. Aiyar, what can we say?
('14', 60, 1, 6, 126571) He has given evidence without thinking.
('14', 60, 1, 7, 126611) It was good of him to have made it plain that he spoke not on behalf of anyone, but on his own responsibility and only for himself.
('14', 60, 1, 8, 126743) He might not have, therefore, done much harm.
('14', 60, 2, 9, 126789) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 11 2 1914
('14', 60, 3, 10, 126831) 55. ON MARRIAGES
('14', 60, 4, 11, 126848) We know that the marriage question has now become the most serious one in this country.
('14', 60, 4, 12, 126936) The Commission is in a fix about it.
('14', 60, 4, 13, 126973) The question raises the issue of an important amendment in the laws of the country.
('14', 60, 4, 14, 127057) We hold that the evidence given by Mr. Anglia and others on this subject was misguided.
('14', 60, 4, 15, 127145) The problem is so complicated that they should not have meddled with it.
('14', 60, 4, 16, 127218) In any case, they should have done so with full understanding.
('14', 60, 4, 17, 127281) Let us now consider what the question involves.
('14', 60, 4, 18, 127329) The correspondence carried on by Mr. Cachalia means that an Indian marriage which is monogamous in fact should be recog nized.
('14', 60, 4, 19, 127456) If a person has more than one wife, the Government, as a matter of grace, should permit the entry of all his wives and his minor children, provided he is an old resident.
('14', 60, 4, 20, 127627) If anyone marries two women in future, he should be allowed to bring in one of them.
('14', 60, 4, 21, 127712) Wives of the last two categories will be entitled legally to no other rights.
('14', 60, 4, 22, 127790) In this, we are not binding ourselves for the future.
('14', 60, 4, 23, 127844) The Commission, it appears, insists that, where a man with only one wife desires to have his marri age legally recognized, the marriage should be considered monoga mous only if he makes a solemn declaration that he will not take another wife during the life time of the first one.
('14', 60, 4, 24, 128125) Mr. Gandhi has strongly opposed this line of argument and pointed out that signing such a declaration amounts to repudiating Hinduism and Islam in the matter of marriage.
('14', 60, 4, 25, 128296) If the law recognized only the first wife, that would be a different matter.
('14', 60, 4, 26, 128373) In this case, no Hindu or Muslim would be acting contrary to his religion.
('14', 60, 4, 27, 128448) Recognition of such marriages would safeguard the rights of hundreds of Indians and these Indians will generally have only one wife.
('14', 60, 4, 28, 128581) The Government is committed to
('14', 61, 0, 1, 128612) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 61, 1, 2, 128653) recognizing the wife in a monogamous marriage.
('14', 61, 1, 3, 128700) The law here also does that.
('14', 61, 1, 4, 128729) The Commission, or anyone else for that matter, has no right to tie us down for the future.
('14', 61, 1, 5, 128821) True, the [exclusive] recognition of monogamous marriages is likely to curb the practice of polygamy.
('14', 61, 1, 6, 128923) Which husband will like to have one wife legally recognized and another treated as a concubine?
('14', 61, 1, 7, 129019) Less than this we cannot accept.
('14', 61, 1, 8, 129052) More than this it is almost impossible that we can get.
('14', 61, 1, 9, 129108) In any case, it seems satyagraha will above be justified for securing more.
('14', 61, 1, 10, 129184) If our demands are met as above, the honour [of our religions] will have been upheld and hundreds of Indian families will have a chance of being happy.
('14', 61, 2, 11, 129336) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 11 2 1914
('14', 61, 3, 12, 129378) 56. IMPORTANT IMMIGRATION CASES
('14', 61, 4, 13, 129410) There have been two important immigration cases in Natal.
('14', 61, 4, 14, 129468) As we were busy writing on other matters, we have had so far no time to explain them.
('14', 61, 4, 15, 129554) We take the opportunity of doing so now.
('14', 61, 4, 16, 129595) In one case, an unusual one, the judgment was given by Justice Broome.
('14', 61, 4, 17, 129666) The Indian concerned might have had to leave this country altogether.
('14', 61, 4, 18, 129736) The position was this: The petitioner, who arrived from India in October last, was not permitted to come in.
('14', 61, 4, 19, 129845) He did not appeal against this as required by law.
('14', 61, 4, 20, 129896) He went back to India, but came again in January.
('14', 61, 4, 21, 129946) Again the officer stopped him.
('14', 61, 4, 22, 129977) This time the petitioner’s lawyer obtained an interdict from the Supreme Court, which prevented the officer from deporting him.
('14', 61, 4, 23, 130105) Finally, the Attorney General conducted an inquiry and found that the petitioner had been wrongly sent back and that he was entitled to stay in Natal.
('14', 61, 4, 24, 130256) His right of residence, thus, was recognized, having been admitted by the Attorney General.
('14', 61, 4, 25, 130348) But the Court had yet to decide who should pay the expenses incurred in obtaining the interdict against the officer.
('14', 61, 4, 26, 130465) Deciding the point, Mr. Justice Broome held that there was no provision in the lawgranting the right of applying for an interdict against an [immigration] officer.
('14', 61, 4, 27, 130629) Under the law, the officer’s order can only be set aside in a case involving corruption and bribery.
('14', 61, 4, 28, 130730) There was no such thing in this case.
('14', 61, 4, 29, 130768) Nevertheless, the Court felt that the officer had acted hastily and erred in sending the petitioner away.
('14', 61, 4, 30, 130874) Had an interdict not been granted, legal though this might have been, it would have resulted in
('14', 62, 0, 1, 130970) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 63
('14', 62, 1, 2, 131014) injustice to the petitioner and cost him his right.
('14', 62, 1, 3, 131066) The Court decided that, in the circumstances, the costs should be borne by the parties themselves.
('14', 62, 1, 4, 131165) This decision cannot be said to be in our favour.
('14', 62, 1, 5, 131215) If the Court cannot intervene in cases of undue haste on the part of officers, the latter might pass arrogant and arbitrary orders, as caprice takes them.
('14', 62, 1, 6, 131370) In matters involving rights of persons, there is bound to be injustice if supreme powers are vested exclusively in the Executive.
('14', 62, 1, 7, 131500) Justice Broome’s decision cannot be accepted as correct.
('14', 62, 1, 8, 131557) If fact,Courts always have powers of granting interdicts and the legal point involved here, we believe, will bear being taken in appeal to Bloemfontein, should a similar situation arise again.
('14', 62, 1, 9, 131750) Meanwhile, it is necessary at any rate to write to the Government about it.
('14', 62, 1, 10, 131826) The second case relates to a decision of Mr. Beans.
('14', 62, 1, 11, 131878) He has now left the Immigration Appeal Court.
('14', 62, 1, 12, 131924) The decision about which we wish to write was his last one.
('14', 62, 1, 13, 131984) True, it does justice, but Mr. Beans was not happy giving it and did not miss having a fling at the community.
('14', 62, 1, 14, 132095) Mr. Justice Broome did an injustice in his decision, but showed that he was not happy doing so.
('14', 62, 1, 15, 132191) Thus two persons, both occupying seats of justice, have two different temperaments.
('14', 62, 1, 16, 132275) The facts of the case decided by Mr. Beans are simple.
('14', 62, 1, 17, 132330) The petitioner had a certificate of 1896. He had been to and returned from India twice with this certificate.
('14', 62, 1, 18, 132440) On this third occasion, the officer stopped him on his arrival and so there was an appeal.
('14', 62, 1, 19, 132531) Mr. Beans remarked rather gratuitously that the petitioner was not stating the facts, but lacked the courage to send him back.
('14', 62, 1, 20, 132658) How is it possible to send back a man who has been here twice?
('14', 62, 1, 21, 132721) For this reason and also because the officer acknowledged that he [the petitioner] was the one who had taken out the certificate, Mr. Beans could not give an unfavourable decision.
('14', 62, 1, 22, 132902) Though giving a favourable decision, he allowed himself to remark that the officer did well in stopping him.
('14', 62, 1, 23, 133011) He went further, and said that, in such cases, criminal proceedings should be instituted; with that end in view, he has forwarded all the evidence regarding the petitioner to the public prosecutor.
('14', 62, 1, 24, 133209) Such is the terrible position we are in.
('14', 62, 1, 25, 133250) A harsh law, administered harshly, and the difficulty of obtaining redress in the lower courts.
('14', 62, 1, 26, 133346) All the same, this case, in all likelihood, will have the result of making it difficult for officers to deport those who may enter on their own certificates.
('14', 62, 2, 27, 133504) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 11 2 1914
('14', 63, 0, 1, 133546) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 63, 1, 2, 133587) 57. RIGHTS OF MINORS
('14', 63, 2, 3, 133608) There was recently a very important immigration case in Pretoria.
('14', 63, 2, 4, 133674) The Immigration Officer refused to admit a Muslim boy.
('14', 63, 2, 5, 133729) We shall say nothing here about some odd reasons given by him but only examine the legal point involved.
('14', 63, 2, 6, 133834) The reason for refusing admission was that the boy was born of a marriage celebrated according to the Muslim faith; since the law does not recognize Muslim marriages, the children of such marriages could not be admitted.
('14', 63, 2, 7, 134055) The applicant wentin appeal against this decision.
('14', 63, 2, 8, 134106) It came up before the new Board appointed at Pretoria.
('14', 63, 2, 9, 134161) The relevant section of the law provides that the wife and children of a man entitled to be here can come in, and the persons so entitled to come in will include a wife by a monogamous marriage recognized in law, and his children.
('14', 63, 2, 10, 134392) The Court interpreted this section in favour of the petitioner.
('14', 63, 2, 11, 134456) Its argument ran as follows: “True, only a wife whose marriage is recognized by law can come in, but there is no rule that only her children can enter.
('14', 63, 2, 12, 134608) Children can come in, whether the parents are married or not.
('14', 63, 2, 13, 134670) This will include the children of a legally married couple.
('14', 63, 2, 14, 134730) Children of couples living together without being legally married are not barred.” Following this argument, the Court gave a decision in favour of the petitioner.
('14', 63, 2, 15, 134893) We must not jump to conclusions from this argument of the Court.
('14', 63, 2, 16, 134958) It will not carry conviction.
('14', 63, 2, 17, 134988) If the Court’s argument is correct, then it will also apply to women.
('14', 63, 2, 18, 135058) In the relevant section of the law, the words “wife” and “child” occur at two places.
('14', 63, 2, 19, 135144) The Court has given different meanings to the word “child” in the two places, but has given the same interpretation to the words “wife” at both places.
('14', 63, 2, 20, 135296) The Court’s reasons for doing so sound plausible but lack substance.
('14', 63, 2, 21, 135365) Its decision, therefore, does not remove our misgivings.
('14', 63, 2, 22, 135422) If, however, its interpretation is correct, we must admit that our protests regarding the position of children in connection with the marriage question will lose some of their force.
('14', 63, 2, 23, 135605) Because children born out of wedlock have been given the right of entry, it does not follow that we have secured all our rights.
('14', 63, 2, 24, 135734) The Immigration Officer has not been happy over the decision of the Court and, therefore, the case will go, at his instance, to the Supreme Court.
('14', 63, 2, 25, 135881) Let us see what happens there.
('14', 63, 2, 26, 135912) That the Immigration Officer is likely to take this case to a higher court shows that the Government does not mean well by us.
('14', 63, 2, 27, 136039) More, it wants to have the laws interpreted strictly and by adopting such methods to root us out altogether.
('14', 63, 2, 28, 136148) It should be realized that we have resorted to satyagraha
('14', 64, 0, 1, 136206) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 65
('14', 64, 1, 2, 136250) against this state of mind.
('14', 64, 1, 3, 136278) Our sufferings will not end with one campaign of satyagraha; we shall have to use this weapon whenever they become intolerable.
('14', 64, 1, 4, 136406) If we do so often enough, the Government will see our strength, will know what our real demands are and give up its obduracy.
('14', 64, 1, 5, 136532) We can see from this case that with the new Appeal Boards things have improved.
('14', 64, 1, 6, 136612) We are sure an Appeal Board of the older type would never have given such a decision.
('14', 64, 1, 7, 136698) The old Appeal Board at Pretoria would have acted in the same manner as its counterpart at Durban in the case of Kulsumbibi.
('14', 64, 1, 8, 136823) We hope, in this case, the petitioner will fight in the Supreme Court with the same skill as he has shown so far.
('14', 64, 1, 9, 136937) When we say that the case is not strong, we do not mean that there are no arguments for it.
('14', 64, 1, 10, 137029) If the Supreme Court takes up a liberal attitude, it may accept the arguments advanced in favour of the petitioner, in which case, the children of all wives will be able to come in.
('14', 64, 1, 11, 137211) If the decision goes against us, there will be no need to feel discouraged, for the great fight on the issue of marriage which we have been carrying on will decide this question too.
('14', 64, 1, 12, 137394) We can very well see from this case how big is our struggle and how many important results it is likely to yield.
('14', 64, 2, 13, 137508) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 11 2 1914
('14', 64, 3, 14, 137550) 58. OUR HOPES
('14', 64, 4, 15, 137564) A gentleman writes to us:
('14', 64, 5, 16, 137590) This is, indeed, a rare time for you, the like of which will not recur.
('14', 64, 5, 17, 137662) Circums tances will never again favour you with a similar opportunity, what with the support India has been giving you and the strong sympathies that have been aroused.
('14', 64, 5, 18, 137831) Nothing, therefore, should be left out from the full citizenship rights which are to be achieved, so that our people may not have to endure hardships again.
('14', 64, 5, 19, 137988) Besides the matters in dispute, there are the questions of the right to own land, the Gold Law, the Township Act, freedom to hold licences in the Transvaal, the franchise, the prohibi tion on Indians putting up stores on new stations, while the Jews are free to do so, and reserved compartments in trains being packed with as many as twelve men.
('14', 64, 5, 20, 138334) There must be many other matters besides these of which you will be aware.
('14', 64, 5, 21, 138409) There is, of course, no need for me to write.
('14', 64, 5, 22, 138455) I have only mentioned this in passing.
('14', 64, 5, 23, 138494) All that I mean is that the present opportunity will not come again and that, therefore, every
('14', 65, 0, 1, 138589) 66 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 65, 1, 2, 138630) right should be secured.
('14', 65, 1, 3, 138655) It is well that we have received this letter.
('14', 65, 1, 4, 138701) We believe that what this one gentleman has put in writing is in the minds of many.
('14', 65, 1, 5, 138785) We have, however, to say with regret that such hopes will lead to disappointment.
('14', 65, 1, 6, 138867) Like everything else, satyagraha has its limits.
('14', 65, 1, 7, 138916) To understand how much may be achieved through it is the first step to success in it.
('14', 65, 1, 8, 139002) It needs to be understood, once and for all, that the path of truth is not meant for ends not consistent with truth.
('14', 65, 1, 9, 139119) It is our belief that raising our demands will amount to untruthfulness.
('14', 65, 1, 10, 139192) Many things, moreover, which can be achieved through satyagraha we shall surely fail to achieve if we are not uncompromising enough in our regard for truth.
('14', 65, 1, 11, 139349) For instance, we should have the right to [own] land in the Transvaal.
('14', 65, 1, 12, 139420) But that was not one of our demands in this struggle.
('14', 65, 1, 13, 139474) We cannot, therefore, advance it at this stage.
('14', 65, 1, 14, 139522) The strength that may be needed to demand the right in future, we do not as yet see in the community.
('14', 65, 1, 15, 139624) In the present satyagraha, the indentured Indians have shaken the world.
('14', 65, 1, 16, 139697) Inspired by their strength, India resounded with protests.
('14', 65, 1, 17, 139756) But we certainly cannot on that strength secure land rights.
('14', 65, 1, 18, 139817) For the right to vote, we need to have many things in us without which, as we believe, the franchise would prove unavailing, even if granted.
('14', 65, 1, 19, 139959) We have no doubt in our minds that it will be a long time before we have the vote.
('14', 65, 1, 20, 140042) For that India herself will have to wake up, indepen dently of everything else.
('14', 65, 1, 21, 140122) In the matter of the Gold Law, licences, etc, provision is made in Section 5. Not that all our grievances in these matters will disappear by virtue of this Section, but an assurance from the Government that the laws in regard to them will be reasonably administered will enable us to build further and obtain redress without resorting to satyagraha.
('14', 65, 1, 22, 140472) As regards hardships on railways, we need to have some grit.
('14', 65, 1, 23, 140533) If there are already six men in a compartment, the seventh must display courage.
('14', 65, 1, 24, 140614) If he demands another compart ment, the conductor is bound to provide it.
('14', 65, 1, 25, 140688) As long as we are prepared to submit to kicks, there will be men ever ready to deliver them.
('14', 65, 1, 26, 140781) If a man does not fight for himself in such matters and is trampled over in consequence, nothing that we can do will help him.
('14', 65, 1, 27, 140908) Letters may be addressed and even assurances that such things will not recur may be received.
('14', 65, 1, 28, 141002) The conductors, however,will persist in their autocratic ways.
('14', 65, 2, 29, 141065) “The opportunity will not come again, we shall not have a fight like this in future.” Such things have been said during every campaign.
('14', 65, 2, 30, 141201) However, the campaign in 1908 turned out to be on a
('14', 66, 0, 1, 141253) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 67
('14', 66, 1, 2, 141297) larger scale than that of 1907, and the one in 1913 than that of 1908. More people went to gaol during 1908 11 than during 1907 8. In 1913, the very highest limit was reached.
('14', 66, 1, 3, 141473) Even so, when the fight comes again, it will go one better.
('14', 66, 1, 4, 141533) It is up to us to see that it does.
('14', 66, 1, 5, 141569) Even when we have the best of dishes placed before us, we can eat only according to our capacity.
('14', 66, 1, 6, 141667) If we eat in excess, we shall get indigestion and may even die.
('14', 66, 1, 7, 141731) The same is true of opportunities.
('14', 66, 1, 8, 141766) The opportunity of the future will far excel the present one, but only if, ignoring it, we rest satisfied with our original demands.
('14', 66, 1, 9, 141899) If we were to raise our demands ever so little, we are sure we would lose the sympathy we have both here and in India.
('14', 66, 1, 10, 142018) “The community may not have to endure hardships again”—these are words of cowardice.
('14', 66, 1, 11, 142103) The community will not acquire stamina except through suffering.
('14', 66, 1, 12, 142168) Every step forward is bound to cost some effort.
('14', 66, 1, 13, 142217) What we have gone through is not to be looked upon as hardship but as requisite effort.
('14', 66, 1, 14, 142305) To wish that one may not have to make any such effort is to desire that Nature’s law shall cease to function.
('14', 66, 1, 15, 142415) Never, in the wide world, have we come across, nor cease to function.
('14', 66, 1, 16, 142485) Never, in the wide world, have we come across, nor have we in history read of, an instance of achievement without effort.
('14', 66, 1, 17, 142607) Finally, Indians need to realize in all seriousness that it is the first principle of satyagraha not to enhance our original demands.
('14', 66, 1, 18, 142741) The second principle is that what is obtained by satyagraha can be retained only by satyagraha.
('14', 66, 1, 19, 142837) The third principle is that what is attainable by satyagraha cannot but be achieved and that satyagraha knows no such word as “defeat”.
('14', 66, 1, 20, 142973) We are convinced that, if this is understood, no misconceptions will arise in the community and that it will be able to make excellent progress.
('14', 66, 2, 21, 143118) [From Gujarati]
('14', 66, 3, 22, 143134) Indian Opinion, 11 2 1914
('14', 67, 0, 1, 143160) 68 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 67, 1, 2, 143201) 59. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH 1
('14', 67, 2, 3, 143236) February 14, 1914
('14', 67, 3, 4, 143254) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('14', 67, 4, 5, 143275) Now that you know the worst about Ritch, you will have to handle the matter in the gentlest manner possible.
('14', 67, 4, 6, 143384) If anything is disclosed apart from my side, you will step in at once and in any event see to it that you secure control over all the funds that may come in future.
('14', 67, 4, 7, 143549) What a tragedy.
('14', 67, 4, 8, 143565) I do feel like taking you away and both of us escaping to the jungle.
('14', 67, 4, 9, 143635) What a snare and delusion this wretched civilization, in the midst of which you and I are still living and of the bitter fruit of which we are still tasting!
('14', 67, 4, 10, 143793) Woe to us if we tarry in it a minute longer than may be absolutely necessary.
('14', 67, 4, 11, 143871) Do wind up your affairs satisfactorily and flee from the tyrant whilst yet there is time.
('14', 67, 4, 12, 143961) Do not deceive yourself into the belief that we are saved until we are quite out of it which we will not be quite even in India all of a sudden.
('14', 67, 4, 13, 144106) The Indian visit will be merely a preparation for the glorious future which must be unalloyed by the poison of the modern craze.
('14', 67, 4, 14, 144235) Do not put your trust in money please.
('14', 67, 4, 15, 144274) You know that you are free to come to Cape Town whenever you wish to come.
('14', 67, 4, 16, 144349) Only finish your work there, both public and private, for there may be no time left after the legislation in Cape Town.
('14', 67, 4, 17, 144469) With love, Yours, UPPER HOUSE

('14', 68, 2, 3, 144832) [CAPE TOWN,] Sunday [After February 15, 1914]
('14', 68, 3, 4, 144878) DEAR SHRI RAOJIBHAI, I must have piled up claims on you in some previous life.
('14', 68, 3, 5, 144957) Else, how could I deserve so much love from you?
('14', 68, 3, 6, 145006) Still, the love that you showed me in my misfortune yesterday was beyond description.
('14', 68, 3, 7, 145092) For this, I pray, may you both grow brighter in your souls.
('14', 68, 3, 8, 145152) You should pray, likewise, that having experienced this love [of yours], I may grow the stronger in my faith in soul force.
('14', 68, 3, 9, 145276) If a trivial pledge, none too important in itself, i.e., the mere undertaking of tapascharya, can achieve so much, there can be no measuring, as the simple rule of three will show, how much may be achieved by tapascharya actually practised.
('14', 68, 3, 10, 145517) Quite so.
('14', 68, 3, 11, 145527) Had I not taken the vow, I would not have tasted pure love as I did; there would have been no speedy discovery of truth and the poor children would not have been proved innocent as they actually were.
('14', 68, 4, 12, 145728) has had to come down from the heights where I had imagined her to be.

('14', 68, 4, 17, 145949) We should act so as not to remind her of them.
('14', 68, 4, 18, 145996) Encourage her to become proficient in household work.
('14', 68, 4, 19, 146050) See that none of the children insults her .

('14', 69, 6, 16, 147621) 62. ANGLIA’S EVIDENCE
('14', 69, 7, 17, 147643) With reference to our criticism, Mr. Anglia writes as follows to Mr. Gandhi:
('14', 69, 8, 18, 147720) I have carefully gone through your comments, in Indian Opinion, on my evidence.
('14', 69, 8, 19, 147800) I very much regret that you thought it fit to pass judgment before publish ing the full evidence in Gujarati.
('14', 69, 8, 20, 147910) Was it worthily done?
('14', 69, 8, 21, 147932) Be that as it may, I believe that the paper exists for the community, and you claim to serve the community.
('14', 69, 8, 22, 148040) If, therefore, you mean to serve it well, you should print the full text of the evidence in the next issue.
('14', 69, 8, 23, 148148) You may then make whatever comments you wish to.
('14', 69, 8, 24, 148197) Until you reproduce the entire evidence, how can the public form their own judgment?
('14', 69, 9, 25, 148282) 1 From the reference to Gandhiji’s being in train (vide fn.
('14', 69, 9, 26, 148342) to preceding item), it appears he reached Cape Town on the morning of February 16. This letter was written the next day and C. F. Andrews left for England on February 21, a Saturday.
('14', 70, 0, 1, 148525) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 71
('14', 70, 1, 2, 148569) We certainly intend to reproduce the evidence.
('14', 70, 1, 3, 148616) We took it that everyone must have read it in the local papers.
('14', 70, 1, 4, 148680) But we have with us a verbatim report.
('14', 70, 1, 5, 148719) We intend to publish in Gujarati the evidence as it appears in this report so that no injustice is done.
('14', 70, 1, 6, 148824) We offered our comments after seeing the report of the evidence in the papers.
('14', 70, 1, 7, 148903) If, after going through the verbatim report, we feel like changing our opinion, we will certainly do so.
('14', 70, 1, 8, 149008) But we found the evidence as reported in the papers so bad that we did not think it proper to wait till we had read the full text.
('14', 70, 1, 9, 149139) It was our duty to give a timely warning.
('14', 70, 1, 10, 149181) If the evidence was not correctly reported in the Press, Mr. Anglia and Mr. Dada Osman should have sent a correction to the Press.
('14', 70, 1, 11, 149312) In any case, we shall, as we have said, write again after going through the full text of the evidence.

('14', 76, 5, 7, 158070) 71. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('14', 76, 6, 8, 158103) [CAPE TOWN, February 24, 1914] 1
('14', 76, 7, 9, 158136) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('14', 76, 8, 10, 158157) I have your letter enclosing Ramdas’s and others’.
('14', 76, 8, 11, 158208) You may well want to treasure Ramdas’s letter.
('14', 76, 8, 12, 158255) It is a gem.
('14', 76, 8, 13, 158268) The boy seems to be shaping beautifully.
('14', 76, 8, 14, 158309) If the composition is his own, it is also good.
('14', 76, 8, 15, 158357) Thambi is now there.
('14', 76, 8, 16, 158378) Please collar him and pacify him.
('14', 76, 8, 17, 158412) Mrs. Gandhi is better but she has ups and downs and continues to cause anxiety.
('14', 76, 8, 18, 158492) Imam is doing good work.
('14', 76, 8, 19, 158517) We have not come here a moment too soon.
('14', 76, 8, 20, 158558) Mrs. Gandhi and I went over to see Miss Hobhouse.
('14', 76, 8, 21, 158608) We saw there Mrs. Botha and Lady Gladstone.
('14', 76, 8, 22, 158652) Miss Hobhouse has a divine face.
('14', 76, 8, 23, 158685) Have never seen a diviner face.
('14', 76, 8, 24, 158717) Gokhale by his features took me by storm.
('14', 76, 8, 25, 158759) Miss Hobhouse has done likewise, only more so.
('14', 76, 8, 26, 158806) I feel like gazing at her in awe for hours.
('14', 76, 9, 27, 158850) Thursday, March 19 The above was found among my papers.
('14', 76, 9, 28, 158906) I knew I had mislaid this.
('14', 76, 9, 29, 158933) But I think that I gave you the substance of what is above written.
('14', 76, 9, 30, 159001) However, you should have it as it is.
('14', 76, 9, 31, 159039) The report of the Commission is very fair and reasonable.
('14', 76, 9, 32, 159097) 2 It is a creditable document and a complete vindication of our position.
('14', 76, 9, 33, 159171) With love,
('14', 76, 10, 34, 159182) Yours, UPPER HOUSE

('14', 77, 3, 6, 159634) 72. LETTER TO RAOJIBHAI PATEL
('14', 77, 4, 7, 159664) CAPE TOWN, Maha Vad 30 [February 24, 1914] 1
('14', 77, 5, 8, 159709) DEAR FRIEND,
('14', 77, 6, 9, 159722) Your letter about J, I have sent on to Doctor and the one about M, I destroyed after reading.
('14', 77, 6, 10, 159816) Putting that letter in his hand might, I thought, have the wrong effect on him.
('14', 77, 6, 11, 159896) Now I feel, however, that you should communicate these views to him direct.
('14', 77, 6, 12, 159972) I have formed a very bad impression about him.
('14', 77, 6, 13, 160019) It seemed to me that, if he were to read your letter, he would be angry with you and would run into sin, and that would have been a state far worse than you have described.
('14', 77, 6, 14, 160192) I thought later whether or no I should send it on to him and in the end decided as above.
('14', 77, 6, 15, 160282) It is beyond all doubt that, if we keep back anything from one whom we trust or give a false impression on about us, we would come to not good.
('14', 77, 6, 16, 160426) And so J’s and .
('14', 77, 6, 17, 160443) .’s sins have been regarded as heinous.
('14', 77, 6, 18, 160483) It is because of their extreme hypocrisy that they could be guilty of such [sins].
('14', 77, 6, 19, 160566) If they had no mind to deceive, they would, after they had turned into beasts under the urge of passion, have soon become human beings again and stopped pursuing pleasure.
('14', 77, 6, 20, 160738) One seems now to be back on the right path and the other caught in the toils of desire and given over to hypocrisy.
('14', 77, 7, 21, 160854) [Blessings from MOHANDAS]
('14', 77, 8, 22, 160880) [From Gujarati] Mahatma Gandhijina Patro

('14', 78, 1, 2, 161069) 73. IN MEMORIAM
('14', 78, 2, 3, 161085) In another column we record the lamented death of yet another martyr to the passive resistance cause.
('14', 78, 2, 4, 161187) Miss Valliamah Moonsamy, a young lady not yet in her twenties, was one of those devoted Indian women who sought imprisonment in protest against a marriage law that dishonoured her parents’ marriage and cast a stigma upon herown birth.
('14', 78, 2, 5, 161422) Her sudden and unexpected demise, two days after her return home, holds in it all the elements of tragedy.
('14', 78, 2, 6, 161529) We mourn the loss of a noble daughter of India who did her simple duty without question, and who has set an example of womanly fortitude, pride and virtue that will, we are sure, not be lost upon the Indian community.
('14', 78, 2, 7, 161747) We tender to her family our most respectful sympathy.
('14', 78, 3, 8, 161801) Indian Opinion, 25 2 1914
('14', 78, 4, 9, 161827) 74. UNTIMELY DEATH OF A YOUNG PASSIVE RESISTER
('14', 78, 5, 10, 161874) It is with extreme regret we announce the death of Miss Valliamah, the eldest daughter of Mr. R. Moonsamy Moodaliar of Johannesburg, on the 22nd instant at Johannesburg, after a prolonged illness in gaol.
('14', 78, 5, 11, 162079) It appears that she was taken to bed immediately after her conviction, and also after her release was suffering greatly.
('14', 78, 5, 12, 162200) The late Miss Valliamah was born in Johannesburg in 1898 and attended the Government School.
('14', 78, 5, 13, 162293) She joined the passive resistance struggle on the 29th October last and proceeded to Newcastle with a party of ladies.
('14', 78, 5, 14, 162412) She afterwards rendered assistance at Charlestown, Dundee, Ladysmith, Dannhauser, Maritzburg, Tongaat and Durban.
('14', 78, 5, 15, 162526) She eventually re crossed the Transvaal border and was convicted, with her mother and others, at Volksrust on the 22nd of December 1913, to three months’ imprisonment with hard labour and was discharged on the 11th instant in terms of the Provisional Agreement Her father is one of the pioneer Indian settlers of the Transvaal.
('14', 78, 5, 16, 162854) He was once in gaol as a passive resister and during the last campaign was very ill and only came out of the hospital where he underwent an operation recently.
('14', 78, 5, 17, 163014) We share the sorrows of the parents and express our deepest sympathy at their irreparable loss.
('14', 78, 6, 18, 163110) Indian Opinion, 25 2 1914

('14', 80, 4, 9, 165451) 76. LETTER TO JAMNADAS GANDHI
('14', 80, 5, 10, 165481) [CAPE TOWN,] Phagan Sud 2, 1970 [February 26, 1914]
('14', 80, 6, 11, 165533) JAMNADAS,
('14', 80, 7, 12, 165543) I see that you and Manilal have for once failed to understand me.
('14', 80, 7, 13, 165609) Had I thought that it was for your good to keep you, I would not have sent you away merely to serve my convenience.
('14', 80, 7, 14, 165725) I could not have fought against the atmosphere here.
('14', 80, 7, 15, 165778) You have no idea of how subtle its effect can be.
('14', 80, 7, 16, 165828) 1 I noted Dr. Gool’s priceless worth long before any of you did.
('14', 80, 7, 17, 165893) However, just as I recognize similar worth in you and yet consider you weak and mere children, and would hesitate to place anyone under your charge, much in the same way I would hesitate to place innocent youths like you under Dr. Gool’s influence.
('14', 80, 7, 18, 166142) Dr. Gool himself knows that he is a mere child.
('14', 80, 7, 19, 166190) He knows his shortcomings too and that is the reason he has kept his own brother away from him.
('14', 80, 7, 20, 166286) .is rash and passionate.
('14', 80, 7, 21, 166311) I do not want to see such rashness and passion in you.
('14', 80, 7, 22, 166366) You have not acquired the discrimination of the swan 2. If you had, there would have been no occasion for me to criticize you so harshly.
('14', 80, 7, 23, 166504) You have found my excess of love scorching on this occasion.
('14', 80, 7, 24, 166565) That happens.
('14', 80, 7, 25, 166579) Calm yourself down, though.
('14', 80, 7, 26, 166607) I have not acted without thinking.
('14', 80, 7, 27, 166642) You are wrong in charging me with arguing like a lawyer.
('14', 80, 7, 28, 166699) Once before also you said this.
('14', 80, 7, 29, 166731) I find from experience that I possess in an especial degree the gift of analysis and of discriminating right from wrong and, in the result, my nice arguments sound like special pleading to others.
('14', 80, 7, 30, 166928) All the same, you may unhesitatingly say whatever you wish to in self defence or with a view to putting me right.
('14', 80, 7, 31, 167042) That is your duty.
('14', 80, 7, 32, 167061) I insist on your continuing to write to me.

('14', 81, 3, 5, 167340) 77. LETTER TO MANILAL GANDHI
('14', 81, 4, 6, 167369) [CAPE TOWN, About February 26, 1914] 1
('14', 81, 5, 7, 167408) 2You have sinned, without knowing it, in charging me with cruelty.
('14', 81, 5, 8, 167475) How could I have grown cruel in fifteen days?
('14', 81, 5, 9, 167521) I have given no such impression to others.
('14', 81, 5, 10, 167564) Nothing of the sort happened in Phoenix.
('14', 81, 5, 11, 167605) I have grown very tender to Ba, as she has observed.
('14', 81, 5, 12, 167658) If I turned cruel to you, what little goodness I claim would be no more than a show and I would think that my life had been wasted.
('14', 81, 5, 13, 167790) But I shall no doubt appear cruel to you at present.
('14', 81, 5, 14, 167843) 3 The veil of ignorance which prevented me from seeing the same veil over you has vanished, leaving only pure love.
('14', 81, 5, 15, 167959) This love appears cruel to you for the time being, for, like a physician, I must make you swallow bitter draughts.
('14', 81, 5, 16, 168074) 4 I have grown impatient to help you.
('14', 81, 5, 17, 168112) 5 to become perfect.
('14', 81, 5, 18, 168133) Impatience is my weakness.
('14', 81, 5, 19, 168160) To the extent that I am impatient, I am but a fond lover.
('14', 81, 5, 20, 168218) I have fondness enough in me yet to make me attached to you for being my son.
('14', 81, 5, 21, 168296) When that has gone, even the cruelty that you think you see in me you will see no more.
('14', 81, 5, 22, 168384) Meanwhile, please bear with me.
('14', 81, 5, 23, 168416) And now for the contradictions in your letter.
('14', 81, 5, 24, 168463) For three days you did not [as you say] go out to see Cape Town because of my harsh words.
('14', 81, 5, 25, 168554) And yet, when leaving, you expressed a desire to do so, though I was in a rage.
('14', 81, 5, 26, 168634) The harsh words had been there, even on Sunday.
('14', 81, 5, 27, 168682) Believing that I was cruel, how could you hope to learn anything by living with me?
('14', 81, 5, 28, 168766) You showed yourself very keen on

('14', 82, 1, 5, 169221) It is your duty not to take notice of my faults.

('14', 82, 4, 18, 170004) 7 BUITENSINGLE, February 27, 1914
('14', 82, 5, 19, 170038) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('14', 82, 6, 20, 170059) Why very Low House?
('14', 82, 6, 21, 170079) I see nothing wrong in your letter regarding food.
('14', 82, 6, 22, 170130) I have seen nobody who has been able to deny himself so much of the world’s good things of life as you have.
('14', 82, 6, 23, 170239) And what does it matter if you have been taking macaroni about which you have so satisfied yourself.
('14', 82, 6, 24, 170340) Indeed if you went back to rice and tomatoes, I should not worry.
('14', 82, 6, 25, 170406) I would certainly like you not to go back to vegetables.
('14', 82, 6, 26, 170463) But your dissatisfaction is that you have been obliged to discuss your food so much.
('14', 82, 6, 27, 170548) We are food reformers and so we cannot help it.
('14', 82, 6, 28, 170596) When our reform becomes part of our nature, we shall cease to discuss it.
('14', 82, 6, 29, 170670) If I discuss it less than you do (which I doubt) it must be because mine has become more natural to me than yours to you.
('14', 82, 6, 30, 170792) Though I love and almost adore Andrews so, I would not exchange you for him.
('14', 82, 6, 31, 170869) You still remain the dearest and the nearest to me and so far as my own selfish nature is considered I know that in

('14', 83, 1, 2, 171026) my lonely journey through the world, you will be the last (if even that) to say good bye to me.
('14', 83, 1, 3, 171122) What right had I to expect so much from you!
('14', 83, 2, 4, 171167) Now about Manilal.
('14', 83, 2, 5, 171186) I have given you some idea.
('14', 83, 2, 6, 171214) He and Jamnadas appeared to me unbalanced.
('14', 83, 2, 7, 171257) They did the very things that they used to criticize in others.
('14', 83, 2, 8, 171321) For instance, they give themselves every indulgence that they denied themselves at Phoenix.
('14', 83, 2, 9, 171413) If Hanif too[k] something outside Phoenix, both of them used to bring it to my notice.
('14', 83, 2, 10, 171500) In spite of Manilal’s sad experience, both took the greatest freedom with the girls.
('14', 83, 2, 11, 171585) They [were] surrounded with much attention and love from all the members of the family.
('14', 83, 2, 12, 171673) Dr. Gool who is such a noble soul but yet youthful, made a deep impression on them by his suave nature.
('14', 83, 2, 13, 171777) The result was that the boy’s faculty for thinking, study or work was paralysed.
('14', 83, 2, 14, 171858) They rose after 6 a.m.
('14', 83, 2, 15, 171881) They never studied.
('14', 83, 2, 16, 171901) Their talk seemed to me to be unnatural.
('14', 83, 2, 17, 171942) They found themselves placed in gaudy surroundings which unhinged them for the moment.
('14', 83, 2, 18, 172029) I felt that to give them a month of this life would be to hurt two very sensitive young promising plants.
('14', 83, 2, 19, 172135) I spoke very sharply and bitterly to them.
('14', 83, 2, 20, 172178) They have resented my tone and my speech as also my action.
('14', 83, 2, 21, 172238) The discovery I made on arrival was so shocking that I certainly became impatient.
('14', 83, 2, 22, 172321) But I am sorry neither for my action nor for my speech.
('14', 83, 2, 23, 172377) I had a right to expect them not to misunderstand me.
('14', 83, 2, 24, 172431) After all I have sent them away to my personal discomfort and for their advantage.
('14', 83, 2, 25, 172514) My presence in their midst could not have counter balanced the unperceived mischief that was working its way into their system.
('14', 83, 2, 26, 172642) Jamnadas must therefore naturally go to Phoenix and Manilal not to Phoenix whilst Jeki is there and that when I am away.
('14', 83, 2, 27, 172763) The only alternative for him was to be at Mountain View where he can do the right thing just to the extent that he is able.
('14', 83, 2, 28, 172887) I wished to place both in circumstances most favourable to their spiritual growth.
('14', 83, 2, 29, 172970) I have advised Manilal that he ought to religiously avoid baker’s bread, tea and coffee and that he should rarely go to Town, never eat the Town food and never sleep in Town.
('14', 83, 2, 30, 173145) But I have told him he is a free agent.
('14', 83, 2, 31, 173185) He need only adopt that part of my advice which appeals to him and no more.
('14', 83, 2, 32, 173261) I do not want him to do anything for my sake.
('14', 83, 2, 33, 173307) I want him to become not a creeper but a vigorous tree.
('14', 83, 3, 34, 173363) I had another glorious interview with Miss Hobhouse yesterday.
('14', 83, 3, 35, 173426) We discussed you fairly fully and I have told her that it is likely you might be here whilst I am also here.

('14', 84, 4, 22, 174601) 79. LETTER TO G. K. GOKHALE
('14', 84, 5, 23, 174629) CAPE TOWN, February 27, 1914
('14', 84, 6, 24, 174658) DEAR MR. GOKHALE,
('14', 84, 7, 25, 174676) For the time being I am at Cape Town watching the course of events.
('14', 84, 7, 26, 174744) I do not want to inflict on you any news about the struggle.
('14', 84, 7, 27, 174805) I shall be as brief as I possibly can.
('14', 84, 7, 28, 174844) Mr. Andrews and Mr. Pearson are truly good men, we all like them very much.
('14', 84, 7, 29, 174920) Sir Benjamin has disappointed us.
('14', 84, 7, 30, 174954) He has hardly done any good and he may do a great deal of harm.
('14', 84, 7, 31, 175018) He is weak and by no means sincere.
('14', 84, 7, 32, 175054) Even now he has hardly grasped the details.
('14', 84, 7, 33, 175098) And he undoubtedly, consciously or unconsciously, fosters divisions among us.
('14', 84, 7, 34, 175176) Mr. Andrews will tell you all about him.
('14', 84, 7, 35, 175217) But I thought that I should give you my impressions of Sir Benjamin.
('14', 84, 7, 36, 175286) If there is a settlement in March, I propose to leave for India in April.

('14', 90, 3, 5, 183589) He has conducted himself in gaol in the same spirit that moved him to come over here.
('14', 90, 3, 6, 183675) The courage and presence of mind he displayed when going to gaol and while in gaol, few others could have shown in their first experience.
('14', 90, 3, 7, 183814) I can recall no such instance at the moment.

('14', 91, 7, 15, 186681) CAPE TOWN, Phagan Sud 4 [March 1, 1914]
('14', 91, 8, 16, 186721) DEAR RAOJIBHAI, I have your letter.
('14', 91, 8, 17, 186757) It has indeed been a deliverance for Nepal 5. I have known his wife to be a hard hearted woman.
('14', 91, 8, 18, 186853) Death should make us think of our duty and fill us with contempt for the body, but
('14', 91, 9, 19, 186936) 1 Chhaganlal, Maganlal and Narandas 2 Accumulated merit or demerit of past lives 3 Lakshmidas, Gandhiji’s eldest brother 4 Vide “Letter to Harilal Gandhi”, 2 3 1914. 5 An indentured Indian who had lived near the Phoenix Settlement with his wife, also indentured.
('14', 91, 9, 20, 187199) Lying ill in bed, he was burnt to death when his hut caught fire.
('14', 91, 9, 21, 187265) His wife had ill treated him because he was of a lower caste.
('14', 92, 0, 1, 187327) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 93
('14', 92, 1, 2, 187371) inspire no fear.
('14', 92, 1, 3, 187388) It seems that a man does not suffer excessively even when he is burnt to death.
('14', 92, 1, 4, 187468) When the pain becomes unbearable, he loses consciousness.
('14', 92, 1, 5, 187526) Those who cling to the body so very tenaciously only suffer the more.
('14', 92, 1, 6, 187596) One who knows the truth about the atman will have no fear of death.
('14', 92, 1, 7, 187664) Thousands of men, thousands of creatures, are burnt to death, like Nepal, every moment now.
('14', 92, 1, 8, 187756) In the universe, Nepal is an infinitely smaller creature than even an ant.
('14', 92, 1, 9, 187831) How many creatures, relatively bigger than Nepal, do we not burn away, knowingly or otherwise, in making fires or using lights at night?
('14', 92, 1, 10, 187968) Imagine a being of immense size like Brahma 1. To him, we must be smaller than ants.
('14', 92, 1, 11, 188053) The very size of his eyes must be so large that we would look like fleas.
('14', 92, 1, 12, 188127) What if Nepal has been burnt to death by a creature like this?
('14', 92, 1, 13, 188190) He might have even believed that he might burn away a creature like Nepal for the happiness of a great being such as he was.
('14', 92, 1, 14, 188315) To us, Nepal is a creature of our size, so that we pity him, afraid of what we might suffer in similar circumstances.
('14', 92, 1, 15, 188433) But the argument we use in our wisdom about creatures like the ant, the bug, the flea and other countless insects invisible to our naked eye, must be the very argument applied to us by the much wiser Brahma.
('14', 92, 1, 16, 188641) If we can understand this, we may learn the following lessons from the case of Nepal and others of the kind: 1. We should have compassion on ourselves as on all creatures, looking on them as one, and draw back in alarm from destruction of life for any purpose of ours.
('14', 92, 1, 17, 188910) 2. We should cherish no fond attachment for the body and have no fear whatever of death.
('14', 92, 1, 18, 188999) 3. We should strive for moksha right now, knowing that the body is all too apt to let us down.
('14', 92, 1, 19, 189094) It is very easy to utter these three maxims but it is difficult to ponder over them and, after pondering, it is like walking on a sword blade to put them into practice.
('14', 92, 1, 20, 189263) It is morning now.
('14', 92, 1, 21, 189282) My ideas flow in this direction, for Ba is in pain again and I am trying to free her from the fear of death.
('14', 92, 2, 22, 189391) With due regards MOHANDAS [From Gujarati] Jivannu Parodh
('14', 92, 3, 23, 189448) 1 The Creator, Supreme Being

('14', 94, 4, 12, 191926) 89. LETTER TO HARILAL GANDHI
('14', 94, 5, 13, 191955) [CAPE TOWN,] Phagan Sud 5 [March 2, 1914] 1
('14', 94, 6, 14, 191999) HARILAL,
('14', 94, 7, 15, 192008) I have your letter.
('14', 94, 7, 16, 192028) You apologize in every letter of yours and put up a defence as well.
('14', 94, 7, 17, 192097) It all seems to me sheer hypocrisy now.
('14', 94, 7, 18, 192137) For years, you have been slack in writing letters, and then coming forward with apologies.
('14', 94, 7, 19, 192228) Will this go on till death, I forgiving every time?
('14', 94, 7, 20, 192280) And what is the point of my forgiving?
('14', 94, 7, 21, 192319) Forgiving has a meaning only to the extent that the person who has apologized does not err again.
('14', 94, 7, 22, 192417) My forgiving you all the time means that I should go on doing my duty as father though you may not do yours as son.
('14', 94, 7, 23, 192533) My duty, of course, I shall continue to do according to my judgment.

('14', 96, 7, 36, 197491) DEAR SIR BENJAMIN,
('14', 96, 8, 37, 197510) It strikes me that, with reference to Mr. Polak’s note, I should mention perhaps the manner in which relief can be granted in the several matters.
('14', 96, 9, 38, 197657) 1 Vide “Letter to Narandas Gandhi”, 29 3 1910 2 A few words are missing here.
('14', 97, 0, 1, 197735) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 97, 1, 2, 197776) Immigration.
('14', 97, 1, 3, 197789) Relief can be easily given in the administration of this Act, as there is one Act applicable to all the Provinces and it can be done by altering the regulations in the desired direction.
('14', 97, 1, 4, 197976) Inter provincial visiting and travelling permits should be granted for the asking and either without a deposit or with a small deposit and no more than a shilling stamp to cover the bare cost.
('14', 97, 1, 5, 198169) Certificates of identity should be of a permanent duration even as the Transvaal certificates are—why should the Transvaal have an advantage over the other Provinces in these matters?
('14', 97, 1, 6, 198353) The question of the withdrawal and return of children should be definitely fixed.
('14', 97, 1, 7, 198435) Proof required from wives who would be administratively admitted should be definitely stated.
('14', 97, 1, 8, 198529) Indeed, it is necessary to go through the regulations clause by clause with Mr. Gorges and then discuss them with General Smuts.
('14', 97, 1, 9, 198658) Dealers’ Licences.
('14', 97, 1, 10, 198677) This is a difficult question.
('14', 97, 1, 11, 198707) The three Provinces have three different laws and they are not administered directly by the Union Government.
('14', 97, 1, 12, 198817) The control is partly in the hands of the Provincial Governments and partly in those of the municipali ties.
('14', 97, 1, 13, 198926) Each municipality has its own policy and bye laws.
('14', 97, 1, 14, 198977) The utmost that can be done is for the Government to address circulars to the responsible bodies warning them of the danger of following a sweep ing policy.
('14', 97, 1, 15, 199134) This method was successfully adopted by the late Mr. Escombe 1 who was himself the author of the Natal licensing law of 1896. And the local administrations will not fail to note the changed attitude of the Union administration if it ever changes for the better.
('14', 97, 1, 16, 199396) The Transvaal Gold Laws.
('14', 97, 1, 17, 199421) In this the Union Government can give definite relief by accepting the meaning that I have ventured to give to the expression ‘vested rights’ which they have promised in their dispatches to respect.
('14', 97, 1, 18, 199620) By ‘vested rights’ I understand the right of the Indian and his successors to live and trade in the township he was living in and trading, no matter how often he shifts his residence or business from place to place in the same township.
('14', 97, 1, 19, 199857) Law of 1885 Transvaal.
('14', 97, 1, 20, 199880) The Government can safely and easily administer the Law in a liberal or, rather, just spirit by granting the
('14', 97, 2, 21, 199989) 1 Sir Harry Escombe (1838 99); leading advocate, who pleaded for Gandhiji’s admission to the Bar of the Natal Supreme Court; was Prime Minister of Natal for a few months in 1897.

('14', 102, 4, 10, 208169) 96. LETTER TO RAOJIBHAI PATEL
('14', 102, 5, 11, 208199) CAPE TOWN, Phagan Sud 10 [March 7, 1914]
('14', 102, 6, 12, 208240) DEAR SHRI RAOJIBHAI,
('14', 102, 7, 13, 208261) I read and re read your letter.
('14', 102, 7, 14, 208293) Shankaracharya has a verse which says that more patience and time are required for disciplining the mind, that is, attaining moksha, than is needed by a man who, sitting on the shore, would empty the ocean of all its water drop by drop with a blade of grass.
('14', 102, 7, 15, 208552) You seem to be in too great a hurry.
('14', 102, 7, 16, 208589) I have not got rid of the fear of death, despite much thinking.
('14', 102, 7, 17, 208653) But I feel no impatience.
('14', 102, 7, 18, 208679) I keep on trying and I am sure I shall get rid of it one day.
('14', 102, 7, 19, 208741) We should not let go a single occasion when we may try.
('14', 102, 7, 20, 208797) That is our duty.
('14', 102, 7, 21, 208815) It is for God to produce or will the result.
('14', 102, 7, 22, 208860) Why worry then?
('14', 102, 7, 23, 208876) When feeding her baby, the mother has no thought of the result.
('14', 102, 7, 24, 208940) The result does follow, though.
('14', 102, 7, 25, 208972) To get rid of the fear of death and to drive away desire, make the effort and keep cheerful ; and they will disappear.
('14', 102, 7, 26, 209091) Otherwise, it will be the same with you as with the man who, resolving not to think about a monkey, kept on thinking of one.
('14', 102, 7, 27, 209216) We are born in sin, and we are enslaved in the body, because of our sinful deeds; how can you hope to cleanse yourself of all the impurity just in a minute?
('14', 102, 7, 28, 209373) You may live as you like, Realize God anyhow.
('14', 102, 7, 29, 209419) This is the teaching of Akha Bhagat 1. Tulsidasji says:
('14', 102, 8, 30, 209475) 1 Mystic poet of the 17th century, famed for his satire; vedantist and rationalist
('14', 103, 0, 1, 209558) 104 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 103, 1, 2, 209600) Whether in adversity or no, repeat over and over again the name of Rama and you will achieve all there is to be achieved.
('14', 103, 1, 3, 209722) This is the end we must aim at.
('14', 103, 1, 4, 209754) Therefore, go on repeating that name.
('14', 103, 1, 5, 209792) Be clear in your mind who this Rama is.
('14', 103, 1, 6, 209832) He is unconditioned, formless.
('14', 103, 1, 7, 209863) Armed with the countless virtues that belong to the godly nature, He destroys Ravana, representing a host of monstrous desires.
('14', 103, 1, 8, 209991) He practised penance for 12 years to earn this strength.
('14', 103, 1, 9, 210048) Finally, do not allow your body or mind to remain idle even for a moment.
('14', 103, 1, 10, 210122) Keep both cheerfully engaged; if you do this, all your troubles are bound to vanish.

('14', 103, 1, 14, 210434) But what do we mean by the heart?
('14', 103, 1, 15, 210468) And when may we believe the heart to be pure?
('14', 103, 1, 16, 210514) The heart is nothing else but the atman or the seat of the atman.
('14', 103, 1, 17, 210580) To imagine that it is pure is to imply perfect realization of the atman and, in the presence of such realization, the cravings of the senses are inconceivable.
('14', 103, 1, 18, 210740) But ordinarily we attribute purity to the heart when we are but striving after such purity.
('14', 103, 1, 19, 210832) Say, I love you.
('14', 103, 1, 20, 210849) This only means that I try to cultivate such a feeling for you.
('14', 103, 1, 21, 210913) If I have unceasing love, I should be a perfectly enlightened man, which, indeed, I am not.
('14', 103, 1, 22, 211005) Anyone for whom I have true love will not misunderstand my intentions or words, nor will such a one bear ill will to me.
('14', 103, 1, 23, 211126) It follows from this that, when anyone looks upon us as his enemy, the fault is primarily ours.
('14', 103, 1, 24, 211222) This is also true of our relations with the whites.
('14', 103, 1, 25, 211274) Perfect purity of heart, therefore, is the final stage.
('14', 103, 1, 26, 211330) Before we have reached that stage, as we advance towards greater and greater purity, the cravings of the senses will subside in corresponding measure.
('14', 103, 1, 27, 211481) These cravings do not originate in the senses.
('14', 103, 1, 28, 211528) The mind alone is the cause of man’s being bound or free.
('14', 103, 2, 29, 211586) The senses are the points at which the impulses in the mind become manifest.
('14', 103, 2, 30, 211663) Through them we come to recognize the impulses as such.
('14', 103, 2, 31, 211719) And so, by destroying the senses, we do not do away with the impulses in the mind.

('14', 104, 2, 3, 212327) We have heard of men who, passionate in their convictions, cut off their organs when they found it impossible to control their minds.

('14', 111, 1, 11, 228615) What a long letter this!
('14', 111, 1, 12, 228640) I think I have covered all the points raised by you.
('14', 111, 1, 13, 228693) With love,

('14', 111, 4, 17, 228806) 101. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('14', 111, 5, 18, 228840) 7 BUITENSINGLE, Tuesday [March 10, 1914]
('14', 111, 6, 19, 228881) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('14', 111, 7, 20, 228902) The greatest grief imaginable has befallen me.
('14', 111, 7, 21, 228949) My brother 1 died yesterday.
('14', 111, 7, 22, 228978) I suppose simply thinking up to his last breath of me.
('14', 111, 7, 23, 229033) What a passionate wish it was on his part to meet me!
('14', 111, 7, 24, 229087) 2 And for me I was hurrying everything on so that I could go to India with the quickest despatch and fall down at his feet and nurse him.
('14', 111, 7, 25, 229225) But it was not to be.
('14', 111, 7, 26, 229247) Now I must go to a family of widows with my poor self as the head.
('14', 111, 7, 27, 229314) You who do not quite know the Indian patriarchal [system] cannot quite realize what this may mean.
('14', 111, 7, 28, 229413) Anyway my desire to go to India is keener than ever.
('14', 111, 7, 29, 229466) And yet who knows!
('14', 111, 7, 30, 229485) I doubt very much whether I shall ever realize that desire.
('14', 111, 7, 31, 229545) However, I must prepare for the pilgrimage and then calmly leave it in the hands of Him who wields
('14', 111, 8, 32, 229644) 1 Lakshmidas Gandhi; vide also “Letter to C.F. Andrews”, 13 3 1914 2 Vide “General Knowledge about Health [—XXXIV]”, 16 8 1913
('14', 112, 0, 1, 229771) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 113
('14', 112, 1, 2, 229816) the almighty power.
('14', 112, 1, 3, 229836) These shocks make in me still more intense fearlessness of death.
('14', 112, 1, 4, 229902) Why should the event agitate one?
('14', 112, 1, 5, 229936) The grief itself has a selfish touch about it.
('14', 112, 1, 6, 229983) It is no calamity that my brother is dead, if I am ready to meet death and consider it as the supreme and welcome crisis in life.
('14', 112, 1, 7, 230113) It is because we fear death so much for ourselves that we shed tears over the deaths of others.
('14', 112, 1, 8, 230209) How can I who know the body to be perishable and the soul to be imperishable mourn over the separation of body from soul.
('14', 112, 1, 9, 230331) But there is a condition attached to a real belief in this beautiful and consoling doctrine.
('14', 112, 1, 10, 230424) He who believes in it must not pamper the body but must be its ruler.
('14', 112, 1, 11, 230494) He must regulate its wants so as to make it serve the dweller within and not allow the body to master him.
('14', 112, 1, 12, 230601) Not to grieve over the death of others is to accept a state almost of perpetual grief for this connection between body and soul is itself grievous.
('14', 112, 1, 13, 230749) These are the thoughts that rule me just now.
('14', 112, 1, 14, 230795) I shall not write another such letter just now.
('14', 112, 1, 15, 230843) This has written itself.
('14', 112, 1, 16, 230868) Please, therefore, pass on to Polak.
('14', 112, 1, 17, 230905) Let Manilal read it.
('14', 112, 1, 18, 230926) And then you may pass on to Chhaganlal for West and others to read.
('14', 112, 1, 19, 230994) I am revolving the idea in my own mind of help for the indentured.
('14', 112, 1, 20, 231061) With love,
('14', 112, 2, 21, 231072) UPPER HOUSE

('14', 112, 4, 24, 231174) 102. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL GANDHI
('14', 112, 5, 25, 231207) CAPE TOWN, Phagan Sud 14, 1970 [March 11, 1914]
('14', 112, 6, 26, 231255) CHHAGANLAL,
('14', 112, 7, 27, 231267) I have some time to myself just now.
('14', 112, 7, 28, 231304) Medh writes to say that they are plotting again in Johannesburg to take my life.
('14', 112, 7, 29, 231385) That would indeed be welcome and a fit end to my work.
('14', 112, 7, 30, 231440) I would not be frightened by this and stay away from Johannesburg on account of this.
('14', 112, 7, 31, 231526) In case I die suddenly, be the reason this or any other, I want to set down here certain ideas which I have thought out and which I have not so far placed before you.
('14', 113, 0, 1, 231693) 114 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 113, 1, 2, 231735) “Service of the family should come first.” This is quite correct from the point of view of our supreme interest.
('14', 113, 1, 3, 231848) He alone who can render such service will be able to serve the community or the country.
('14', 113, 1, 4, 231937) What that service consists in is the only point to consider.
('14', 113, 1, 5, 231998) I think selfless conduct will show that quite easily.
('14', 113, 1, 6, 232052) The life of service or political work which we have followed so far seems to me of the lowest order.
('14', 113, 1, 7, 232153) Ours is a notorious family, that is, we are known to belong to a band of robbers.
('14', 113, 1, 8, 232235) Without disparaging our elders, we may say that they have possibly done service to the people, but only incidentally, while they pursued their selfish interests.
('14', 113, 1, 9, 232397) Judged by common standards, it would seem that they have acted with a fair measure of justice.
('14', 113, 1, 10, 232492) That is, they treated people to a smaller measure of oppression.
('14', 113, 1, 11, 232557) At present, the family has fallen on evil days.
('14', 113, 1, 12, 232605) Any member who failed to obtain a paid job would be on the streets.
('14', 113, 1, 13, 232673) The highest our eyes can look up to is Narandas, slaving away in Bombay.
('14', 113, 1, 14, 232746) Other members of the family just loiter about or, wallowing in the politics of [princely] States, manage to earn just enough for their food from day to day.
('14', 113, 1, 15, 232903) All of them are busy multiplying, arran ging marriages, etc.
('14', 113, 1, 16, 232964) The utmost limit of a grandmother’s or a daugh ter in law’s ambition is to get [the grandson or] the son married.
('14', 113, 1, 17, 233078) How may we save ourselves from this?
('14', 113, 1, 18, 233115) If possible, we should take another road.
('14', 113, 1, 19, 233157) We should become farmers, in the first instance.
('14', 113, 1, 20, 233206) If, to our misfortune, that should bring unbearable hardships on us, we should labour as weavers, etc., and live in the same state as we do in Phoenix.
('14', 113, 1, 21, 233358) We must reduce our wants to the minimum.
('14', 113, 1, 22, 233399) As for diet, we should, as far as possible, adhere to the system which we have thought out.
('14', 113, 1, 23, 233491) Milk, which is generally considered a pure substance, may be taken, but it should be looked upon rather as the opposite of pure.
('14', 113, 1, 24, 233620) This is an important change.
('14', 113, 1, 25, 233649) Its roots go deep; and its consequences will be far reaching.
('14', 113, 1, 26, 233711) It is a separate question whether or not the change will prove acceptable to all.
('14', 113, 1, 27, 233793) But knowing at least that this article is denied to millions, one should avoid it.
('14', 113, 1, 28, 233876) The idea that it is pure flesh and not in keeping with the way of non violence will never leave my mind.
('14', 113, 1, 29, 233981) I do not think I shall ever be able to consume milk, ghee, etc., while I inhabit this body.
('14', 113, 1, 30, 234073) You should do with the minimum use of fire.
('14', 113, 1, 31, 234117) Any boys from the family who might wish to join should be allowed to do so and admitted.
('14', 113, 1, 32, 234206) They should not be permitted to stay on if they failed to follow these ideas.
('14', 113, 1, 33, 234284) Widows who might not wish to live such a life should be respectfully told that you would pay
('14', 114, 0, 1, 234377) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 115
('14', 114, 1, 2, 234422) them each one and a half times as much as would be spent on each if they were to follow that way of life and so clear your debt to them, that, apart from this, you could give them nothing else.
('14', 114, 1, 3, 234616) Never trouble yourself to get anyone married and provided for.
('14', 114, 1, 4, 234679) The boy, on growing up, will arrange the business himself if he wants to marry.
('14', 114, 1, 5, 234759) If it does become necessary to find husbands for daughters, we would offer them to those who are prepared to marry them with no more than a tulsi leaf for dowry.
('14', 114, 1, 6, 234921) We would not spend a single pie.
('14', 114, 1, 7, 234954) We would wait till we came across such a candidate and teach the daughter to be patient.
('14', 114, 1, 8, 235043) We should be prepared for some gossiping in consequence, and to be sneered at.
('14', 114, 1, 9, 235122) All this, we would bear with love.
('14', 114, 1, 10, 235157) If we remain upright in our conduct, we would come to no harm.
('14', 114, 1, 11, 235220) To have offspring is no religious obligation on us.
('14', 114, 1, 12, 235272) It is none of our duty to multiply numbers in the world.
('14', 114, 1, 13, 235329) The real secret of life seems to consist in so living in the world as it is, without being attached to it, that moksha might become easy of attainment to us and to others.
('14', 114, 1, 14, 235501) This will include service of self, the family, the community, and the State.
('14', 114, 1, 15, 235578) We should not stop till we reach that stage.
('14', 114, 1, 16, 235623) Whoever joins us in this way of living will be to us as a member of our family.
('14', 114, 1, 17, 235703) We shall take in Raojibhai, Maganbhai, Pragji and any others who may come forward.
('14', 114, 1, 18, 235786) Should I meet with an untimely end, it is my desire that you should order your life as indicated here.
('14', 114, 1, 19, 235889) Be in no hurry to leave Phoenix, but bear these objects in mind and stay on.
('14', 114, 1, 20, 235966) I am quite hopeful about Maganlal.
('14', 114, 1, 21, 236001) If Jamnadas gets trained up, he has the necessary spirit.
('14', 114, 1, 22, 236059) He has determination, too.
('14', 114, 1, 23, 236086) After my death, the money needed on account of the widows who have been my special responsibilities should be obtained from Dr. Mehta.
('14', 114, 1, 24, 236221) If it is not forthcoming, all of you who agree with the aims set out above should make the necessary provision even if you have to put yourselves to extreme difficulty and slave for the purpose.
('14', 114, 1, 25, 236416) Harilal will have to fend for himself.
('14', 114, 1, 26, 236455) He may entrust the children to you.
('14', 114, 1, 27, 236491) or anyone else who is in India.
('14', 114, 1, 28, 236523) Fuli has enough and to spare, so that there is no question of providing for her.
('14', 114, 1, 29, 236604) And now remain Gokibehn 1, Nandkorbhabhi 2, Gangabhabhi 3 and Gokuldas’s 4 wife.
('14', 114, 1, 30, 236685) If they live
('14', 114, 2, 31, 236698) 1 Raliyatbehn, Ghandhiji’s sister 2 Widow of Lakshmidas Gandhi 3 Widow of Karsandas 4 Son of Gandhiji’s sister, who died within a fortnight of his marriage in 1908.
('14', 115, 0, 1, 236863) 116 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 115, 1, 2, 236905) together, that will be very good of them, graceful of them.
('14', 115, 1, 3, 236965) If they do not, separate provision should be made for each.
('14', 115, 1, 4, 237025) Children may be handed over [to them].
('14', 115, 1, 5, 237064) But it would be better if they come over to live with the others.
('14', 115, 1, 6, 237130) In that case, the total cost of maintaining them is not likely to be [even] as much as Rs. 40. The expenses for Ba also should be estimated on a similar scale.
('14', 115, 1, 7, 237290) She should, at any rate, understand that the right thing for her would be to live with them.

('14', 115, 1, 16, 238019) No one will be justified in expecting, or will expect, anything above your own standard of living.
('14', 115, 1, 17, 238118) Since I consider that to be the best way of living, the ideas outlined above do not appear to be harsh.
('14', 115, 1, 18, 238222) The logic behind this reasoning is based on poverty which, indeed, appears to be the only sound basis.
('14', 115, 1, 19, 238325) After my death, you may show this letter to anyone you like.

('14', 121, 1, 2, 249220) own conclusions, tentative and immature as they are.
('14', 121, 1, 3, 249273) The basic principle, undoubtedly, is this: one should make do with the fewest possible articles [of food] and in the smallest possible quantity, no more than what is absolutely necessary to pay the body its hire.
('14', 121, 1, 4, 249486) It will be best to frame the rules of our diet bearing this principle in mind.
('14', 121, 1, 5, 249565) A man who cooks a meal of just an ounce of rough ground wheat and is free in five minutes is far superior to the one who wrings (as I do) the utmost pleasure from a variety of fruits.
('14', 121, 1, 6, 249749) Another, however, who lives on no more than five bananas will out distance the first.
('14', 121, 1, 7, 249835) In other words, one who lives on fruit diet stands a far better chance of rising than the other.
('14', 121, 1, 8, 249932) Even here, the mental attitude is the primary factor.
('14', 121, 1, 9, 249986) The motive is the chief thing.
('14', 121, 1, 10, 250017) We cannot deduce any rule that, if we can consume the fruit, we can also consume the leaves, the bark, etc.
('14', 121, 1, 11, 250125) The reason why certain green vegetables are permitted on ekadashi 1 but wheat is forbidden seems to be an obvious one rather than anything abstract.
('14', 121, 1, 12, 250274) Since people do not have an entire meal of vegetables or look upon them as food, some vegetables were permitted for gratifying the palate; but wheat, being food was excluded and in this way the original aim of eating less on ekadashi was to some extent maintained.
('14', 121, 1, 13, 250539) Gourds, etc., are, like tomatoes, more or less a kind of fruit.
('14', 121, 1, 14, 250603) The tomatoes are allowed because they can be eaten uncooked.
('14', 121, 1, 15, 250664) It is doubtful if gourd and the like, if uncooked, can be digested by all.
('14', 121, 1, 16, 250739) Radish, etc., are but roots of a weed and the consumption of roots is thoroughly objectionable according to Jain principles.
('14', 121, 1, 17, 250864) When Ba wanted to have ginger, I ate it with her to know its effects.
('14', 121, 1, 18, 250934) I liked it and continued to take it after neem juice.
('14', 121, 1, 19, 250988) Ba has quite an enthusiasm for it.
