('14', 121, 1, 22, 251092) They were nothing but roots.
('14', 121, 1, 23, 251121) I ate them for a day or two and relished them very much indeed.
('14', 121, 1, 24, 251185) This morning, I was filled with compassion and despised myself.
('14', 121, 1, 25, 251249) It was as though I could see the souls in these pieces of ginger.
('14', 121, 1, 26, 251315) On one knot of it, there are several tender shoots.
('14', 121, 1, 27, 251367) To eat them amounted to destroying so many embryos.
('14', 121, 1, 28, 251419) Deeply pained, I gave up ginger today.
('14', 121, 1, 29, 251458) I had not done so till now, having kept myself free to eat it when necessary.
('14', 121, 1, 30, 251536) Henceforth, I will treat it as forbidden and avoid eating it as far as possible.

('14', 123, 5, 11, 254680) 108. LETTER TO “INDIAN OPINION”
('14', 123, 6, 12, 254712) THE EDITOR INDIAN OPINION
('14', 123, 8, 13, 254738) I have been so overwhelmed with wires from different parts of the Union expressing sympathy with my wife and myself regarding the death of my brother in India that it is impossible for me to thank severally the Associations and individual senders.
('14', 123, 8, 14, 254986) Numerous messages have been received from Durban, Maritzburg, Johannesburg and other places.
('14', 123, 8, 15, 255079) I thank all most heartily for their sympathy.
('14', 123, 8, 16, 255125) Whilst doing so I would like to say just a word.
('14', 123, 8, 17, 255174) To me as a passive resister and as a firm believer in the oneness of the Soul, my brother’s loss should occasion no greater pain than the death of Nagappen, Narayanasamy and Hurbatsing, who were just as much my brothers as my blood brother whose loss so many friends are mourning with me.
('14', 123, 8, 18, 255463) Valliamah Moonsamy’s untimely end is, if possible, a greater stab from the hand of Death than my brother’s end.
('14', 123, 8, 19, 255575) Yet I share the common human failing, and the thoughts that arise in the mind from the loss of my brother, who was in the place of father to me and to whom, next to my
('14', 124, 0, 1, 255743) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 125
('14', 124, 1, 2, 255788) dead mother, I owe all I am in life, are more vivid than those that arose in me when those three brother passive resisters and the sister passive resister died.
('14', 124, 1, 3, 255949) The idea that is uppermost in my mind just now is that death should cause no fear in us, if we have lived in the fear of God and have done nothing in violation of the voice of our conscience.
('14', 124, 1, 4, 256141) Then, indeed, is death but a change for the better and, therefore, a welcome change which need not evoke any sorrow.
('14', 124, 1, 5, 256258) Such a change, I feel, my brother’s death must mean for him.
('14', 124, 1, 6, 256319) And we in South Africa, especially those who are passive resisters, must learn not only not to fear death but must be prepared to face it and welcome it when it comes to us in the performance of our duty.
('14', 124, 1, 7, 256524) So have died Narayansamy and his three successors.
('14', 124, 1, 8, 256575) I wish for no better end and I am sure no other passive resister does.
('14', 124, 1, 9, 256646) Finally, may I ask those friends who have overwhelmed me with their sympathy in my bereavement to help me, if the points of passive resistance are satisfactorily settled in the near future, in my desire to return to India to fall at the feet of my brother’s widow and to take charge of the domestic cares of five widows in my father’s family, in which the hand of death now leaves me the responsible head, according to the Hindu usage.
('14', 124, 2, 10, 257082) etc., M. K. GANDHI
('14', 124, 3, 11, 257101) Indian Opinion, 18 3 1914

('14', 125, 5, 7, 258012) 110. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('14', 125, 6, 8, 258046) 7 BUITENSINGLE, March 20 [1914] 1
('14', 125, 7, 9, 258080) MY DEAR LOWER HOUSE,
('14', 125, 8, 10, 258101) You seem just now to be the busiest man in our circle.
('14', 125, 8, 11, 258156) Your correspondence is invariably (almost) written in the train.
('14', 125, 8, 12, 258221) Well, I hope, the result of this activity will be greater peace for you and a great benefit to the circle.
('14', 125, 8, 13, 258328) I am not joking.
('14', 125, 8, 14, 258345) I am serious though naturally I am sceptical about the value of such restless activity.
('14', 125, 8, 15, 258433) But under exceptional circumstances it may be the lesser evil.
('14', 125, 8, 16, 258496) You asked me a question about the counting of beads.
('14', 125, 8, 17, 258549) I forgot to deal with it.
('14', 125, 8, 18, 258575) There is undoubtedly great efficacy in knowingly and deliberately uttering some sacred name as often as you can.
('14', 125, 8, 19, 258688) The love of the owner of the name then grows on you and you ultimately merge in Him.
('14', 125, 8, 20, 258773) Now every rosary has a stated number of beads.
('14', 125, 8, 21, 258820) The Hindu rosary has 108. You take the 108 names of the deity once every turn of the rosary.
('14', 125, 8, 22, 258913) And as the number of the beads is fixed you never omit a name.
('14', 125, 8, 23, 258976) Thus you simply contemplate the name without worrying to know how often you have taken it or whether you have omitted any.
('14', 125, 8, 24, 259099) The Muslims have 99 beads to correspond to the 99 names of God.
('14', 125, 8, 25, 259163) Some Hindus simply mutter the same name.
('14', 125, 8, 26, 259204) In that case the number of beads is of no consequence so long as it is the same rosary.
('14', 125, 8, 27, 259292) You are in a position to know then how often during the day you have taken the sacred name.
('14', 125, 8, 28, 259384) Thus to mutter the name of the Highest without a selfish purpose is a most desirable practice.
('14', 125, 9, 29, 259479) 1 From the contents
('14', 126, 0, 1, 259499) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 127
('14', 126, 1, 2, 259544) the universality of rosaries.
('14', 126, 1, 3, 259574) I want to continue the counting if I can.
('14', 126, 1, 4, 259616) The more secretly it is done, the better of course.
('14', 126, 1, 5, 259668) The early morning and sunset are the best times and I try to keep these times at present.
('14', 126, 1, 6, 259758) I do not ≈ cannot for my eyes get up very early nowadays.

('14', 128, 1, 2, 263441) I shall cite in passing one instance, my own.
('14', 128, 1, 3, 263487) Ba wanted to take ginger.
('14', 128, 1, 4, 263513) Since I was under no vow to avoid it, I started taking it along with her in order to test its properties.

('14', 128, 1, 7, 263695) I fell in love with them, so much so that I also used to chew four or five of these tender shoots, of the size of a grain of gram.
('14', 128, 1, 8, 263826) One day, Ba collected a quantity of these from Mrs. Gool’s basket and placed them in [our] room.
('14', 128, 1, 9, 263923) I was struck with horror to see them.
('14', 128, 1, 10, 263961) The night passed.
('14', 128, 1, 11, 263979) I sprang out of bed in a fright, early in the morning.
('14', 128, 1, 12, 264034) How could one eat ginger?
('14', 128, 1, 13, 264060) This thing, a single joint of which proliferated into so many shoots, must indeed be full of lives.
('14', 128, 1, 14, 264160) Moreover, to eat fresh shoots was as good as killing delicate babies.
('14', 128, 1, 15, 264230) I felt extremely disgusted with myself.
('14', 128, 1, 16, 264270) I resolved that I would never eat ginger, not in this life.
('14', 128, 1, 17, 264330) But the real fun comes now.

('14', 128, 1, 24, 264557) The vow holds, but the tongue and the eye are like dogs.

('14', 128, 1, 27, 264721) But just as a dog greedily watching food left over will not dare to eat it in the presence of the master, the tongue is prevented from touching the ginger by the watchfulness of Mr. Atman.
('14', 128, 1, 28, 264910) My eye falls on it the whole day because it is lying just where my papers are.
('14', 128, 1, 29, 264989) It seems more difficult for me to turn away my mind from ginger than it was to give up sugar or salt, such is the state I find myself in.
('14', 128, 2, 30, 265127) What, then, should you blame yourself for?
('14', 128, 2, 31, 265170) It is not for nothing that the mind has been compared to a monkey that has got drunk.

('14', 132, 1, 10, 271949) Moreover, abstention from tendering evidence has, in the event, proved to be an advantage.

('14', 132, 1, 23, 273181) In these circumstances we could not have entertained strong hopes for settlement as we do now.
('14', 132, 1, 24, 273276) Thus, our remaining faithful to an oath taken in the face of advice to the contrary by the Viceroy was sacred in itself and it has yielded gratuitously other good sweet fruit.

('14', 140, 4, 12, 288830) 123. A MARRIAGE PROCLAMATION
('14', 140, 5, 13, 288859) The Union Government Gazette of the 24th March contains a marriage proclamation which is of some importance, as it bears on the expected legislation on the Indian marriage difficulty.
('14', 140, 5, 14, 289043) We give elsewhere the proclamation in full.
('14', 140, 5, 15, 289087) In effect, it requires banns to be published of intended Mahomedan or Hebrew marriages, in terms of the existing Natal legislation.
('14', 140, 5, 16, 289219) If the proclamation has reference in practice only to Hebrew marriages, we can have nothing to say.
('14', 140, 5, 17, 289319) If it anticipates the Indian marriages legislation and is intended to be a feeler, it is an ill omen.
('14', 140, 5, 18, 289421) For the essence of the Indian proposal is that Indian marriages celebrated in accordance with the religious ceremonial prescribed by any of the great Indian faiths should be recognized by the law of South Africa so long as they are monogamous in fact.
('14', 140, 5, 19, 289673) Now Indian religions do not require publication of banns.
('14', 140, 5, 20, 289731) We have our own method (in our opinion, far superior to that of the publication of banns) of widely advertising approaching marriages.
('14', 140, 5, 21, 289866) No Indian priest worthy of the name can possibly perform a marriage ceremony if there is any objection offered against it in terms of the religious custom or law.
('14', 140, 5, 22, 290029) And it is the caste or the guild which takes severe notice of any breach of the canonical law.
('14', 140, 5, 23, 290124) Whilst we do not wish to offend the sentiment of the Europeans of South Africa regarding monogamy, we certainly do not contemplate surrendering our religious principles by a hair’s breadth.
('14', 140, 5, 24, 290314) We think it but right to utter this note of warning whilst the proposed legislation is still unpublished.
('14', 140, 6, 25, 290420) Indian Opinion, 8 4 1914
('14', 140, 7, 26, 290445) 1 Lafcadio Hearn, British journalist, author of several works on Japan, who married a Japanese woman and became a Japanese citizen
('14', 141, 0, 1, 290576) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('14', 141, 12, 16, 291975) 1 A reply to this was received to the effect that the matter was under consideration and it would be dealt with after the passage of the Asiatic legislation.

('14', 142, 1, 2, 292178) submitted by me on behalf of the Indian community is that past de facto monogamous marriages celebrated according to Indian religious customs should be legalised and that, in future, such marriages should be recognized as legal.
('14', 142, 1, 3, 292407) The Marriage Proclamation in question introduces the practice of the publication of banns, a practice which is totally opposed to both the Hindu and the Mahomedan usage; nor is any such publication necessary, because of the respective religions themselves requiring an elaborate process which renders fraudulent marriages impossible.

('14', 142, 1, 7, 293246) One of the chief points that the Commission had to advise upon was the £3 tax, and it is submitted that this deduction might have been stopped by the Government at least pending the report of the Com mission, and now that the Commission has made such strong recom mendations for the repeal of the Tax, I do trust that the officials concerned will be advised, if they have not been already, not to insist upon this deduction, for I assume that, if the Government bring in a Bill for the repeal of the Tax, the arrears will be remitted.

('14', 143, 7, 27, 295634) You, Polak and Manilal are sufficiently interested in her health to want to know about it daily; hence the letter from Miss Schlesin and the instructions that she herself should write as often as possible.
('14', 143, 7, 28, 295840) There would have been no such letter had Mrs. Gandhi not been sick.

('14', 143, 7, 30, 295988) Do you see my point and your pettiness?

('14', 145, 4, 24, 300429) 128. LETTER TO MANILAL GANDHI
('14', 145, 5, 25, 300459) [PHOENIX, NATAL, Sunday, Chaitra Vad 2, April 12, 1914] 1
('14', 145, 6, 26, 300517) MANILAL,
('14', 145, 7, 27, 300526) 2 Whatever Mr. Kallenbach’s hour for going to bed, you must follow one rule alone.
('14', 145, 7, 28, 300609) And the same about eating.
('14', 145, 7, 29, 300636) Here is the meaning of the sentences which you could not understand: “All acts done in a purely legalistic spirit (in accordance with the literal
('14', 145, 8, 30, 300782) 1 The date was supplied by Raojibhai Patel.
('14', 145, 8, 31, 300826) 2 Some words appear to have been omitted here.
('14', 146, 0, 1, 300873) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 147
('14', 146, 1, 2, 300918) meaning) are, indeed, cursed.
('14', 146, 1, 3, 300948) Even so, it is stated that those who do not keep doing the things as indicated by [the letter of] the law are all cursed.” 1 The point is that mere bookish souls can never attain moksha.
('14', 146, 1, 4, 301135) The Gita has a verse to the same effect, which you may ponder over.
('14', 146, 1, 5, 301203) “The Vedas keep on the plane of the three gunas; be thou, Arjuna, beyond those gunas.”—This is what Shri Krishna said to Arjuna.
('14', 146, 1, 6, 301332) This does not mean that one need not do the duties prescribed in the Shastras.
('14', 146, 1, 7, 301411) It means rather that doing them is not quite enough, that one must understand their hidden significance, their aim, and go beyond the actions themselves.
('14', 146, 1, 8, 301565) The man who renounces the prescribed duties and professes himself a barren Brahmavadin 2 will have no footing anywhere.
('14', 146, 1, 9, 301685) He will have lost the support provided by the Shastras while the foundation of inward illumination has not yet been built, so that he is bound to fall.
('14', 146, 1, 10, 301837) St. Paul therefore told the Galatians: “Do perform the acts enjoined by the scriptures; but you will remain under a curse, if you have no faith in the teachings of the Lord Jesus and do not follow his teachings.” The same meaning is to be read in “bond maid” and “free woman”.
('14', 146, 1, 11, 302114) 3 Bond means bandhan.
('14', 146, 1, 12, 302136) Scriptures are compared to the mother in flesh who, it is pointed out, has the status of a slave so that her children are also born slaves.
('14', 146, 2, 13, 302276) Faith, which means bhakti, is described as a divine mother, whose children are angels.
('14', 146, 2, 14, 302363) Read the sentences which precede and follow in the light of this explanation and tell me whether you follow them properly or not.
('14', 146, 2, 15, 302493) The 56th verse of Chapter 15 in I Corinthians means that sin is the sting of death, that, in other words, that a sinful man alone feels death as a sting.
('14', 146, 2, 16, 302647) For the virtuous, it is the means of attaining moksha.
('14', 146, 2, 17, 302702) The second line means that mere dry knowledge of the scripture has the power of a curse.
('14', 146, 2, 18, 302791) We observe this at every step.
('14', 146, 2, 19, 302822) Hundreds of sins are committed in the name of scripture.
('14', 146, 2, 20, 302879) The meaning of Romans V, 20 is simple enough.
('14', 146, 2, 21, 302925) Scripture made its appearance again and led to more crimes.

('14', 155, 4, 13, 319643) 136. “HIND SWARAJ” 1
('14', 155, 5, 14, 319664) I wrote Hind Swaraj in 1909 on board the ship during the return voyage from England.
('14', 155, 5, 15, 319749) Copies of the book having been confiscated in the Bombay Presidency, I published a translation in 1910. It is now five years since the ideas in it were expressed in public.
('14', 155, 5, 16, 319922) And during this period, many persons have had discussions with me on those ideas.
('14', 155, 5, 17, 320004) Englishmen and Indians, both have written to me about them, several expressing dissent.
('14', 155, 5, 18, 320092) At the end of it all, however, I find that the convictions I stated in the book have grown stronger.
('14', 155, 5, 19, 320193) If only I had the time, I could set forth the same ideas more elaborately, with additional arguments and illustrations.
('14', 155, 5, 20, 320313) I see no reason at all for revising them.
('14', 155, 5, 21, 320355) Numerous requests having been received for a second edition of Hind Swaraj, the inmates of Phoenix and the pupils there have found time to print it as a labour of love.
('14', 155, 5, 22, 320524) I should like to comment on one thing only.
('14', 155, 5, 23, 320568) I have gathered an impression that, though Hind Swaraj does not advocate the use of physical force at any time and in any circumstances, and advocates always the use of soul force to gain the desired end, the result of its teaching has been to create hatred for the British and to suggest that they should be expelled through armed fighting or use of violence otherwise.
('14', 155, 5, 24, 320939) I was unhappy to know this.
('14', 155, 5, 25, 320967) Such was by no means my object in writing Hind Swaraj, and I can only say that those who have
('14', 155, 6, 26, 321061) 1 This is the preface to the second Gujarati edition of Hind Swaraj which was published in May 1914. For the preface and text of the first edition, vide “Hind Swaraj”, 22 11 1909.
('14', 156, 0, 1, 321241) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 157
('14', 156, 1, 2, 321286) drawn from it the foregoing conclusion have totally failed to understand the book.
('14', 156, 1, 3, 321369) I, for one, bear no ill will against the British or against any people or individuals.
('14', 156, 1, 4, 321456) All living creatures are of the same substance as all drops of water in the ocean are the same in substance.
('14', 156, 1, 5, 321565) I believe that all of us, individual souls, living in this ocean of spirit, are the same with one another with the closest bond among ourselves.
('14', 156, 1, 6, 321710) A drop that separates soon dries up and any soul that believes itself separate from others is likewise destroyed.
('14', 156, 1, 7, 321824) For myself, I am an uncompromising enemy of the present day civilization of Europe.
('14', 156, 1, 8, 321908) I tried to elaborate my view in Hind Swaraj and show that it is not the British that are responsible for the misfortunes of India but we who have succumbed to modern civilization.
('14', 156, 1, 9, 322088) India can be free this very moment if we turn our back on this modern civilization and go back to our ancient way of life, which embodied the right ethical principles.
('14', 156, 1, 10, 322256) The key to an understanding of Hind Swaraj lies in the idea that worldly pursuits should give way to ethical living.
('14', 156, 1, 11, 322373) This way of life has no room for violence in any form against any human being, black or white.

('14', 163, 4, 18, 333809) The result is that she is better in health.

('14', 165, 7, 13, 336760) The news was cabled to Mr. Kallenbach, and it soon became common property amongst the many who had come to look upon Mrs. Mayo with regard and veneration.

('14', 165, 7, 17, 337122) To the Indians of South Africa her memory will be a cherished treasure for her very warm and loving sympathy during their troubles.

('14', 166, 1, 2, 337651) 152. LETTER TO “THE TRANSVAAL LEADER” 1
('14', 166, 2, 3, 337691) [JOHANNESBURG,] May 23, 1914
('14', 166, 4, 4, 337720) In your today’s issue of the Leader, you publish certain remarks made by Mr. Justice Mason, to which you give the headings “Credibility of Evidence”, “Judge’s Remarks on Indians”.
('14', 166, 4, 5, 337900) I have no desire in any way to controvert His Lordship’s statement which may be justified by the facts brought to his notice from time to time, but it should be well understood by the public that Mr. Justice Mason confined his remarks to a certain class of Indians only, whom my Association has no desire to direct from such criticism.
('14', 166, 4, 6, 338236) He did not, as Mr. Greenberg appeared to suppose condemn Indian evidence on national or racial grounds at all.
('14', 166, 4, 7, 338347) There are also certain classes of non Indians equally guilty of attempts to mislead the Court, but I do not presume that, in similar circumstances, you would speak of the Judge’s remarks on Europeans.
('14', 166, 4, 8, 338548) It is notorious that lawyers, like doctors, see mainly the seamy side of life, and they will necessarily draw conclusions from what they see.
('14', 166, 4, 9, 338690) In spite, however, of
('14', 166, 5, 10, 338712) 1 This was signed by A. M. Cachalia and was in reply to the following report in The Transvaal Leader: “Some rather strong observations regarding the credibility of Indian witnesses were made by Judge and counsel in the Witwatersrand Local Division yesterday.
('14', 166, 5, 11, 338971) The case was one in which an Indian applied for the sequestration of a compatriot’s estate and the latter resisted an order on the ground that the applicant was not a creditor to the amount of £50 as provided by the Insolvency Law.
('14', 166, 5, 12, 339203) “Mr. Justice Mason remarked that the evidence in support of the respondent’s case was what one very often found in Indian cases.
('14', 166, 5, 13, 339332) There generally seemed a number of witnesses for one side fortuitously at hand when the opposite side gave away its whole case.
('14', 166, 5, 14, 339460) In giving Judgment, Mr. Justice Mason said that the respondent’s case was that, in order to defeat other creditors, the applicant agreed with him to take over certain goods in reduction of his debt, and that that was done.
('14', 166, 5, 15, 339683) In support of that, the respondent produced witnesses who conveniently happened to be present when the agreement was made, although the parties making it must have known that the arrangement was one which would be somewhat open to criticism in the eyes of the law.
('14', 166, 5, 16, 339948) Then there were two more witnesses who happened to come on the scene when the arrangements were being carried out, and who seemed to know all about the collusive agreement.
('14', 166, 5, 17, 340121) Now, these were coincidences which, if true, were of a remarkable character.
('14', 166, 5, 18, 340198) Unfortunately, however, these coincidences so often appeared in Indian cases.
('14', 166, 5, 19, 340276) They had got to face that fact.”
('14', 167, 0, 1, 340309) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 167, 1, 2, 340351) what might have been to a less just man a strong temptation to exaggerate, Mr. Justice Mason confined his remarks to that section of the community which he believed to be guilty and did not level an indictment against the whole of the Indian community, as one might suppose from the first few lines of your report.
('14', 167, 1, 3, 340666) I trust that you will find space for this letter in order to remove any wrong impression that might have been created.

('14', 167, 4, 6, 340824) 153. PRAYER SPEECH
('14', 167, 5, 7, 340843) [JOHANNESBURG, May 23, 1914]
('14', 167, 6, 8, 340872) I shall not be pleased just because you recite verses from the Gita.
('14', 167, 6, 9, 340941) I don’t care whether or not you read history, do sums in arithmetic or learn Sanskrit.
('14', 167, 6, 10, 341028) What is necessary is that you should acquire self control.
('14', 167, 6, 11, 341087) That is what I want.
('14', 167, 6, 12, 341108) I may agree to be some one’s slave, but not that of my mind.
('14', 167, 6, 13, 341169) There is no sin as base asbeing the slave to one’s mind.
('14', 167, 6, 14, 341226) Be wise, therefore, and learn to discipline your mind.
('14', 167, 6, 15, 341281) So you will be able to live with me.
('14', 167, 6, 16, 341318) Otherwise I have no need of anyone.
('14', 167, 6, 17, 341354) Nor am I conceited enough to want to teach you or anyone else.
('14', 167, 6, 18, 341417) I have a pupil, to train whom is the most difficult task.
('14', 167, 6, 19, 341475) It is only by training that pupil that I can do some good to you, to India or the world.
('14', 167, 6, 20, 341564) That pupil is myself, what I call my mind.
('14', 167, 6, 21, 341607) Only those who thus become their own pupils are fit to stay here.
('14', 167, 6, 22, 341673) Others who cannot stand such a life had better not stay here.
('14', 167, 6, 23, 341735) Such a person would do well to leave this place.
('14', 167, 6, 24, 341784) It is a sin, however, to do anything blindly (without a purpose, mechanically).
('14', 167, 6, 25, 341864) I want no such thing.

('14', 168, 3, 4, 342024) Upon Clause l Mr. Gandhi indicated that he valued this provision mainly for the sake of appearances.
('14', 168, 3, 5, 342125) He thought that the appointment of a large number of Indian priests as marriage officers might easily lead to abuses, as some persons representing themselves as priests might not be of the highest character.
('14', 168, 3, 6, 342333) He contemplated therefore that a somewhat sparing use would be made of the power of appointment, and that only such priests would be selected as were known to be of unimpeachable reputation.
('14', 168, 3, 7, 342524) He thought that, for practical purposes, the machinery of registration under Clause 2 would and should become the usual method of legalizing Indian marriages, and he therefore deprecated very strongly the limitation of the right to such marriages only as existed at the commencement of the Act.

('14', 169, 2, 10, 346025) Mr. Gandhi renewed his request for an assurance that, so long as the immigration of Natal born Indians into the Cape did not exceed its present dimensions, such Indians should be admitted without the imposition of a test, and particularly without the application of the provisions of Section 4(1)(a) of last year’s immigrants Regulation Act.
('14', 169, 2, 11, 346367) He did not ask for legislation, as presumably he is well aware of the very serious difficulty which the Government would experience if the question of the Cape entry were again to be raised in Parliament even by the introduction of the small amendment recom mended by the Commission on page 16 of their Report.
('14', 169, 2, 12, 346678) I gather that the Commission attached no great importance to this recommendation andthat after the position had been explained to them and they had been apprised of the reason why the words “at the commencement of this Act” had been inserted in Section 4(2)(a) of Act 22 of 1913, they intimated that the recommendation was not one which they would be disposed to press.

('14', 171, 5, 14, 350291) 156. THE RELIEF BILL
('14', 171, 6, 15, 350312) The long expected Indian Bill has now been published.
('14', 171, 6, 16, 350366) We reproduce the full text with the schedule.
('14', 171, 6, 17, 350412) 2 It is a simple and short measure and seems to carry out the recommendations of the Indian Commission in so far as legislative action is necessary.
('14', 171, 6, 18, 350561) The Bill removes the marriage difficulty and restores the status as it existed before the Searle judgment.
('14', 171, 6, 19, 350668) It repeals the £3 tax and remits the unpaid arrears.
('14', 171, 6, 20, 350721) Lastly, it validates Natal certificates of domicile, if the owner can establish his identity with the certificate by proving that the thumb impression on it is his own.
('14', 171, 6, 21, 350890) There is another clause in the Bill with which the community is not concerned.
('14', 171, 6, 22, 350969) It is the clause which enables the Government to give a free passage to any Indian not otherwise provided for if he renounces for himself and his family all claim to domicile in Natal or any other Province of the Union.
('14', 171, 6, 23, 351189) There are certain alterations necessary in the Bill.
('14', 171, 6, 24, 351242) It will be a proper thing to use for validating future unions the machinery provided in the Bill for validating existing unions.
('14', 171, 6, 25, 351371) Amendment will also be necessary for protecting the children of deceased wives, where such wives, if alive, could have been recognized under the present Bill.
('14', 171, 7, 26, 351530) 1 It was introduced in the House of Assembly on June 2 2 Vide “The Indians Relief Act”, 1914.
('14', 172, 0, 1, 351624) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 173
('14', 172, 1, 2, 351669) Assuming that the Bill with the suggested alterations becomes law, there will still remain the other matters recommended by the Commission and the matters covered by Mr. Cachalia’s and Mr. Gandhi’s letters.
('14', 172, 1, 3, 351876) These require administrative treatment and include the Free State question, the Cape entry and the administration of existing laws.
('14', 172, 1, 4, 352008) If satisfactory assurances are issued in connection with them, the struggle that has gone on for years, and that has meant enormous losses and sufferings to the community, may be said to have fitly and honourably closed.

('14', 173, 1, 2, 353569) 158. FRAGMENT OF LETTER
('14', 173, 2, 3, 353593) CAPE TOWN, Tuesday, Jyestha Vad 2 [June 9, 1914] We cannot pass any judgment on Mr. Sinha on the basis of what we read in newspapers at this distance.
('14', 173, 2, 4, 353744) Mr. Norton also acted formerly as a public prosecutor in such cases.
('14', 173, 2, 5, 353813) Who is a leader and who is not is a matter of opinion.
('14', 173, 2, 6, 353868) Generally, a satyagrahi will express no opinion.
('14', 173, 2, 7, 353917) In the kind of situation you mention, if one were to offer satyagraha and be imprisoned in consequence, the purpose of satyagraha would have been served.
('14', 173, 2, 8, 354071) We need not always speak out in such cases.
('14', 173, 2, 9, 354115) There is no ready answer to the question when satyagraha should be offered.
('14', 173, 2, 10, 354191) A satyagrahi does not deliberate in advance when embarking on satyagraha.
('14', 173, 2, 11, 354265) When he finds anything done that violates his conscience, he should use soul force against it.
('14', 173, 2, 12, 354360) Even at the time that I first started satyagraha, I considered it to be but a part of dharma.
('14', 173, 2, 13, 354454) I have discov ered from experience that it is the only religion and the only chint amani 1, and it has, therefore, developed in me especially in its aspect as dharma.
('14', 173, 2, 14, 354621) He is a satyagrahi who has resolved to practise nothing but truth and such a one will know the right way every time.
('14', 173, 2, 15, 354738) One’s entire life should be permeated with truth.
('14', 173, 2, 16, 354788) This will come about gradually through the observance of yamas 2, niyamas 3, etc.
('14', 173, 2, 17, 354870) Just as, in learning secular subjects, one has to work at them for many years, so too must one make efforts to understand the nature of satyagraha.
('14', 173, 2, 18, 355018) As the veils which cover your atman and mine fall off, the atman of each will shine the more brightly and be the more resolute satyagrahis in battle.
('14', 173, 3, 19, 355168) [From Gujarati] Mahatma Gandhijina Patro
('14', 173, 4, 20, 355209) 1 A fabulous gem supposed to yield to its possessor all that he desires; the philosophers’ stone 2 This means any moral duty or religious observance.
('14', 173, 4, 21, 355359) The yamas are usually said to be ten, but their names are given differently by different authorities.
('14', 173, 4, 22, 355461) They include celibacy, compassion, truth, charity, non violence, etc.
('14', 173, 4, 23, 355531) 3 Any voluntary or self imposed religious observance, dependent on external conditions.

('14', 174, 1, 2, 355664) 159. INDIAN GRIEVANCES
('14', 174, 2, 3, 355687) The Bill as originally circulated, but not gazetted, has already been amended in the sense indicated as being necessary in our leading article 1 last week.
('14', 174, 2, 4, 355843) It will be remembered that the original draft required Indians applying for the validation of a marriage by virtue of its provisions to satisfy the Marriage Officer “that there existed at the commencement of this Act between them a union then recognized as a marriage under the tenets of an Indian religion which they profess”.
('14', 174, 2, 5, 356171) The Bill as amended, and now gazetted, reads that the officer must be satisfied “that there exists between them a union then recognized as a marriage under the tenets of an Indian religion which they profess”.
('14', 174, 2, 6, 356381) This amendment provides, therefore, for the validation of future marriages celebrated within the Union or elsewhere.
('14', 174, 2, 7, 356498) Then, again, para graph 3, sub section 2, of the Bill is amended to provide that “the child under the age of sixteen” shall include “the child of the exem pted person and a deceased woman who, if she had been alive, could have been recognized as the wife (as herein defined) or whose union with the exempted person could have been registered as a marriage under section 2 of this Act”.
('14', 174, 2, 8, 356884) The amendment speaks for itself, and the Bill now seems to satisfy the legislative requirements of Passive Resisters.
('14', 174, 2, 9, 357002) We hope that it will have a speedy passage through Parliament.
('14', 174, 3, 10, 357065) Indian Opinion, 10 6 1914

('14', 175, 1, 4, 357824) Prahlad, by disobeying his father’s order, rendered a service to him and brought about his deliverance.
('14', 175, 1, 5, 357928) Mirabai 1, by leaving Kumbha Rana, turned the Rana himself into her disciple.
('14', 175, 1, 6, 358006) Dayanand 2 ran away from his parents, breaking betrothal already solemnized, and even gave the slip to the men who had been sent after him; in this way he showed his devotion to his mother and father.
('14', 175, 1, 7, 358207) Lord Buddha went away as his young wife lay asleep.
('14', 175, 1, 8, 358259) We find many similar examples.
('14', 175, 1, 9, 358290) Pondering over them, we must, in the difficult situation in which we are placed, do what seems the right thing from the point of view of true ethics.
('14', 175, 1, 10, 358440) In the case of Shravana, the finer, intangible form of service happened to flow in the same channel as outward, physical service.
('14', 175, 1, 11, 358570) Not infrequently, therefore,we fail to discover from his example what the right course should be.
('14', 175, 1, 12, 358668) He who habitually follows the path of truth will know the right way at the crucial moment.
('14', 175, 1, 13, 358759) If the things such as poems about disinterested ness, which we read are of no help to us when faced with moral dilemmas, we will have read them in vain, parrot like.
('14', 175, 1, 14, 358925) We could not have reflected over them.
('14', 175, 1, 15, 358964) If, despite our having read the Gita, it does not come to our help at the last moment, we might as well have not read it.
('14', 175, 1, 16, 359086) This is the reason why I have always said: “Read little, but reflect over the little that you read, understand its significance and be ready to put it into practice.” It is only when we cease to be selfishly attached to those we love that the heart feels true compassion and renders service to them.
('14', 175, 1, 17, 359386) To the extent that I have grown free of such attachment for Ba, I am able to serve her better.
('14', 175, 1, 18, 359481) The Buddha, by leaving his parents, brought deliverance to them as well.
('14', 175, 1, 19, 359554) Gopichand, by his renunciation, displayed the purest love for his mother.
('14', 175, 1, 20, 359628) In the same way, you will be serving your parents by strengthening your character and cultivating spotless morality.
('14', 175, 1, 21, 359745) When your soul has grown pure, it cannot but produce a corresponding effect on all those whom you love.
('14', 175, 2, 22, 359849) [With due regards, MOHANDAS] [From Gujarati] Gandhijini Sadhana
('14', 175, 3, 23, 359913) 1 A medieval saint poetess of Rajasthan 2 Swamy Dayanand Saraswati (1824 83); founder of the Arya Samaj

('14', 181, 10, 15, 370393) The second reading of the Indian Bill was carried by a very substantial majority and became the occasion for a weighty pronouncement on the Government’s Indian policy.
('14', 181, 10, 16, 370561) 2 General Smuts’speech was studiously moderate and not at all offensive as some of his speeches on the subject have been in the past.
('14', 181, 10, 17, 370695) General Botha’s speech was worthy of the occasion.
('14', 181, 10, 18, 370746) We feel grateful for his declaration that the Government proposed to stand or fall by the Bill.
('14', 181, 10, 19, 370842) The other speeches delivered in favour of the Bill were of the same high order and, if the spirit of justice and conciliation that pervaded the speeches is continued in the administration of the existing laws, there need be no fear whatsoever of any Indian trouble arising in the future.
('14', 181, 10, 20, 371130) We take the speeches as an earnest of the intention of the Government and the legislature that the resident population is to be
('14', 181, 11, 21, 371258) 1 Kunvarji Vithalbhai Mehta, manager of the Patidar Students’ Hostel at Surat, in Gujarat 2 This was on June 8, 1914.

('14', 182, 1, 2, 371421) treated with justice and fair play.

('14', 182, 1, 4, 371690) We trust that the same policy will be followed in the future.
('14', 182, 2, 5, 371752) What could have contributed to this high tone of the debate?

('14', 183, 6, 6, 373667) 168. LETTER TO INDENTURED INDIANS
('14', 183, 7, 7, 373701) [CAPE TOWN, After June 22, 1914]
('14', 183, 8, 8, 373734) TO INDIANS COMING WITHIN THE SCOPE OF ACT 17 OF 1895
('14', 183, 9, 9, 373787) MY DEAR BRETHREN,
('14', 183, 10, 10, 373805) You must have known by now that the £3 tax which you, your wives and grown up children had to pay every year has been repealed and that the collection of arrears has been suspended.
('14', 183, 10, 11, 373987) This means that you can live in freedom in this Province without re indenturing yourselves.
('14', 183, 10, 12, 374079) The Act of 1891 which applied to those who arrived before 1895 will now apply to you as well.
('14', 183, 10, 13, 374173) It was in order to bring this about that you, I and hundreds of our brethren put up a struggle and went through suffering.
('14', 183, 10, 14, 374296) But The Natal Mercury has stated that your position has become worse than it was and that now you will be either compelled to re indenture yourselves or sent back to India.
('14', 183, 10, 15, 374469) This is not true.
('14', 183, 10, 16, 374487) The Government has stated categorically in one of its commu nications that the inference which the Mercury has drawn is not correct.
('14', 183, 10, 17, 374620) 1 The Imperial Government and the Government of India are parties to the settlement.
('14', 183, 10, 18, 374705) I know how they understand it.
('14', 183, 10, 19, 374736) They have no doubt that the repeal of the tax means that you can live as free men and that, if you live so in Natal for three years, you will get the same
('14', 183, 11, 20, 374891) 1 Vide 1st footnote of “Letter to E.M. Gorges”, 11 6 1914.
('14', 184, 0, 1, 374950) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 185
('14', 184, 1, 2, 374995) rights of residence as Indians who arrive as free immigrants.
('14', 184, 1, 3, 375057) And finally I want to tell you that, if, under the new Act, you are treated as prohibited immigrants, as The Natal Mercury says you will be, no matter in what part of the world I may be, I shall use all my strength to get so terrible an injustice removed.
('14', 184, 1, 4, 375313) I am convinced, however, that the Government intends nothing of the kind and also that the Act bears no such meaning.
('14', 184, 1, 5, 375431) This is the view of Mr. Marshall Campbell, too, who worked so hard to secure the repeal of the tax.
('14', 184, 1, 6, 375531) You need have, therefore, no apprehensions on this score and I hope that no Indian will henceforth re indenture himself out of fear of being expelled from this Colony.
('14', 184, 2, 7, 375699) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 29 7 1914
('14', 184, 3, 8, 375741) 169. THE LATE SIR DAVID HUNTER
('14', 184, 4, 9, 375772) The news reached Durban on Sunday that Sir David Hunter, K.C.M.G., one of Natal’s most sincere and broad minded public men, had passed away, after an operation at a nursing home in Edinburgh.
('14', 184, 4, 10, 375964) Sir David was well known as one who stood up for the weak and oppressed.
('14', 184, 4, 11, 376037) In as out of Parliament his voice could always be heard in favour of justice and fair play, especially on behalf of those who were unrepresented in the Legislature.
('14', 184, 4, 12, 376202) The Indian community will feel his loss very keenly.
('14', 184, 4, 13, 376255) During his twenty six years’ connection with the Natal Government Railways as General Manager he was known as a humane employer.
('14', 184, 4, 14, 376384) He always spoke well of his Indian employees and they always thought highly of their Chief.
('14', 184, 4, 15, 376476) We well remember, at the time of Mr. Gokhale’s visit, Sir David speaking at the historic banquet in the Durban Drill Hall, in the capacity of Chairman, saying that, through long and varied experience, he had learned to respect his Indian staff for their faithful and useful service, and he, therefore had satisfaction in believing that they reciprocated his feelings towards them by loyal trust in him.
('14', 184, 4, 16, 376879) He also spoke of the innate dignity and courtesy which were characteristic of the Indian race.
('14', 184, 4, 17, 376974) Sir David, along with many others, maintained that the £3 tax was an unjust imposition, and we had the assurance from his own lips that he intended to support its repeal at the earliest opportunity.
('14', 184, 4, 18, 377173) Had it not been for the unfortunate illness which took him to Scotland in the hope of relief, we are confident that there would not have been a more faithful
('14', 185, 0, 1, 377331) 186 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 185, 1, 2, 377373) supporter of the present Indians’ Relief Bill than Sir David Hunter.
('14', 185, 1, 3, 377442) To the relatives and friends we offer our sincere sympathy and condolence, and we feel sure that the whole Indian community will share our feelings.
('14', 185, 2, 4, 377591) Indian Opinion, 24 6 1914

('14', 186, 5, 13, 379936) 172. SPEECH AT CONGRATULATORY MEETING 1
('14', 186, 6, 14, 379976) CAPE TOWN, June 27, 1914
('14', 186, 7, 15, 380001) Mr. Gandhi, in replying, referred to the period 21 years ago when he first came to this country, an Agnostic.
('14', 186, 7, 16, 380111) He had since learned, however, to recognize that there was a Divine purpose in the world, and a Divine hand guiding events conformably thereto.
('14', 186, 7, 17, 380255) In the long struggle for the removal of Indian disabilities, a struggle which had absorbed the best part of his life, he had had many a hard knock, and many things had been attributed to him that he
('14', 186, 8, 18, 380454) 1 Gandhiji spoke at a gathering of European and Indian friends who had assembled in the evening to congratulate him on the passage of the Indians’ Relief Bill.
('14', 186, 8, 19, 380614) Senator Marshall Campbell and Hugh M. Meyler, M. L. A., expressed pleasure at the removal of £3 tax and other outstanding disabilities of the Indians in South Africa.
('14', 186, 8, 20, 380781) The report in the indirect form is from a despatch by the Parliamentary Representative of The Natal Mercury.
('14', 187, 0, 1, 380890) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 187, 1, 2, 380932) had neither done nor intended to do.
('14', 187, 1, 3, 380969) The method on which he had relied, which he thought was now beginning to be better understood had nothing in it of a lawless or desperate spirit, but he knew always that it made more demands on a man’s courage and endurance than methods of violence could do.
('14', 187, 2, 4, 381228) Mr. Gandhi said it was a harder form of agitation, which, in the present
('14', 187, 3, 5, 381301) case, could not have succeeded had his own countrymen not supported him, as
('14', 187, 4, 6, 381377) was their duty.
('14', 187, 4, 7, 381393) He felt himself to have been but a tool, and one of many tools.
('14', 187, 5, 8, 381457) His deep thanks were due to the many European friends whose help had most
('14', 187, 6, 9, 381531) materially contributed to the success now realised.
('14', 187, 6, 10, 381583) He remembered how, during
('14', 187, 7, 11, 381609) the month of the trying march into the Transvaal, a large number of Europeans
('14', 187, 8, 12, 381687) had met the Indian column at various points along the road and encouraged
('14', 187, 9, 13, 381761) them with sympathy and practical assistance.
('14', 187, 9, 14, 381806) Potent, however, though
('14', 187, 10, 15, 381830) passive resistance was as an instrument for winning reforms—perhaps the
('14', 187, 11, 16, 381902) mightiest instrument on earth—it could not have achieved success had the
('14', 187, 12, 17, 381975) Indian community not moderated their demands to what was reasonable and
('14', 187, 13, 18, 382047) practical.
('14', 187, 13, 19, 382058) This, again, was not possible until some of them were able to see
('14', 187, 14, 20, 382124) the question of Indian rights from the European standpoint.
('14', 187, 15, 21, 382184) Mr. Gandhi went on to say he had made it his aim to see that question with the
('14', 187, 16, 22, 382263) eyes of those who had seemed to his fellow countrymen to be doing them an
('14', 187, 17, 23, 382337) injustice; and he thought that, after long effort, he had fairly well succeeded.
('14', 187, 18, 24, 382418) As to the Bill, he would say that it was a settlement of present difficulties.
('14', 187, 19, 25, 382497) felt that his countrymen in South Africa, after their struggle of eight years,
('14', 187, 20, 26, 382576) were entitled to a reasonable period of peace.
('14', 187, 20, 27, 382623) He had been impressed by the
('14', 187, 21, 28, 382652) spirit of national and Imperial responsibility manifested in the recent
('14', 187, 22, 29, 382724) speeches on the Bill in the Union Parliament, and, if that spirit continued, he
('14', 187, 23, 30, 382804) had no doubt the Government here would be able to solve the problems which
('14', 187, 24, 31, 382879) still remained in regard to their Indian subjects.
('14', 187, 24, 32, 382930) He did not see that the peace
('14', 187, 25, 33, 382960) now accomplished needed ever to be disturbed.
('14', 187, 25, 34, 383006) There would be no more influx
('14', 187, 26, 35, 383036) of Indians into the country.
('14', 187, 26, 36, 383065) Indentured labour had been stopped for ever—let
('14', 187, 27, 37, 383113) them thank heaven for that.
('14', 187, 27, 38, 383141) The Indians knew perfectly well which was the
('14', 187, 28, 39, 383187) dominant and governing race.
('14', 187, 28, 40, 383216) They aspired to no social equality with
('14', 187, 29, 41, 383256) Europeans.
('14', 187, 29, 42, 383267) They felt that the path of their development was separate.
('14', 187, 29, 43, 383326) They did
('14', 187, 30, 44, 383335) not even aspire to the franchise, or, if the aspiration existed, it was with no
('14', 187, 31, 45, 383415) idea of its having present effect.
('14', 187, 31, 46, 383450) Ultimately—in the future—he believed his
('14', 187, 32, 47, 383491) people would get the franchise if they deserved to get it, but the matter did not
('14', 187, 33, 48, 383573) belong to practical politics.
('14', 187, 33, 49, 383603) All he would ask for the Indian community was
('14', 187, 34, 50, 383649) that, on the basis of the rights now conceded to them, they should be suffered
('14', 188, 0, 1, 383728) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 189
('14', 188, 1, 2, 383773) to live with dignity and honour on the soil of South Africa.
('14', 188, 2, 3, 383834) We do not aspire to social equality, and I dare say our social evolution lies along different lines.
('14', 188, 2, 4, 383935) We have stated so repeatedly — that we shall not at present ask for the whole franchise.
('14', 188, 2, 5, 384024) We understand who is the predominant race here.
('14', 188, 2, 6, 384072) In the process of time, when we have deserved it, we shall get the franchise also.
('14', 188, 2, 7, 384155) I dare say, but that is not a question of practical politics.
('14', 188, 2, 8, 384217) There will be no further influx of Indians from India—thank Heaven!
('14', 188, 2, 9, 384285) —so that it is only a question of the fair and just treatment of the Indian population that is here, and, if that population is to live in peace, the least it is entitled to is to have the ability and opportunity of living here in absolute peace, and with honour and dignity.
('14', 188, 2, 10, 384561) If that is not what we are entitled to, I do not know what we are entitled to.
('14', 188, 3, 11, 384640) The Natal Mercury, 29 6 1914 and 30 6 1914

('14', 190, 1, 2, 388262) 174. LETTER TO E. M. GORGES
('14', 190, 2, 3, 388290) CAPE TOWN, June 30, 1914
('14', 190, 3, 4, 388315) DEAR MR. GORGES,
('14', 190, 4, 5, 388332) I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter 1 of even dateherewith setting forth the substance of the interview that General Smuts was pleased, notwithstanding many other pressing calls upon his time, to grant me on Saturday last.
('14', 190, 4, 6, 388563) I feel deeply grateful for the patience and courtesy which the Minister showed during the discussion of the several points submitted by me.
('14', 190, 4, 7, 388703) The passing of the Indians’ Relief Bill and this correspondence finally closes the passive resistance struggle which commenced in the September of 1906 and which to the Indian community cost much physical suffering and pecuniary loss and to the Government much anxious thought and consideration.
('14', 190, 4, 8, 388999) As the Minister is aware, some of my countrymen have wished me to go further.
('14', 190, 4, 9, 389077) They are dissatisfied that the trade licences laws of the different provinces, the Transvaal Gold Law, the Transvaal Townships Act 2, the Transvaal Law 3 of 1885 have not been altered, so as to give them full rights of residence, trade and ownership of land.
('14', 190, 4, 10, 389336) Some of them are dissatisfied that full inter provincial migration is not permitted, and some are dissatisfied that, on the marriage question, the Relief Bill goes no further than it does.
('14', 190, 4, 11, 389525) They have asked me that all the above matters might be included in the passive resistance struggle.
('14', 190, 4, 12, 389625) I have been unable to comply with their wishes.
('14', 190, 4, 13, 389673) Whilst, therefore, they have not been included in the programme of passive resistance, it will not be denied that some day or other these matters will require further and sympathetic consideration by the Government.
('14', 190, 4, 14, 389889) Complete satisfac tion cannot be expected until full civic rights have been conceded to the resident Indian population.
('14', 190, 4, 15, 390009) I have told my countrymen that they will have to exercise patience and by all honourable means at their
('14', 190, 5, 16, 390113) 1 Vide “Letter from E.M. Gorges”, 30 6 1914. 2 The Gold Law and the Townships Act of 1908 prevented Indians from residing or trading except in Locations in all the Gold areas.
('14', 191, 0, 1, 390289) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 191, 1, 2, 390331) disposal educate public opinion so as to enable the Government of the day to go further than the present correspondence does.
('14', 191, 1, 3, 390457) I shall hope that, when the Europeans of South Africa fully appreciate the fact that now, as the importation of indentured labour from India is prohibited and as the Immigrants Regulation Act of last year has in practice all but stopped further free Indian immigration and that my countrymen do not aspire to any political ambition, they, the Europeans, will see the justice and, indeed, the necessity of my countrymen being granted the rights I have just referred to.
('14', 191, 1, 4, 390926) Meanwhile, if the generous spirit that the Government have applied to the treatment of the problem during the past few months continues to be applied, as promised in your letter, in the administration of the existing laws, I am quite certain that the Indian community throughout the Union will be able to enjoy some measure of peace and never be a source of trouble to the Government.
('14', 191, 3, 5, 391311) Yours faithfully, M. K. GANDHI
('14', 191, 4, 6, 391342) From a photostat of the typewritten office copy: S. N. 5999

('14', 192, 4, 7, 391967) I am making a desperate effort to leave by the 18th instant.

('14', 193, 1, 3, 393359) We also owe thanks to Mr. Kallenbach, Mr. Polak and all other European friends who have helped us during difficult times.
('14', 193, 2, 4, 393481) Speaking on the new Bill, he said:
('14', 193, 3, 5, 393516) We could see that the Union Government worked to get the Assembly and the Senate to pass a Bill which would satisfy the Imperial Government, the Government of India and the Indians of South Africa.
('14', 193, 3, 6, 393714) General Botha, it must be admitted, has done much for us, seeing that, for the sake of a community as docile as the Indians, he threatened to resign if the Bill was not passed.
('14', 193, 3, 7, 393891) We also thank the Opposition for treating this issue, not as a matter of party politics, but as an Imperial problem.
('14', 193, 3, 8, 394008) We are thankful, too, to the Imperial Government and to Lord Hardinge, that noble Viceroy of India, for their help.
('14', 193, 3, 9, 394124) The help which India gave us under the leadership of Mr. Gokhale and the invaluable help from Mr. Andrews—each I of these surpassed the other and it is thanks to them that we have this final and satisfactory settlement today.
('14', 193, 3, 10, 394350) The spirit which animated the Govern ment in dealing out justice to us will also inspire the administration of the Act and, if so, there will be no occasion again for a struggle like this.
('14', 193, 3, 11, 394539) But, with their leave, I wish to point out to my countrymen that the remedy for every hardship lies in the first instance with us; after that, we have the weapon of satyagraha.
('14', 193, 3, 12, 394716) I shall for ever cherish the sacred memory of European friends and the love my countrymen have borne towards me.

('14', 194, 2, 3, 394949) Sunday morning, July 5, 1914
('14', 194, 3, 4, 394978) MY DEAR FRIEND AND SEEKER,
('14', 194, 4, 5, 395005) First the experiment.
('14', 194, 4, 6, 395027) My ration was 3 bananas, 4 apples, 2 oranges, 6 naarangi[s], 4 dates, 4 oz.
('14', 194, 4, 7, 395103) monkey nuts, 2 spoonful oil and lemon and orange squash.
('14', 194, 4, 8, 395160) Had no noises and only one motion for the whole day well bound.
('14', 194, 4, 9, 395224) I am looking forward to the result of yours which is so thorough.
('14', 194, 4, 10, 395290) About Joseph, you were hopelessly wrong.
('14', 194, 4, 11, 395331) You ought to have bought his ticket Polak could not be considered.
('14', 194, 4, 12, 395398) If you did not want to buy, you should not have taken the money and having failed to do either, you should have had the courage to give Joseph the real reason for not buying.
('14', 194, 4, 13, 395573) It was a lie.
('14', 194, 4, 14, 395587) Do you think Joseph could not under stand?
('14', 194, 4, 15, 395630) He was quite nice and allowed us to chat away.
('14', 194, 4, 16, 395677) He was no disturbing factor.
('14', 194, 4, 17, 395706) Turn your reading to account.
('14', 194, 4, 18, 395736) Not until you have truth in you, will you make real progress.
('14', 194, 4, 19, 395798) Fear God only.
('14', 194, 4, 20, 395813) Do not fear man.
('14', 194, 4, 21, 395830) Be ever brave but be truthful or do not speak.
('14', 194, 4, 22, 395877) You could easily have said, ‘Joseph, and Polak and Gandhi are going to have a private chat.
('14', 194, 4, 23, 395969) So better not go but if you must, ask their permission or I cannot help you to get the ticket’.

('14', 194, 4, 25, 396110) Hope Medh sent the wire to Union Castle.
('14', 194, 4, 26, 396151) Finish everything without worry.
('14', 194, 4, 27, 396184) May God give you strength and courage.

('14', 195, 1, 2, 396377) 178. SPEECH AT DURBAN MEETING 1
('14', 195, 2, 3, 396409) [July 5, 1914]
('14', 195, 3, 4, 396424) The inference that the Mercury and other papers have drawn about the £3 tax is altogether wrong and misleading.
('14', 195, 3, 5, 396536) It does not at all follow from the Act.
('14', 195, 3, 6, 396576) After the Mercury’s comments were published, General Smuts was addressed on the matter, and he is also convinced that the Act does not bear the meaning which the Mercury has read in it.
('14', 195, 4, 7, 396762) Speaking on the marriage question, Mr. Gandhi said: Some Indians have asked for a marriage law similar to the one in Mauritius.
('14', 195, 4, 8, 396890) I have, however, read that law; it is worse, on the contrary [than the law here].
('14', 195, 4, 9, 396972) We shall not find anywhere else a better solution to the marriage problem than the one we have secured.
('14', 195, 5, 10, 397076) Proceeding, he said that the issue of the right of entry of South Africa born Indians into the Cape and the problem of the Orange Free State had also been satis factorily settled, and added that the Government had given assurances for reasonable and lenient administration of the Act.
('14', 195, 5, 11, 397361) Concluding, he thanked them for gathering in such large numbers to honour him.

('14', 198, 1, 2, 400837) 183. LETTER TO E. M. GORGES
('14', 198, 2, 3, 400865) PHOENIX, NATAL, July 7, 1914
('14', 198, 3, 4, 400894) DEAR MR. GORGES,
('14', 198, 4, 5, 400911) I have now got a moment to submit my note upon the Gold Law.
('14', 198, 4, 6, 400972) As you know, after maturer consideration, I refrained from pressing for the insertion of a special clause defining “vested rights” in connection with the Gold Law and Townships Amendment Act, because I felt that any definition in the correspondence might result in restricting the future action of my countrymen.
('14', 198, 4, 7, 401285) However, so far as my interpretation of “vested rights” is concerned, I think that I shall reduce it to writing.
('14', 198, 4, 8, 401398) General Smuts was good enough to say that he would endeavour to protect vested rights as defined by me.
('14', 198, 4, 9, 401502) The following is the definition I submitted to Sir Benjamin Robertson, who, I understood, submitted it to General Smuts.
('14', 198, 4, 10, 401623) My letter 1 contai ning, among other matters, the definition, is dated the 4th March, 1914. “By ‘vested rights’ I understand the right of an Indian and his successors to live and trade in the townships in which he was living and trading, no matter how often he shifts his residence or business from place to place in the same township.” I am fortified in my interpretation by the answer given by Mr. Harcourt in connection with the matter, in the House of Commons, on the 27th June, 1911:
('14', 198, 5, 11, 402112) Complaints against that legislation (the Gold Law and Townships Amendment Act) have been made and are now being investigated by the Government of the Union of South Africa, who have lately stated that there is no intention of interfering with any business or right to carry on business acquired and exercised by Indians prior to the date of the legislation.
('14', 198, 5, 12, 402470) I have also now traced the note by Mr. de Villiers which I alluded to in our conversation.
('14', 198, 5, 13, 402561) It is contained in a White Paper published in London in March, 1912, and has the following:
('14', 198, 6, 14, 402653) No right or privilege which a Coloured person has at the present time is taken away by the new Act (Act 35 of 1908).
('14', 198, 7, 15, 402770) 1 Vide “Letter to Sir Benjamin Robertson”, 4 3 1914.
('14', 199, 0, 1, 402823) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 199, 1, 2, 402865) And again,
('14', 199, 2, 3, 402876) Section 131, which, before the Billas introduced into Parliament, formed the subject of questions in the English House of Commons and of despatches from the Secretary of State to the Governor, has been amended in Committee so as to safeguard any rights which a Coloured person may, at the present time, have of occupying land in mining areas.
('14', 199, 2, 4, 403219) Certainly, prior to the passing of the Gold Law, no restrictions were, to my knowledge, placed upon the movement or the trade of British Indians in the Gold Areas.
('14', 199, 2, 5, 403383) There can, therefore, be no justification for any restriction now, especially in regard to those who are already settled in their respective townships.
('14', 199, 4, 6, 403535) Yours truly, M. K. GANDHI E. M. GORGES, ESQ.

('14', 199, 8, 12, 403849) 2 He hoped they would forgive him for appearing in that strange costume, which he had adopted on his premature discharge from prison, as a sign of mourning.

('14', 200, 1, 2, 405070) dress, he felt that, in the mental attitude which possessed him at that moment, he could not render a greater respect for them than in appearing as he did.
('14', 200, 1, 3, 405226) (Cheers.) Referring to the addresses which had been presented to him, he said that, while he valued them, he valued more the love and sympathy which the addresses had expressed.
('14', 200, 1, 4, 405404) He did not know that he would be able to make adequate compensation.

('14', 200, 1, 7, 405591) Many an Indian woman had done greater service during the struggle than Mrs. Gandhi.

('14', 200, 1, 9, 405790) The community had done well in recognizing Mr. Kallenbach’s worth.
('14', 200, 1, 10, 405857) Mr. Kallenbach would tell them that he came to the struggle to gain.
('14', 200, 1, 11, 405926) He considered that, by taking up their cause, he gained a great deal in the truest sense.
('14', 200, 1, 12, 406016) Mr. Kallenbach had done splendid work during the strike at Newcastle and, when the time came, he cheerfully went to prison, again thinking that he was the gainer and not the loser.
('14', 200, 1, 13, 406197) Proceeding, Mr. Gandhi referred to the time of his arrival in 1897 when his friend Mr. Laughton had stood by him against the mob.
('14', 200, 1, 14, 406327) 1 He also remembered with gratefulness the action of Mrs. Alexander, the wife of the late Superintendent of Police in Durban, who protected him with her umbrella from the missiles thrown by the excited crowd.
('14', 200, 1, 15, 406536) Referring to passive resistance, he claimed that it was a weapon of the purest type.
('14', 200, 1, 16, 406621) It was not the weapon of the weak.
('14', 200, 1, 17, 406656) It needed, in his opinion, far greater courage to be a passive resister than a physical resister.
('14', 200, 1, 18, 406754) It was the courage of a Jesus, a Daniel, a Cranmer, a Latimer and a Ridley who could go calmly to suffering and death, and the courage of a Tolstoy who dared to defy the Czars of Russia, that stood out as the greatest.
('14', 200, 1, 19, 406973) Mr. Gandhi said he knew the Mayor had received some telegrams stating that the Indians’ Relief Bill was not satisfactory.
('14', 200, 1, 20, 407095) 2 It would be a singular thing if in this world they would be able to get anything that satisfied everybody, but, in the condition of things in South Africa at the present time, he was certain they could not have had a better measure.
('14', 200, 1, 21, 407330) I do not claim the credit for it.
('14', 200, 1, 22, 407364) It is rather due to the women and children and young people like Nagappen, Narayansamy, and Valliamah who have died for the cause and to those who quickened the conscience of South Africa.
('14', 200, 1, 23, 407553) Our thanks are due also to the Union Government.
('14', 200, 1, 24, 407602) I shall never forget that General Botha showed the greatest statesmanship when he said his Government would stand or fall by this measure.
('14', 200, 1, 25, 407741) I followed the whole of that historic debate— historic to me, historic to my countrymen, and possibly historic to South Africa and the world.

('14', 201, 0, 1, 408088) 202 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 201, 1, 2, 408130) Proceeding, Mr. Gandhi said that it was well known to them how the Government had done justice, and how the Opposition had come to their assistance.
('14', 201, 1, 3, 408279) They had also received handsome help from both the Imperial and The manner in which India, led by their great and distinguished countryman, Mr. Gokhale, had responded to the cry which came from the hearts of thousands of their countrymen in South Africa was one of the results of the passive resistance movement, and left, he hoped, no bitter traces or bitter memories.
('14', 201, 1, 4, 408649) (Applause.) This assurance I wish to give.
('14', 201, 1, 5, 408692) I go away with no ill will against a European.
('14', 201, 1, 6, 408739) I have received many hard knocks in my life, but here I admit that I have received those most precious gifts from Europeans—love and sympathy.
('14', 201, 1, 7, 408882) (Cheers.)
('14', 201, 2, 8, 408892) This settlement, he said, had been achieved after an eight years’ struggle.
('14', 201, 2, 9, 408968) The Indians in South Africa had never aspired to any political ambition, and as regards the social question, that could never arise in connection with the Indians.
('14', 201, 2, 10, 409132) I do not hold for one moment that East and West cannot combine.
('14', 201, 2, 11, 409196) I think the day is coming when East must meet West, or West meet East, but I think the social evolution of the West today lies in one channel, and that of the Indian in another channel.
('14', 201, 2, 12, 409382) The Indians have no wish today to encroach on the social institutions of the European in South Africa.
('14', 201, 2, 13, 409485) (Cheers.) Most Indians are natural traders.
('14', 201, 2, 14, 409529) There are bound to be trade jealousies and those various things that come from competition.
('14', 201, 2, 15, 409621) I have never been able to find a solution of this most difficult problem, which will require the broad mindedness and spirit of justice of the Government of South Africa to hold the balance between conflicting interests.
('14', 201, 3, 16, 409842) Referring to his stay in South Africa, Mr. Gandhi said that he should retain the most sacred memories of this land.
('14', 201, 3, 17, 409958) He had been fortunate in forming the happiest and most lasting friendship with both Europeans and Indians.
('14', 201, 3, 18, 410065) He was now returning to India—a holy land, sanctified by the austerities of the ages.
('14', 201, 3, 19, 410151) In conclusion, Mr. Gandhi said, he hoped that the same love and sympathy which had been given to him in South Africa might be extended to him, no matter in what part of the world he might be.
('14', 201, 3, 20, 410343) He hoped that the settlement embodied in the Indians’ Relief Bill would be carried out in a spirit of broad mindedness and justice in the administration of the laws lately passed in connection with the affairs of the Indian community.
('14', 201, 3, 21, 410578) Then, I think there will be no fear on the part of my country men in their social evolution.
('14', 201, 3, 22, 410671) That is one of the lessons of the settle ment.
