('14', 202, 0, 1, 410839) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 203
('14', 202, 1, 2, 410884) 185. THE END
('14', 202, 2, 3, 410897) A struggle of eight years’ duration has at last finally closed.
('14', 202, 2, 4, 410961) The Indians’ Relief Bill and the correspondence 1 between the Government and Mr. Gandhi embody a complete and mutually satisfactory and honourable settlement of the problems that were affected by the passive resistance movement.
('14', 202, 2, 5, 411190) For this happy ending we have to thank the Imperial, Indian and Union Governments, the Motherland, guided and moved by Mr. Gokhale, and Mr. Andrews’ mission.
('14', 202, 2, 6, 411348) The suffe rings of thousands of Passive Resisters, the martyrdom of Valliamah, Narayansamy, Nagappen and Harbatsingh brought these forces into being.
('14', 202, 2, 7, 411498) Passive Resistance, as a lawful weapon, has thus once more been vindicated.
('14', 202, 2, 8, 411574) The lengthy reference made by Lord Gladstone to the settlement shows its importance.
('14', 202, 2, 9, 411659) We are grateful to His Excellency for clearly placing before the people of South Africa the Imperial aspect.
('14', 202, 2, 10, 411768) It now remains for the Union Government to follow up this happy solution of a difficult problem by a sympathetic and just administration of the laws that affect the Indian community and for the latter to show by its action that it is ever worthy of just treatment.
('14', 202, 2, 11, 412033) If the community is permitted to enjoy rest, it will be possible to find an easy method of dealing with the matters dealt with in Mr. Gandhi’s letter and which some day or other will demand attention in order that the resident population may be restored to the ordinary rights of citizenship.
('14', 202, 2, 12, 412326) For it must not be forgotten that, though there is cause for thankfulness in that the most pressing grievances have been removed, we shall still labour under legal disabilities which intense colour prejudice has brought into being.
('14', 202, 2, 13, 412558) Administration of trade licence laws, largely on racial lines, the deprivation of the right to own land in the Transvaal, the precarious position under the Transvaal Gold Law, inter provincial restrictions—these and many other such limitations of our liberty show how true were Lord Gladstone’s words when he said that the Indians’ Relief Bill did but the barest justice.
('14', 202, 2, 14, 412930) Indeed, it can only be taken as an instalment and as an earnest of the future.
('14', 202, 2, 15, 413009) The struggle will, therefore, have done much more than give us the Bill and the administrative measures, if it has also altered the repressive policy of the Government to a progressive one, such that we may look forward to a steady improvement in the future.
('14', 202, 3, 16, 413268) Indian Opinion, 8 7 1914
('14', 202, 4, 17, 413293) 1 Vide “Letter with E.M. Gorges”, 27 5 1914; “Letter to E.M. Gorges”, 11 6 1914; 27 6 1914; ”Letter to E.M. Gorges”, 30 6 1914 & 7 7 1914.
('14', 203, 0, 1, 413432) 204 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 203, 1, 2, 413474) 186. THE END OF THE STRUGGLE
('14', 203, 2, 3, 413503) The struggle that went on for eight years has come to an end, and such an end as, we believe, hardly any other movement in modern times has been crowned with.
('14', 203, 2, 4, 413662) The foundation of the struggle was laid in Johannesburg in September, 1906. The issue then concerned only the Registration Act.
('14', 203, 2, 5, 413790) The Government refused to listen to us.
('14', 203, 2, 6, 413830) Gaol going was resorted to.
('14', 203, 2, 7, 413858) While the struggle had not yet ended, the Immigration Act was passed.
('14', 203, 2, 8, 413928) A conditional settlement followed.
('14', 203, 2, 9, 413963) The Government failed to honour its commitment.
('14', 203, 2, 10, 414011) The movement was revived and had to beextended to cover the effect of the Immigration Act on the Registration Act.
('14', 203, 2, 11, 414126) A new issue was thus added, that there should be no racial discrimination in the Immigration Act.
('14', 203, 2, 12, 414224) Naturally, our feelings were aroused still further in consequence.
('14', 203, 2, 13, 414291) The struggle was prolonged and a second deputation went to England.
('14', 203, 2, 14, 414359) 1 The Union Government, however, refused in so many words to remove the racial discrimination.
('14', 203, 2, 15, 414454) While the struggle was thus being prolonged, in 1911 again a provisional settlement came about.
('14', 203, 2, 16, 414550) This covered a third issue.
('14', 203, 2, 17, 414578) Since a problem created by a law of the Transvaal had to be solved by the Union Parliament, the satyagrahis took the stand that they could not accept legislation which, though it might meet their requirement, would endanger the rights of others.
('14', 203, 2, 18, 414824) Accordingly, a condition was included in the provisional settlement of 1911 to the effect that the existing rights of Indians in all the parts of the Union should be left untouched.
('14', 203, 2, 19, 415006) There was no decision, however, until 1913. In the meantime, there was the visit of Mr. Gokhale.
('14', 203, 2, 20, 415103) The Government gave him a promise that the £3 tax would be removed.
('14', 203, 2, 21, 415171) Even so, had the Government granted the satyagrahis’ demands in full during the settlement in 1913, the movement would not have been revived and the £3 tax would have had to be taken up as a separate issue.
('14', 203, 3, 22, 415378) Meanwhile, the Searle judgment raised the marriage question.
('14', 203, 3, 23, 415439) This also entailed the loss of existing rights.
('14', 203, 3, 24, 415487) In 1913, the late Mr. Fis cher carried through the Immigration Act in the face of our protests.
('14', 203, 3, 25, 415583) It conceded much, but also denied a few things.
('14', 203, 3, 26, 415631) The marriage ques tion was left unsolved and in other ways, too, existing rights were endangered.
('14', 203, 3, 27, 415729) This led to the resumption of satyagraha a fourth time
('14', 203, 4, 28, 415784) 1 This was in 1909.
('14', 204, 0, 1, 415804) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 205
('14', 204, 1, 2, 415849) and our demands naturally increased.
('14', 204, 1, 3, 415886) Now that the Government has had to concede all the demands, the struggle has ended.
('14', 204, 1, 4, 415970) We can see from this, if we will, that every time the Govern ment went back on its word, it was obliged to yield more to us.
('14', 204, 1, 5, 416095) This it is which makes one say that chicanery never pays.
('14', 204, 1, 6, 416153) Double dealing may remain unexposed only where both sides play more or less the same [dirty] game.
('14', 204, 1, 7, 416252) In satyagraha, one side alone plays this game.
('14', 204, 1, 8, 416299) The satyagrahi himself cannot conceivably do so.
('14', 204, 1, 9, 416348) We can also see that the more the struggle was prolonged the greater became the strength of the people and their capacity to suffer, so that the suffering that the masses endured towards the end of the last year was unparalleled in modern history.
('14', 204, 1, 10, 416596) And, if the suffering has been great, the relief obtained has also been proportionately great.
('14', 204, 1, 11, 416691) This correlation goes to prove another eternal law of Nature.
('14', 204, 1, 12, 416753) Man can be happy only in the measure that he suffers.
('14', 204, 1, 13, 416807) He who merely scrapes the soil on the surface can harvest nothing but grass.
('14', 204, 1, 14, 416884) He alone can harvest grain who ploughs deeper.
('14', 204, 1, 15, 416931) In other words, it is vain to hope for happiness without undergoing suffering.
('14', 204, 1, 16, 417010) Thus it is that the life of austerity, the fakir’s self denial and other such practices have every where been held in high esteem and their praises sung.
('14', 204, 1, 17, 417164) What the community has bought at the cost of so much suffe ring it will be able to keep and add to, only so long as it retains the same capacity for suffering.
('14', 204, 1, 18, 417324) If it loses that capacity, it will lose all it has gained, and more.
('14', 204, 1, 19, 417393) All this is plain enough, but we often lose sight of it.
('14', 204, 2, 20, 417450) NEW ACT Let us now have a look at our gains.
('14', 204, 2, 21, 417495) The new Act covers two things.
('14', 204, 2, 22, 417526) In the first place, the £3 tax has been abolished.
('14', 204, 2, 23, 417577) Arrears have also been remitted.
('14', 204, 2, 24, 417610) In this connection, it has been suggested by The [Natal] Mercury and other papers that in gaining one thing we have lost something else; for, though the Government has repealed the tax, the consequence will be that the indentured labourers, poor creatures, will be obliged to leave this country or continue for ever under inden ture.
('14', 204, 2, 25, 417944) This suggestion is entirely unfounded, as is clear from General Smuts’ own letter.
('14', 204, 2, 26, 418027) The other point is about the marriage question.
('14', 204, 2, 27, 418075) The manner in which it has been solved gives us more, not less, than what we had been demanding.
('14', 204, 2, 28, 418172) This Act confirms the position that was believed to obtain before the Searle judgment.
('14', 204, 2, 29, 418259) Prior to that judgment, we had assumed that the local law recognized monogamous marriages
('14', 205, 0, 1, 418349) 206 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 205, 1, 2, 418391) celebrated under any faith, including marriages solemnized under our rites.
('14', 205, 1, 3, 418467) Mr. Justice Searle, however, ruled otherwise and held that Christian marriages could be recognized but not Hindu and Muslim marriages, even if such marriages were in fact monogamous.
('14', 205, 1, 4, 418650) This was obviously an affront to the two religions.
('14', 205, 1, 5, 418702) Mr. Cachalia therefore desired amendment of the law.
('14', 205, 1, 6, 418755) The demand has now been met.
('14', 205, 1, 7, 418784) The Act does not involve any other change.
('14', 205, 1, 8, 418827) The position with regard to divorce, inheritance and polygamy remains what it was.
('14', 205, 1, 9, 418910) The Act safeguards the interests of children by a deceased wife.
('14', 205, 1, 10, 418975) Its provisions are permissive.
('14', 205, 1, 11, 419006) No one is obliged to have his or her marriage registered.
('14', 205, 1, 12, 419064) As for those coming from India, the question just does not arise.
('14', 205, 1, 13, 419130) The main object of getting a marriage registered is to ensure that children’s interests do not suffer.
('14', 205, 1, 14, 419233) Now that the danger has been removed, it is not necessary for any Indian to have his or her marriage registered.
('14', 205, 1, 15, 419346) We would rather advise them not to do so.
('14', 205, 1, 16, 419388) The situation required a [new] law.
('14', 205, 1, 17, 419424) It was necessary to undo the affront to [our] religions.
('14', 205, 1, 18, 419481) It should be sufficient that we have succeeded in this.
('14', 205, 1, 19, 419537) The Act has been so drafted as to secure children’s interests without requiring registration of the marriages.
('14', 205, 1, 20, 419648) In view of this, the question whether a marriage is monogamous or polygamous will not arise at all.
('14', 205, 1, 21, 419748) In any case, one who intends to marry more than one woman, would do well not to have his marriage with any of them registered.
('14', 205, 1, 22, 419875) It was necessary to have provisions made for appointment of our priests as marriage officers.
('14', 205, 1, 23, 419969) But we would not advise that this right be availed of.
('14', 205, 1, 24, 420024) We are of the view that such appointments will lead to dishonesty in the community and expose the priests to temptations.
('14', 205, 1, 25, 420146) As for marriages already solemnized, there is no need for such appointments since these marriages can be registered before any magistrate.
('14', 205, 1, 26, 420285) It is the same with regard to marriages that may be celebrated in future.
('14', 205, 1, 27, 420359) In other words, we can have a marriage solemnized by any Maulvi 1 or Gor 2 and get it registered subsequently before a magistrate whenever we choose.
('14', 205, 1, 28, 420509) We would, there fore, particularly advise the community, not to take the trouble of getting marriage officers appointed.
('14', 205, 1, 29, 420630) Before we leave this point, it has to be said that in no other Colony does a [marriage] law go as far as the one passed here does.
('14', 205, 1, 30, 420761) It has been said that in Mauritius [Indian] marriages are recognized whether polygamous or not, but this is not true and the law there is not as good
('14', 205, 2, 31, 420911) 1 Muslim priest 2 Hindu priest
('14', 206, 0, 1, 420942) VOL. 14: 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 207
('14', 206, 1, 2, 420986) as the one here, as we show elsewhere in this very issue.
('14', 206, 1, 3, 421044) A third point that has been satisfactorily settled in this Act is that, in case of any doubt regarding the domicile certificate of a resident of Natal, the certificate must be accepted as genuine if the thumb impression on it is identical with the one on the copy in possession of the Immigration Officer.
('14', 206, 1, 4, 421350) The result will be that people will not be unneces sarily harassed, as at present, with inquiries and sent away for making false claims in spite of the genuineness of the thumb impression having been established.
('14', 206, 1, 5, 421563) Those who can prove the thumb impression to be genuine have their right secured now.
('14', 206, 1, 6, 421648) This section does not however mean that one who has been away from Natal for a number of years will, just because he has the [domicile] certificate, be safe.
('14', 206, 1, 7, 421806) Everyone, of course, will have to prove that he had not left Natal for good.
('14', 206, 2, 8, 421883) ADMINISTRATIVE RELIEF
('14', 206, 3, 9, 421905) The kind of ameliorative measures needed outside the law can be judged from the correspondence between the Government and Mr. Gandhi.
('14', 206, 3, 10, 422039) These concern issues such as South African Indians, the Free State and the administration of existing laws.
('14', 206, 3, 11, 422147) Only one of these points calls for comment here.
('14', 206, 3, 12, 422196) In view of the promise of reasonable adminis tration of the laws in force, with due regard to existing rights, it will be possible for the community to obtain redress in every case of injustice.
('14', 206, 3, 13, 422391) This clause, we believe, should prove very useful in future.
('14', 206, 3, 14, 422452) But its usefulness will depend on how the community’s leaders exert them selves.
('14', 206, 3, 15, 422533) If they sleep on, the clause will have been passed in vain.
('14', 206, 3, 16, 422593) The laws which will most need to be watched are two: the licensing law in each Province and the Gold Law of the Transvaal.
('14', 206, 3, 17, 422716) Mr. Gandhi has pointed out in his letter that we shall have to agitate in future to secure amendment of these laws.
('14', 206, 3, 18, 422832) In starting any such agitation, the community will have to be particularly careful in obeying the laws in question; if it does so, it will, for the present at any rate, enjoy peace.
('14', 206, 3, 19, 423014) We must admit that on this occasion the Government have dis played a desire for justice and that the leading members of Parliament have also been actuated by the same desire in their speeches.
('14', 206, 3, 20, 423207) It would also appear from the speeches of the ministers, and especially from that of General Smuts, that he is inclined to deal justly in future.
('14', 206, 3, 21, 423353) We advise the community to profit by this desire, and this it will be able to

('14', 207, 1, 2, 423473) do only if it has unity, manly spirit and regard for truth.

('14', 207, 3, 4, 423574) 187. MARRIAGE LAW IN MAURITIUS
('14', 207, 4, 5, 423605) We had heard that in Mauritius the law recognized polygamous marriages in the case of Indians.
('14', 207, 4, 6, 423700) Thereupon we made inquiries.
('14', 207, 4, 7, 423729) We have not received a copy of the Act.
('14', 207, 4, 8, 423769) This law was the result of agitation by Indians there.
('14', 207, 4, 9, 423824) It was passed on December 17, 1912. It provides for the appointment of Hindu and Muslim priests as mar riage officers.
('14', 207, 4, 10, 423943) No Indian marriage is to be recognized as valid unless it complies with the provisions of the Act of 1890. That is, the general law which applies to all applies to our people also.
('14', 207, 4, 11, 424124) It is specifically mentioned in that general law that the provisions of sections 46 to 51 regulating marriages also apply to Indian marriages.
('14', 207, 4, 12, 424267) If the husband is below 21 years and the wife below 18, the consent of the parents of both is necessary.
('14', 207, 4, 13, 424372) There are other sections prescribing the duties and functions of marriage officers, the manner of maintaining registers, etc.
('14', 207, 4, 14, 424498) Violation of any of the provisions or registration of an unlawful marriage is punishable with a fine up to Rs. 500/ .
('14', 207, 4, 15, 424616) The following are some of the conditions to be observed by priests under this Act: l.
('14', 207, 4, 16, 424702) A boy under the age of 18 and a girl under 15 cannot be married except by special permission of the Governor.
('14', 207, 5, 17, 424812) 2. If one wife is living, marriage with another woman cannot be contracted unless the former is lawfully divorced.
('14', 207, 6, 18, 424927) 3. In case of divorce for adultery, the divorced party cannot marry the partner in such adultery.
('14', 207, 7, 19, 425025) 4. A widow or divorced woman cannot remarry until after ten months.
('14', 207, 8, 20, 425093) 5. No marriages can take place between a man and his niece, a woman and her nephew, and man and his brother’s wife, even where the woman is a widow.
('14', 207, 9, 21, 425242) Besides these, there are many other provisions which, how ever, we do not notice here.
('14', 207, 9, 22, 425329) What we have given above shows that the general law in Mauritius is applicable to Indians in regard to divorce, polygamous
('14', 208, 0, 1, 425452) VOL. 14: 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 209
('14', 208, 1, 2, 425496) marriages, the minimum age for marriage and such other essential matters.
('14', 208, 1, 3, 425570) The only change introduced by the new law is that, whereas Indian priests could not register marriages formerly, such priests can be appointed now for that purpose.
('14', 208, 2, 4, 425735) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 8 7 1914

('14', 211, 1, 2, 431660) 191. SPEECH AT SPORTS FUNCTION 1
('14', 211, 2, 3, 431693) DURBAN, [July 9, 1914]
('14', 211, 3, 4, 431716) Mr. Gandhi said that he was deeply grateful to the Farewell Committee for having organised those sports and for having set apart that day for the sake of the Indian children and gathered them together at that short notice, and he must confess that he was not at all equally grateful for the function that they had in the Town Hall.
('14', 211, 4, 5, 432048) For him that had been insipid, but that function that afternoon would carry with it or would send with him the pleasandest recollections of his stay in South Africa.
('14', 211, 4, 6, 432214) He knew the community of South Africa, but he scarcely knew the community of India.
('14', 211, 4, 7, 432298) He felt confidand that if he wanded to give a knowledge to anybody as to how the lndian mind in South Africa would run on a particular occasion, he should be able to state accurately the direction in which it would go, but he had no knowledge at all as to what the Indian mind in India itself could do or would do on a particular occasion.
('14', 211, 4, 8, 432638) To that extent he knew his countrymen in South Africa, and it gave him very great pleasure that afternoon to see those around him when he was about to say good bye to South Africa and to say good bye to his dear countrymen and to all those boys and girls.
('14', 211, 4, 9, 432894) He then addressed the children.
('14', 211, 4, 10, 432926) He said they had come there that afternoon to indulge in sports, and sports were good, they were excellent, if they knew the meaning of those sports, but he would leave those alone that afternoon and would like to direct their attention to the real sport in life.
('14', 211, 4, 11, 433190) They had raced for prizes and, as Mr. Baillie had just reminded him, the prize giving might have a demoralising effect upon those who had the training of the children in their hands as well as upon the children themselves.
('14', 211, 4, 12, 433413) He shared that fear, but, if they had raced that afternoon for the sake of racing in order to show that during the past few years they had been endeavouring to keep the physical portion of their being in a fit and proper state, it showed also the value of the industry, the courage and the time that they had put forth in a disciplined manner in order to gain that particular purpose in life.
('14', 211, 4, 13, 433806) But in life there was a better race for them and for him to run—did they know what that race was?
('14', 211, 4, 14, 433904) All the children who went to churches if they were Christians, or all the children who were Hindus if they had any Hindus to teach them what their own religion taught, or if they were Mahomedans and had priests to tell them, he felt sure that they would all tell them that there was that race in life where they had to make themselves good in future and behave themselves if they grew up as men and women.
('14', 211, 4, 15, 434310) In his opinion, if he might

('14', 212, 1, 2, 434580) address a few remarks to the teachers also, having played at teaching himself for a number of years, it seemed to him that the real teaching consisted not in giving the children a knowledge of letters merely, but in developing their character, and that, in so far as the boys and girls developed their character whilst they were still tender and whilst they could still be moulded, and, if their teachers told them that character was the first, the middle and the last and that their knowledge of letters was purely and simply an aid to develop that character, then he thought that they were doing well in attending those schools and it was well for their parents also [to allow them] to do that; but, if their parents sent them, if they went to schools, merely to have a knowledge of letters, so that they might earn a few pounds anyhow in future, then he was afraid that their education was not education and he felt that he should say that little word to them that afternoon.
('14', 212, 2, 3, 435559) Presently they were going to receive prizes, but they had been told that the Sporting Association of the Natal Province was about to receive a wandering trophy from Mr. Rustomjee, and he understood that it was not a trophy which was intrin sically valueless, but that it had actually cost a sum of over £30. He hoped that the Natal Sporting Association deserved that trophy, but he did not dwell upon the trophy because it was a valuable thing, but he did hope that the Natal Sporting Association would behave in a sportsmanlike spirit, and in that real sport in the world and in that race in life would set a noble example to the children, the boys and girls who had gathered together there that afternoon, by gaining trophies not from one Parsee Rustomjee but from everyone of their countrymen in South Africa by placing themselves at their disposal and by serving them in a sportsmanlike manner.
('14', 212, 2, 4, 436458) And, even as these schools had run the races and put their whole spirit into the race, so he hoped that the Association would do so, and he thought that they had given him an earnest of what they were doing from the manner in which they had conducted those proceedings, because it was, he thought, on their shoulders that the brunt of the burden had fallen, led as they had been and still were by Mr. Rustomjee.
('14', 212, 2, 5, 436870) And one word for Mr. Rustomjee.

('14', 212, 2, 7, 437076) He knew that he had worked himself practically to death in connection with that farewell, but he did hope it had not been because a friend of his was going away from South Africa, but in order to show what they had got to do in South Africa, in order to show that South Africa had a reputation, or the Indians in South Africa had, in keeping up the reputation of the Motherland, and he showed also by his energy and by his supporting all such movements what they had got to do.
('14', 212, 2, 8, 437554) He knew that Mr. Rustomjee was at times hard to please.

('14', 214, 12, 25, 441870) He had certainly stood up against Mr. Chamney and the
('14', 214, 13, 26, 441924) 1 Gandhiji attended a farewell meeting at Pretoria, presided over by Vere Stent Chamney, Hajee Habib and Mangalbhai eulogized Gandhiji’s work and leadership.
('14', 215, 0, 1, 442082) 216 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 215, 1, 2, 442124) management of his office, but there had been no personal ill will on the speaker’s part, and he always received the utmost courtesy at Mr. Chamney’s hands.
('14', 215, 1, 3, 442280) He appreciated the compliment Mr. Chamney paid him by coming out to arrest him with one man only to assist, when the speaker was at the head of 2,000 men and women.
('14', 215, 1, 4, 442445) It showed the confidence Mr. Chamney had in him as a passive resister.
('14', 215, 1, 5, 442516) He thanked them for the purse, the contents of which, in common with those of any others received, would not be used for himself, but first for the furtherance of the interests of the Indians of South Africa, and, secondly, for any work he might have to do in India which had commended itself to them in the course of the conversations they had had.
('14', 215, 1, 6, 442866) He felt that the settlement they had received was a kind of Magna Charta.
('14', 215, 1, 7, 442940) It was not a final settlement in the sense that they had no wrongs left.
('14', 215, 1, 8, 443013) They had to exercise patie nce and cultivate European opinion, in order to get those wrongs redressed.
('14', 215, 1, 9, 443116) They had to maintain the sympathy which men like Mr. Stent might think fit to extend to them.
('14', 215, 1, 10, 443210) He paid a glowing tribute to the work done for the Indian cause by Miss Schlesin.

('14', 215, 3, 12, 443318) 195. THE THEORY AND PRACTICE OF PASSIVE RESISTANCE
('14', 215, 4, 13, 443369) [Before July 11, 1914] 1
('14', 215, 5, 14, 443394) I shall be at least far away from Phoenix, if not actually in the Motherland, when this Commemoration Issue is published.
('14', 215, 5, 15, 443516) 2 I would, however, leave behind me my innermost thoughts upon that which has made this special issue necessary.
('14', 215, 5, 16, 443629) Without Passive Resistance, there would have been no richly illustrated and importand special issue of Indian Opinion, which has, for the last eleven years, in an unpreten tious and humble manner, endeavoured to serve my countrymen and South Africa, a period covering the most critical stage that they will, perhaps, ever have to pass through.
('14', 215, 5, 17, 443973) It marks the rise and growth of Passive Resistance, which has attracted world wide attention.
('14', 215, 5, 18, 444067) The term does not fit the activity of the Indian community during the past eight years.
('14', 215, 5, 19, 444155) Its equivalent in the vernacular, 3 rendered into English, means
('14', 215, 6, 20, 444220) 1 En route to India, Gandhiji left Phoenix on July 11. 2 The “Golden Number” of Indian Opinion, dealing with the Indian struggle in South Africa, was released on December 1, 1914. 3 “Satyagraha”, the phrase Gandhiji preferred to use; vide “Gujarati Equivalents for Passive Resistance, Etc..
('14', 216, 0, 1, 444511) VOL. 14: 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 217
('14', 216, 1, 2, 444555) Truth Force.
('14', 216, 1, 3, 444568) I think Tolstoy called it also Soul Force or Love Force, and so it is.
('14', 216, 1, 4, 444639) Carried out to its utmost limit, this force is independent of pecuniary or other material assistance; certainly, even in its elementary form, of physical force or violence.
('14', 216, 1, 5, 444812) Indeed, violence is the negation of this great spiritual force, which can only be cultivated or wielded by those who will entirely eschew violence.
('14', 216, 1, 6, 444960) It is a force that may be used by individuals as well as by communities.
('14', 216, 1, 7, 445033) It may be used as well in political as in domestic affairs.
('14', 216, 1, 8, 445093) Its universal applicability is a demons tration of its permanence and invincibility.
('14', 216, 1, 9, 445178) It can be used alike by men, women, and children.
('14', 216, 1, 10, 445228) It is totally untrue to say that it is a force to be used only by the weak so long as they are not capable of meeting violence by violence.
('14', 216, 1, 11, 445368) This superstition arises from the incompleteness of the English expression.
('14', 216, 1, 12, 445444) It is impossible for those who consider themselves to be weak to apply this force.
('14', 216, 1, 13, 445527) Only those who realise that there is something in man which is superior to the brute nature in him, and that the latter always yields to it, can effectively be Passive Resisters.
('14', 216, 1, 14, 445706) This force is to violence and, therefore, to all tyranny, all injustice, what light is to darkness.
('14', 216, 1, 15, 445806) In politics, its use is based upon the immutable maxim that government of the people is possible only so long as they consent either consciously or uncon sciously to be governed.
('14', 216, 1, 16, 445985) We did not wand to be governed by the Asiatic Act of 1907 of the Transvaal, and it had to go before this mighty force.
('14', 216, 1, 17, 446104) Two courses were open to us—to use violence when we were called upon to submit to the Act, or to suffer the penalties prescribed under the Act, and thus to draw out and exhibit the force of the soul within us for a period long enough to appeal to the sympathetic chord in the governors or the law makers.
('14', 216, 1, 18, 446409) We have taken long to achieve what we set about striving for.
('14', 216, 1, 19, 446471) That was because our Passive Resistance was not of the most complete type.
('14', 216, 1, 20, 446546) All Passive Resisters do not understand the full value of the force, nor have we men who always from conviction refrain from violence.
('14', 216, 1, 21, 446681) The use of this force requires the adoption of poverty, in the sense that we must be indifferent whether we have the wherewithal to feed or clothe ourselves.
('14', 216, 1, 22, 446839) During the past struggle, all Passive Resisters, if any at all, were not prepared to go that length.
('14', 216, 1, 23, 446940) Some again were only Passive Resisters so called.
('14', 216, 1, 24, 446990) They came without any conviction, often with mixed motives, less often with impure motives.
('14', 216, 1, 25, 447082) Some even, whilst engaged in the struggle, would gladly have resorted to violence but for most vigiland supervision.
('14', 216, 1, 26, 447199) Thus it was that the struggle became prolonged; for the exercise of the purest soul force, in its perfect
('14', 217, 0, 1, 447305) 218 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 217, 1, 2, 447347) form, brings about instandaneous relief.
('14', 217, 1, 3, 447388) For this exercise, prolonged training of the individual soul is an absolute necessity, so that a perfect Passive Resister has to be almost, if not entirely, a perfect man.
('14', 217, 1, 4, 447560) We cannot all suddenly become such men, but, if my proposition is correct—as I know it to be correct—the greater the spirit of Passive Resistance in us, the better men we will become.
('14', 217, 1, 5, 447744) Its use, therefore, is, I think; indisputable, and it is a force which, if it became universal, would revolutionise social ideals and do away with despotisms and the ever growing militarism under which the nations of the West are groaning and are being almost crushed to death, and which fairly promises to overwhelm even the nations of the East.
('14', 217, 1, 6, 448091) If the past struggle has produced even a few Indians who would dedicate them selves to the task of becoming Passive Resisters as nearly perfect as possible, they would not only have served themselves in the truest sense of the term, they would also have served humanity at large.
('14', 217, 1, 7, 448371) Thus viewed, Passive Resistance is the noblest and the best education.
('14', 217, 1, 8, 448442) It should come, not after the ordinary education in letters of children, but it should precede it.
('14', 217, 1, 9, 448541) It will not be denied that a child, before it begins to write its alphabet and to gain worldly knowledge, should know what the soul is, what truth is, what love is, what powers are latent in the soul.
('14', 217, 1, 10, 448742) It should be an essential of real education that a child should learn that, in the struggle of life, it can easily conquer hate by love, untruth by truth, violence by self suffering.
('14', 217, 1, 11, 448925) It was because I felt the force of this truth, that, during the latter part of the struggle, I endeavoured, as much as I could, to train the children at Tolstoy Farm and then at Phoenix along these lines, and one of the reasons for my departure to India is still further to realise, as I already do in part, my own imperfection as a Passive Resister, and then to try to perfect myself, for I believe that it is in India that the nearest approach to perfection is most possible.

('14', 218, 1, 2, 449483) 196. SPEECH AT DURBAN BANQUET 1
('14', 218, 2, 3, 449515) [July 11, 1914]
('14', 218, 3, 4, 449531) Mr. Gandhi thanked those present for the hearty way they had received the toast.
('14', 218, 3, 5, 449612) Amid all the kind words that had been spoken of him, there was a danger of developing a swollen head.
('14', 218, 3, 6, 449714) When much praise was being bestowed, that was the time to beware.
('14', 218, 3, 7, 449780) Speaking of the Settlement, he said that, whilst it was a settlement of the present difficulties, it was not a complete settlement.
('14', 218, 3, 8, 449912) It was not a charter of full liberties.
('14', 218, 3, 9, 449952) 2 There were many questions which would require patience to solve.
('14', 218, 3, 10, 450019) One of these was the licensing question.
('14', 218, 3, 11, 450060) He had never been able to find a solution.
('14', 218, 3, 12, 450103) It would need much tact and a sense of justice on the part of the Government and a desire to meet all the requirements of sanitary and building by laws on the part of the Indian community.
('14', 218, 3, 13, 450292) A certain class of Indians were born traders and if these people were to be driven from their means of livelihood, a serious position would arise.
('14', 218, 3, 14, 450439) The value of the settlement lay in the struggle which preceded it—a struggle which quickened the conscience of South Africa—and the fact that there was a different tone prevailing to day.
('14', 218, 3, 15, 450627) (Hear, hear.) It would rest upon themselves to keep up that tone.
('14', 218, 3, 16, 450693) That which they had gained was but a portion of that which they had to gain.
('14', 218, 3, 17, 450770) Speaking generally of the opposition with which they were faced, he said that, although there was great prejudice, in his opinion, unreasonable and unjustifiable, there was also a spirit of justice behind that prejudice.
('14', 218, 3, 18, 450991) 3 He appealed to his fellow countrymen to exercise patience and try to live down prejudices which were against them.
('14', 218, 3, 19, 451108) They had not received all they were entitled to, but it depended very largely upon themselves whether they received in the future a full measure of justice.
('14', 218, 3, 20, 451265) Referring to the Provincial barrier, he said that the Union was no Union for them so long as they were confined within their own Province.
('14', 218, 3, 21, 451404) They appealed for and should have freedom of movement no matter to what Province they desired to go.
('14', 218, 3, 22, 451505) In conclusion, Mr. Gandhi spoke of the British Constitution and ideals, and remarked that so long as both were retained as they were, and the traditions maintained then it was a good thing, but evil would be the day when the Constitution crumbled, and its ideal was changed.

('14', 228, 5, 8, 475176) 202. SPEECH AT FAREWELL BANQUET 3
('14', 228, 6, 9, 475210) JOHANNESBURG, July 14, 1914
('14', 228, 7, 10, 475238) Mr. Gandhi said that they or circumstances had placed him that evening in a most embarrassing position.
('14', 228, 7, 11, 475342) Hitherto those who had known him in Johannesburg had known him in the capacity of one of many hosts at gatherings of that kind, but that evening they had placed him in the unfortunate position of being a guest, and he did not know how he would be able to discharge that duty.
('14', 228, 7, 12, 475618) For the other he thought long experience had fitted him, if he might say so with due humility, most admirably; but the present position was entirely new to him and Mrs. Gandhi, and he was exceedingly diffident as to how he was going to discharge the new duty that had been imposed upon him.
('14', 228, 7, 13, 475909) So much had been said about Mrs. Gandhi and himself, their so called devotion, their so called self sacrifice, and many other things.
('14', 228, 7, 14, 476043) There was one injunction of his religion, and he thought it was true of all religions, and that was that, when one’s praises were sung, one should fly from those praises, and, if one could not do that, one should stop one’s ears, and if one could not do either of these things, one should dedicate everything that was said in connection with one to the
('14', 228, 8, 15, 476396) 1 On their arrival at Park Station, Gandhiji and Kasturba were greeted by a large crowd of Indians.

('14', 229, 0, 1, 477178) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 229, 1, 2, 477220) Almighty, the Divine Essence, which pervaded everyone and everything in the Universe, and he hoped that Mrs Gandhi and he would have the strength to dedicate all that had been said that evening to that Divine Essence.
('14', 229, 1, 3, 477438) Of all the precious a gifts that had been given to them, those four boys were the most precious, and probably Mr. Chamney could tell them something of the law of adoption in India and what Mr. and Mrs. Naidoo, both of them old gaol birds, had done.
('14', 229, 1, 4, 477687) They had gone through the ceremony of adoption, and they had surrendered their right to their four children and given them (Mr. and Mrs. Gandhi) the charge.
('14', 229, 1, 5, 477844) He did not know that they were worthy to take charge of those children.
('14', 229, 1, 6, 477916) He could only assure them that they would try to do their best.
('14', 229, 1, 7, 477980) The four boys had been his pupils when he had been conducting a school for Passive Resisters at Tolstoy Farm and later on at Phoenix.
('14', 229, 1, 8, 478114) Then when Mrs. Naidoo had sought imprisonment, the boys had been taken over to Johannesburg, and he thought that he had lost those four pearls, but the pearls had returned to him.
('14', 229, 1, 9, 478294) He only hoped that Mrs. Gandhi and he would be able to take charge of the precious gift.
('14', 229, 2, 10, 478383) Johannesburg was not a new place to him.
('14', 229, 2, 11, 478424) He saw many friendly faces there, many who had worked with him in many struggles in Johannesburg.
('14', 229, 2, 12, 478522) He had gone through much in life.
('14', 229, 2, 13, 478556) A great deal of depression and sorrow had been his lot, but he had also learnt during all those years to love Johannesburg even though it was a Mining Camp.
('14', 229, 2, 14, 478713) It was in Johannesburg that he had found his most precious friends.
('14', 229, 2, 15, 478781) It was in Johannesburg that the foundation for the great struggle of Passive Resistance was laid in the September of 1906. It was in Johannesburg that he had found a friend, a guide, and a biographer in the late Mr. Doke.
('14', 229, 2, 16, 479003) It was in Johannesburg that he had found in Mrs. Doke, a loving sister, who had nursed him back to life when he had been assaulted by a countryman who had misunderstood his mission and who misunderstood what he had done.
('14', 229, 2, 17, 479224) It was in Johannesburg that he had found a Kallen bach, a Polak, a Miss Schlesin, and many another who had always helped him, and had always cheered him and his countrymen.
('14', 229, 2, 18, 479397) Johannesburg, therefore, had the holiest associations of all the holy associations that Mrs. Gandhi and he would carry back to India, and, as he had already said on many another platform, South Africa, next to India, would be the holiest land to him and to Mrs. Gandhi and to his children, for, in spite of all the bitternesses them those life long companions.
('14', 229, 2, 19, 479758) It was in Johannes burg again that the European Committee had been formed, when Indians were going through the darkest stage in their history, presided over then, as it still was, by Mr. Hosken.
('14', 229, 2, 20, 479953) It was last, but not least, Johannesburg that had given Valiamma, that young girl, whose picture rose before him even as he spoke, who had died in the cause of truth.
('14', 229, 2, 21, 480120) Simple minded in faith—she had not the knowledge that he had, she did not know what Passive Resistance was, she did not know what it was the community would gain, but she was simply taken up with unbounded enthusiasm for her people— she went to gaol, came out of it a wreck, and within a few days died.
('14', 229, 2, 22, 480423) It was Johannes

('14', 230, 1, 2, 480484) burg again that produced a Nagappen and Narayansamy, two lovely youths hardly out of their teens, who also died.
('14', 230, 1, 3, 480597) But both Mrs. Gandhi and he stood living before them.
('14', 230, 1, 4, 480651) He and Mrs. Gandhi had worked in the lime light; those others had worked behind the scenes, not knowing where they were going, except this, that what they were doing was right and proper, and, if any praise was due anywhere at all, it was due to those three who died.
('14', 230, 1, 5, 480919) They had had the name of Hurbatsingh given to them.
('14', 230, 1, 6, 480971) He (the speaker) had had the privilege of serving imprisonment with him.
('14', 230, 1, 7, 481044) Hurbatsingh was 75 years old.
('14', 230, 1, 8, 481074) He was an ex indentured Indian, and when he (the speaker) asked him why he had come there, that he had gone there to seek his grave, the brave man replied, “What does it matter?
('14', 230, 1, 9, 481252) I know what you are fighting for.
('14', 230, 1, 10, 481286) You have not to pay the £3 tax, but my fellow ex indentured Indians have to pay that tax and what more glorious death could I meet?” He had met that death in the gaol at Durban.
('14', 230, 1, 11, 481464) No wonder if Passive Resistance had fired and quickened the conscience of South Africa!
('14', 230, 1, 12, 481552) And, therefore, whenever he had spoken, he had said that, if the Indian community had gained anything through this settlement, it was certainly due to Passive Resistance; but it was certainly not due to Passive Resistance alone.
('14', 230, 1, 13, 481781) He thought that the cablegram that had been read that evening showed that they had to thank that noble Viceroy, Lord Hardinge, for his great effort.
('14', 230, 1, 14, 481930) He thought, too, that they had to thank the Imperial Government, who, during the past few years, in season and out of season, had been sending despatches after despatches to General Botha, and asking him to consider their standpoint—the Imperial standpoint.
('14', 230, 1, 15, 482188) They had to thank also the Union Government for the spirit of justice they had adopted at that time.
('14', 230, 1, 16, 482289) They had, too, to thank the noble members of both Houses of the Legislature who had made those historic speeches and brought about the settlement; and, lastly, they had to thank the Opposition also for their co operation with the Government in bringing about the passage of the Bill, in spite of the jarring note produced by the Natal Members.
('14', 230, 1, 17, 482633) When one considered all these things, the service that he and Mrs. Gandhi might have rendered could be only very little.
('14', 230, 1, 18, 482754) They were but two out of many instruments that had gone to make this settlement.
('14', 230, 1, 19, 482835) And what was that settlement?
('14', 230, 1, 20, 482865) In his humble opinion, the value of the settlement, if they were to examine it, would consist not in the intrinsic things they had received, but in the sufferings and the sorrows long drawn out that were necessary in order to achieve those things.
('14', 230, 1, 21, 483113) If an outsider were to come there and find that there was a banquet given to two humble individuals for the humble part they played in a settlement which freed indentured Indians from a tax which they should never have been called upon to pay, and if he were told also that some redress were given in connection with their marriages, and that their wives who were lawfuly married to them according to their own religions had not hitherto been recognized as their wives, but by this settlement those wives were recognized as valid wives according to the law of South Africa, that outsider would laugh, and consider that those Indians, or those Europeans who had joined them in having a banquet, and
('14', 231, 0, 1, 483811) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 231, 1, 2, 483853) giving all those praises and; so on, must be a parcel of fools.
('14', 231, 1, 3, 483917) What was there to gloat over in having an intolerable burden removed which might have been removed years ago?
('14', 231, 1, 4, 484027) What was there in a lawful wife’s being recognized in a place like South Africa?
('14', 231, 1, 5, 484108) But, proceeded Mr. Gandhi, he concurred with Mr. Duncan in an article he wrote some years ago, when he truly analysed the struggle, and said that behind that struggle for concrete rights lay the great spirit which asked for an abstract principle, and the fight which was undertaken in 1906, although it was a fight against a particular law, was a fight undertaken in order to combat the spirit that was seen about to overshadow the whole of South Africa, and to undermine the glorious British Constitution, of which the Chairman had spoken so loftily that evening, and about which he (the speaker) shared his views.
('14', 231, 1, 6, 484724) It was his knowledge, right or wrong, of the British Constitution which bound him to the Empire.
('14', 231, 1, 7, 484821) Tear that Constitution to shreds and his loyalty also would be torn to shreds.
('14', 231, 1, 8, 484900) Keep that Constitution intact, and they held him bound a slave to that Constitution.
('14', 231, 1, 9, 484985) He had felt that the choice lay for himself and his fellow countrymen between two courses, when this spirit was brooding over South Africa, either to sunder themselves from the British Constitution, or to fight in order that the ideals of that Constitution might be preserved—but only the ideals.
('14', 231, 1, 10, 485282) Lord Ampthill had said, in a preface 1 to Mr. Doke’s book, that the theory of the British Constitution must be preserved at any cost if the British Empire was to be saved from the mistakes that all the previous Empires had made.
('14', 231, 1, 11, 485511) Practice might bend to the temporary aberration through which local circumstances might compel them to pass, it might bend before unreasoning or unreasonable prejudice, but theory once recognized could never be departed from, and this principle must be maintained at any cost.
('14', 231, 1, 12, 485788) And it was that spirit which had been acknowledged now by the Union Government, and acknowledged how nobly and loftily.
('14', 231, 1, 13, 485908) The words that General Smuts so often emphasised still rang in his ears.
('14', 231, 1, 14, 485981) He had said, “Gandhi, this time we wand no misunderstanding, we wand no mental or other reservations, let all the cards be on the table, and I wand you to tell me wherever you think that a particular passage or word does not read in accordance with your own reading,” and it was so.
('14', 231, 1, 15, 486264) That was the spirit in which he approached the negotiations.
('14', 231, 1, 16, 486325) When he remembered General Smuts of a few years ago, when he told Lord Crewe that South Africa would not depart from its policy of racial distinction, that it was bound to retain that distinction, and that, therefore, the sting that lay in this Immigration Law would not be removed, many a friend, including Lord Ampthill, asked whether they could not for the time being suspend their activity.
('14', 231, 1, 17, 486720) He had said “No.” If they did that, it would undermine his loyalty, and even though he might be the only person, he would still fight on.
('14', 231, 1, 18, 486858) Lord Ampthill had congratulated him, and that great nobleman had never deserted the cause
('14', 231, 2, 19, 486948) 1 Vide “Lord Ampthill’s Introduction to “M.K. Gandhi: An Indian Patriot in South Africa”, 26 8 1909.
('14', 232, 0, 1, 487049) VOL. 14: 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 233
('14', 232, 1, 2, 487093) even when it was at its lowest ebb, and they saw the result that day.
('14', 232, 1, 3, 487163) They had not by any means to congratulate themselves on a victory gained.
('14', 232, 1, 4, 487237) There was no question of a victory gained, but the question of the establishment of the principle that, so far as the Union of South Africa at least was concerned, its legislation would never contain the racial taint, would never contain the colour disability.
('14', 232, 1, 5, 487498) The practice would certainly be different.
('14', 232, 1, 6, 487541) There was the Immigration Law—it recognized no racial distinctions, but in practice they had arranged, they had given a promise, that there should be no undue influx from India as to immigration.
('14', 232, 1, 7, 487737) That was a concession to present prejudice.
('14', 232, 1, 8, 487781) Whether it was right or wrong was not for him to discuss then.
('14', 232, 1, 9, 487844) But it was the establishment of that principle which had made the struggle so importand in the British Empire, and the establishment of that principle which had made those sufferings perfectly justifiable and perfectly honourable, and he thought that, when they considered the struggles from that standpoint, it was a perfectly dignified thing for any gathering to congratulate itself upon such a vindication of the principles of the British Constitution.
('14', 232, 1, 10, 488300) One word of caution he wished to utter regarding the Settlement.
('14', 232, 1, 11, 488365) The Settlement was honourable to both parties.
('14', 232, 1, 12, 488412) He did not think there was any room left for misunderstanding, but whilst it was final in the sense that it closed the great struggle, it was not final in the sense that it gave to Indians all that they were entitled to.
('14', 232, 1, 13, 488633) There was still the Gold Law which had many a sting in it.
('14', 232, 1, 14, 488692) There was still the Licensing Law throughout the Union, which also contained many a sting.
('14', 232, 1, 15, 488783) There was still a matter which the Colonial born Indians especially could not understand or appreciate, namely, the watertight compartments in which they had to live; whilst there was absolutely free inter communication and inter migration between the Provinces for Europeans, Indians had to be cooped up in their respective Provinces.
('14', 232, 1, 16, 489119) Then there was undue restraint on their trading activity.
('14', 232, 1, 17, 489177) There was the prohibition as to holding landed property in the Transvaal, which was degrading, and all these things took Indians into all kinds of undesirable channels.
('14', 232, 1, 18, 489346) These restrictions would have to be removed.
('14', 232, 1, 19, 489391) But for that, he thought, sufficient patience would have to be exercised.
('14', 232, 1, 20, 489465) Time was now at their disposal, and how wonderfully the tone had been changed!
('14', 232, 1, 21, 489544) And here he had been told in Cape Town, and he believed it implicitly, the spirit of Mr. Andrews had pervaded all those statesmen and leading men whom he saw.
('14', 232, 1, 22, 489703) He came and went away after a brief period, but he certainly fired those whom he saw with a sense of their duty to the Empire of which they were members.
('14', 232, 1, 23, 489857) But, in any case, to whatever circumstances that healthy tone was due, it had not escaped him.
('14', 232, 1, 24, 489952) He had seen it amongst European friends whom he met at Cape Town; he had seen it more fully in Durban, and this time it had been his privilege to meet many Europeans who were perfect strangers even on board the train, who had come smilingly forward to congratulate him on what they had called a great victory.
('14', 232, 1, 25, 490262) Everywhere he had noticed that healthy tone.
('14', 232, 1, 26, 490307) He asked European friends to continue that activity, either through the European Committee or through other channels, and
('14', 233, 0, 1, 490429) 234 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 233, 1, 2, 490471) to give his fellow countrymen their help and extend that fellow feeling to them also, so that they might be able to work out their own salvation.
('14', 233, 1, 3, 490617) To his countrymen he would say that they should wait and nurse the Settlement, which he considered was all that they could possibly and reasonably have expected, and that they would now live to see, with the co operation of their European friends, that what was promised was fulfilled, that the administration of the existing laws was just, and that vested rights were respected in the administration; that after they had nursed these things, if they cultivated European public opinion, making it possible for the Government of the day to grand a restoration of the other rights of which they had been deprived, he did not think that there need be any fear about the future.
('14', 233, 1, 4, 491292) He thought that, with mutual co operation, with mutual goodwill, with due response on the part of either party, the Indian community need never be a source of weakness to that Government or to any Government.
('14', 233, 1, 5, 491501) On the contrary, he had full faith in his countrymen that, if they were well treated, they would always rise to the occasion and help the Government of the day.
('14', 233, 1, 6, 491662) If they had insisted on their rights on many an occasion, he hoped that the European friends who were there would remember that they had also discharged the responsibilities which had faced them.
('14', 233, 1, 7, 491858) And now it was time for him to close his remarks and say a few words of farewell only.
('14', 233, 1, 8, 491945) He did not know how he could express those words.
('14', 233, 1, 9, 491995) The best years of his life had been passed in South Africa.
('14', 233, 1, 10, 492055) India, as his distinguished countryman, Mr. Gokhale, had reminded him; had become a strange land to him.
('14', 233, 1, 11, 492160) South Africa he knew, but not India.
('14', 233, 1, 12, 492197) He did not know what impelled him to go to India, but he did know that the parting from them all, the parting from the European friends who had helped him through thick and thin, was a heavy blow, and one he was least able to bear; yet heknew he had to part from them.
('14', 233, 1, 13, 492466) He could only say farewell and ask them to give him their blessing, to pray for them that their heads might not be turned by the praise they had received, that they might still know how to do their duty to the best of their ability, that they might still learn that first, second, and last should be the approbation of their own conscience, and that, then, whatever might be due to them would follow in its own time.

('14', 234, 1, 2, 493095) 203. INTERVIEW TO “THE TRANSVAAL LEADER”
('14', 234, 2, 3, 493136) [JOHANNESBURG, July 14, 1914]
('14', 234, 3, 4, 493166) I am going to India for good.
('14', 234, 3, 5, 493196) I am going with the intention of never returning, and if ever I have to return to South Africa or leave India, it will be owing to circumstances beyond my control, and at present beyond my conception.
('14', 234, 3, 6, 493397) The Settlement I consider to be entirely honourable to both parties.
('14', 234, 3, 7, 493466) I believe both General Botha and General Smuts have acted most justly.
('14', 234, 3, 8, 493537) There has been no mental reservation whatever.
('14', 234, 3, 9, 493584) The one desire on the part of General Smuts was that there should be no misunderstanding left, and he endeavoured to appreciate the Indian standpoint at every stage of the interviews that he gladly gave me, even when he was pressed with work.
('14', 234, 3, 10, 493827) And I do feel that nothing could have been finer than the co operation that the Opposition gave whole heartedly.
('14', 234, 3, 11, 493940) In fact, the whole spirit of the debate, both in the Senate and the Assembly, in spite of a jarring note from Natal, was of a highly Imperial order.
('14', 234, 3, 12, 494089) And it will be a thousand pities if either my own countrymen, by excessive agitation, or Europeans spoil that tone and destroy the good effect produced by the Settlement.
('14', 234, 3, 13, 494260) It respects all the reasonable demands of the Europeans with reference to immigration and such other matters, and it concedes to the Indians entirely what they have been fighting for and suffering for during the last eight years.
('14', 234, 3, 14, 494490) Throughout my travelling I have noticed a very exemplary attitude on the part of European friends, many of whom have been really strangers to the question, and certainly strangers to me personally.
('14', 234, 4, 15, 494688) [REPORTER:] Is the struggle really at an end—will Indians here not fight, constitutionally no doubt, for political equality?
('14', 234, 4, 16, 494813) We have never asked for political equality.
('14', 234, 4, 17, 494857) We do not hope to get that.
('14', 234, 5, 18, 494885) You wand the vote?
('14', 234, 5, 19, 494904) No; my view on that would be to leave the question of the political vote severely alone, and my firm conviction is that passive resistance is infinitely superior to the vote.
('14', 234, 5, 20, 495079) I have never asked for the
('14', 235, 0, 1, 495106) 236 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 235, 1, 2, 495148) What I always have insisted on was the removal of racial distinctions, not for equality.
('14', 235, 2, 3, 495237) Mr. Gandhi then went on to recall some of the more remarkable incidents in his career, particularly the march of the Indian strikers into the Transvaal in Nove mber last year which he described as his most wonderful experience in South Africa.
('14', 235, 2, 4, 495481) Through that march, I learned to love human nature more, and to appreciate that no matter whether the human spirit flourished under European or Indian, under the Western or the Eastern sky, it could respond in an equal measure to the same chord.
('14', 235, 3, 5, 495727) In recounting his experiences on the march, Mr. Gandhi did not dwell on the hardships; these he seemed to have forgotten.
('14', 235, 3, 6, 495849) But he recalled the little acts of kind ness that were done by obscure individuals.
('14', 235, 3, 7, 495933) There was the station master who brought him a glass of milk and a couple of boiled eggs, and many other delicacies to tempt a starving man.
('14', 235, 3, 8, 496074) It seemed rank ingratitude to refuse them, but I kept to my vow, and I explained to the station master that I seldom ate eggs, and could not taste the milk and the other nice things he had brought, because I had to accept the same treatment as the rank and file.
('14', 235, 3, 9, 496337) He seemed hurt,: and I was sorry, but I was not ungrateful, and I hope the kind soul understood.
('14', 235, 3, 10, 496434) At another place the proprietor of an hotel said to me: “You are shivering.
('14', 235, 3, 11, 496510) Come to my hotel, and I will put you up.” I thanked him, but declined, and, pointing to my companions, I said: “They too feel the cold, and are shivering.” “Oh!
('14', 235, 3, 12, 496671) It is not a case of putting you on the verandah,” he said, “I will give you a room.” His kind offer I was obliged to decline.
('14', 235, 3, 13, 496797) At another place we reached, a woman who ran a small store placed everything she had at our disposal.
('14', 235, 3, 14, 496899) I remonstrated, but she would have her way.
('14', 235, 3, 15, 496943) She said: “Though you are all Indians, you are suffering and I hope I have enough of the old British sense of sympathy left in me to help you.” At Charlestown and Newcastle the whole community helped us, and we helped them.
('14', 235, 3, 16, 497167) There was no pilfering, no drunkenness.
('14', 235, 3, 17, 497207) I explained to the men before they started that they would win,not by putting their sticks over the shoulders of others, but over their own.
('14', 235, 3, 18, 497348) It took them some time to see it, but that was the condition on which I allowed them to come with me.
('14', 235, 3, 19, 497450) So our army kept on its way.
('14', 235, 3, 20, 497479) We rose before the sun in the morning and did the best of our day’s march before food passed our lips.
('14', 235, 3, 21, 497582) Then we halted for a small
('14', 236, 0, 1, 497609) VOL. 14: 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 237
('14', 236, 1, 2, 497653) ration of bread and sugar.
('14', 236, 1, 3, 497680) It was, you will admit, a wonderful thing for two thousand men to have marched so far without violating the law, without stealing or rioting.
('14', 236, 2, 4, 497822) As to the treatment of himself personally, and of his family during those troubled times, Mr. Gandhi could not find words to express his appreciation.

('14', 241, 6, 11, 510616) 205. TRIBUTE TO PASSIVE RESISTANCE MARTYRS 1
('14', 241, 7, 12, 510661) BRAAMFONTEIN, July 15, 1914
('14', 241, 8, 13, 510689) Mr. Gandhi said he thought that, in Johannesburg, among their intimate European friends, Mrs. Phillips was the oldest, and therefore, if they considered her to be the mother of the family, they only gave her her due.
('14', 241, 8, 14, 510906) Mrs. Phillips had set the seal upon that that morning by unveiling those two monuments.

('14', 249, 1, 2, 533382) they had certainly come out almost as well as the Tamils had, but the Tamils had sustained the struggle for the last eight years and had shown of what stuff they were made from the very beginning.

('14', 249, 1, 18, 535173) That was one of the things they had fought for and had got.
('14', 249, 1, 19, 535233) Truth was what they had been fighting for, and Truth had conquered—not he or they.
('14', 249, 1, 20, 535316) They might fight tomorrow for an unrighteous thing, and as sure as fate they would be beaten and well beaten.
('14', 249, 1, 21, 535426) Truth was unconquerable, and whenever the call to duty came, he hoped they would respond.
('14', 249, 1, 22, 535516) There was one thing more.
('14', 249, 1, 23, 535542) They had sometimes, as every other section of the community had, jealousies amongst themselves.
('14', 249, 1, 24, 535638) They had petty jealousies not in connection with the struggle, but in matters which had nothing to do with the struggle.
('14', 249, 1, 25, 535759) All those petty jealousies and differences he hoped would go, and they would rise higher still in the estimation of themselves and of those who at all grew to know them and the depth of character which they had.
('14', 249, 1, 26, 535971) They had also, as ail sections of the Indian community had, not only those jealousies but sometimes many bickerings also, and petty quarrels.
('14', 249, 1, 27, 536113) He felt these also should be removed especially from their midst, because they had shown themselves so fit to give themselves to the Motherland.
