('14', 252, 3, 17, 543009) 211. THE LEGAL POSITION
('14', 252, 4, 18, 543033) [Before July 18, 1914] 1
('14', 252, 5, 19, 543058) As the removal of the £3 tax has given rise to the fear that it makes the Indians affected by it prohibited immigrands and that, therefore, their position becomes worse than before, it may be worth while examining the true legal position.
('14', 252, 5, 20, 543297) For, if it is a fact that the removal makes them prohibited immigrands, the first clause of Paragraph 2 of the letter 2 from the Secretary for the Interior addressed to Mr. Gandhi, providing for the issue of discharge certificates to such Indians, does not, as The Natal Mercury says, take them out of the category.
('14', 252, 5, 21, 543613) That clause was inserted, not for the purpose, as the Mercury would have us believe, of securing these poor men’s right of domicile.
('14', 252, 5, 22, 543746) It was inserted simply to enable the men to move about the Province without vexatious inquiries from the Police and to free them from liability of arrest for being without passes.
('14', 252, 5, 23, 543926) Now the contention that has been made by the Mercury is that, if the men do not pay the tax, they
('14', 252, 6, 24, 544024) 1 Evidently, this item was written before July 18 when Gandhiji left for England en route to India.
('14', 252, 6, 25, 544124) 2 Vide Appendix “Letter from E.M. Gorges”, 30 6 1914.
('14', 253, 0, 1, 544178) 254 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 253, 1, 2, 544220) have to perform one of the other two conditions of their contract, namely, to re indenture or to repatriate themselves to India, and, if they do not do either—so it is argued—they can be declared prohibited immigrands in virtue of Section 30 of the Immigrands’ Regulation Act of last year, which defines the term “domicile”, declaring those who may have entered the Union under terms of conditional residence prohibited immigrands.
('14', 253, 1, 3, 544652) If the above contention were correct, those Indians who have not paid the tax for years could all have been declared prohibited immigrands and driven out of the Province immediately after the passing of the Immigrands’ Regula tion Act.
('14', 253, 1, 4, 544888) But no such thing was done.
('14', 253, 1, 5, 544916) The contracts containing the conditions as to re indenture or re patriation are made with the Immigration Trust Board, a private body.
('14', 253, 1, 6, 545051) It is a well known maxim oflaw, that contracts which are opposed to public morals or are in restraint of personal liberty, are invalid.
('14', 253, 1, 7, 545187) Therefore, the clause as to repatriation, being against public morals and in restraint of personal liberty, is invalid, and a special statute would be necessary to make them valid and effective in law.
('14', 253, 1, 8, 545389) This is what the late Natal Government tried and failed to obtain from the Government of India, and the only thing—though it was a wrong and shameful thing—that the then Government of India consented to do, was to make the men, who did not repatriate themselves, liable to pay the tax.
('14', 253, 1, 9, 545675) Therefore, the tax being removed, the clause as to repatriation or re indenture becomes ineffective and valueless.
('14', 253, 1, 10, 545790) Another maxim of law is that any Statute which does not provide a sanction, that is, a penalty, for a breach of any of the obli gations which it may impose upon the subject is powerless to compel the subject to perform that obligation.
('14', 253, 1, 11, 546026) This was clearly laid down by the Supreme Court of the Transvaal in a case that arose out of Law 3 of 1885, which requires Indians to reside in Locations.
('14', 253, 1, 12, 546181) If they do not so reside, no penalty is provided in that Law, and the Supreme Court has, therefore, held that Indians cannot be compelled to live in Locations, and that position remains unchanged, and, in spite of the Section referred to, Indians reside where they like in the Transvaal.
('14', 253, 1, 13, 546469) It is, therefore, absolutely clear, so far as the legal aspect is concerned, that the Indians affected by the repeal of the tax are exactly in the same position as those who came under Law 25 of 1891. Adding to this the fact that the Commission themselves, composed of three distinguished lawyers, recommended the repeal of Section 6 of the Act of 1895 in question, and considered the repeal to be sufficient to put the men who came under it in the same position as
('14', 254, 0, 1, 546935) VOL. 14: 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 255
('14', 254, 1, 2, 546979) those who came under Law 25 of 1891, that the Government of India and the Imperial Government, too, hold the same opinion as the Commission, and understood clearly that the men, after the repeal of the tax, would be free to settle in the Province after completing their present indenture and that the Union Government themselves have declared that such is also their reading of the law, we fail to see the slightest cause for alarm.
('14', 254, 1, 3, 547412) The Mercury further has suggested that, whilst the assurance of the Union Government may be enough, should the legal interpretation placed upon it be found to be true, that assurance will not be of any value if General Hertzog were to become the Premier.
('14', 254, 1, 4, 547667) We cannot share this fear, no matter what policy General Hertzog may have on the Indian question.
('14', 254, 1, 5, 547765) In a constitution[al] State such as the Union of South Africa is, General Hertzog would be bound by the promise made by his predecessor to third parties.
('14', 254, 1, 6, 547919) He can change policy, he can alter laws, but he cannot, he dare not, alter or commit a breach of promise made by predecessors in office to third parties.
('14', 254, 1, 7, 548073) If he could, it is easy to see that there would be an end to government, and that people could not with any assurance have dealings with governments where there is Responsible Ministry [sic].
('14', 254, 1, 8, 548265) Lastly, our countrymen need have no fear as to the future.
('14', 254, 1, 9, 548324) Many things are possible; they are highly improbable.
('14', 254, 1, 10, 548378) It is possible that the Supreme Court may interpret the law as the Mercury has.
('14', 254, 1, 11, 548458) It is possible, though highly improbable, that any future Government or even the present Government would commit a breach of the promise deli berately made.
('14', 254, 1, 12, 548615) Surely, in those circumstances, with the clearest con science and with the fullest justification before the world, Indians can make use of the same irresistible weapon of Passive Resistance, as they have hitherto done.
('14', 254, 2, 13, 548834) Indian Opinion, 22 7 1914
('14', 255, 0, 1, 548860) 256 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 255, 1, 2, 548902) 212. FAREWELL LETTER 1
('14', 255, 2, 3, 548925) [CAPE TOWN, July 18, 1914]
('14', 255, 3, 4, 548952) I would like, on the eve of my departure for India, to say a few words to my countrymen in South Africa, and also to the European community.
('14', 255, 3, 5, 549093) The kindness with which both European and Indian friends have overwhelmed me sends me to India a debtor to them.
('14', 255, 3, 6, 549206) It is a debt I shall endeavour to repay by rendering in India what services I am capable of rendering there; and if, in speaking about the South African Indian question, I am obliged to refer to the injustices which my countrymen have received and may hereafter receive, I promise that I shall never wilfully exaggerate, and shall state the truth and nothing but the truth.
('14', 255, 3, 7, 549580) A word about the Settlement, and what it means.
('14', 255, 3, 8, 549628) In my humble opinion, it is the Magna Charta of our liberty in this land.
('14', 255, 3, 9, 549702) I give it the historic name, not because it gives us rights which we have never enjoyed and which are in themselves new or striking, but because it has come to us after eight years’ strenuous suffering, that has involved the loss of material possessions and of precious lives.
('14', 255, 3, 10, 549979) I call it our Magna Charta because it marks a change in the policy of the Govern ment towards us and establishes our right not only to be consulted in matters affecting us, but to have our reasonable wishes respected.
('14', 255, 3, 11, 550197) It moreover confirms the theory of the British Constitution that there should be no legal racial inequality between different subjects of the Crown, no matter how much practice may vary according to local circumstance.
('14', 255, 3, 12, 550416) Above all, the Settlement may well be called our Magna Charta, because it has vindicated passive resistance as a lawful, clean weapon, and has given in passive resistance a new strength to the community and I consider it an infinitely superior force to that of the vote, which history shows has often been turned against the voters themselves.
('14', 255, 3, 13, 550760) The Settlement finally disposes of all the points that were the subject matter of passive resistance, and in doing so it breathes the spirit of justice and fair play.
('14', 255, 3, 14, 550927) If the same spirit guides the
('14', 255, 4, 15, 550957) 1 Gandhiji released this to Reuter’s Agent at Cape Town.
('14', 255, 4, 16, 551014) Addressed to Indians and Europeans in South Africa, it was also published in Rand Daily Mail, 20 7 1914, and The Transvaal Leader, 24 7 1914.
('14', 256, 0, 1, 551156) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 257
('14', 256, 1, 2, 551201) administration of the existing laws, my countrymen will have comparative peace, and South Africa will hear little of the Indian problem in an acute form.
('14', 256, 1, 3, 551355) Some of my countrymen have protested against it.
('14', 256, 1, 4, 551404) The number of these protestants is numerically very small, and in influence not of great importance.
('14', 256, 1, 5, 551505) They do not object to what has been granted, but they object that it is not enough.
('14', 256, 1, 6, 551589) It is impossible, therefore, to withhold sympathy from them.
('14', 256, 1, 7, 551650) I have had an opportunity of speaking to them, and I have endeavoured to show to them that, if we had asked for anything more, it would have been a breach of submission made on behalf of the British Indians in a letter addressed to the Govern ment by Mr. Cachalia during the latter part of last year and we should have laid ourselves open to the charge of making new demands.
('14', 256, 1, 8, 552026) But I have also assured them that the present settlement does not preclude them from agitation (as has been made clear in my letter to the Secretary of the Interior of the 16th ultimo) for the removal of other disabilities which the community will still suffer from under the Gold Law, the Townships Act, the Law 3 of 1885 of the Transvaal and the Trade Licences Laws of Natal and the Cape.
('14', 256, 1, 9, 552417) The promise made by General Smuts to administer the existing law justly and with due regard to vested rights gives the community breathing time, but these laws are in themselves defective, and can be, as they have been, turned into engines of oppression and instruments by indirect means to drive the resident Indian population from South Africa.
('14', 256, 1, 10, 552764) The concession to popular prejudice in that we have reconciled ourselves to almost the total prohibition by administrative methods of a fresh influx of Indian immigrants, and to the deprivation of all political power, is, in my opinion, the utmost that could be reasonably expected from us.
('14', 256, 1, 11, 553055) These two things being assured, I venture to submit that we are entitled to full rights of trade, inter Provincial migration, and ownership of landed property being restored in the not distant future.
('14', 256, 1, 12, 553256) I leave South Africa in the hope that the healthy tone that pervades the European community in South Africa today will continue, and that it will enable Europeans to recognize the inherent justice of our submission.
('14', 256, 1, 13, 553472) To my countrymen I have, at various meetings that I have addressed during the past fortnight, attended in several cases by thousands, said, “Nurse the Settlement; see to it that the promises made are being carried out.
('14', 256, 1, 14, 553691) Attend to development and progress from within.
('14', 256, 1, 15, 553739) Zealously remove all causes which we may have given for the rise and growth of anti 
('14', 257, 0, 1, 553824) 258 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 257, 1, 2, 553866) Indian prejudice or agitation, and patiently cultivate and inform Euro pean opinion so as to enable the Government of the day and Legislature to restore to us our rights.
('14', 257, 1, 3, 554037) “ It is by mutual co operation and goodwill that the solution of the balance of the pressing disabilities which were not made points for passive resistance may be obtained in the natural course, and without trouble or agitation in an acute form.
('14', 257, 1, 4, 554283) The presence of a large indentured and ex indentured Indian population in Natal is a grave problem.
('14', 257, 1, 5, 554383) Compulsory repatriation is a physical and political impossibility, voluntary repatriation by way of granting free passages and similar inducements will not—as my experience teaches me—be availed of to any appreciable extent.
('14', 257, 1, 6, 554608) The only real and effective remedy for this great State to adopt is to face responsibility fairly and squarely, to do away with the remnant of the system of indenture, and to level up this part of the population and make use of it for the general welfare of the Union.
('14', 257, 1, 7, 554877) Men and women who can effectively strike in large bodies, who can for a common purpose suffer untold hardships, who can, undisciplined though they are, be martyrs for days without police supervision and yet avoid doing any damage to property or person, and who can in times of need serve their King faithfully and capably, as the ambulance corps raised at the time of the late war (and which had among other classes of Indians nearly 1,500 indentured Indians) bore witness, are surely people who will, if given ordinary opportunities in life, form an honourable part of any nation.
('14', 257, 1, 8, 555459) If any class of persons have special claim to be considered, it is these indentured Indians and their children, to whom South Africa has become either a land of adoption or of birth.
('14', 257, 1, 9, 555642) They did not enter the Union as ordinary free immigrants, but they came upon invitation and, indeed, even after much coaxing by agents of South African employers of this class of labour.
('14', 257, 1, 10, 555829) In this letter I have endeavoured as accurately and as fairly as is in my power to set forth the Indian situation, and the extraordinary courtesy, kindness and sympathy that have been shown to me during the past month by so many European friends.
('14', 257, 1, 11, 556076) The frankness and generosity with which General Smuts, in interviews that he was pleased to grant me, approached the questions at issue, and the importance that so many distinguished members of both Houses of Parliament attached to the Imperial aspect of the problem, give me ample reason for believing that my countrymen who have made South Africa their home will receive a fairly full measure of
('14', 258, 0, 1, 556474) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 259
('14', 258, 1, 2, 556519) justice and will be enabled to remain in the Union with self respect and dignity.
('14', 258, 1, 3, 556601) Finally, in bidding good bye to South Africa, I would like to apologise to so many friends on whom I have not been able, through extreme pressure of work, to call personally.
('14', 258, 1, 4, 556776) I once more state that, though I have received many a hard knock in my long stay in this country, it has been my good fortune to receive much personal kindness and consideration from hundreds of European friends, well wishers and sympathisers.
('14', 258, 1, 5, 557020) I have formed the closest friendships, which will last for ever, for this reason and for many similar reasons, which I would love to reduce to writing but for fear of trespassing unduly upon the courtesy of the Press.
('14', 258, 1, 6, 557238) This sub continent has become to me a sacred and dear land, next only to my motherland.
('14', 258, 1, 7, 557326) I leave the shores of South Africa with a heavy heart, and the distance that will now separate me from South Africa will but draw me closer to it, and its welfare will always be a matter of great concern, and the love bestowed upon me by my countrymen and the generous forbearance and kindness extended to me by the Europeans will ever remain a most cherished treasure in my memory.
('14', 258, 2, 8, 557709) I am, etc., M. K. GANDHI

('14', 258, 4, 10, 557760) 213. FAREWELL SPEECH AT CAPE TOWN 1

('14', 262, 10, 18, 566115) I have left South Africa, but not my connection with that land.
('14', 262, 10, 19, 566179) I said in many of my speeches during the final days that I would not give up that connection.
('14', 262, 10, 20, 566273) My writings in Indian Opinion will furnish some proof of my keeping the promise.
('14', 262, 10, 21, 566354) In them, I shall express my thoughts from time to time, hoping that readers will like them and find them useful as well.
('14', 262, 10, 22, 566475) I am commencing this article on board the Kinfauns Castle.
('14', 262, 10, 23, 566534) Five days have passed since we left the Cape.
('14', 262, 10, 24, 566580) We are travelling third class, Mr. Kallenbach, my wife and I. This is my first experience of a voyage to England in this class.
('14', 262, 10, 25, 566708) Of first class I have had experience on several occasions.
('14', 262, 10, 26, 566767) I must say that we are happier in third class than we could have been in first.
('14', 262, 10, 27, 566847) There are no attendants here keeping constant watch on us.
('14', 262, 10, 28, 566906) We feel no pricking of conscience that we are living in special style, segregated from the poor.
('14', 262, 10, 29, 567003) One does not have
('14', 263, 0, 1, 567021) 264 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 263, 1, 2, 567063) here the feeling of closeness one has in first class, nor has one to submit oneself to meaningless conventions.
('14', 263, 1, 3, 567175) There are no inconven iences in particular.
('14', 263, 1, 4, 567219) The usual ones which attend on poverty prove wholesome in the end.
('14', 263, 1, 5, 567286) I do not mean by these comments of mine that every Indian should travel third class.
('14', 263, 1, 6, 567371) I have always felt that those who are rich and wish to live among the rich must, of course, travel first class, as a matter of duty at least; otherwise, we are likely to invite the charge of miserliness.
('14', 263, 1, 7, 567575) It is certain, however, that travelling in first class for the sake of better comforts is sinful.
('14', 263, 1, 8, 567673) Men like me, moreover, who travel at public expense and whose mode of travelling has no bearing on the prestige of their community must necessarily travel third class, or in a still lower class, if there be any.
('14', 263, 2, 9, 567885) All three of us live almost entirely on fruit, though we cook fruit which may not have ripened, or boil things like groundnuts.
('14', 263, 2, 10, 568013) The labour is generally Mr. Kallenbach’s.
('14', 263, 2, 11, 568055) He has at present accepted manual work as a kind of religion and takes joy in it.
('14', 263, 2, 12, 568137) For Mr. Kallen bach and my wife, this is the first occasion when they have had no sea sickness.
('14', 263, 2, 13, 568233) I believe it is their simple habits and heir fruit diet which have made the difference.
('14', 263, 2, 14, 568321) We are getting more convinced by experi ence every day that a fruit diet is the best.
('14', 263, 2, 15, 568407) We hardly ever come into contact with other passengers.
('14', 263, 2, 16, 568463) We have divided up our time and do everything at the appointed hour, so that the days pass easily.
('14', 263, 2, 17, 568562) The love of our Indian brethren in their thousands and the honour they accorded us are constantly in our minds.

('14', 264, 5, 6, 569825) During the last campaign, the very highest limit was reached.
('14', 264, 5, 7, 569887) I have had simply no time to write of the experience.
('14', 264, 5, 8, 569941) I had meant to share it with the readers of Indian Opinion.
('14', 264, 5, 9, 570001) They will remember that the last struggle was, as it were, the third chapter in the story of satyagraha.
('14', 264, 5, 10, 570106) When the first chapter came to a close, we, at any rate I, had thought that it was definitely the last.
('14', 264, 5, 11, 570210) When the time came for the second chapter to open, many friends said to me: “Now who will fight?
('14', 264, 5, 12, 570307) The community cannot be expected to put forth so much strength every time.” I laughed when I heard this.
('14', 264, 5, 13, 570412) My faith in truth was unshakable and I replied, “The people, having tasted once the joy of struggle, will fight now with even greater zeal.” And that was precisely what happened.
('14', 264, 5, 14, 570591) On the first occasion, a hundred or two hundred Indians went to gaol.
('14', 264, 5, 15, 570661) The second time, not only did hundreds court imprisonment, but the whole of Natal woke up and leaders came from there to join the struggle.
('14', 264, 5, 16, 570801) The fight dragged on, but the morale never went down and we advanced.
('14', 264, 5, 17, 570871) When it came to launching the last fight, I heard only talk of defeat.

('14', 279, 4, 6, 604161) 222. SPEECH AT LONDON RECEPTION 1
('14', 279, 5, 7, 604195) August 8, 1914
('14', 279, 6, 8, 604210) To you, Mr. Basu, and to Mrs. Sarojini Naidu, I can only say that you have both overwhelmed me; I do not even know that I can struggle through what I have to say.
('14', 279, 6, 9, 604373) I would make the briefest reference to the tremendous crisis 2 which has overwhelmed the Empire.
('14', 279, 6, 10, 604470) Since we reached England and heard the news, I have been reading and thinking about it.
('14', 279, 6, 11, 604558) I think of husbands and sons who have gone to fight, of mothers, wives, and sisters left weeping behind.
('14', 279, 6, 12, 604663) I ask: ‘What is my duty?
('14', 279, 6, 13, 604688) I am an exile of 21 years from my Motherland, so cannot speak as the representative of the imaginary India which my friends tell me I have pictured.’ If I were in South Africa, I should certainly speak as the representative of my people.
('14', 279, 6, 14, 604926) I have not yet come to any conclusion, but trust we can do something in concrete shape.
('14', 279, 6, 15, 605014) I hope those of you who are as young as I am, those who are fellow students of mine—I am still a student—will think what can be done, consult with our elders and follow their advice if it commends itself to our consciences.
('14', 279, 6, 16, 605238) It is impossible to express in adequate terms the sense of

('14', 279, 7, 20, 605581) Bhupendranath Basu presided.

('14', 280, 0, 1, 605714) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 281
('14', 280, 1, 2, 605759) gratitude which Mrs. Gandhi and I feel to you all.
('14', 280, 1, 3, 605810) We come among you almost as barbarians.
('14', 280, 1, 4, 605850) We have lived isolated on a little farm, cut off from the cities.
('14', 280, 1, 5, 605916) That is why I said we were “barbarians”.
('14', 280, 1, 6, 605957) We have worked in the limelight, and you have seen what we have done in exaggerated form.
('14', 280, 1, 7, 606047) If we merit any approbation, how much more those behind us, who went into the battle with simple faith, with no thought of appreciation.
('14', 280, 1, 8, 606184) What will you say to Hurbatsingh, an ex indentured Indian, 75 years of age, who was with me at Volksrust Gaol?
('14', 280, 1, 9, 606295) He was 6 feet tall and of noble carriage.
('14', 280, 1, 10, 606337) “Why have you come?” I asked.
('14', 280, 1, 11, 606367) “How could I help it?” was his reply.
('14', 280, 1, 12, 606405) “In the evening of my days I am content to pass the rest of my life in prison to deliver my countrymen.” He remained in gaol and died there.
('14', 280, 1, 13, 606546) What do you think of the young lad, Narayansamy, whose parents came from what is falsely called the Benighted Presidency, Madras?
('14', 280, 1, 14, 606676) He had never seen India except as a deportee; he starved for some days when he returned.
('14', 280, 1, 15, 606765) He died.
('14', 280, 1, 16, 606774) And what of Nagappen, another lad from Madras who suffered imprisonment.
('14', 280, 1, 17, 606847) He worked as a prisoner on the African veldt in the bitter cold of winter, in the early morning when there was no sun.
('14', 280, 1, 18, 606966) You know what the cold of a London winter is like, but few of you know the biting cold of the early mornings of winter on the veldt.
('14', 280, 1, 19, 607099) Unfit for work, he still held on, but at last he died.
('14', 280, 1, 20, 607154) Then there is Sister Valliamma, a girl of 18. She went to prison and was only discharged when she was very ill.
('14', 280, 1, 21, 607266) I remember well when Mr. Polak and I went to see her; how we lifted her with greatest care on to her carpet, and tended her to the best of our powers.
('14', 280, 1, 22, 607417) She died, leaving thousands of Indians in South Africa to mourn the loss.
('14', 280, 1, 23, 607491) There were 20,000 strikers who left their tools and work because there was something in the air.
('14', 280, 1, 24, 607588) People said that they did not know why they had struck.
('14', 280, 1, 25, 607644) There was a half truth in that saying; they went out in faith.
('14', 280, 1, 26, 607707) Violence was entirely eschewed.
('14', 280, 1, 27, 607739) These men and women are the salt of India; on them will be built the Indian nation that is to be.
('14', 280, 1, 28, 607837) We are poor mortals before these heroes and heroines.
('14', 280, 1, 29, 607891) But victory is due not only to their work.
('14', 280, 1, 30, 607934) They quickened the conscience of the Empire and of South Africa.
('14', 280, 1, 31, 607999) Success was due also to the help given by the Motherland in the hour of trial of her sons and daughters, led by that saintly politician, Gopal Krishna Gokhale; to the stand made by India; and to the action of that great Viceroy,
('14', 281, 0, 1, 608228) 282 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 281, 1, 2, 608270) Lord Hardinge.
('14', 281, 1, 3, 608285) Success would, however, have been impossible had not the conscience of South Africa been quickened, had not the people realised the moral force which Indians could bring to bear against brute force.
('14', 281, 1, 4, 608484) Marching over the veldt last November, Europeans came to our aid.
('14', 281, 1, 5, 608550) I have spoken elsewhere of unreasonable and unreasoning prejudice; but the masses stood aside; they never worried us; and during the march they helped us and showed us practical sympathy.
('14', 281, 1, 6, 608738) The Botha Government, too, “played the game”.
('14', 281, 1, 7, 608784) Mr. Smuts said to me: “We do not want any misunderstanding; we want all the cards on the table.
('14', 281, 1, 8, 608880) Take these documents; read them; come to me again and again if you are not satisfied; we will make changes.” And he did.
('14', 281, 1, 9, 609001) You see many things conspired to enable the Settlement to be made.
('14', 281, 1, 10, 609068) But I must mention one more: Mr. Andrews.
('14', 281, 1, 11, 609110) You have no notion what he did; how he worked in selfless zeal, preaching love for India through his Master—the poet saint at Bolpur whom I have come to know through Mr. Andrews—Rabindranath Tagore.
('14', 281, 1, 12, 609309) I have called the Settlement the Magna Charta of the British Indians of South Africa; after due deliberation I repeat my statement.
('14', 281, 1, 13, 609441) It is the Magna Charta of British Indians, not only because of its substance, which is great enough, but for its spirit, which indicates a change of attitude on the part of South Africa and the South African Government.
('14', 281, 1, 14, 609661) The sufferings of our countrymen sealed the Settlement.
('14', 281, 1, 15, 609717) The discovery was made that the ancient force could be applied in South Africa; conviction came after the sufferings of eight long drawn out years.
('14', 281, 1, 16, 609865) They saw that Indians, when in earnest, were irresistible; that they would not take a bit less than the minimum they demanded.
('14', 281, 1, 17, 609992) Mr. Cartwright is here; he has been our staunch friend throughout and I honour him for his help.
('14', 281, 1, 18, 610089) But I tell him here that he almost tried to weaken us.
('14', 281, 1, 19, 610144) I remember, and he will remember how he came to me in Johannesburg Gaol, and said: “Will not this letter do?” “No, Mr. Cartwright,” was my reply; “not until this alteration is made.” “But everything is achieved by compromise,” he urged.
('14', 281, 1, 20, 610381) “There can be no compromise on principles,” I answered.
('14', 281, 1, 21, 610437) There never was any compromise on principles from 1906 to 1914. The Settlement is final on all the points of our passive resistance, but not of all our grievances.
('14', 281, 1, 22, 610601) Grievances remain which will have to be
('14', 282, 0, 1, 610641) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 283
('14', 282, 1, 2, 610686) redressed in no distant future.
('14', 282, 1, 3, 610718) But I hope it will not be by way of passive resistance.
('14', 282, 1, 4, 610774) They are capable of settlement by pressure of Indian public opinion, by pressure from Downing Street, and from Delhi or Calcutta.
('14', 282, 1, 5, 610904) The attitude of South Africa has changed; that is our greatest asset.
('14', 282, 1, 6, 610974) On our behaviour depends the future settlement in South Africa.
('14', 282, 1, 7, 611038) I thank again, on behalf of Mrs. Gandhi and myself, Mr. Basu and Mrs. Naidu for all their kind words.
('14', 282, 1, 8, 611140) But you have only seen the bright side; you do not know our weaknesses.
('14', 282, 1, 9, 611212) Indians are altogether too generous; they overlook faults and magnify virtues; this had led us to incarnating our heroes.
('14', 282, 1, 10, 611334) I think of what is written in our scriptures—that it is our duty to fly away from praises, we must lay them all at the feet of the Almighty.
('14', 282, 1, 11, 611475) I hope we have enough courage, and courage to lay them at His feet, in whose name and in the name of Mother India we have endeavoured to do our duty, but nothing but our duty.

('14', 282, 3, 13, 611677) 223. LETTER TO UNDER SECRETARY FOR COLONIES
('14', 282, 4, 14, 611721) [LONDON,] August 10, 1914 THE UNDER SECRETARY OF STATE COLONIAL OFFICE, S.W.
('14', 282, 6, 15, 611798) Mr. Hermann Kallenbach is a German by birth, his parents having migrated from Russia and settled in Germany at the border town of Russ, East Prussia.
('14', 282, 6, 16, 611948) He is a Jew by religion, an architect by profession.
('14', 282, 6, 17, 612001) He has settled in South Africa for the last 18 years.
('14', 282, 6, 18, 612055) He is owner of Tolstoy Farm in the Transvaal and considerable other landed property in the same Province.
('14', 282, 6, 19, 612161) He has been connected with my activity in South Africa for the last 10 years and has come with me, both of us being on our way to India.
('14', 282, 6, 20, 612298) Mr. Kallenbach never formally became a British subject, but as he was coming with me to India, both of us came to the conclusion that it would be better for him to become naturalised.
('14', 282, 6, 21, 612482) Before, therefore, we left South Africa, that is before the 18th July, he filed his
('14', 283, 0, 1, 612566) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 283, 1, 2, 612608) application for naturalisation with the Secretary for the Interior at Pretoria.
('14', 283, 1, 3, 612688) He was to have taken the oath of allegiance in India, where his papers were to follow him.
('14', 283, 1, 4, 612779) Owing to the crisis, both Mr. Kallenbach and I are now stranded here and both of us hope shortly to be able to offer our services as non combatants during the crisis that has overtaken the Empire.
('14', 283, 1, 5, 612976) I write this, however, to ascertain whether, as Mr. Kallenbach does not yet hold the certificate of naturalisation, he is to take any steps in connection with the notices published requiring Germans to register themselves.
('14', 283, 1, 6, 613199) In any event, Mr. Kallenbach wishes to place himself entirely at the disposal of the authorities.
('14', 283, 2, 7, 613297) I have the honour to remain,
('14', 283, 4, 8, 613326) Your most obedient servant, M. K. GANDHI

('14', 284, 1, 2, 614153) 225. LETTER TO UNDER SECRETARY FOR INDIA
('14', 284, 2, 3, 614194) [LONDON,] August l4, 1914 TO THE UNDER SECRETARY OF STATE FOR INDIA
('14', 284, 4, 4, 614262) It was thought desirable by many of us that, during the crisis that has overtaken the Empire and whilst many Englishmen, leaving their ordinary vocation in life, are responding to the Imperial call, those Indians who are residing in the United Kingdom and who can at all do so, should place themselves unconditionally at the disposal of the Authorities.
('14', 284, 4, 5, 614616) With a view of ascertaining the feeling of the resident Indian population, the undersigned sent out a circular letter to as many Indians in the United Kingdom as could be approached during the 30 hours that the organisers gave themselves.
('14', 284, 4, 6, 614855) The response has been generous and prompt and, in the opinion of the undersigned, representative of His Majesty’s subjects from the Indian Empire at present residing in the different parts of the United Kingdom.
('14', 284, 4, 7, 615067) On behalf of ourselves and those whose names appear on the list appended hereto, we beg to offer our services to the Authorities.
('14', 284, 4, 8, 615197) We venture to trust that the Right Hon’ble the Marquess of Crewe will approve of our offer and secure its acceptance by the proper authority.
('14', 284, 4, 9, 615339) We would respectfully emphasise the fact that the one dominant idea guiding us is that of rendering such humble assistance as we may be considered capable of performing, as an earnest of our desire to share the responsibilities of membership of this great Empire, if we would share its privileges.
('14', 284, 4, 10, 615637) It may be added that some of those whose names are sent herewith are already doing work in connection with some of the organisations that are already rendering assistance, and we have no doubt that, if our humble offer is accepted, as the news permeates the Indian community, many more volunteers will come forward.
('14', 284, 5, 11, 615953) M. K. GANDHI and others Indian Opinion, 16 9 1914
('14', 284, 6, 12, 616003) 1 The Under Secretary of State for India, Charles Roberts, replied to this co communication, indicating Government’s qualified acceptance of the offer.
('14', 284, 6, 13, 616155) Vide Appendix “Letter from C.Roberts”, After 14 8 1914.

('14', 285, 1, 2, 616253) 226. LETTER TO C. ROBERTS
('14', 285, 2, 3, 616279) [LONDON,] August 24, 1914
('14', 285, 3, 4, 616305) DEAR MR. ROBERTS,
('14', 285, 4, 5, 616323) You have no doubt heard of Mr. Hermann Kallenbach who has been associated with the Indian movement in South Africa for the last 10 years.
('14', 285, 4, 6, 616461) His parents originally came from Russia and settled in Germany at Russ, East Prussia.
('14', 285, 4, 7, 616547) Mr. Kallenbach was born there and has been a German subject.
('14', 285, 4, 8, 616608) He has settled in South Africa for the last 18 years and has carried on the profession of an architect.
('14', 285, 4, 9, 616712) He is owner of considerable landed property in the Transvaal.
('14', 285, 4, 10, 616774) Not having exercised the duties required of German citizens in the Transvaal, Mr. Kallenbach forfeited, according to German law, the rights of German nationality.As he was accompanying me to India before we left South Africa, both of us came to the conclusion that he should become naturalised.
('14', 285, 4, 11, 617069) He, therefore, completed his application for naturalisation on the 15th July last at Johannesburg.
('14', 285, 4, 12, 617168) And instructions were left with his solicitor to forward the certificate to his Indian address, as we did not expect to stay in London for any length of time.
('14', 285, 4, 13, 617327) He was to have taken the oath of allegiance in India.
('14', 285, 4, 14, 617381) As I do not know what Mr. Kallenbach’s legal status exactly is, for his protection, I have placed the above facts before the Colonial Office and am now awaiting their answer.
('14', 285, 4, 15, 617556) Mr. Kallenbach is desirous of joining the Indian Volunteer Corps and taking First Aid instruction in the class that is being formed under Dr. Cantlie.
('14', 285, 4, 16, 617707) But he does not wish to take any such steps without the knowledge and approval of the India Office.
('14', 285, 4, 17, 617807) Will you kindly consider the matter and, if this letter reaches you in time, favour me with your reply before Wednesday morning; the class, as you know, commences at 10 a.m.
('14', 285, 4, 18, 617981) that day.
('14', 285, 5, 19, 617991) I remain, Yours truly, M. K. GANDHI CHARLES ROBERTS, ESQ., M.P. INDIA OFFICE

('14', 286, 1, 2, 618145) 227. LETTER TO MAGANLAL GANDHI
('14', 286, 2, 3, 618176) 84 85, PALACE CHAMBERS, WESTMINSTER, LONDON, Bhadarva Sud 5 [August 26, 1914] 1
('14', 286, 3, 4, 618256) MAGANLAL,
('14', 286, 4, 5, 618266) As my affairs are in a mess, I do not know what to write.
('14', 286, 4, 6, 618324) I am attending these days one of the training classes 2 recently started for nursing the wounded.
('14', 286, 4, 7, 618422) All told, we are 59 Indians in this class, which will run for three weeks.
('14', 286, 4, 8, 618497) After that, I may have some idea when I shall be there [in India].
('14', 286, 4, 9, 618564) There may be some difficulty, perhaps, about Mr. Kallenbach’s going.
('14', 286, 4, 10, 618633) 3 In that case, my departure is likely to be delayed.
('14', 286, 4, 11, 618687) I have been coming up against one obstacle after another to my going to India.
('14', 286, 4, 12, 618766) You may commence writing to me.
('14', 286, 4, 13, 618798) All of you are on your trial there.
('14', 286, 4, 14, 618834) Use money with the utmost care.
('14', 286, 4, 15, 618866) Let everyone be scrupulous in observing the various restrictions on food.
('14', 286, 4, 16, 618940) That will keep you collected both in body and mind and bring credit to Phoenix.
('14', 286, 4, 17, 619020) I am not writing this time to everyone.
('14', 286, 4, 18, 619060) Next week, I may possibly get more time.
('14', 286, 4, 19, 619101) Send me a list of the persons in your party.
('14', 286, 5, 20, 619146) I read in Indian Opinion that all of you were honoured in Durban.
('14', 286, 5, 21, 619212) Let everyone of you be absorbed in studies there.
('14', 286, 5, 22, 619262) I hope Maganbhai 5 is keeping well.
('14', 286, 5, 23, 619298) If you need anything, see Mr. Deodhar 6
('14', 286, 6, 24, 619338) of the Servants of India Society.
('14', 286, 6, 25, 619372) I think you are put up with Revashankerbhai 7. I had a letter from him in which he said that you

('14', 286, 7, 27, 619681) 3 Kallenbach, being a German, was denied a passport to India.
('14', 286, 7, 28, 619743) 4 The reference is to the party of Phoenix inmates bound for India.
('14', 286, 7, 29, 619811) 5 Maganbhai Patel 6 Gopal Krishna Deodhar (1869 1935); a social worker who worked for the Servants of India Society and Sevasadan, an institution for women’s uplift, in Poona 7 Revashanker Jagjivan Jhaveri, brother of Dr. Mehta and a life long friend of Gandhiji

('14', 287, 4, 5, 620248) 228. LETTER TO MAGANLAL GANDHI
('14', 287, 5, 6, 620279) [LONDON,] Bhadarva Sud 14 [September 3, 1914]
('14', 287, 6, 7, 620325) MAGANLAL,
('14', 287, 7, 8, 620335) I wrote a letter to you last week.
('14', 287, 7, 9, 620370) 1 I hope you get all my letters.
('14', 287, 7, 10, 620403) Here I am quite engrossed in work.
('14', 287, 7, 11, 620438) It seems that one who wants to do his duty should expect no leisure.
('14', 287, 7, 12, 620507) Today we had an examination in first aid.
('14', 287, 7, 13, 620549) I too had to read a lot.
('14', 287, 7, 14, 620574) The questions were as follows: “What is the cure for opium poisoning?” “What is the treatment for a broken collarbone?” “What should be done to stop bleeding from a wound in the palm?” We are 70 Indians in the class.
('14', 287, 7, 15, 620791) From tomorrow begins the next session.
('14', 287, 7, 16, 620830) And, besides, I must see all these volunteers who keep turning up.
('14', 287, 7, 17, 620897) There is no knowing what the outcome of the War will be, or whether we shall have to go on special duty.
('14', 287, 7, 18, 621002) Things are thus in an uncertain state.
('14', 287, 7, 19, 621041) Ba keeps excellent health.
('14', 287, 7, 20, 621068) My weakness has not disappeared yet, thanks to fasting.
('14', 287, 7, 21, 621124) Mr. Kallenbach is learning Gujarati.
('14', 287, 7, 22, 621161) I am yearning for letters from you all.
('14', 287, 7, 23, 621201) This letter is for all of you to read.
('14', 287, 7, 24, 621240) I see that you will be tried much more severely than we thought.
('14', 287, 7, 25, 621305) For the present, I do not write separately to Maganbhai, Manilal, Jamnadas, and others.
('14', 287, 7, 26, 621393) I shall see next week.
('14', 287, 7, 27, 621416) Keep writing to me.
('14', 287, 7, 28, 621436) I am anxious to hear about the health of Maganbhai and Santok.
('14', 287, 8, 29, 621499) Blessings from MOHANDAS
('14', 287, 9, 30, 621523) From a photostat of the Gujarati original in Gandhiji’s hand: G. N. 2763

('14', 288, 1, 2, 621668) 229. LETTER TO MAGANLAL GANDHI
('14', 288, 2, 3, 621699) [LONDON,]
('14', 288, 3, 4, 621709) Bhadarva Vad 13 [September 18, 1914]
('14', 288, 4, 5, 621746) MAGANLAL,
('14', 288, 5, 6, 621756) I had no time last week to write to you.
('14', 288, 5, 7, 621797) Most of the time is spent in the training class for first aid to the injured and the rest with Mr. Gokhale.
('14', 288, 5, 8, 621905) He is keeping good health at present.
('14', 288, 5, 9, 621943) They will give us training for two more months and then send us to the front.
('14', 288, 5, 10, 622021) This means that my going to India in the immediate future is out of the question, unless the War suddenly comes to an end.
('14', 288, 5, 11, 622144) All of you may want to know why I have undertaken even the nursing of the wounded.
('14', 288, 5, 12, 622227) Recently, I used to say, in South Africa, that, as satyagrahis we cannot help in this way either, for such help also amounted to supporting a war.
('14', 288, 5, 13, 622374) One who would not help a slaughter house should not help in cleaning the butcher’s house either.
('14', 288, 5, 14, 622471) But I found that, living in England, I was in a way participating in the War.
('14', 288, 5, 15, 622549) London owes the food it gets in war time to the protection of the Navy.
('14', 288, 5, 16, 622621) Thus to take this food was also a wrong thing.
('14', 288, 5, 17, 622668) There was only one right course left, which was to go away to live in some mountainor cave in England itself and subsist there on whatever food or shelter Nature might provide, without seeking assistance from any human being.
('14', 288, 5, 18, 622894) I do not yet possess the spiritual strength necessary for this.
('14', 288, 5, 19, 622958) It seemed to me a base thing, therefore, to accept food tainted by war without working for it.
('14', 288, 5, 20, 623053) When thousands have come forward to lay down their lives only because they thought it their duty to do so, how could I sit still?
('14', 288, 5, 21, 623183) A rifle this hand will never fire.
('14', 288, 5, 22, 623218) And so there only remained nursing the wounded and I took it up.
('14', 288, 5, 23, 623283) This is how I communed to myself.
('14', 288, 5, 24, 623317) I cannot say for certain that the step I have taken is the right one.
('14', 288, 5, 25, 623387) I have thought much about the matter though, but so far I have discovered no alternative.
('14', 288, 5, 26, 623477) My guess is that we shall be here for at least four months more.
('14', 288, 5, 27, 623542) The War should not go on longer than that.
('14', 288, 5, 28, 623585) Ba is keeping good health.
('14', 288, 5, 29, 623612) She can even walk long distances.
('14', 288, 5, 30, 623646) Here she has given up wheat as well.
('14', 288, 5, 31, 623683) She takes only milk in addition to what I do.
('14', 288, 5, 32, 623729) Mr. Kallenbach, too, enjoys excellent health.
('14', 288, 5, 33, 623775) He keeps up his study of Gujarati.
('14', 288, 5, 34, 623810) Mr. Sorabji sees me every day.
('14', 288, 5, 35, 623841) He has joined the War along with me.
('14', 289, 0, 1, 623878) 290 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 289, 1, 2, 623920) are 70 in the class.
('14', 289, 1, 3, 623941) He has passed the first examination, that is, the entrance examination [for the Bar].
('14', 289, 1, 4, 624027) He will take three more years to be called to the bar.
('14', 289, 1, 5, 624082) I am growing more convinced with experience that coming here for degrees serves no useful purpose whatsoever.
('14', 289, 1, 6, 624192) The students’ plight is pitiable.
('14', 289, 1, 7, 624226) Maybe they do get some education, but they learn nothing.
('14', 289, 1, 8, 624284) Their character is ruined.
('14', 289, 1, 9, 624311) Perhaps the coming over of a very small number may be useful (only at a mature age, though).
('14', 289, 1, 10, 624404) All of you should read this letter.
('14', 289, 1, 11, 624440) Make a copy and send the original to Dr. Mehta.
('14', 289, 1, 12, 624488) Send the copy to Harilal.
('14', 289, 1, 13, 624514) Write to me regularly at this address: 84 85, Palace Chambers, Westminster, London.
('14', 289, 1, 14, 624598) I do not write separately to the others.
('14', 289, 1, 15, 624639) This may be taken, therefore, as meant for all.
('14', 289, 1, 16, 624687) You must be finding yourselves in a trying situation indeed, all of you.
('14', 289, 1, 17, 624760) I pray to God to be your help and to give you the firmness of mind to do your duty.
('14', 289, 1, 18, 624844) Send a copy of this letter to Samaldas 1 also.
('14', 289, 1, 19, 624891) He should join us.
('14', 289, 1, 20, 624910) Who knows when I shall be able to bow down my head before the sisters in law.
('14', 289, 1, 21, 624988) I am eager to know if Maganbhai has been to his people.
('14', 289, 1, 22, 625044) See if you can arrange for [teaching] Tamil to Fakiri 2
('14', 289, 2, 23, 625100) andKuppu 3. You may see Mr. Natarajan 4.4 He will guide you.
('14', 289, 2, 24, 625161) Ask everyone to write to me.
('14', 289, 2, 25, 625190) Tell me how things are with Kalyandas 55.
('14', 289, 3, 26, 625232) Blessings from BAPU

('14', 290, 1, 2, 625642) 230. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL GANDHI
('14', 290, 2, 3, 625675) [LONDON,] Bhadarva Vad 14 [September 19, 1914]
('14', 290, 3, 4, 625722) CHHAGANLAL,
('14', 290, 4, 5, 625734) I still hesitate to send you what I have written, so afraid I am about the post.
('14', 290, 4, 6, 625815) There have been no letters from you so far by the latest mail.
('14', 290, 4, 7, 625878) To me this country seems like poison.
('14', 290, 4, 8, 625916) My soul is in India.
('14', 290, 4, 9, 625937) I am, however, staying on because I think I must.
('14', 290, 4, 10, 625987) I want to write more about this but I have neither the time for it just now, nor the mood.
('14', 290, 4, 11, 626078) Do go on writing to me here.
('14', 290, 4, 12, 626107) Give my salaams to Imam Saheb.
('14', 290, 4, 13, 626138) I wish to write again to him.
('14', 290, 4, 14, 626168) I do not know, though, when I shall be able to do so.
('14', 290, 4, 15, 626222) Ask Raojibhai and Pragji to write.
('14', 290, 4, 16, 626257) I have given £190 to Sorabji for admission to the Bar.
('14', 290, 4, 17, 626312) Debit that to Dr. Mehta’s account and send me a draft for the amount by registered post.
('14', 290, 4, 18, 626401) If I am not here, the letter will follow me to India.
('14', 290, 5, 19, 626455) Blessings from
('14', 290, 6, 20, 626470) MOHANDAS

('14', 290, 8, 22, 626552) 231. CIRCULAR REGARDING TRAINING CORPS 1
('14', 290, 9, 23, 626593) September 22, 1914
('14', 290, 10, 24, 626612) In response to a desire widely expressed by Indian students resident in the United Kingdom to take some active part in the defence of the country and in service abroad, it has been decided to organise a Field Ambulance Training Corps in connection with theRed Cross Society, and to give members of this Corps, when adequa tely trained, an opportunity of serving with the Indian Army in Europe.
('14', 290, 10, 25, 627006) The nucleus of such a Corps has already been formed in London, and drilled and trained for some weeks under Dr. James Cantlie, and steps are now being taken, with the co operation of the War Office and the authorities of the London University Officers’
('14', 290, 11, 26, 627259) 1 The original entitled “Indian Field Ambulance Training Corps” was drafted by Gandhiji and Mr. Mallet; vide “Letter to C. Roberts”, 25 10 1914
('14', 291, 0, 1, 627403) 292 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 291, 1, 2, 627445) Training Corps, to expand and develop this nucleus into a highly organised corps.
('14', 291, 1, 3, 627527) The Government of India has given its sanction, and Lieutenant Colonel Baker of the Indian Medical Service (retired) has consented to act as Commander of the Corps.
('14', 291, 1, 4, 627692) Indian gentlemen desirous of joining it should send in their names without delay to the Indian Volunteers Committee, 60, Talbot Road, Bayswater, London.
('14', 291, 1, 5, 627845) The Corps is intended mainly for residents in London; but Indian students from other centres will be admitted if they desire to join.
('14', 291, 1, 6, 627979) Men with medical training will be able to undertake special duties, but all men willing to train and serve will be of use.
('14', 291, 1, 7, 628102) Applicants will be asked to enrol themselves in the Indian Field Ambulance Training Corps, and will require to be passed by a Medical Board as physically fit.
('14', 291, 1, 8, 628261) They will then be drilled almost every day by trained instructors in London, at an hour which will not interfere unduly with their ordinary studies or occupations; and at each week end they will be expected to go into camp for further training from Friday night to Monday morning.
('14', 291, 1, 9, 628542) A camping ground within easy reach of London will be placed at the disposal of the Corps, and uniforms and equip ment will be procured.
('14', 291, 1, 10, 628678) After some weeks of training—which will involve hard and steady work—they will, when efficient, be entitled to volunteer to serve for six months as a Detachment under the Red Cross Society in connection with the Indian troops abroad.
('14', 291, 1, 11, 628912) The terms and conditions of such service will be announced later.
('14', 291, 1, 12, 628978) But it is hoped that the Red Cross Society will be able, in the first instance, to find places in the Detachment sent abroad for 10 Medical Officers and for 50 other recruits who would serve as Nursing Orderlies, Dressers, Compounders, Bearers, &c.
('14', 291, 1, 13, 629227) The rates of pay on active service will probably be 20s.
('14', 291, 1, 14, 629284) per day for Medical Officers and 4s.
('14', 291, 1, 15, 629321) per day, with free rations, for the rest.
('14', 291, 1, 16, 629363) Preference in the filling of these places would be given to recruits who, in the opinion of the Commanding Officer, were the most efficiently trained.
('14', 291, 2, 17, 629514) From a printed leaflet: S. N. 6053

('14', 292, 3, 5, 629651) DEAR DR.
('14', 292, 3, 6, 629660) ABDURRAHMAN
('14', 292, 4, 7, 629672) I think you should inform the Minister that you represent not only the Malay community but the other Mahomedans also who are not Malays.
('14', 292, 4, 8, 629809) At the same time, a statement of your case should certainly be submitted to him.
('14', 292, 4, 9, 629890) You will read in this week’s Indian Opinion counsel’s opinion which would show you that the resident Mahomedans are also affected by the judgement.
('14', 292, 4, 10, 630038) What you desire is that (you will tell him) non Christian marriages celebrated according to the rites of the respective religions of the parties should be recognised and that if a deputation was received a way out of the difficulty might be found and further that the Minister will then notice the intensity of the feeling roused.
('14', 292, 4, 11, 630369) I hope that you will be satisfied with nothing less than an alteration of the Law—no assurances can be accepted as sufficient.

('14', 292, 8, 15, 630636) [LONDON, October 1, 1914]
('14', 292, 9, 16, 630662) Mr. Gandhi spoke of Dr. Cantlie’s splendid spirit in all the work that had been done, but added that, if he had one weakness, it was his keen desire “to make us wear kilts in order to keep ourselves thoroughly warm!” The one who laughed longest and
('14', 292, 10, 17, 630911) 1 At a public meeting held at the Polytechnic Institution, Regent Street, the Indian Voluntary Aid Corps, which was trained by Dr. James Cantlie in First Aid, Sanitation and Hygiene, received recognition from the War Office as the Indian Field Ambulance Corps.
('14', 292, 10, 18, 631172) R. J. Baker, an ex member of the Indian Medical Corps, took over charge of further instruction.
('14', 292, 10, 19, 631268) Gandhiji presided over the meeting which was addressed by the Aga Khan and attended, among others, by Kasturba, Sarojini Naidu, Ameer Ali and Kallenbach.
('14', 292, 10, 20, 631422) Earlier, Gandhiji presented Dr. Cantlie with a set of Tagore’s works in appreciation of his services to the Corps.
('14', 293, 0, 1, 631537) 294 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 293, 1, 2, 631579) loudest was Dr. Cantlie himself.
('14', 293, 1, 3, 631612) To the Directors of the Polytechnic Institution Mr. Gandhi also paid a fine and deserved tribute; it has made a home for the Indian Corps, given them the use of its splendid equipment, of its rooms and halls, of its many facilities, for practically nothing because dominated by the spirit of patriotism and service.
('14', 293, 2, 4, 631928) When speaking of H. H. the Aga Khan—to “introduce” him, said Mr. Gandhi, would be an impertinence, especially by one who had been for more than twenty years an exile from his Motherland—Mr. Gandhi, as might be expected, fastened upon the offer of His Highness to serve as a private in the British ranks in this time of crisis.
('14', 293, 2, 5, 632255) It was a noble example set by one to whom every avenue in the army might be open; it would comfort, encourage and cheer the Indian Corps, who would gladly serve His Highness.
('14', 293, 2, 6, 632430) A word was added about the unfailing encouragement and substantial financial help which His Highness had always given to the struggle in South Africa, of his help to Mr. Gokhale in his strenuous work on behalf of the Indians in South Africa, and of the thrill of joy which touched not only the hearts of the Aga Khan’s followers, of whom there were some in the midst of the struggle, but of all Indians, irrespective of creed.
('14', 293, 3, 7, 632857) Mr. Gandhi afterwards expressed on behalf of Hindus complete sympathy with Mussulmans in their resentment of Mr. Lloyd George’s words, and made the sugges tion that they should raise a farthing subscription and present to the Chancellor of the Exchequer an authentic narrative which would prove that the Prophet of Islam was not the monster he thought him to be.

('14', 293, 5, 9, 633246) 234. LETTER TO COL.
('14', 293, 5, 10, 633266) R. J. BAKER
('14', 293, 6, 11, 633278) LONDON, October 13, 1914
('14', 293, 7, 12, 633303) DEAR COLONEL BAKER,
('14', 293, 8, 13, 633323) I thank you for your note of today’s date, supplemented by the message sent by you, verbally, through Mr. Venkatraman who was good enough to take [my] note to you.
('14', 293, 8, 14, 633487) I am aware that strict military discipline requires that all complaints by members of a Corps should be sent to the commanding officer through section leaders.
('14', 293, 8, 15, 633647) I am also aware of the fact that, in the military sense, I am no more than any other private, but I have been
('14', 293, 9, 16, 633757) 1 The gathering was then addressed by the Aga Khan,
('14', 294, 0, 1, 633809) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 295
('14', 294, 1, 2, 633854) under the belief that in the interests of the Corps, and unofficially, I would be allowed to act as a humble channel of communication between you and the members of the Corps, so as to avoid any friction or stiffness, especially in the initial stages, when the members who have never undergone military discipline are likely to misunderstandexperiences which may be quite new to them.
('14', 294, 1, 3, 634239) I also thought that you would not mind recognising my representative capacity as Chairman of the Volunteer Corps, and would not resent my approaching you in the matters affecting the Corps, and it was in that belief that, being entirely a cripple, I took the liberty of inviting you to my room so that we could have a mutual discussion, which I have always known to be far more satisfactory than letter writing, and if you think it worth while, I would still ask you to favour me with a call.
('14', 294, 1, 4, 634732) Meanwhile, and in any case, here are the complaints so far as they have been brought to my notice.
('14', 294, 1, 5, 634831) First, grievous dissatisfaction has been caused by the appoint ment of section leaders without reference to the feeling of the members of the Corps.
('14', 294, 1, 6, 634980) They are disappointed, and I share their disappointment, that they were not in any way consulted as to the appointment.
('14', 294, 1, 7, 635100) The leaders appointed may or may not be desirable persons, and I hardly know any of them, but I think that the efficient and smooth working of the Corps demands the appointments of officers who are likely to be popular with its members.
('14', 294, 1, 8, 635337) I, therefore, venture to suggest that the appointments already made may be rec alled, and that the members of the Corps may be invited to elect sec tion leaders and other officers whose appointment would depend entirely upon you, and in the event of your not approving of the choice made by the members, that they should elect others in the place of those rejected by you.
('14', 294, 1, 9, 635710) The other complaints are of minor importance.
('14', 294, 1, 10, 635756) The blankets supplied are not considered enough, nor of sufficient length.
('14', 294, 1, 11, 635831) The quantity, as also the kind of rations, requires revision.
('14', 294, 1, 12, 635893) There are still some other matters with which I will not burden this note, which is, I fear, too long as it is.
('14', 294, 2, 13, 636005) I remain, Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('14', 294, 3, 14, 636045) From the typewritten office copy signed by Gandhiji: S. N. 6069B

('14', 295, 1, 2, 636152) 235. RESOLUTION 1
('14', 295, 2, 3, 636170) [LONDON, October 13, 1914]
('14', 295, 3, 4, 636197) This meeting of the Indian Volunteers of the Indian Field Ambulance Training Corps hereby places on record its deep sense of regret in connection with the appointment of corporals without reference to the wishes of the members of the Corps and expresses further regret that the Commanding Officer has not seen his way to comply with the reasonable request of the Chairman of the Corps suggesting that the appointments already made may be recalled and that members may be given an opportunity of electing during the training period Corporals and other officers subject to confirmation by the Commanding Officer, and respectfully resolves that, unless the appointments above mentioned are recalled and some means adopted of ascertaining definitely the wishes of the members of the Corps in making fresh appointments, the members will be reluctantly obliged to abstain from further drilling and week end camping.
('14', 295, 4, 5, 637107) From the typewritten office copy: S. N. 6069B

('14', 296, 1, 3, 638113) 1 And though officiallythere were even several Europeans who occupied ranks, Colonel Gallwey and Major Baptey, who was under him, were good enough not to take any steps without reference to me with a view to ascert aining the wishes of the Corps.
('14', 296, 1, 4, 638360) And you may know that we were attached to a column of 30,000, were under strictest military discip line, and the Corps was called upon to work at the most critical period of the Boer War and when, in the initial stages, British arms had suffered reverses.
('14', 296, 1, 5, 638616) I assure that nothing can be further from my thought than to undermine your proper authority or to do anything subversive of military discipline, but if you desire to train us for that discipline, in my opinion, there is no other way than the one I have ventured to suggest.
('14', 296, 1, 6, 638891) It will enable you to know your Corps better, and may I say that, by accepting my humble advice, you will add to your popularity and prestige.
('14', 296, 1, 7, 639034) We had an enthusiastic meeting of the Corps last night.
('14', 296, 1, 8, 639090) There were 53 members present.
('14', 296, 1, 9, 639121) I attended though I was in agony and in defiance of medical instructions.
('14', 296, 1, 10, 639195) The subjoined resolution was carried by 49 votes against 2 dissentients.
('14', 296, 1, 11, 639268) I have asked the members present to attend at the drilling time this afternoon.
('14', 296, 1, 12, 639348) If you could possibly see your way, in the interest of the Corps, to alter your decision, the drilling will go on.
('14', 296, 1, 13, 639463) If you could not do so, those of us who voted for the resolution and the others who may fall in with it will be informed of your unfavourable decision and will therefore respectfully with draw.
('14', 296, 1, 14, 639657) I hope that you will reconsider your decision and avoid what would undoubtedly be a catastrophe.
('14', 296, 1, 15, 639754) I assure you that I am most anxious to please you as our Commanding Officer, but I am equally anxious to serve my countrymen many of whom have joined this movement upon my advice.
('14', 296, 1, 16, 639934) Mr. Gandevia who has kindly offered to take this letter to you will await your reply.
('14', 296, 2, 17, 640020) I remain,
('14', 296, 3, 18, 640030) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('14', 297, 1, 2, 640255) 237. LETTER TO C. ROBERTS
('14', 297, 2, 3, 640281) [LONDON,] October 16, 1914
('14', 297, 3, 4, 640308) DEAR MR. ROBERTS, An unfortunate situation has arisen in connection with the Indian Field Ambulance Training Corps which may disrupt it if it is not handled in the right spirit.
('14', 297, 3, 5, 640486) Last week, Colonel Baker appointed section commanders with out reference to the wishes of the members of the Corps.
('14', 297, 3, 6, 640602) There was grave dissatisfaction and, when it was brought to my notice, I shared it.
('14', 297, 3, 7, 640686) On Tuesday morning I appealed to Colonel Baker to recall the appointment, and appoint those whom the members of the Corps may choose, subject to further election by them, in the event of the choice not being accepted by Col.
('14', 297, 3, 8, 640911) He, however, much to my surprise, took up what to my mind was an untenable attitude.
('14', 297, 3, 9, 640996) He thought that any complaints that the members might have to make could only be brought before him through the section commanders and that recall of the appointments would be subversive of all discipline.
('14', 297, 3, 10, 641202) My committee at once called a meeting of the members of the Corps and a resolution was adopted on Wednesday night requesting Col.
('14', 297, 3, 11, 641332) Baker to recall the appointments and to allow us to submit names for his approval.
('14', 297, 3, 12, 641415) He not only did not accede to our request but considered it a grave breach of military discipline to have convened the meeting.
('14', 297, 3, 13, 641543) I submit that Col.
('14', 297, 3, 14, 641562) Baker has grievously misunderstood his position and that of the Corps.
('14', 297, 3, 15, 641633) I venture to think:
('14', 297, 4, 16, 641653) That up to the present we are only probationers undergoing training in ambulance work.
('14', 297, 4, 17, 641740) 2. That we have yet to sign contracts which would bind us in the military sense.
('14', 297, 4, 18, 641821) 3. That the internal administration of the Corps should rest in the hands of the Volunteer Committee.
('14', 297, 4, 19, 641923) 4. That our services have been accepted only as a voluntary aid detachment and that, therefore, the full military code can never apply to us.
('14', 297, 4, 20, 642065) I may be permitted to draw your attention to two precedents within my knowledge.
('14', 297, 4, 21, 642146) At the time of the Boer War the Indian Ambulance Corps was 1200 strong.
('14', 297, 4, 22, 642218) There was also a European
('14', 298, 0, 1, 642244) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 299
('14', 298, 1, 2, 642289) Ambulance Corps, I think much larger.
('14', 298, 1, 3, 642327) We were all under Col.
('14', 298, 1, 4, 642350) Gallwey’s command.
('14', 298, 1, 5, 642369) But Col.
('14', 298, 1, 6, 642378) Gallwey never claimed to interfere with the internal administration of the Corps, although we were under military discipline.
('14', 298, 1, 7, 642504) And we were not then, as the Corps is now, merely a training body.
('14', 298, 1, 8, 642571) We were in action at the most critical period of the war.
('14', 298, 1, 9, 642629) Gallwey did not appoint section commanders.
('14', 298, 1, 10, 642673) We appointed our own leaders and others.
('14', 298, 1, 11, 642714) As it so happened, all orders ultimately passed through my hands.
('14', 298, 1, 12, 642780) Similarly, at the time of the Zulu rebellion in Natal, we were under Col.
('14', 298, 1, 13, 642854) Sparks’ command.
('14', 298, 1, 14, 642871) Sparks never appointed officers of our Corps.
('14', 298, 1, 15, 642917) We appointed from among ourselves our officers and the sole responsibility for carrying out orders as to military duty rested upon one of us.
('14', 298, 1, 16, 643059) You may be aware that both Corps found honourable mention in dispatches.
('14', 298, 1, 17, 643132) There may be precedents to the contrary 2. I do not know the military code.
('14', 298, 1, 18, 643208) If a grave and punishable breach of discipline has been committed in the calling of the meeting alluded to above, or in any other manner, I alone must be held responsible and I shall cheerfully bear the penalty.
('14', 298, 1, 19, 643420) But if the Corps is to be held together, I cannot help feeling that the appointments of the corporals should be recalled, the status of the Corps exactly defined and the position of Col.
('14', 298, 1, 20, 643607) Baker and my Committee determined.
('14', 298, 1, 21, 643642) I need hardly assure you that I have addressed this communication to you in no irresponsible manner.
('14', 298, 1, 22, 643743) I know that this is not the time for squabbles or quibbles but for solid work.
('14', 298, 1, 23, 643822) I fear however that Col.
('14', 298, 1, 24, 643847) Baker’s uncompromising attitude has made it impossible for many of us to work through him unless he can alter his attitude.
('14', 298, 1, 25, 643971) I venture to trust that you will be able to suggest a way out of the difficulty.
('14', 298, 3, 26, 644052) Yours truly, M. K. GANDHI CHARLES ROBERTS, ESQ., M.P., ETC.

('14', 299, 3, 6, 644496) I hope however that such is not the case.

('14', 299, 8, 16, 645039) I thank you for your letter received this morning.

('14', 299, 8, 18, 645404) I shall be prepared to advise the Committee to accept the position stated in your letter and resume duties which have been unhappily suspended.

('14', 299, 8, 21, 645812) Baker and that the principle of consultation is to be applied to all matters affecting

('14', 300, 4, 10, 646987) 240. LETTER TO C. ROBERTS
('14', 300, 5, 11, 647013) 16, TREBOVIR ROAD, LONDON, S. W., October 25, 1914
('14', 300, 6, 12, 647064) DEAR MR. ROBERTS,
('14', 300, 7, 13, 647082) I have to thank you for your prompt reply of the 23rd instant.
('14', 300, 7, 14, 647145) The correspondence between us was read to the meeting referred to in my letter of the 22nd instant and with but two dissentients, the meeting passed a resolution expressing deep regret over your letter under reply and authorising me to negotiate for a settlement on the lines of my last letter.
('14', 300, 7, 15, 647440) I fear very much that there seems to be a complete misunder standing between the India Office and my Committee as to its func tions and the relative positions of Col.
('14', 300, 7, 16, 647607) Baker and the Committee.
('14', 300, 7, 17, 647632) The issue of the circular 1 which was drafted by Mr. Mallet and myself, and of which I enclose copy herewith, was simultaneous with the appoint ment of Col.
('14', 300, 7, 18, 647789) Baker as the Commanding Officer.
('14', 300, 7, 19, 647822) That circular exp ressly contemplates exclusive recruiting by my Committee.
('14', 300, 7, 20, 647898) And up to the time of the unfortunate rupture, recruiting has been exclusively done by it with the knowledge of Col.
('14', 300, 7, 21, 648015) It is, therefore, hardly fair to suggest that I am now even challenging Col.
('14', 300, 7, 22, 648092) Baker’s right to
('14', 300, 8, 23, 648109) 1 Vide “Circular regarding Training Corps”,22 9 1914.
('14', 301, 0, 1, 648163) 302 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 301, 1, 2, 648205) recruit—a right which never belonged to him.
('14', 301, 1, 3, 648250) Indeed, if I may say so, we have a right to complain that, whilst we were trying our best to healthe breach, circulars inviting recruits were issued by Col.
('14', 301, 1, 4, 648407) Baker and even the Students’ Department intervened and more or less formally wrote to those who were likely to respond to Col.
('14', 301, 1, 5, 648534) Baker’s efforts.
('14', 301, 1, 6, 648551) These attempts suggest that there is no intention on his part to retain my Committee’s co operation.
('14', 301, 1, 7, 648652) It would certainly have been more becoming, if he had waited for the result of the negotiations carried on by me for a settlement.
('14', 301, 1, 8, 648783) If, therefore, in spite of resumption of duties by the Corps, Col.
('14', 301, 1, 9, 648850) Baker were to continue recruiting, the Corps would lose its national and voluntary character and his action would be contrary to the circular referred to by me and the practice based upon it.
('14', 301, 1, 10, 649042) It would moreover be contrary to the spirit of your letter of the 18th August wherein the signatories to the offer were invited to form a committee.
('14', 301, 1, 11, 649191) The least that is, in my opinion, due to the Committee, is, in the event of a settlement, to be allowed to retain its exclusive right to recruit.
('14', 301, 1, 12, 649337) Your letter further suggests that it would be impracticable for Col.
('14', 301, 1, 13, 649406) Baker to accept the principle of consultation with my Committee in matters affecting the internal administration of the Corps.
('14', 301, 1, 14, 649533) It has not, I feel sure, been Col.
('14', 301, 1, 15, 649568) Baker’s experience hitherto.
('14', 301, 1, 16, 649597) He has not, for instance, found it impracticable to seek and value the co operation and advice of the Committee rendered through me as to the method of managing the Commissariat, the way of dealing with the difficult question of different sections wanting different foods as also of dealing with the equally difficult question of uniforms.
('14', 301, 1, 17, 649937) It is, not suggested by me that upon matters of rendering service and doing work my Committee might be consulted.
('14', 301, 1, 18, 650051) I am well aware of the fact that, in the forms of contract voluntarily signed by us, we have undertaken to obey all lawful commands of our commanding officer.
('14', 301, 1, 19, 650210) But we have not undertaken to subscribe to the exercise by that officer of functions that we have all along understood do not belong to him.
('14', 301, 1, 20, 650351) I may be allowed to state that I have before now known how to obey and I hope that, if it becomes my good fortune to serve during this crisis in any capacity whatsoever for which I may be fitted, I shall not be wanting.
('14', 301, 1, 21, 650571) And I think I may say the same of my fellow workers.
('14', 301, 1, 22, 650624) Throughout this unfortunate affair, their one desire has been to fulfil the letter as also the spirit of the contract forms signed by them.
('14', 301, 1, 23, 650764) I have already written at much greater length than I had desired
('14', 302, 0, 1, 650829) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 303
('14', 302, 1, 2, 650874) My Committee and I are very anxious to see a settlement.
('14', 302, 1, 3, 650931) And as I know that nothing conduces to a mutual understanding so much as personal conversation, may I avail myself of your offer to visit me again when necessary.
('14', 302, 1, 4, 651094) I am under strict medical orders not to leave my bed at least for a fortnight.
('14', 302, 1, 5, 651173) I shall, therefore, be deeply grateful, if you could find time to come over.
('14', 302, 1, 6, 651250) Any time and day will suit me.
('14', 302, 3, 7, 651281) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('14', 302, 5, 9, 651376) 241. LETTER TO MAGANLAL GANDHI
('14', 302, 6, 10, 651407) LONDON, Kartak Sud 7, 1971 [October 25, 1914]
('14', 302, 7, 11, 651453) MAGANLAL,
('14', 302, 8, 12, 651463) I have not been able to write to you lately.
('14', 302, 8, 13, 651508) Being better today, I have sat down to write.
('14', 302, 8, 14, 651554) I am still confined to bed and shall be so, it seems, for another ten days at least.
('14', 302, 8, 15, 651639) This time the pain was extreme and the reason for it, in my opinion, was that I listened to doctor friends.
('14', 302, 8, 16, 651747) Pressed by everyone, I agreed to take things against which I had not taken an inviolable pledge.
('14', 302, 8, 17, 651844) I ate dal, rice, and vegetables for four days.
('14', 302, 8, 18, 651891) The pain went on increasing all these days, instead of subsiding as expected.
('14', 302, 8, 19, 651969) On the fifth day, I took salt.
('14', 302, 8, 20, 652000) The pain on that day was unbearable.
('14', 302, 8, 21, 652037) On the sixth day, I gave up the doctors and went back to my own remedies.
('14', 302, 8, 22, 652111) The pain vanished entirely and the piles also disappeared.
('14', 302, 8, 23, 652170) The pain returned, however, thanks to my own foolishness.
('14', 302, 8, 24, 652228) On the day I ate salt there was blood in my cough, for the first time in my life.
('14', 302, 8, 25, 652310) I still get it.
('14', 302, 8, 26, 652326) And so Mr. Kallenbach brought a white doctor, a vegetarian whom I know.
('14', 302, 8, 27, 652398) He said that there was no need for salt, but pointed to the need for roots and tubers.
('14', 302, 8, 28, 652485) He suggested, moreover, that the body having grown extremely weak through fasting, I should not take oil, nuts, etc., for the present.
('14', 302, 8, 29, 652620) Hence I live at present on barley water, eight ounces of fresh fruit, and eight ounces of soup of turnip, carrot, potato and cabbage mixed.
('14', 302, 8, 30, 652760) The body is extremely emaciated.
('14', 302, 8, 31, 652793) I do not have full
('14', 303, 0, 1, 652812) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 303, 1, 2, 652854) faith even in this treatment.
('14', 303, 1, 3, 652884) Since, however, I have not myself hit upon the key to my health, I am trying out this experiment.
('14', 303, 1, 4, 652982) The pain has stopped.
('14', 303, 1, 5, 653004) Blood continues to come up while coughing.
('14', 303, 1, 6, 653047) I have lost all taste for food and hence this is an excellent opportunity for mastering the palate.
('14', 303, 1, 7, 653147) The doctor has stopped lemon as well, so that, in the absence of oil, the soup of turnip, carrot and cabbage is not very inviting, but I take it with relish.
('14', 303, 1, 8, 653305) In the beginning, barley water did not taste nice.
('14', 303, 1, 9, 653356) But now I think I can stand it.
('14', 303, 1, 10, 653388) I write all this in detail toyou, but there is no need to worry.
('14', 303, 1, 11, 653453) I hope I will be all right, and that too, I still feel, with fruits.
('14', 303, 1, 12, 653522) It is yet to be seen whether this is borne out by experience.
('14', 303, 1, 13, 653584) Friends insist that I should take milk, but I have flatly refused to do so.
('14', 303, 1, 14, 653660) I have told them that I have vowed not to consume it and would not therefore have it even if I should die without it.
('14', 303, 1, 15, 653778) Ba’s stamina is wonderful.
('14', 303, 1, 16, 653805) She is coming to have more faith in my remedies.
('14', 303, 1, 17, 653854) I have had to start a satyagraha here against the India Office, details of which I will give in my next letter.
('14', 303, 2, 18, 653966) Follow all the ideals of Phoenix even at the cost of extreme suffering.
('14', 303, 2, 19, 654038) Tell me in detail how everybody is keeping and what has been the effect of the environment on the minds of the children after going there.
('14', 303, 3, 20, 654177) Blessings from BAPU [From Gujarati] Gandhijini Sadhana
