('14', 305, 1, 2, 656429) 244. LETTER TO “INDIA”
('14', 305, 2, 3, 656452) [ LONDON], November 4, 1914
('14', 305, 3, 4, 656480) TO THE EDITOR INDIA [LONDON]
('14', 305, 5, 5, 656509) There were at the Netley Hospital last Sunday nearly 470 Indian wounded soldiers.
('14', 305, 5, 6, 656591) Many more are expected to arrive shortly, if they are not there already.
('14', 305, 5, 7, 656664) The need for Indian Volunteer orderlies is greater than ever.
('14', 305, 5, 8, 656726) Nearly 70 members of the local Indian corps are already serving as nurses there.
('14', 305, 5, 9, 656807) Leaving aside the medical members of the corps, there are now very few left to answer the further call when it comes.
('14', 305, 5, 10, 656925) May I, therefore, trespass upon the hospitality of your columns to appeal to the Indian young men residing in the United Kingdom to enlist without delay?
('14', 305, 5, 11, 657079) In my humble opinion, it ought to be our proud privilege to nurse the Indian soldiers back to health.
('14', 305, 5, 12, 657181) Colonel Baker’s cry is for more orderlies.
('14', 305, 5, 13, 657224) And in order to make up the requisite number, as also to encourage our young men, several elderly Indians occupying a high position have gone or are going to Netley as orderlies.
('14', 305, 5, 14, 657403) Among them arc Mr. M. A. Turk had, a former vice president of the Rajkumar College in Kathiawar; Mr. J. M. Parikh, barrister at law; and Lieutenant Colonel Kanta Prasad, of the Indian Medical Service (retired), who has served in five campaigns.
('14', 305, 5, 15, 657648) I hope that the example set by these gentlemen will inspire others with alike zeal, and that many Indians who can at all afford to do so will be equal to the emergency that has arisen.
('14', 305, 5, 16, 657833) Those who desire to enlist can do so at the Indian Volunteers Committee’s rooms at 16, Trebovir Road, near Earl’s Court, at any time during working hours.
('14', 305, 6, 17, 657988) [I am, etc.,] M. K. GANDHI CHAIRMAN, INDIAN VOLUNTEERS COMMITTEE
('14', 305, 7, 18, 658053) India, 6 11 1914

('14', 306, 1, 2, 658115) 245. A CIRCULAR LETTER 1
('14', 306, 2, 3, 658140) [LONDON,] November 4, 1914
('14', 306, 3, 4, 658167) There were at the Netley Hospital last Sunday nearly 470 Indian wounded soldiers.
('14', 306, 3, 5, 658249) Many more are expected to arrive shortly, if they are not there already.
('14', 306, 3, 6, 658322) Nearly all the available members of the Indian Volunteers Corps are working either as nurses or as orderlies at Netley.
('14', 306, 3, 7, 658442) The cry is for more orderlies.
('14', 306, 3, 8, 658473) The Committee thinks that it should be considered a proud privilege by us to be able to nurse our own wounded countrymen.
('14', 306, 3, 9, 658595) Atleast two hundred more recruits will be required in order to cope with the work that lies before us.
('14', 306, 3, 10, 658698) The service will be required for no more than three months.
('14', 306, 3, 11, 658758) Students, therefore, will not be called upon to sacrifice more than three months of their time after being enlisted.
('14', 306, 3, 12, 658875) Several of our elderly countrymen have gone to Netley as orderlies.
('14', 306, 3, 13, 658943) Mr. M. A. Turkhad, ex Vice President, Rajkumar College, Kathiawar, Mr. J. M. Parikh, Barrister at Law, and Lieut.
('14', 306, 3, 14, 659057) Kanta Prasad, I.M.S., (retired), who has served in five different campaigns before, are now working as orderlies at Netley.

('14', 312, 1, 2, 668506) 252. LETTER TO PRAGJI DESAI
('14', 312, 2, 3, 668534) LONDON, Kartak Vad 12 [November 15, 1914] 1
('14', 312, 3, 4, 668578) DEAR PRAGJI, I have your letter.
('14', 312, 3, 5, 668611) I can well understand that you have doubts.
('14', 312, 3, 6, 668655) I think I have sent 2 to someone the replies to your questions.
('14', 312, 3, 7, 668719) All the same, I shall try to answer them again.
('14', 312, 3, 8, 668767) A satyagrahi cannot support war directly or indirectly.
('14', 312, 3, 9, 668823) There are no two opinions about that.
('14', 312, 3, 10, 668861) I am not such a perfect satyagrahi.
('14', 312, 3, 11, 668897) I am trying to be one.
('14', 312, 3, 12, 668920) Meanwhile, one should go as far as one can.
('14', 312, 3, 13, 668964) Soon after I landed here, the War started.
('14', 312, 3, 14, 669007) I spent some days thinking out my duty.
('14', 312, 3, 15, 669047) It seemed to me that to go on living in England, keeping my thoughts to myself, also amounted to taking part in the War.
('14', 312, 3, 16, 669168) It was obvious to me that, if this island were not protected by the Navy, the people would starve and they would all fall into the hands of Germans.
('14', 312, 3, 17, 669317) I am being protected, therefore, by that Navy, which means that I was indirectly supporting the War.
('14', 312, 3, 18, 669418) As a satyagrahi, it was my duty to go away to a spot where I would not need such protection and could do without the food so procured.
('14', 312, 3, 19, 669553) Such a place would be the mountains here.
('14', 312, 3, 20, 669595) There, one is not under any protection.
('14', 312, 3, 21, 669635) If the Germans took me away, I should not mind.
('14', 312, 3, 22, 669683) I must subsist on whatever fruit or grass or leaves grew on the mountains.
('14', 312, 3, 23, 669758) This food is not protected by the Navy.
('14', 312, 3, 24, 669798) I am not, however, ready for this manner of living.
('14', 312, 3, 25, 669850) I could not summon the necessary courage.
('14', 312, 3, 26, 669892) It is for cultivating such courage that I am going to India, where the circumstances are favourable.
('14', 312, 3, 27, 669993) They are not so here, and to create them here one must have an atman a hundred thousand times stronger than mine.
('14', 312, 3, 28, 670107) What is my next duty, then?
('14', 312, 3, 29, 670135) Brothers, husbands and sons have gone, rightly or wrongly, to get themselves killed, leaving behind weeping sisters, wives and mothers.
('14', 312, 3, 30, 670271) Thousands have already been killed.
('14', 312, 3, 31, 670307) And am I, doing nothing, to continue enjoying myself, eating my food?
('14', 312, 3, 32, 670377) The Gita says that he who eats without performing yajna 3 is a thief.
('14', 312, 3, 33, 670447) In the present situation here sacrifice meant, and means, self sacrifice.
('14', 312, 3, 34, 670521) I saw, therefore, that I too must
('14', 312, 4, 35, 670555) 1 In the original, Gandhiji has given Kartak Vad 3, November 6, at the top, but he says at the end of the letter that he resumed writing on November 14 and finished it on November 15. 2 Vide “Letter to Maganlal Gandhi”, 18 9 1914. 3 Sacrifice
('14', 313, 0, 1, 670798) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 313, 1, 2, 670840) perform yajna.
('14', 313, 1, 3, 670855) I myself could not shoot, bur could nurse the wounded.
('14', 313, 1, 4, 670910) I might even get Germans to nurse.
('14', 313, 1, 5, 670945) I could nurse them without any partisan spirit.
('14', 313, 1, 6, 670993) There would be no violation of the spirit of compassion then.
('14', 313, 1, 7, 671055) And so I decided to offer my services.
('14', 313, 1, 8, 671094) Now, I am not a private individual, but a public figure.
('14', 313, 1, 9, 671151) I must also talk to others.
('14', 313, 1, 10, 671179) These others are out for fighting and are not opposed to war.
('14', 313, 1, 11, 671241) I must address them; an unconditional letter, which I did.
('14', 313, 1, 12, 671300) 1 But you must have seen in it a sentence to the effect that we would unconditionally undertake any work for which we were qualified.
('14', 313, 1, 13, 671434) Everyone knows that I am not fit for active service.
('14', 313, 1, 14, 671487) I could not, therefore, be asked to fight.
('14', 313, 1, 15, 671530) This is the explanation for using the expression “unconditional”.
('14', 313, 1, 16, 671596) The main point, however, is whether I could even undertake to nurse the wounded.
('14', 313, 1, 17, 671677) I have explained it, therefore, at greater length.
('14', 313, 1, 18, 671728) It is possible you may even then remain unconvinced.
('14', 313, 1, 19, 671781) If so, write to me again.
('14', 313, 1, 20, 671807) I shall keep writing to you in reply whenever I have time.
('14', 313, 1, 21, 671866) Gradually, you will come to see the point.
('14', 313, 1, 22, 671909) It is after much deliberation that I have taken this step.
('14', 313, 1, 23, 671968) Whenever I was questioned there, I used to reply that I could not even join in ambulance work now.
('14', 313, 1, 24, 672067) You have seen that my position is still the same.
('14', 313, 1, 25, 672117) It is on a level with the idea that I must not kill a snake.
('14', 313, 1, 26, 672178) But so long as, in my cowardice, I fear a snake, I would certainly remove it to a distance, if not kill it outright.
('14', 313, 1, 27, 672295) This also is a form of violence.
('14', 313, 1, 28, 672328) If, while I am removing one, it struggles hard, I should hold it so tight between the sticks that it might bleed, and even be crushed to death.
('14', 313, 1, 29, 672472) Even so, my statement that I ought not to kill a snake would and must hold true.
('14', 313, 1, 30, 672553) So long as I have not developed absolute fearlessness, I cannot be a perfect satyagrahi.
('14', 313, 1, 31, 672642) I am striving incessantly to achieve it, and will continue to do so.
('14', 313, 1, 32, 672711) Till I have succeeded, do all of you save me [from doing anything wrong] and put up with my cowardice.
('14', 313, 1, 33, 672814) You should all keep struggling to make yourselves fearless.
('14', 313, 1, 34, 672874) Let everyone there read this letter and then send it to Medh.
('14', 313, 1, 35, 672936) Afterwards, send it on, or a copy of it, to Chi.
('14', 313, 1, 36, 672985) Maganlal, so that he, too, may have some points explained.
('14', 313, 1, 37, 673044) I have written this letter in three instalments.
('14', 313, 1, 38, 673093) I am so busy even here.
('14', 313, 1, 39, 673117) I commenced it last week, resumed it yesterday and finished it today, the [Kartak vad] 12th 2. Further news you will get from the other letters.
('14', 313, 1, 40, 673262) Sorabji is busy

('14', 314, 4, 5, 673557) 253. LETTER TO A. H. WEST
('14', 314, 5, 6, 673583) LONDON, S.W., November 20, 1914
('14', 314, 6, 7, 673615) MY DEAR WEST,
('14', 314, 7, 8, 673629) I have your welcome letter after months.
('14', 314, 7, 9, 673670) You all say that you had not heard from me at all.
('14', 314, 7, 10, 673721) That’s strange.
('14', 314, 7, 11, 673737) Certainly, not a mail has been missed by me—either I wrote myself or Sorabji for me, at least to someone or other in Phoenix.
('14', 314, 7, 12, 673863) It is evident, therefore, that my letters have all, or some of them, miscarried.
('14', 314, 7, 13, 673944) I wish that your surmise was true and that I was working among our wounded soldiers.
('14', 314, 7, 14, 674029) Most of the members of the Corps are certainly doing so, at Netley.
('14', 314, 7, 15, 674097) When the last batch went I was bedridden.
('14', 314, 7, 16, 674139) In any case, my presence was necessary here, in order to get together the required number of men.
('14', 314, 7, 17, 674237) I was to have followed, however; but now unheard of difficulties are being put in my way and am prevented from going to Netley, or to any of the other hospitals where our wounded soldiers are being received.
('14', 314, 7, 18, 674445) It seems to me that I am being prevented, because the officials immediately in charge fear that I might make mischief.
('14', 314, 7, 19, 674564) The ostensible reason given to prevent my going is ill health.
('14', 314, 7, 20, 674627) I may be quite wrong in my surmise, however.
('14', 314, 7, 21, 674672) At any rate, I have placed the whole facts before Mr. Roberts, the Under Secretary for India—and I should know before long probably.
('14', 314, 7, 22, 674805) So you will see that I have not yet been separated either from Mrs. Gandhi or Mr. Kallenbach.
('14', 314, 7, 23, 674899) We are all now living under Mr. Gandevia’s roof.
('14', 314, 7, 24, 674948) He, as you know, is the Secretary of the Corps.
('14', 314, 7, 25, 674996) He is the proprietor of a boarding house for Indian students.
('14', 314, 7, 26, 675058) He has placed one of his best rooms at our disposal.
('14', 314, 7, 27, 675111) I envy you your gardening work.
('14', 314, 7, 28, 675143) Just now my own health seems to have been completely shattered.
('14', 314, 7, 29, 675207) I feel that I hopelessly misman aged my constitution in the fast.
('14', 314, 7, 30, 675273) I was in a hurry to regain my lost energy.
('14', 314, 7, 31, 675316) I, therefore, overfed the system and overstrained the body in
('14', 315, 0, 1, 675378) 316 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 315, 1, 2, 675420) compelling myself to take long strenuous walks.
('14', 315, 1, 3, 675468) I was too impatient and am paying the penalty: I can now scarcely walk with any strenuousness without the original pain starting.
('14', 315, 1, 4, 675598) The ribs seem to have become shattered—they will not stand any strain, nor the groins.
('14', 315, 1, 5, 675685) I, therefore, am obliged largely to keep indoors and remain in bed.
('14', 315, 1, 6, 675753) Of food I can take very little—the slightest excess would upset me.
('14', 315, 1, 7, 675821) In spite of all this, I am able to attend to my work.
('14', 315, 1, 8, 675875) Nor does all this imply that I am only skin and bones.
('14', 315, 1, 9, 675930) By carefulness I am able to undo the mischief done.
('14', 315, 1, 10, 675982) The mental and moral atmosphere is also a great drawback.
('14', 315, 1, 11, 676040) Everything appears so artificial, so materialistic and immoral that one’s soul almost becomes atrophied.
('14', 315, 1, 12, 676145) I am longing to go to India and so is Mrs. Gandhi;.
('14', 315, 1, 13, 676197) but a sense of duty and—I am not sure that, on this occasion, it is a right sense of duty that compels me to remain here.
('14', 315, 1, 14, 676319) I share your views about the War.
('14', 315, 1, 15, 676353) If I had the moral strength, however, I would certainly be the passive resister that you have pictured in your letter.
('14', 315, 1, 16, 676472) I am glad that you all are getting on well there and that your little ones are doing so well and add to the joys of your life.
('14', 315, 1, 17, 676599) I hope that everything there is going on peacefully.
('14', 315, 1, 18, 676652) Please remember us to all.
('14', 315, 1, 19, 676679) I may not be writing any other letter this week so that I would like you to show this to everybody.
('14', 315, 1, 20, 676779) This letter is being taken down, you will be glad to know, by an Indian friend.
('14', 315, 1, 21, 676859) After James, he is the first Indian friend I have found capable of taking shorthand notes.
('14', 315, 1, 22, 676950) He is just now staying in the same house with me awaiting instructions to proceed to one of the hospitals where our Indian troops are.
('14', 315, 1, 23, 677085) His name is Manic Lal Chandra, and has been in England for about four years.
('14', 315, 1, 24, 677162) Mr. Chandra, from what I understand, is a much travelled man.
('14', 315, 1, 25, 677224) I shall try and write to Polak, but you may pass this letter on to him lest I fail to do so.
('14', 315, 2, 26, 677317) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('14', 315, 3, 27, 677347) From a photostat of the handwritten original signed by Gandhiji: C. W. 4416 Courtesy: A. H. West

('14', 316, 1, 2, 677489) 254. LETTER TO G. K. GOKHALE
('14', 316, 2, 3, 677518) [LONDON,] November 26, 1914
('14', 316, 3, 4, 677546) DEAR MR. GOKHALE,
('14', 316, 4, 5, 677564) I have your cable to which I have replied.
('14', 316, 4, 6, 677607) 1 I cannot bring my malady under control.
('14', 316, 4, 7, 677649) Nor can the doctors.
('14', 316, 4, 8, 677670) They would say that they could if I followed them implicitly.
('14', 316, 4, 9, 677732) This I am unable to do.
('14', 316, 4, 10, 677756) I do not want to live on any terms.
('14', 316, 4, 11, 677792) Dr. Allinson, the Vegetarian doctor, consi ders my own treatment to be perfect in the circumstances.
('14', 316, 4, 12, 677893) Dr. Mehta has been most attentive.
('14', 316, 4, 13, 677928) I listen to him wherever it is possible.
('14', 316, 4, 14, 677969) I had a serious relapse last week.
('14', 316, 4, 15, 678004) I am still in bed but much better and seemingly progressing.
('14', 316, 4, 16, 678065) Pray do not be anxious about me.
('14', 316, 4, 17, 678098) If I cannot recover, I shall try to leave for India.
('14', 316, 4, 18, 678151) We all wish that in your cable you had said something about your own health.
('14', 316, 4, 19, 678228) I hope that it is much better.
('14', 316, 4, 20, 678259) Anyhow you have now surroundings you were longing for.
('14', 316, 4, 21, 678314) I remain, Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('14', 317, 3, 6, 679351) 256. LETTER TO MAGANLAL GANDHI
('14', 317, 4, 7, 679382) Magshar Vad 2 [December 4, 1914]
('14', 317, 5, 8, 679415) MAGANLAL, I am still confined to bed.
('14', 317, 5, 9, 679453) I have sat up to write a long letter to you.
('14', 317, 5, 10, 679498) I do not know when I shall finish it.
('14', 317, 5, 11, 679536) Have no anxiety on my account.
('14', 317, 5, 12, 679567) I have a very sweet letter from Mr. Andrews.
('14', 317, 5, 13, 679612) He says that Gurudev also, on his part, will be very happy to have youall in Santiniketan.
('14', 317, 5, 14, 679703) He adds that your presence there willhelp to remove whatever unhealthy caste distinctions stillremain and that, on the whole, your visit will certainly benefit Santiniketan.
('14', 317, 5, 15, 679877) It is up to you all to see that it does.
('14', 317, 5, 16, 679918) If all our Phoenix ideals are kept up, Gurudev’s expectations are sure to befulfilled.
('14', 317, 5, 17, 680005) Let everyone of you give some service rather than ask for any.
('14', 317, 5, 18, 680068) Do not forget agriculture.
('14', 317, 5, 19, 680095) You must not think that you will not be there to enjoy the benefit of the trees you plant.
('14', 317, 5, 20, 680186) Rise earlier than the others do.
('14', 317, 5, 21, 680219) Do your own cooking, of course, but also undertake cooking for the whole establishment, if you can.
('14', 317, 5, 22, 680319) Out of respect for Gurudev and by way of inducement to you all, I have started study of Bengali in my bed.
('14', 317, 5, 23, 680426) I have completed Mrs. Murat’s grammar and the Bengali primer.
('14', 317, 5, 24, 680488) This is the fifth day.
('14', 317, 5, 25, 680511) I started the study on Monday.
('14', 317, 5, 26, 680542) Today is Friday.
('14', 317, 5, 27, 680559) I see that it is easy for a Gujarati to learn Bengali.
('14', 317, 5, 28, 680614) Everyone of you should pick it up.
('14', 317, 5, 29, 680649) The alphabet, too, is simple.
('14', 317, 5, 30, 680679) Study of Gujarati and Tamil should also continue.
('14', 317, 5, 31, 680729) Sanskrit, of course, you must be doing.
('14', 317, 5, 32, 680769) Your boarding expenses are to be borne by Gurudev.
('14', 317, 5, 33, 680820) Approach Rajangam through the Doctor for his help in Tamil.
('14', 317, 5, 34, 680880) The latter says that his sons are there.
('14', 317, 5, 35, 680921) You must be in correspondence with him.
('14', 317, 5, 36, 680961) Sendfor Maganbhai’s son.
('14', 317, 5, 37, 680986) More later.
('14', 317, 5, 38, 680998) This letter is meant for all.
('14', 317, 5, 39, 681028) Ba is pining to see you all.
('14', 317, 5, 40, 681057) Her nursing is incomparable.

('14', 318, 1, 2, 681239) 257. LETTER TO MAGANLAL GANDHI
('14', 318, 2, 3, 681270) [LONDON,] Magshar Vad 8 [December 10, 1914]
('14', 318, 3, 4, 681314) MAGANLAL,
('14', 318, 4, 5, 681324) I got the letters from all of you.
('14', 318, 4, 6, 681359) In my present helpless condition, I do not write to everyone.
('14', 318, 4, 7, 681421) Hence, take this letter as meant for all and, on your part, all of you continue to write to me.
('14', 318, 4, 8, 681517) You say you would ask me for permission for whey after I return.
('14', 318, 4, 9, 681582) But I give it straight from here.
('14', 318, 4, 10, 681616) After observing the conditions there, make any exceptions that you find necessary.
('14', 318, 4, 11, 681699) Do not wait to consult me.
('14', 318, 4, 12, 681726) Only, in all that you do, remember the need for self discipline.
('14', 318, 4, 13, 681791) You are right in concluding that agriculture is the only real prayer and service.
('14', 318, 4, 14, 681873) It is not only fitting but it is actually one’s duty to keep repeating God’s name, whether we are busy in the fields or having our meal, whether playing or wandering aimlessly, during a bath or at any other hour.
('14', 318, 4, 15, 682086) One who wants to lose himself in Rama, who is striving to do so, requires no particular hour; all the same, it is necessary to have some kind of a rule for the young.
('14', 318, 4, 16, 682253) And so the time not meant for work in the fields should be specially appointed for prayers, that is, just before daybreak, when it is still dark.
('14', 318, 4, 17, 682399) The shastras lay down that sandhya 1, etc., should be performed before dawn.
('14', 318, 4, 18, 682476) The evening hour that we have set apart is the right one.
('14', 318, 4, 19, 682534) Intensify your interest in agriculture.
('14', 318, 4, 20, 682574) Plant fruit trees.
('14', 318, 4, 21, 682593) Send for wheat from Bombay.
('14', 318, 4, 22, 682621) Use the indigenous grinding stones.
('14', 318, 4, 23, 682657) Make copra or ground nut oil at home.
('14', 318, 4, 24, 682695) You will get both milk and ghee by crushing fresh cocoanut kernel to a fine paste and straining it through a piece of cloth.
('14', 318, 4, 25, 682820) It seems this is very beneficial.
('14', 318, 4, 26, 682854) Since it is certain that you will be there for quite some time, there is nothing wrong in stocking the necessary articles.
('14', 318, 4, 27, 682977) Wheat must be available in Calcutta.
('14', 318, 4, 28, 683014) It seems they do not use tamarind there.
('14', 318, 4, 29, 683055) I have written a letter 2 to Mr. Pearson, which I think he will show you.
('14', 318, 4, 30, 683129) It will be an excellent thing if the elders among you undertake to do some service for every teacher.
('14', 318, 4, 31, 683231) As for the expenditure on all of you, that on Kuppu’s and
('14', 318, 5, 32, 683289) 1 Prayer to Sun god, usually in the morning and evening 2 This is not available.
('14', 319, 0, 1, 683370) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 319, 1, 2, 683412) Naidoo’s sons and for Maganbhai will be met from the Satyagraha Fund.
('14', 319, 1, 3, 683482) For you, Manilal and others, I shall make some arrangement.
('14', 319, 1, 4, 683542) The money for Sivapujan, Shanti and Navin is to be provided by the respective parents.
('14', 319, 1, 5, 683629) The expenses for Chhotam are to be met from the Satyagraha Fund.
('14', 319, 1, 6, 683694) From what Mr. Andrews wrote, it appeared that Gurudev would bear the expenses.
('14', 319, 1, 7, 683773) But you need not discuss the question.
('14', 319, 1, 8, 683812) Let him, if he does; if not, it should not matter.
('14', 319, 1, 9, 683863) Make everything you can with your own hands.
('14', 319, 1, 10, 683908) Get used to doing without the things which you cannot make.
('14', 319, 1, 11, 683968) If only we learn to maintain ourselves by agriculture and manual labour, there will be nothing more for us to earn or learn.
('14', 319, 1, 12, 684093) That is what I too must learn.
('14', 319, 1, 13, 684124) I may, however, pass away without doing so.
('14', 319, 1, 14, 684168) Let that not happen to you.
('14', 319, 1, 15, 684196) If Gurudev is likely to be put to inconvenience and if there is not enough room there, ask him to let you live in a tent or make some other arrangements.
('14', 319, 1, 16, 684350) Personally, I have always felt, and it now appears that there is no institution today in the world to excel Phoenix in its ideals or its way of life.
('14', 319, 1, 17, 684500) If there is any, the civilized world has not heard of it.
('14', 319, 1, 18, 684558) I am happy that all of you have the same impression.
('14', 319, 1, 19, 684611) While I am yet to recover, Ba has had an acute attack of menorrhagia since yesterday.
('14', 319, 1, 20, 684697) I do not know what God has willed.
('14', 319, 1, 21, 684732) Ba is confined to bed and so I have forced myself to get up.
('14', 319, 1, 22, 684793) Let none of you be anxious, however.
('14', 319, 1, 23, 684830) Since my diet was deficient in organic salts, Dr. Allinson 1 has advised me to take roots and tubers and leafy vegetables.
('14', 319, 1, 24, 684953) And so, even in this dangerous condition, I am making experiments.
('14', 319, 1, 25, 685020) My diet is as follows: In the morning, I have soup with two or three tea spoonfuls of dry banana brought from there 2 and ground nut, with tomatoes and a spoonful of oil added.
('14', 319, 1, 26, 685197) At noon, I take a small carrot and one half of a small raw turnip, with eight biscuits, made of wheat or banana flour, boiled.
('14', 319, 1, 27, 685324) Sometimes, in place of carrot and turnip, I take two leaves of cabbage, crushed.
('14', 319, 1, 28, 685405) In the evening, two spoonfuls of rice, boiled, with vegetables as above or dry figs, soaked in water, with a small piece of bread made of banana flour or wheat.
('14', 319, 1, 29, 685566) This is the routine at present.
('14', 319, 2, 30, 685598) 1 Dr. T. R. Allinson, author of books on health and hygiene which Gandhiji found helpful; a member of the London Vegetarian Society till he was censured for his unorthodox views on birth control 2 South Africa
('14', 320, 0, 1, 685808) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 321
('14', 320, 1, 2, 685853) The intention is to replace cooked items with uncooked articles and wheat by nuts.
('14', 320, 1, 3, 685936) I take two apples in the morning.
('14', 320, 1, 4, 685970) I have been taking raw vegetables for nearly a month now.
('14', 320, 1, 5, 686028) I have observed no harm from this at any rate.
('14', 320, 1, 6, 686075) You used to say that vegetables could be eaten raw, but I would not believe it.
('14', 320, 1, 7, 686155) I find many persons here eating vegetables raw.
('14', 320, 1, 8, 686203) The practice has many implications.
('14', 320, 1, 9, 686239) I cannot write about them, however.
('14', 320, 1, 10, 686275) Later, I may.
('14', 320, 1, 11, 686289) I have taken a final vow here not to have milk and ghee.
('14', 320, 1, 12, 686346) Doctors were very insistent, and I feared I might give in if I did not take a solemn vow.
('14', 320, 1, 13, 686436) Hereafter, I will never consume these things in this present life.
('14', 320, 1, 14, 686503) I will take other vows when I am there, though I cannot be sure that I will not take some here meanwhile, occasion arising.

('14', 322, 1, 2, 689544) 260. INTERVIEW TO REUTER 1
('14', 322, 2, 3, 689571) LONDON, December 18, 1914
('14', 322, 3, 4, 689597) In the course of an interview with Reuter, the Indian leader emphasised that the settlement made in South Africa was a most happy thing for the Indians, who were rallying to the Government in the time of the great crisis.
('14', 322, 3, 5, 689819) He had he said, the most pleasant recollections of his last interviews with General Botha and General Smuts.
('14', 322, 4, 6, 689928) Mr. Gandhi paid a tribute to the Union Government for taking into account Indian feelings, even in small matters and he was glad to be able to announce this in India.

('14', 324, 4, 8, 694789) We are keeping well considering the stormy weather.

('14', 326, 7, 15, 699411) Wonderful is the sport of God!
('14', 326, 7, 16, 699442) I have been able to leave London unexpectedly early and in an unexpected manner.
('14', 326, 7, 17, 699523) It remains to be seen whether I reach home safe.

('14', 326, 7, 19, 699635) I have been disappointed many times.
('14', 326, 7, 20, 699672) We are both keeping good health, now at any rate.
('14', 326, 7, 21, 699722) We are very careful.

('14', 326, 7, 23, 699791) We live on the food we have brought from England.
('14', 326, 7, 24, 699841) Mixing two parts banana flour and one part wheat flour, we have made biscuits and rotis.

('14', 326, 7, 26, 699975) Ripe fruit we obtain from the ship.
('14', 326, 7, 27, 700011) Ripe bananas are over, so they put half ripe bananas into the oven for ripening before giving them to us.
('14', 326, 7, 28, 700117) We have brought our own stock of groundnuts, dates, etc.
('14', 326, 7, 29, 700174) We have our meals both times only in the cabin.
('14', 326, 7, 30, 700222) We have second class tickets.
('14', 326, 7, 31, 700252) There is no third class or deck accommodation on this ship.
('14', 326, 7, 32, 700312) It is very crowded.
('14', 326, 7, 33, 700332) There is no room for moving about on the deck.
('14', 326, 7, 34, 700379) I think we should reach Bombay on January 11th or 12th.

('14', 333, 4, 9, 714092) 269. INTERVIEW TO “THE BOMBAY CHRONICLE”
('14', 333, 5, 10, 714133) January 9, 1915
('14', 333, 6, 11, 714149) On January 9, 1915, the day of his arrival in Bombay from abroad, Gandhiji was interviewed by a representative of The Bombay Chronicle.
('14', 333, 6, 12, 714285) I need hardly say that having been out of India for practically [a] quarter of a century, and without interruption for over 13 years, both my wife and I were exceedingly glad to see again the dear old Motherland, and the kind and hearty reception which the public gave us has added to the joy, and overwhelmed us.
('14', 333, 6, 13, 714599) I can only hope that by our future conduct we shall have deserved this welcome.
('14', 333, 6, 14, 714679) As the public know, I, in common with many of our countrymen, offered my services to the authorities in connection with the War.
('14', 333, 6, 15, 714808) These services were accepted, 2 and I had hoped that I should be able to render personal service in one or other of the hospitals that had been placed at the disposal of the wounded Indian soldiers.
('14', 333, 6, 16, 715007) Unfortunately, however, I was suffering from pleurisy, and the Commanding Officers in charge of the various sections would not listen to my going to any of the hospitals.
('14', 333, 6, 17, 715178) Meanwhile, Mrs. Gandhi had a relapse of an old malady, and the Under Secretary of State for India 3, on hearing this, immediately wrote to me saying that, after all, my work, so far as the organisation of the corps was concerned, was finished, and that as both of us were ill.
('14', 333, 6, 18, 715455) we should at once return to
('14', 333, 7, 19, 715483) 1 Pragji Khandubhai Desai, Gandhi’s co worker in South Africa; among the earliest to arrive at the Tolstoy Farm; taught the youngsters at the Farm and wrote regularly for the Gujarati section of Indian Opinion 2 Vide “Letter to Under Secretary for India”, 14 8 1914 3 Charles Roberts
('14', 334, 0, 1, 715767) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 335
('14', 334, 1, 2, 715812) Hence it is that we are here before our time.
('14', 334, 1, 3, 715858) I know that the public would like something with reference to the South African situation, and I can but repeat what I have said so often before, that every point on which passive resistance was directed has been completely gained, through the great assistance that was rendered by our noble Viceroy 1 and the generous public of India, led by the Hon.
('14', 334, 1, 4, 716210) Mr. Gokhale 2. I must confess that the Ministers there were very frank, and entered into the spirit of the struggle, and, as you are aware, General Smuts 3, speaking during the debate on the deportationof the leaders of the railway strike, distinguished passive resistance from the latter and justified our position.
('14', 334, 1, 5, 716527) There is now a spirit of sympathy, and, I think a desire to consult Indian opinion before undertaking any special legislation affecting us in South Africa.
('14', 334, 1, 6, 716683) I have, therefore, every hope for the future.
('14', 334, 1, 7, 716729) Not that all the disabilities have been removed, but the bulk of them have, and by proper conduct on our part, and sympathetic administration on the part of the Government, there need be no fear of a repetition of the miseries so many of us have had to go through.
('14', 334, 2, 8, 716994) Questioned as to his future movements, Mr. Gandhi said he had come to India to settle here, and he would not go back to Africa unless circumstances rendered it necessary.
('14', 334, 2, 9, 717165) He did not know what he would do here, but he would be at the service of Mr. Gokhale, whom he had for years recognised as his guide and leader, and his movements would be largely controlled and directed by him.
('14', 334, 2, 10, 717376) Mr. Gandhi concluded: For the present, as Mr. Gokhale has very properly pointed out, 4
('14', 334, 3, 11, 717463) I, having been out of India for so long, have no business to form any definite conclusions about matters essentially Indian, and that I should pass some time here as an observer and a student.
('14', 334, 3, 12, 717656) This I have promised to do, and I hope to carry out my promise.
('14', 334, 4, 13, 717720) The Bombay Chronicle, 11 1 1915

('14', 335, 1, 2, 718022) 270. INTERVIEW TO “THE TIMES OF INDIA”
('14', 335, 2, 3, 718061) January 9, 1915
('14', 335, 3, 4, 718077) Questioned regarding the position of Indians in South Africa, he [Gandhiji] said that it was much better than it was before the settlement, all the points to which passive resistance was applied having been gained.
('14', 335, 3, 5, 718292) He thought that on the whole the Indian community was satisfied with the “relieving legislation” 1 that had been passed.
('14', 335, 3, 6, 718413) The future, he said, very largely depended upon the Indians themselves, as well as on the personnel of the Ministry.
('14', 335, 3, 7, 718530) One great thing which I think has been attained is that the Government have recognised that, in any legislation affecting the British Indians in South Africa, Indians should be consulted and their wishes respected as far as possible.
('14', 335, 3, 8, 718764) This I think to be an advance in the right direction.
('14', 335, 3, 9, 718818) This happy result has no doubt been arrived at owing to the valuable assistance afforded to our great and righteous cause by H. E. Lord Hardinge and the magnificent response made bythe Motherland under the spirited guidance of my esteemed friend, the Hon.
('14', 335, 3, 10, 719074) Mr. Gokhale.
('14', 335, 4, 11, 719087) Describing the present attitude of the Indian settlers in South Africa, Mr. Gandhi said there was no hesitation on the part of the whole community in offering their services to the local and Imperial Governments during the war.
('14', 335, 4, 12, 719315) Though the occasion for the acceptance of the services had not arisen, the offer was much appreciated by the Governments.
('14', 335, 4, 13, 719437) Mr. Gandhi added that on the whole the present Ministry 2 was not unsympathetic and, as it understood Indian questions, was probably better able to understand the Indian mind and therefore better calculated to advance Indian interests than any other Ministry.
('14', 335, 4, 14, 719697) The material position of the Indians in the colony was not all that could be desired, but its improvement depended upon the future commercial outlook.
('14', 335, 5, 15, 719848) Mr. Gandhi said that he intended to devote his time to study Indian problems during the remainder of his life and he did not propose to return to the scene of his former activities unless some unforeseen call was made upon him.
('14', 335, 6, 16, 720076) The Times of India, 11 1 1915

('14', 336, 1, 2, 720260) 271. SPEECH AT RECEPTION, GHATKOPAR
('14', 336, 2, 3, 720296) January 11, 1915
('14', 336, 3, 4, 720313) At a reception to Mr. and Mrs. M. K..
('14', 336, 3, 5, 720351) Gandhi at Ghatkopar [Bombay] on Monday, Mr. Gandhi was presented with an address enclosed in a silver casket, with fetters made of gold, Rao Bahadur Vassanji Khimji presiding.
('14', 336, 4, 6, 720527) Mr. Gandhi, in acknowledging the gifts, described the silver casket and the fetters as somewhat unsuitable to a person who had neither a roof over his head nor locked doors to his house.
('14', 336, 4, 7, 720714) Fetters, whether of gold or of iron, were the same to him, as they were fetters after all.
('14', 336, 4, 8, 720805) A function like the one they held, he said, was most uncongenial to him, and the temptations it involved would tend to spoil a person like him whose only thought was to serve his Motherland, irrespective of praise or blame, with no expectation of any reward whatsoever.
('14', 336, 5, 9, 721075) The only idea behind his work was duty.
('14', 336, 5, 10, 721115) He had only been able to do so far one anna of it and he had returned to his country after all these years to try his best to do what he could of the other 15 annas in the years that were left to him.
('14', 336, 5, 11, 721316) He hoped for nothing and wished for nothing, beyond being able to fulfil the duty that lay before him.
('14', 336, 5, 12, 721419) He entreated them all to accept whatever service he could give, and not to give him costly presents which he could not use, and which could be put to far better uses.
('14', 336, 5, 13, 721586) He sincerely trusted that they would not misunderstand him; he was only expressing his innermost feelings.
('14', 336, 6, 14, 721693) The Bombay Chronicle, 15 1 1915

('14', 338, 4, 7, 725008) 273. SPEECH AT PUBLIC RECEPTION, BOMBAY
('14', 338, 5, 8, 725048) January 12, 1915
('14', 338, 6, 9, 725065) A public reception was accorded by the elite of Bombay to Gandhiji and Shrimati Kasturba Gandhi at Mount Petit, on January 12, 1915, over 600 distinguished citizens being present, including Europeans.
('14', 338, 6, 10, 725266) The Hon.
('14', 338, 6, 11, 725275) Sir Pherozeshah Mehta 2, who presided, warmly welcomed the guests of the evening.
('14', 338, 7, 12, 725357) Replying to the toast, Mr. Gandhi said that he did not know that the right word would come to him to express the feelings that had stirred within him that afternoon.
('14', 338, 7, 13, 725523) He had felt that he would be more at home in his own Motherland than he used to be in South Africa among their own countrymen.
('14', 338, 7, 14, 725650) But during the three days that they had passed in Bombay, they had felt—and he thought he was voicing the feelings of his wife, too—that they were much more at home among those indentured Indians, who were the truest heroes of India.
('14', 338, 7, 15, 725884) They felt that they were indeed in strange company here in Bombay, and that reminded himof one thing said to him by a great Englishman, namely, that duty would be merited [sic] at the last.
('14', 338, 8, 16, 726074) In what he had done, he had done nothing beyond his duty and it remained to be seen how far he had succeeded in doing his duty.
('14', 338, 8, 17, 726202) That was not a mere lip expression but he asked them to believe sincerely that these were his feelings.
('14', 338, 8, 18, 726306) He felt all that his elders had done for him, all that his political leaders had done for him, all that Sir Pherozeshah Mehta had done for him and he could recall many an incident when he, i.e., Sir Pherozeshah Mehta, had cheered him up while he was a young briefless barrister in his disappointments.
('14', 338, 8, 19, 726608) He had had the honour of receiving instruction, guidance, and advice from many other distinguished countrymen of his own, and

('14', 339, 1, 9, 727720) They were paying these regards to them, who were but poor creatures, while the real heroes were the indentured labourers.
('14', 339, 1, 10, 727842) He wished to remind them of the indentured Indian that staggered him in jail.
('14', 339, 1, 11, 727920) When he met that Indian, he did not know what inspired the latter to go to jail, and what inspired him to utter the words he did utter.
('14', 339, 1, 12, 728056) He told the Indian that there was no occasion for him to go there and that he had never advised such of his countrymen as Harbat Singh 2 to go there.
('14', 339, 1, 13, 728206) But that old Indian said that he could not restrain himself from going there when he saw his poor brothers and sisters go there for the honour of the country.
('14', 339, 1, 14, 728365) How could he leave himself out, he asked, and added that he wanted to die there.
('14', 339, 1, 15, 728446) They were alive and he was dead.
('14', 339, 1, 16, 728479) That man was the hero and there were many of his type.
('14', 339, 1, 17, 728534) If he had lived and come out to India, they would not have noticed him, perhaps he too would not have noticed him.
('14', 339, 1, 18, 728649) All honour was due to the memory of Harbat Singh.
('14', 339, 2, 19, 728699) They had also honoured Mrs. Gandhi as the wife of the great Gandhi.
('14', 339, 2, 20, 728767) He had no knowledge of the great Gandhi, but he could say that she could tell them more about the sufferings of women who rushed with babies to jail and who had now joined the majority than he could.
('14', 339, 3, 21, 728967) In conclusion, Mr. Gandhi appealed to them to accept the services of himself and his wife for, he said, they had come to render such service as God would enable them to do.
('14', 339, 3, 22, 729140) They had not come to receive big entertainments like that because they did not think they were worthy of such presents.
('14', 339, 3, 23, 729260) He felt that they would only spoil them if ever by such action a thought crossed their minds that they had done something to deserve such a big tamasha made in their honour.
('14', 339, 3, 24, 729434) He, however, thanked them on behalf of his wife and himself most sincerely for the great honour done to them that afternoon and he hoped to receive the blessings of the whole country in their endeavour to serve the Motherland.
('14', 339, 3, 25, 729661) Hitherto, he said, they had known nothing

('14', 340, 3, 7, 730551) 274. SPEECH AT NATIONAL UNION MEETING AT BOMBAY
('14', 340, 4, 8, 730599) January 13, 1915
('14', 340, 5, 9, 730616) At a meeting convened by the Bombay National Union at Hirabag [Bombay] on the 13th instant to welcome Mr. and Mrs. Gandhi, Mr. Tilak 1 was present, though no formal invitation was sent to him.
('14', 340, 5, 10, 730809) The meeting was attended by about 250 persons.
('14', 340, 5, 11, 730856) Mr. Tilak addressing the gathering said that they were only doing their duty in honouring Mr. and Mrs. Gandhi, as they had fought for the honour of India in a distant land.
('14', 340, 5, 12, 731029) He said that India ought to produce more men and women of the self sacrificing spirit of the honoured guests, and impressed upon the audience that this was the lesson they had to learn from the career of Mr. Gandhi.
('14', 340, 6, 13, 731245) Mr. Gandhi’s speech was colourless and formal; he expressed the gratefulness of the Indians in South Africa to the mother country which contributed lavishly to the fund 2 for their relief during the late struggle.
('14', 340, 6, 14, 731459) He said it was a pleasure to meet Mr. Tilak in Bombay as he fully intended to pay his respects to him when he visited Poona.
('14', 340, 7, 15, 731584) Mr. Baptista said that it did not matter whom Mr. Gandhi selected as his guru (this refers to a remark made by Mr. Gandhi that Mr. Gokhale was his guru), so long as he always held before him the ideals of honour and self respect, as he had done throughout his life.
('14', 340, 7, 16, 731850) Both he and Mr. Ali Muhammad Bhimji referred to the gallantconduct of the Indian troops in support of the cause of right in the present war.

('14', 341, 1, 2, 732244) 275. SPEECH AT SERVANTS OF INDIA SOCIETY, BOMBAY
('14', 341, 2, 3, 732293) January 14, 1915
('14', 341, 3, 4, 732310) The premises of the Servants of India Society’s 1 Home in Bombay were tastefully decorated for the entertainment that was given to Mr. & Mrs. Gandhi on the evening of 14th January by the members of the Bombay Branch of the Society and by some of those who were associated with it as its helpers, supporters and co workers....Among those present were Sir Bhalchandra Krishna, Sir Vithaldas Thakersey, Sir Jagmohandas, Shet Dani, Shet Hansraj Pragjee, Mrs. Ramabai Ranade, Lady Jagmohandas, Mrs. Sonabai Jayker, Mrs. Bahadurjee and others.
('14', 341, 3, 5, 732848) On the arrival of Mr. and Mrs. Gandhi, Mr. Devadhar spoke on behalf of those that were assembled.
('14', 341, 3, 6, 732946) Mr. Gandhi, then, in the course of a brief speech, said that he was proud to have seen so many men and women who helped the Servant of India Society, which would soon be the sphere of his work.
('14', 341, 3, 7, 733140) He had accepted Mr. Gokhale as his political leader and guide and he considered those people fortunate who had the privilege of being associated with Mr. Gokhale in their work.
('14', 341, 3, 8, 733317) He would go over the country for one year and, after studying things for himself, he would decide his line of work.
('14', 341, 3, 9, 733433) In conclusion, he thanked all the ladies and gentlemen, on his behalf as well as on behalf of his wife, for the honour they did them.
('14', 341, 4, 10, 733567) Sir Bhalchandra garlanded Mr. Gandhi and Mrs. Ramabai garlanded Mrs. Gandhi.
('14', 341, 4, 11, 733644) After the distribution of flowers, etc., the whole assembly partook [of] refreshments.

('14', 341, 6, 13, 733757) 276. SPEECH AT GURJAR SABHA RECEPTION, BOMBAY 2
('14', 341, 7, 14, 733805) January 14, 1915
('14', 341, 8, 15, 733822) A garden party in honour of Gandhiji and Shrimati Kasturba Gandhi was given by members of the Gurjar Sabha, Bombay, on the grounds of Mangaldas House, on January 14, 1915. Messrs M. A. Jinnah 3, Chairman of the Sabha, who presided on the occasion, and K. M. Munshi 4 having spoken (in English) welcoming the guests,
('14', 341, 9, 16, 734138) 1 Founded by Gokhale in 1905 with headquarters in Poona, the members being life workers in the service of the nation 2 A brief report of this also appeared in Gujarati, 17 1 1915. 3 Mohammad Ali Jinnah (1876 1948), Muslim leader, founder and first Governor General of Pakistan 4 (1887 ), lawyer, politician and author; founder and President of Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan; Governor of U.P., 1952 7
('14', 342, 0, 1, 734531) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 343
('14', 342, 1, 2, 734576) Gandhiji replied as follows:
('14', 342, 2, 3, 734605) Mr. Gandhi, who spoke in Gujarati, thanked Mr. Jinnah for presiding at this function and said that while he was in South Africa and anything was said about Gujaratis, it was understood to have a reference to the Hindu community only and Parsis and Mahomedans were not thought of.
('14', 342, 2, 4, 734885) He was, therefore, glad to find a Mahomedan a member of the Gurjar Sabha and the chairman of that function.
('14', 342, 3, 5, 734993) With regard to their words of praise and welcome, he was at a loss to say anything.
('14', 342, 3, 6, 735077) As he had said so often before, he and his wife had done nothing beyond their duty.
('14', 342, 3, 7, 735161) He did not wish to repeat the same thing, but he desired to say that he considered all these good feelings and kind words as their blessings and he prayed to God.
('14', 342, 3, 8, 735324) that those blessings might enable him and his wife faithfully to serve their country.
('14', 342, 3, 9, 735410) They first intended to study all the Indian questions and then enter upon the service of the country.
('14', 342, 3, 10, 735512) He had looked upon the Hon.
('14', 342, 3, 11, 735540) Mr. Gokhale as his guide and leader and he had full confidence in him and he was sure that Mr. Gokhale would not put him on the wrong track.
('14', 342, 3, 12, 735681) He had visited His Excellency the Governor 1 that morning and while thanking him for the honour, he also mentioned the same thing that he was absolutely confident that under the guiding spirit of the Hon.
('14', 342, 3, 13, 735886) Mr. Gokhale he would be adopting the right course.
('14', 342, 4, 14, 735937) Continuing, Mr. Gandhi said that the chairman had referred to the South African question.
('14', 342, 4, 15, 736027) He had a good deal to say on this subject and he would explain the whole situation in the very near future to the Bombay public and through them to the whole of India.
('14', 342, 4, 16, 736195) The compromise was satisfactory and he trusted that what had remained to be gained would be gained.
('14', 342, 4, 17, 736295) The South Africans had now learnt that they could not utterly disregard the Indians or disrespect their feelings.
('14', 342, 5, 18, 736409) With regard to the Hindu Mahomedan question he had much to learn, but he would always keep before his eyes his twenty one years’ experience in South Africa and he still remembered that one sentence uttered by Sir Syed Ahmed 2, namely, that the Hindus and Mahomedans were the two eyes of Mother India and if one looked at one end and the other at the other, neither would be able to see anything and that if one was gone, the other would see to that extent only.
('14', 342, 5, 19, 736871) Both the communities had to bear this in mind in the future.
('14', 342, 6, 20, 736932) In conclusion, he thanked them for the great honour done to him and his wife.
('14', 342, 7, 21, 737010) The Bombay Chronicle, 15 1 1915
('14', 342, 8, 22, 737042) 1 Lord Willingdon 2 Sir Syed Ahmed Khan (1817 98), educationist and reformer; founder of the Mahomedan Anglo Oriental College at Aligarh

('14', 344, 1, 2, 738394) 279. SPEECH AT RAJKOT IN REPLY TO CITIZENS ADDRESS 1
('14', 344, 2, 3, 738447) January 17, 1915
('14', 344, 3, 4, 738464) I have not been keeping very fit and, during the last thirty six hours, my health has gone down very badly; but I have conserved my strength as much as possible in order to be able to visit my native town, Rajkot.
('14', 344, 3, 5, 738678) Coming here, I fully realize what a loss I have suffered in the death of Shri Kevalrambhai, whom I respected as an elder.
('14', 344, 3, 6, 738800) This is a painful thought to me.
('14', 344, 3, 7, 738833) I have been laid under an obligation by Shri Pandit who has won the affection [of the people] of this Province by his fine qualities and who has expressed good wishes for me.
('14', 344, 3, 8, 739008) I regard it as my good fortune, moreover, that in the absence of Shri Kavelrambhai I have been presented this address by you, a friend of his.
('14', 344, 3, 9, 739151) His Excellency the Governor told me that the spontaneous demonstration of popular feeling towards me suggested that I was likely to have a fruitful career.
('14', 344, 3, 10, 739307) I have had today first hand proof of the truth of this.
('14', 344, 3, 11, 739363) The daughter of my friend, Mr. Shukla 2, was the first to put a tilak on me and garland me.
('14', 344, 3, 12, 739455) I look upon this as a blessing.
('14', 344, 3, 13, 739487) The honour I have been receiving in Rajkot is beyond all bounds.
('14', 344, 3, 14, 739552) In India it has become a kind of custom to accord such excessive honour.
('14', 344, 3, 15, 739625) Hills, they say, look pleasing from a distance; you have only heard my praises.
('14', 344, 3, 16, 739705) But we have done nothing in particular.
('14', 344, 3, 17, 739745) We have come here only as novices ready to learn.
('14', 344, 3, 18, 739795) Everyone must have observed that nowadays people work with a variety of motives.
('14', 344, 3, 19, 739876) It is extremely difficult to know what is in the heart of any individual.
('14', 344, 3, 20, 739950) We are now in India and you will find it easier to form a correct opinion about us from what we do.
('14', 344, 3, 21, 740050) The world is full of selfish men, who work with some ulterior motive or other.
('14', 344, 3, 22, 740129) But to work in this manner is like mixing poison in milk.
('14', 344, 3, 23, 740187) We have much to learn from Kathiawar and, when we have gone through the training, you will have an opportunity of testing us.
('14', 344, 3, 24, 740313) I must tell you, however, that you will then see our failures also; I ask of you that [even then] you should keep up, unimpaired, the love which you have shown today.
('14', 344, 3, 25, 740480) Let the rest of the
('14', 344, 4, 26, 740500) 1 Bejonji Meherwanji Damri, the Dewan of Rajkot, presiding 2 A barrister practising at Rajkot; friend and fellow student of Gandhiji
('14', 345, 0, 1, 740633) 346 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 345, 1, 2, 740675) country forsake me, if it will, because of any failure of mine; if the people of Rajkot even then overlook my shortcomings with a generous heart I shall believe that your expression of love today was really the result of genuine feeling.
('14', 345, 1, 3, 740913) This love of yours will be put to the test at that time.
('14', 345, 1, 4, 740970) As for our achievements in South Africa, I tell you that people of lower standing than ours did a thousand times better work than we.
('14', 345, 1, 5, 741104) An old man of 75 and a young girl of 17 both died in jail.
('14', 345, 1, 6, 741163) 1 I am a barrister and it is natural, therefore, that I should feel impelled to work.
('14', 345, 1, 7, 741249) But innumerable men and women, poor souls, gave their lives in the service of the nation, suffering the hardships of Jail life, merely because of their faith and as a matter of duty.
('14', 345, 1, 8, 741432) What honour will you do to them?
('14', 345, 1, 9, 741465) These persons, like truly heroic spirits, sacrificed their lives.
('14', 345, 1, 10, 741531) Accepting, now, this honour you have done to us as a form of blessing, we dedicate our services to the country and declare here that we should be thought of as good children of Rajkot if we always show ourselves keen on doing our duty; but as unworthy ones if we are found to be remiss.

('14', 354, 3, 4, 754777) Truthfulness, brahmacharya, non violence, non stealing and non hoarding, these five rules of life are obligatory on all aspirants.
('14', 354, 3, 5, 754908) Everyone should be an aspirant.
('14', 354, 3, 6, 754940) A man’s character, therefore, is tobe built on the foundation of these disciplines.
('14', 354, 3, 7, 755024) Beyond doubt, they are to be observed by everyone in the world.
('14', 354, 3, 8, 755088) Though a business man, one must never utter or practise untruth; though married, one must remain celibate; though keeping oneself alive, one can practise non violence.
('14', 354, 3, 9, 755256) It is difficult to be of the world and yet not to steal (to observe the rule of non stealing) and not to hoard wealth or any other thing.
('14', 354, 3, 10, 755394) One must, nevertheless, keep that as an ideal to be attained and have some limit in these respects; when the mind has begun to turn away from these things, one may even embrace the supreme renunciation.
('14', 354, 3, 11, 755597) Everyone who observes these vows will be able to find a way out of all perplexities.

('14', 357, 4, 12, 759889) 299. REPLIES TO QUESTIONS AT POONA MEETINGS
('14', 357, 5, 13, 759933) February 11/12, 1915
('14', 357, 6, 14, 759954) Mr. Gandhi came to Poona on Monday morning .
('14', 357, 6, 15, 759999) was garlanded at several places during his drive through the city to the buildings of the Servants of India Society, where he put up.
('14', 357, 6, 16, 760133) On Thursday evening the Deccan Sabha met him in a friendly gathering.
('14', 357, 6, 17, 760203) The next evening he was treated to a friendly party by the Sarvajanik Sabha in its hall.
('14', 357, 6, 18, 760292) Mr. Gandhi’s conversation at both these conversazione parties was most enjoyable and edifying.
('14', 357, 6, 19, 760387) To see the living embodiment of simple life and high thoughts was an education in itself.
('14', 357, 6, 20, 760477) His unassuming demeanour and free and hearty talk were revelations of the pure and burning spirit within.
('14', 357, 6, 21, 760583) He was asked several questions to which he gave straightforward replies.
('14', 357, 7, 22, 760656) Asked about his future plans he replied that he had not yet settled anything and that it was not certain that he would join the Servants of India Society.
('14', 357, 8, 23, 760811) Respecting South Africa he was asked why it was that some people there still complained that the question was not yet finally and satisfactorily determined and in what sense he thought it finally settled.
('14', 357, 8, 24, 761016) Mr. Gandhi replied by pointing out the difference between grievances for which people were ready to sacrifice property and life—in fact, become passive resisters—and grievances which were not felt so acutely.
('14', 357, 8, 25, 761225) There was a settlement as far as the former kind of grievances were concerned, though there remained others such as those relating to locations and racial distinctions on tramways and railways, towards the removal of which attempts still
('14', 357, 9, 26, 761463) 1 Gandhiji’s eldest son
('14', 358, 0, 1, 761487) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 359
('14', 358, 1, 2, 761532) must be made.
('14', 358, 1, 3, 761546) But these latter, though serious, were not felt so acutely as to justify the initiation or continuation of the Passive Resistance Movement.
('14', 358, 2, 4, 761686) Asked wherefrom exactly the pressure came upon the Union Govt.,— what exactly as the difficulty which in a way forced that Govt.
('14', 358, 2, 5, 761815) to yield, he replied that it was the favourable European public opinion in the colony which made it possible for the Passive Resistance Movement to succeed.
('14', 358, 2, 6, 761972) He recognised the value of the representations of the Indian Government and the Imperial Government, but he thought all these would not have availed much, had the passive resisters not the advantage of the sympathy of the general European public towards their cause.
('14', 358, 2, 7, 762239) The passive resisters, weak, indigent and unarmed as they were; could not have marched in the way they did in a foreign and alien country had not the tacit sympathy of the general population been on their side.
('14', 358, 2, 8, 762450) In their march they emptied tanks of water belonging to the Europeans with impunity and even without much remonstrance, and that was saying much in a country where water was very deficient.
('14', 358, 2, 9, 762640) Some of the white settlers even helped the marching party with food.
('14', 358, 2, 10, 762709) One of the passive resisters was tempted to steal a blanket but he was not prosecuted by the European owner but generously forgiven.
('14', 358, 2, 11, 762842) That showed the attitude of the general public of white settlers.
('14', 358, 2, 12, 762908) The Bantoos, that is, the original settlers, were not at all hostile, but favourable, if anything, to the Indian cause.
('14', 358, 2, 13, 763028) The opposition came mainly from some Boers and the trading and industrial classes of the European white population.
('14', 358, 2, 14, 763144) The planters and the traders—those were the strong opponents of Indian claims.
('14', 358, 2, 15, 763223) The traders did not stand competition with the Indian merchants and hawkers.
('14', 358, 2, 16, 763300) The planters opposed the Indians but they could not do without Indian labour.
('14', 358, 3, 17, 763378) Asked whether the traders and planters wanted to send Indians bag and baggage back to India, Mr. Gandhi said that the planters wanted Indians very badly—but only as indentured labourers.
('14', 358, 3, 18, 763565) The plantations would be waste lands without Indians.
('14', 358, 3, 19, 763619) Indigenous labour was not so steady and skilful as the Indian.
('14', 358, 3, 20, 763682) In fact it was the Indians who were largely contributing to the industrial prosperity of the colony.
('14', 358, 3, 21, 763783) And Mr. Gandhi clinched his point by remarking that he had always said to the planters to boycott Indians, if they really did not want them.
('14', 358, 3, 22, 763924) That was in their hands and Indians could not have legally complained about it.
('14', 358, 3, 23, 764004) But the Indians were useful labourers and traders and they could not be spared—that was why they were not boycotted.
('14', 358, 4, 24, 764121) Asked whether there were any temples for Hindus and mausoleums of the Mahomedans, he said there were some but they were more or less apologies of temples and mausoleums.
('14', 358, 4, 25, 764291) He knew the priests there, and he was obviously sad when he had to speak of their character.
('14', 358, 5, 26, 764384) Asked how people from different provinces managed to speak with each other, he proudly referred to Hindi.
('14', 358, 5, 27, 764490) As to social customs, he said that there was inter dining among the different sections of the Hindus, but not intermarriage.

('14', 359, 1, 2, 764657) To the question, whether the Indians there would be absorbed by the population of their country of adoption, he had to give an emphatic “No”—thanks to the Indian civilization.

('14', 360, 4, 8, 766959) 301. SPEECH AT POONA PUBLIC MEETING
('14', 360, 5, 9, 766995) February 13, 1915
('14', 360, 6, 10, 767013) On Saturday Mr. Gandhi visited the Anath Balikashram of Prof.
('14', 360, 6, 11, 767075) Karve 2, the Fergusson College and the Anandashram, at all of which places he was warmly welcomed.
('14', 360, 6, 12, 767174) In the evening there was a public meeting held in the Kirloskar Theatre.
('14', 360, 6, 13, 767247) The speakers were Sirdar Nowroji Padamji, the President, Sir R. G. Bhandarker 3 and Mr. Wadia.
('14', 360, 7, 14, 767342) Mr. Gandhi made an appropriate reply in which he referred to Poona as a place of learning, culture and noted for the spirit of self sacrifice of its citizens—a city which, whether he made his future ‘home’ or not, would be considered by him and his wife as a sacred place of pilgrimage.
('14', 360, 7, 15, 767629) He had, he said, rendered very little service to the country, but what little he rendered had raised such high expectations about him that he feared, they perhaps would be disappointed and he prayed that in case he disappointed the people’s hopes about himself, he would be judged in a spirit of generosity and forgiveness.
('14', 360, 7, 16, 767953) He closed his speech remarking that his guide and teacher 4 had asked him to endeavour to close his lips and keep open his ears for some time.
('14', 360, 7, 17, 768096) He finished off his nice little speech with expressing thanks for the honour done to him and hoping to be judged generously if he slipped in future.

('14', 361, 2, 3, 768863) February 14, 1915
('14', 361, 3, 4, 768881) It seems India is now under the deadly sway of the Iron Age.
('14', 361, 3, 5, 768942) I have been moving about in this country for a month and seen on what an enormous scale fraud is prevalent here.
('14', 361, 3, 6, 769055) I had firmly resolved that for twelve months I would go round everywhere, keeping my ears open and hear everything, but address no meeting and express no opinion on any subject.
('14', 361, 3, 7, 769233) But I must advise you, students, to read these prize books carefully, to reflect over their real import and, keeping in mind all the profound truths set out in them, follow the path enjoined by religion.
('14', 361, 3, 8, 769437) Whether you are a girl or a boy, you will grow up one day and have to carry a heavy burden of worldly duties; give some thought, therefore, to the future.
('14', 361, 3, 9, 769592) Truth is revealed not only in our scriptures but in the scriptures of other religions as well.
('14', 361, 4, 10, 769687) It is the duty of students to assimilate whatever they have learnt.
('14', 361, 4, 11, 769755) They should have religious and moral instruction, as much of it as they can usefully apply.
('14', 361, 4, 12, 769847) They need education in such measure that it would not become too much of a useless burden on them.
('14', 361, 4, 13, 769946) I should like to address a few words exclusively to students.
('14', 361, 4, 14, 770008) Men and women students, you will benefit from what you have learnt only to the extent that you have assimilated it.
('14', 361, 4, 15, 770124) That should be the object of this institution too.
('14', 361, 4, 16, 770175) You should ponder over the element of truth in whatever books of religion you read.
('14', 361, 4, 17, 770259) If you cling to truth, success is yours.
('14', 361, 4, 18, 770300) I would advise you, from my experience, to profit well from your education.
('14', 361, 4, 19, 770376) That will be to your advantage and to your country’s as well.

('14', 365, 16, 20, 775891) February 20, 1915
('14', 365, 17, 21, 775909) My one desire tonight is that my heart may reach your hearts and that there should be a real at one ment between us.
('14', 365, 17, 22, 776026) You have all learnt something about Tulsidas’s Ramayana.

('14', 366, 1, 2, 776287) most stirring part is that about the companionship of the good.
('14', 366, 1, 3, 776351) We should seek the company of those who have suffered and served and died.
('14', 366, 1, 4, 776426) One such was Mr. Gokhale.
('14', 366, 1, 5, 776452) He is dead, but his work is not dead, for his spirit lives.
('14', 366, 1, 6, 776512) The masses came to know of Gokhale’s efficiency in work.
('14', 366, 1, 7, 776569) All know Gokhale’s life of action.
('14', 366, 1, 8, 776604) But few know of his religious life.
('14', 366, 1, 9, 776640) Truth was the spring of all his actions.
('14', 366, 2, 10, 776681) This was behind all his works, even his politics.
('14', 366, 2, 11, 776731) This was the reason he founded the Servants of India Society, the ideal of which was to spiritualise the political as well as the social life of the nation.
('14', 366, 2, 12, 776888) It was fearlessness which ruled all the actions of his life.
('14', 366, 2, 13, 776949) But as he was fearless he was also thorough.
('14', 366, 2, 14, 776994) One of his favourite shlokas 2
('14', 366, 3, 15, 777025) from the shastras says: Real wisdom is not to begin a thing but to see the thing through to the end.
('14', 366, 3, 16, 777126) This characteristic of thoroughness may be seen from this incident.
('14', 366, 3, 17, 777194) He once had to speak to a large audience andhe spent three days in order to prepare a short speech for this meeting and he asked me to write out a speech for him.
('14', 366, 3, 18, 777357) I wrote out the speech.
('14', 366, 3, 19, 777381) He took it and smiled his heavenly smile, discussed it with me and said, “Give me something better, rewrite it.” For three days he worried over it.
('14', 366, 3, 20, 777529) When the speech was given, it thrilled the whole audience.
('14', 366, 3, 21, 777588) He delivered his speeches without notes, but he did so, because he was so thorough, that one might say he wrote his speeches with his own blood.
('14', 366, 3, 22, 777733) As he was thorough and fearless, so he was gentle.
('14', 366, 3, 23, 777784) He was human from top to toe in all his dealings.
('14', 366, 3, 24, 777834) He was sometimes impatient, but he would ask forgiveness, coming forward with his smile, whether to a servant or a great man, saying, “I know you will forgive me, won’t you?” He had a great struggle during the latter days of his life, a struggle with his conscience.
('14', 366, 3, 25, 778101) He had to decide whether he should continue to take part in a struggle at the expense of his health.
('14', 366, 3, 26, 778202) His conscience ruled every action of his life.
('14', 366, 3, 27, 778249) He did not wear it on his sleeve, he wore it in his heart.
('14', 366, 3, 28, 778308) Therefore he is living still, and may we all have the strength to carry out his last wish.
('14', 366, 3, 29, 778399) His last words to those members of the Servants of India Society who were with him were: “I do not want any memorial or any statue.
('14', 366, 3, 30, 778531) I want only that men should love their country and serve it with their lives.” This is a message for

('14', 367, 1, 4, 778859) His love for India was truthful and therefore he wanted nothing for India which he did not want for humanity also.

('14', 368, 1, 2, 780480) 310. LETTER TO CHIEF TRAFFIC MANAGER, E. I. RAILWAY
('14', 368, 2, 3, 780532) SERVANTS OF INDIA SOCIETY, POONA CITY, [February 23, 1915] 1
('14', 368, 3, 4, 780593) THE TRAFFIC MANAGER EAST INDIAN RAILWAY CALCUTTA
('14', 368, 5, 5, 780642) Mrs. Gandhi, two friends and I travelled on the 21st instant by the 3 up mail from Burdwan to Kalyan en route for Poona.
('14', 368, 5, 6, 780763) We were holders of 3rd class tickets Nos.
('14', 368, 5, 7, 780805) 7186 to 7189. Upon the train steaming in, I found that the 3rd class compartment was uncomfortably crowded containing far more passengers than the number specified on the label.
('14', 368, 5, 8, 780983) However, we tried to get in.
('14', 368, 5, 9, 781012) The station clerk who was standing by prevented us from doing so.
('14', 368, 5, 10, 781078) I suggested that we would stand in the carriage as it was necessary for us to reach Poona at the earliest possible moment.
('14', 368, 5, 11, 781201) The clerk would not listen to me.
('14', 368, 5, 12, 781235) I then suggested that we should travel in an intermediate compartment until we could find accommodation in the 3rd class carriage.
('14', 368, 5, 13, 781366) This suggestion was accepted.
('14', 368, 5, 14, 781396) We got into an intermediate carriage.
('14', 368, 5, 15, 781434) The station clerk duly reported the matter to the guard who insisted that we must pay the difference between the 3rd class and intermediate fares as far as Jubbulpore or we should not travel by mail train at all and go by the passenger train which was to follow.
('14', 368, 5, 16, 781697) I protested but my protest was of no avail.
('14', 368, 5, 17, 781741) I had therefore no alternative but to consent under protest to pay the difference which was taken from me at Assansol.
('14', 368, 5, 18, 781860) The excess fare ticket number was 274577. Ipaid Rs. 19 12 0. I asked the ticket master to note on the ticket that I paid the excess fare under protest.
('14', 368, 5, 19, 782012) He disregarded my request.

('14', 369, 1, 2, 782388) 3rd class compartment but he declined to do so.
('14', 369, 1, 3, 782436) I submit that, in the circumstances above mentioned, my party should have been found seats in the 3rd class compartment, failing that, permitted to travel intermediate without extra fare until the pressure had been removed; in any case it was unfair to insist on excess fare being paid as far as Jubbulpore and that as my party actually transferred to the 3rd class compartment at Mughalsarai, there is no warrant for the retention of the excess fare between Mughalsarai and Jubbulpore.
('14', 369, 1, 4, 782923) I trust that the Railway Administration will direct a refund of the full excess fare.
('14', 369, 1, 5, 783009) I have thought it to be my duty to bring this matter to your notice, as; much for the sake of the recovery of the excess fare paid (having operated upon public funds for my travels) as for the principle 3rd class passengers are entitled to proper treatment.

('14', 369, 1, 7, 783359) I have no doubt that the Administration do not desire to see 3rd class passengers in any way roughly handled by inconsiderate officials.

('14', 370, 3, 4, 784240) MY DEAR SISTER,

('14', 373, 3, 4, 788652) MY DEAR FRIEND,
('14', 373, 4, 5, 788668) I have before me your two letters.
('14', 373, 4, 6, 788703) I have not left out a single week.
('14', 373, 4, 7, 788738) But when I was physically unable to write, being engaged here, there or elsewhere, I asked someone to write to you.
('14', 373, 4, 8, 788854) I am happy, am progressing, am strong spiritually and becoming stronger physically but I hate the rush and the constant moving about.
('14', 373, 4, 9, 788988) Yet it is necessary, I feel.
('14', 373, 4, 10, 789017) Before I settle down I have to see certain things.
('14', 373, 4, 11, 789068) I was in Bolpur last week but Mr. Gokhale’s sudden death brought me back to Poona.
('14', 373, 4, 12, 789151) What an end!
('14', 373, 4, 13, 789164) He died in harness.
('14', 373, 4, 14, 789184) He was in full possession of all his faculties to the last and was working away.
('14', 373, 4, 15, 789265) I was with him the Sunday previous to his death, which took place on the Friday following.
('14', 373, 4, 16, 789356) Well, I am without a helmsman.
('14', 373, 4, 17, 789387) But it is well.
('14', 373, 4, 18, 789403) He lives in the spirit and his spirit is enthroned in my heart.
('14', 373, 4, 19, 789467) I have not joined the Society.
('14', 373, 4, 20, 789498) Yet I pleaded for admission but there were differences which could not be bridged.
('14', 373, 4, 21, 789581) So I am to travel about and see tings for myself and study.
('14', 373, 4, 22, 789641) This I shall do.
('14', 373, 4, 23, 789658) Meanwhile I am trying to settle the boys somewhere, possibly near Bombay, i.e., 150 miles from it — in Ahmedabad.
('14', 373, 4, 24, 789772) Maganlal is now in Ahmedabad looking into affairs [sic].
('14', 373, 4, 25, 789829) He has risen to the occasion fully.
('14', 373, 4, 26, 789865) I retain the idea that there is something in the atmosphere here which enables you to be easily spiritual.
('14', 373, 4, 27, 789972) In spite of the rush I am going through there is peace within.
('14', 373, 4, 28, 790035) May such peace be also yours.
('14', 373, 4, 29, 790065) I was going to concoct a letter to the Viceroy about you in conjunction with Andrews when I was called away, as I have said before.
('14', 373, 4, 30, 790197) I hope to try again on reaching Bolpur.
('14', 373, 4, 31, 790237) If I fail, I can only advice that you should stay in London where you are.
('14', 373, 4, 32, 790312) Better to put up with the ills we have than to risk having greater ones whilst trying to avoid what we have.
('14', 373, 4, 33, 790421) No happiness obtainable from without.
('14', 373, 4, 34, 790459) You may study agriculture there.
('14', 373, 4, 35, 790492) I can understand that.
('14', 373, 4, 36, 790515) And is there not a better chance of our meeting earlier if you are there than if you were anywhere else?
('14', 373, 4, 37, 790620) Surely that thought should rivet you to England.

('14', 374, 1, 4, 790968) It surprises me with what tenacity she holds on to a purely fruitarian diet and mostly uncooked.

('14', 376, 1, 2, 794113) 318. SPEECH AT GOKHALE CONDOLENCE MEETING, POONA
('14', 376, 2, 3, 794162) March 3, 1915
('14', 376, 3, 4, 794176) At a crowded meeting of the citizens of Poona held at the Kirloskar Theatre on March 3,1915, under the presidentship of the Governor of Bombay, to condole the recent death of Mr. G. K. Gokhale, the following resolution proposed by Gandhiji was passed:
('14', 376, 4, 5, 794428) That the citizens of Poona in public meeting assembled place on record the great loss the whole country, and especially Poona, has sustained in the untimely death of the Hon.
('14', 376, 4, 6, 794603) Mr. G. K. Gokhale who was the leader of the wholecountry and who by his devotion and self sacrifice has left a great example to his countrymen of selfless public work.
('14', 376, 4, 7, 794771) That this meeting deeply sympathises with Mr. Gokhale’s daughters and other relatives in their grief and requests the President to communicate this Resolution to them.
('14', 376, 5, 8, 794939) Mr. Gandhi proposing the resolution paid an eloquent tribute to the memory of the deceased statesman.
('14', 376, 5, 9, 795041) The speaker said it would look a presumption on his part if he were to add to the glowing tribute which H.E. Lord Willingdon had paid to the memory of the deceased patriot.
('14', 376, 5, 10, 795214) One thing he would like to mention and that was the deep seated religious feelings of the man from which sprang a thoroughness which was one of his chief characteristics.
('14', 376, 5, 11, 795385) He also possessed a conscience.
('14', 376, 5, 12, 795417) Shortly before his death, Mr. Gokhale was called upon to decide whether he should attend a certain conference.
('14', 376, 5, 13, 795528) After much deliberation, he decided to do so in the interests of his country, though at a grave risk to his life.
('14', 376, 6, 14, 795642) The Bombay Chronicle, 4 3 1915 and The Amrita Bazar Patrika, 5 3 1915

('14', 377, 1, 26, 797951) In the other, though knowing better, we fall through weakness.
('14', 377, 1, 27, 798014) In this latter, there is scope for rising yet.
('14', 377, 1, 28, 798061) In the former, one has set one’s face against rising.
('14', 377, 1, 29, 798115) Rising is looked upon rather as falling.

('14', 378, 6, 9, 799248) 320. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH

('14', 380, 3, 4, 801232) MR. CHAIRMAN AND FRIENDS,
('14', 380, 4, 5, 801258) I do not know in what terms to return my thanks to you for giving me such a hearty welcome.
('14', 380, 4, 6, 801350) You, sir (President), have blessed me and have entrusted a charge to me also.
('14', 380, 4, 7, 801428) I hope I shall have deserved your blessing and I shall have power enough and willingness enough to carry out the charge that you have entrusted.
('14', 380, 4, 8, 801573) Calcutta revives hallowed memories.
('14', 380, 4, 9, 801609) It was in 1902 that I recognised, as I had not recognised before, in Mr. Gokhale my political master.
('14', 380, 4, 10, 801711) It was at his feet that I learnt all that I felt I should learn.
('14', 380, 4, 11, 801776) It was at his place that I came to know Dr. P. C. Roy 2. I wondered if I should be able to see his face during my visit and I am thankful that I have been able to do so.
('14', 380, 4, 12, 801946) You have said much which I know I do not deserve.
('14', 380, 4, 13, 801996) If I can steal a corner of your heart, what do you propose to do to Harbat Singh, who went to jail in South Africa against the wishes of his friends and against my wish also?
('14', 380, 5, 14, 802171) Harbat Singh, Mr. Gandhi went on to say, died in prison.
('14', 380, 5, 15, 802228) How could he describe the deed of Baliama 3 than whom a sweeter woman was not born?
('14', 380, 5, 16, 802312) She was a girl of 17. What would they give to Harbat and Baliama?
('14', 380, 5, 17, 802378) If anybody deserved anything, it was they who deserved a corner of their heart but not heroes like himselfwho were imported from England.
('14', 380, 5, 18, 802516) Whatever he was able to do or say, he learnt in England.
('14', 380, 5, 19, 802573) Harbat was uneducated, he did not know a word of English but he was the worthiest of all.
('14', 380, 5, 20, 802663) It was Baliama and not his wife who should be exalted.
('14', 380, 6, 21, 802718) Proceeding, Mr. Gandhi said it was the life of Mr. Gokhale which inspired him and would do so throughout the work that lay before him.
('14', 380, 6, 22, 802853) Mr. Gandhi was described as one who did not break the law.
('14', 380, 6, 23, 802912) 4 That, Mr. Gandhi said, had only a restricted meaning.
