('14', 383, 1, 2, 807250) equipment required for them.
('14', 383, 1, 3, 807279) Where there is a recurring danger of famine, we shall no doubt store food grains.
('14', 383, 1, 4, 807361) But we shall always ask ourselves whether bullocks and food grains are in fact needed.
('14', 383, 1, 5, 807448) We are to observe all the yamas in thought as well, so that we shall grow more secure in them from day to day and come to think of fresh things to renounce.
('14', 383, 1, 6, 807605) Renunciation has no limit to it.
('14', 383, 1, 7, 807638) The more we renounce, the more shall we grow in the knowledge of the atman 1. If the mind continues to move towards renunciation of the desire for hoarding and if in practice we give up hoarding as far as it is physically possible to do, we shall have kept the vow of non hoarding.
('14', 383, 1, 8, 807920) The same is true about non stealing.
('14', 383, 1, 9, 807957) Non hoarding refers to stocking of things not needed.
('14', 383, 1, 10, 808011) Non stealing refers to the use of such things.
('14', 383, 1, 11, 808058) If I need only one shirt to cover myself with but use two, I am guilty of stealing one from another.
('14', 383, 1, 12, 808159) For, a shirt which could have been of use to someone else does not belong to me.
('14', 383, 1, 13, 808240) If five bananas are enough to keep me going, my eating a sixth one is a form of theft.
('14', 383, 1, 14, 808327) Suppose we have a stock of 50 limes, thinking that among us all we would need them.
('14', 383, 1, 15, 808411) I need only two, but take three because there are so many.
('14', 383, 1, 16, 808470) This is theft.
('14', 383, 1, 17, 808485) Such unnecessary consumption is also a violation of the vow of non violence.
('14', 383, 1, 18, 808562) If, with the ideal of non stealing in view, we reduce our consumption of things, We would grow more generous.
('14', 383, 1, 19, 808672) If we do so, actuated by the ideal of non violence, we would grow more compassionate.
('14', 383, 1, 20, 808758) In assuring, as it were, every animal or living thing that it need have no fear on our account, we entertain compassion — love—for it.
('14', 383, 1, 21, 808893) A man who entertains such love will not find any living being inimical to him, not even in thought.
('14', 383, 1, 22, 808993) That is the most emphatic conclusion of the shastras and my experience as well.
('14', 383, 1, 23, 809073) The principle underlying all these vows is truth.
('14', 383, 1, 24, 809123) By deceiving oneself, one may refuse to recognize an act of stealing or hoarding as such.
('14', 383, 1, 25, 809213) Hence, by taking careful thought we can ensure at every step that truth prevails.
('14', 383, 1, 26, 809295) Whenever we are in doubt whether a particular thing should be stored or not, the simple rule is not to store it.
('14', 383, 1, 27, 809408) There is no violation of truth in renunciation.
('14', 383, 1, 28, 809456) When in doubt about the wisdom ofspeaking, it is the duty of a man who has taken the vow of truth not to speak.
('14', 383, 1, 29, 809568) I want all of you to take only such vows as each one feels

('14', 384, 1, 2, 809683) inclined to, of his own free will.
('14', 384, 1, 3, 809718) I always feel that vows are necessary.
('14', 384, 1, 4, 809757) But anyone may take them only when he himself feels the need and take only such as he wants to.
('14', 384, 1, 5, 809853) Ramchandra may have been a man of great prowess, performed innumerable feats and killed hundreds of thousands of monsters, but no one would think of him today if he had not had such devoted men as Lakshmana and Bharata to follow him.
('14', 384, 1, 6, 810087) The point is, if Ramchandra had had no more than extraordinary strength as a fighter, his greatness would have been forgotten after a while.
('14', 384, 1, 7, 810228) There have been many brave warriors who killed monsters as he did.
('14', 384, 1, 8, 810295) There has been none among them whose fame and greatness are sung in every home.
('14', 384, 1, 9, 810375) Ramchandra possessed power of some other kind which he could induce into Lakshmana and Bharata and in virtue of which the latter became great men of austerities.
('14', 384, 1, 10, 810537) Singing in praise of their austerities, Tulsidasji asked who else, if Bharata had not been born and practised austerities unattainable even by great sages, would have turned an ignorant man like him to Rama?
('14', 384, 1, 11, 810745) This is as much as to say that Lakshmana and Bharata were the guardians of Rama’s fame, that is, of his teaching.
('14', 384, 1, 12, 810859) Moreover, austerities are not everything.
('14', 384, 1, 13, 810901) For, if Lakshmana went without food or sleep for 14 years, so did Indrajit 1. But the latter did not know the true significance of austerities which Lakshmana had learnt from Rama; on the contrary, he possessed a nature which inclined him to misuse the power earned through austerities and so came to be known merely as a monster and suffered defeat at the hands of Lakshmana, the man of self mastery, a lover of God and seeker of deliverance.
('14', 384, 1, 14, 811345) In the same way, however great the ideal of Gurudev 2, if there is no one to implement that ideal, it will remain hidden in the profound darkness of the ages.
('14', 384, 1, 15, 811504) Conversely, if there are any to put it into practice, it will spread its light multiplied many times over.
('14', 384, 1, 16, 811611) The steps which one has to climb in order to practise an ideal constitute tapas.
('14', 384, 1, 17, 811692) One should realise, therefore, how very necessary it is to bring tapas—discipline—into the life of children.

('14', 387, 1, 2, 815478) 328. AMENDMENTS TO “OBJECTS” OF IMPERIAL INDIAN CITIZENSHIP ASSOCIATION 1
('14', 387, 2, 3, 815552) [On or after March 16, 1915]
('14', 387, 3, 4, 815581) The following clauses are suggested in place of l to 4 under the head ‘objects’ 2. To ascertain the condition of Indian settlers not excluding indentured labourers outside India and to agitate for the removal of their disabilities and grievances.
('14', 387, 3, 5, 815828) To secure for such settlers equal status with all the other settlers in the respective parts of the world.
('14', 387, 3, 6, 815935) To investigate the conditions of transport under which immigrants travel to their destination and secure an amelioration of such conditions where they may be found to be defective.
('14', 387, 3, 7, 816116) To secure with all the other British subjects equality of treatment alike as to terms of admission and as to residence for all British Indian emigrants to any part of the world including British self governing Colonies.
('14', 387, 3, 8, 816336) To maintain a bureau of information for the benefit of emigrants.
('14', 387, 3, 9, 816402) To establish and maintain a library containing colonial and foreign laws and journals and all other special books of interest to emigrants.
('14', 387, 4, 10, 816542) From a photostat of a draft in Gandhiji’s hand: S.N. 6305
('14', 387, 5, 11, 816600) 1 Amendments suggested in reply to Jahangir Bomanjee Petit’s letter of March 16, 1915, forwarding a draft copy of the rules and regulations of the Imperial Indian Citizenship Association for Gandhiji’s perusal and suggestions 2 “Objects” 1 to 4 were as follows: (1) To protect and safeguard the civic interest of Indians in general in any part of the world outside India, including the self governing British Colonies; (2) To work for, insist upon and obtain for Indians in all British foreign possessions in particular, absolutely equal treatment in all respects with all other British citizens; (3) To establish and maintain by all possible constitutional means the right of Indians to emigrate into and settle in any part of the British Empire, including self governing Colonies, on the same terms as other members of the Empire; (4) To maintain by all legitimate and constitutional means the inherent right and privileges of Indians within the Empire as British citizens.

('14', 388, 1, 2, 817621) 329. LETTER TO AGENTS OF B. I. S. N. COMPANY
('14', 388, 2, 3, 817666) [RANGOON,] March 19, 1915
('14', 388, 3, 4, 817692) THE AGENTS BRITISH INDIA STEAM NAVIGATION COMPANY
('14', 388, 4, 5, 817742) GENTLEMEN,
('14', 388, 5, 6, 817753) With Mrs. Gandhi and five others, I was a deck passenger from Calcutta to Rangoon per s.s.
('14', 388, 5, 7, 817844) Lunka which arried here yesterday 1. I have been in the habit of travelling as a deck passenger now for some time.
('14', 388, 5, 8, 817959) I was surprised to find that the arrangements for deck passengers on s.s.
('14', 388, 5, 9, 818033) Lunka were the worst I have yet seen.
('14', 388, 5, 10, 818071) The deck was uncomfortably crowded.
('14', 388, 5, 11, 818107) There was hardly enough sitting accommodation for the number of passengers taken.
('14', 388, 5, 12, 818189) My party could not all fully stretch ourselves during night although several passengers were anxious to make us comfortable.
('14', 388, 5, 13, 818314) I saw many lying anyhow and anywhere thoroughly cramped.
('14', 388, 5, 14, 818371) The latrines were in a dangerously filthy state.
('14', 388, 5, 15, 818420) The floor space between the seats and the doors was used as urinals.
('14', 388, 5, 16, 818489) There seemed to be no outlet for the urine.
('14', 388, 5, 17, 818533) There was therefore always a pool of urine in front of you.
('14', 388, 5, 18, 818593) The walls of the latrines I found to be extremely dirty and sticky.
('14', 388, 5, 19, 818661) The doors were without bolts.
('14', 388, 5, 20, 818691) The only bathing room I saw was used by the passengers for urinary purposes.
('14', 388, 5, 21, 818768) There was no check against passengers spitting anywhere.
('14', 388, 5, 22, 818825) The deck used by them was never washed.
('14', 388, 5, 23, 818865) I am sure that a great company like yours do not wish to treat their deck passengers in the manner described above.
('14', 388, 5, 24, 818981) May I ask you please to forward this letter to the proper quarters for attention?
('14', 388, 5, 25, 819063) I am likely to return to Calcutta next week and may I hope that my party and I, in common with the other passengers, will be able to have the ordinary sanitary comforts which a human being should have?
('14', 388, 6, 26, 819265) I remain, Yours faithfully
('14', 388, 7, 27, 819292) From a photostat of the original draft in Gandhiji’s hand: S.N. 6167
('14', 388, 8, 28, 819361) 1 On the 17th, both according to the “Diary for 1915’.
('14', 388, 8, 29, 819416) and the Company’s letter of the 20th, acknowledging this letter and promising an inquiry into the complaint about the state of latrines (S.N. 6168)

('14', 389, 2, 3, 819640) Chaitra Sud 6 [March 21, 1915] 1
('14', 389, 3, 4, 819673) BHAISHRI MAGANBHAI, I have your letter.
('14', 389, 3, 5, 819713) I shall be here till Monday night.
('14', 389, 3, 6, 819748) I shall reach Calcutta on Thursday and hope to be at Santiniketan on Saturday.
('14', 389, 3, 7, 819827) It is very good that the work there is proceeding well.
('14', 389, 3, 8, 819883) We should continue to help in it to the best of our ability.
('14', 389, 3, 9, 819944) Look after Messrs.
('14', 389, 3, 10, 819963) Andrews 2
('14', 389, 4, 11, 819973) and Pearson 3 very carefully.
('14', 389, 4, 12, 820003) You have not given any news about Pal Baba’s health.
('14', 389, 4, 13, 820056) Maganlal shall have reached there before my arrival.
('14', 389, 4, 14, 820109) I had told Manilal to send the dried fruit immediately.
('14', 389, 4, 15, 820165) You must have received it soon after your letter.
('14', 389, 4, 16, 820215) It is extremely hot here.
('14', 389, 4, 17, 820241) I am now tired of all the honour and respect being showered on me, I do not see any meaning in it.
('14', 389, 4, 18, 820340) All the three 4 of us are well.

('14', 389, 6, 20, 820400) Look after your health.

('14', 389, 6, 22, 820498) Look after him.
('14', 389, 6, 23, 820514) Give him my regards if he has already come, and give the necessary news.

('14', 389, 8, 25, 820656) 331. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('14', 389, 9, 26, 820690) RANGOON, March 21 [1915]
('14', 389, 10, 27, 820715) MY DEAR FRIEND, This is my second letter from Rangoon.
('14', 389, 10, 28, 820770) Yours of the 12th February has followed me here.
('14', 389, 10, 29, 820819) You want to know my personal life.
('14', 389, 10, 30, 820854) I shall therefore restrict this to its description.
('14', 389, 10, 31, 820906) I rise never later than 5 a.m.
('14', 389, 10, 32, 820937) and often at 4 a.m.
('14', 389, 11, 33, 820957) 1 From the contents it is evident that this letter was written from Rangoon and after the one to the addressee dated March 15, 1915. 2 C. F. Andrews 3 William Winstanley Pearson 4 Ramdas and Chhaganlal Gandhi had accompanied Gandhiji to Rangoon.
('14', 390, 0, 1, 821203) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 391
('14', 390, 1, 2, 821248) Here in Rangoon I go out for a long walk with Dr. Mehta.
('14', 390, 1, 3, 821305) At 10 a.m.
('14', 390, 1, 4, 821316) we take the first meal.
('14', 390, 1, 5, 821340) Mine and Mrs. Gandhi’s consists of uncooked fruits and nuts.
('14', 390, 1, 6, 821401) Ground nuts are roasted.
('14', 390, 1, 7, 821426) My menu today was 4 bananas, 2 tiny tomatoes, 1 tiny unripe mango chopped, 2 spoonfuls of grated fresh coconut, 4 walnuts, perhap 2 ounces of date, ground nut meal mixed, 1 naarangi, 2 slices of wretched melon, 2 lemons and a drink of coconut water.
('14', 390, 1, 8, 821676) Much the same will be taken at 5 p.m.
('14', 390, 1, 9, 821714) Dr. Mehta joins me in the fruitarian meal.
('14', 390, 1, 10, 821757) He adds milk and almonds to the above.
('14', 390, 1, 11, 821796) Both of us walk about the Town barefoot.
('14', 390, 1, 12, 821837) Mrs. Gandhi cooks unripe bananas when she can get them.
('14', 390, 1, 13, 821893) I have now no desire for cooked bananas.
('14', 390, 1, 14, 821934) Hitherto, there has been no difficulty about procuring fruits and nuts.
('14', 390, 1, 15, 822006) Several young men in different parts of the country are trying the fruitarian diet.
('14', 390, 1, 16, 822090) I have asked them to let me have results.
('14', 390, 1, 17, 822132) The tutor to Dr. Mehta’s sons is trying the experiment with me.
('14', 390, 1, 18, 822196) We retire here at about 10 p.m.
('14', 390, 1, 19, 822228) Elsewhere I have not been able to do so.
('14', 390, 1, 20, 822269) The pains in the ribs are still there somewhat.
('14', 390, 1, 21, 822317) I notice nothing in the groins or the right calf.
('14', 390, 1, 22, 822367) I have a good appetite now and my bowels move twice.
('14', 390, 1, 23, 822420) I anticipate no difficulty about continuing the experiment.
('14', 390, 1, 24, 822480) This country seems to be peculiarly fitted for fruitarian diet.
('14', 390, 1, 25, 822544) The temptations which I feared there have not overtaken me at all.
('14', 390, 1, 26, 822611) On the contrary, living our ideals here seems to be comparatively easier.
('14', 390, 1, 27, 822685) Dr. Mehta’s house is nice and airy.
('14', 390, 1, 28, 822721) It is very simply conducted.
('14', 390, 1, 29, 822750) His life is transparent.
('14', 390, 1, 30, 822775) There is no cant or hypocrisy about it.
('14', 390, 1, 31, 822815) You would have liked the life here immensely.
('14', 390, 1, 32, 822861) He has a farm also which is groaning under the weight of fruit trees that were there when he bought it.
('14', 390, 1, 33, 822965) He has introduced handlooms there.
('14', 390, 1, 34, 823000) I leave here on the 29th instant and reach Santiniketan about the 5th April.
('14', 390, 2, 35, 823077) Now good bye.
('14', 390, 2, 36, 823091) With love from us all,
('14', 390, 3, 37, 823114) Yours, OLD FRIEND
('14', 390, 4, 38, 823132) From the original: Gandhi Kallenbach Correspondence.
('14', 390, 4, 39, 823185) Courtesy: National Archives of India
('14', 390, 5, 40, 823222) 1 However, Gandhiji left Rangoon on March 26 and reached Santiniketan on April 2; vide also “Diary for 1915”, 9 January 915.
('14', 391, 0, 1, 823347) 392 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 391, 1, 2, 823389) 332. INTERVIEW AT RANGOON
('14', 391, 2, 3, 823415) [Before March 22, 1915]
('14', 391, 3, 4, 823439) A correspondent from Rangoon writes under the date March 22:
('14', 391, 4, 5, 823500) When I asked Mr. Gandhi to grant me an interview on behalf of a local paper, he simply would not hear of it.
('14', 391, 4, 6, 823609) He said he had returned from S. Africa only recently.
('14', 391, 4, 7, 823663) He had not given to the, problems of India the amount of study they required.
('14', 391, 4, 8, 823741) Therefore he could not be expected to speak on Indian affairs with any semblance of authority.
('14', 391, 4, 9, 823836) He was at present engaged in studying our problems on the late lamented Mr. G. K. Gokhale’s advice.
('14', 391, 4, 10, 823936) When his studies were over, then he would be “out for interviews”, but not till then.
('14', 391, 4, 11, 824022) But I assured him that I had no intention of asking him his opinions about topical matters.
('14', 391, 4, 12, 824114) I said I represented a Tamil paper, that I was myself a member of the Tamil community and that I merely intended to ask him what he thought of the Tamil community with whom he must have largely come into contact in South Africa.
('14', 391, 4, 13, 824343) On hearing this he seemed greatly relieved and without the slightest pause, like a man who had already formed his final opinions on this subject, he delivered a glowing eulogy on the Tamil people.
('14', 391, 5, 14, 824540) He started by saying he could quote chapter and verse for the good work performed by them in South Africa.
('14', 391, 5, 15, 824647) They were of the greatest help to him during the passive resistance struggle.
('14', 391, 5, 16, 824725) All the Indian communities were of very great help to him, but especially the Tamil community.
('14', 391, 5, 17, 824820) It was considered a shame among them for one man not to have gone to jail at least once for the common cause.
('14', 391, 5, 18, 824930) That was not true of any other community, but that was entirely true of the Tamil.
('14', 391, 5, 19, 825013) When he first met them, he learnt to admire them.
('14', 391, 5, 20, 825063) Ever afterwards he had found them better and better.
('14', 391, 5, 21, 825116) He said: I consider I have more in common with the Tamil community than with any other.
('14', 391, 6, 22, 825204) I asked him whether he had any ulterior purpose in visiting Burma.
('14', 391, 6, 23, 825271) His answer was simple.
('14', 391, 6, 24, 825294) He said: My work lies in India.
('14', 391, 7, 25, 825326) The Hindu, 30 3 1915
('14', 392, 0, 1, 825347) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 393
('14', 392, 1, 2, 825392) 333. LETTER TO JAMNADAS GANDHI
('14', 392, 2, 3, 825423) Chaitra Sud 12 [March 28, 1915] 1
('14', 392, 3, 4, 825457) JAMNADAS,
('14', 392, 4, 5, 825467) I have your letter.
('14', 392, 4, 6, 825487) About the diet, you will be able to speak of your experience only after some time.
('14', 392, 4, 7, 825570) With patience, you will see the results.
('14', 392, 4, 8, 825611) It happens that one needs glasses for the eyes, whether to buy them or not, we shall consider by and by.
('14', 392, 4, 9, 825716) I too am surprised how the pillars came down all of a sudden.
('14', 392, 4, 10, 825778) If they were the ones which bore the invaluable inscriptions, the thing is very much to be regretted.
('14', 392, 4, 11, 825880) What you did was quite right.
('14', 392, 4, 12, 825910) You had them brought down after getting your doubts cleared, and that was but proper.
('14', 392, 4, 13, 825996) Show me this place.
('14', 392, 5, 14, 826016) We shall know more then.
('14', 392, 5, 15, 826041) I don’t think tamarind induces weakness.
('14', 392, 5, 16, 826082) An excessive quantity of food must have been taken.
('14', 392, 5, 17, 826134) Fiction means an imagined story.
('14', 392, 5, 18, 826167) It is beyond doubt that the Ramayana and the Mahabharata have less of history and more of imagination.
('14', 392, 5, 19, 826270) They are both sacred books; tens of millions of people look upon them as more than history, and rightly.
('14', 392, 5, 20, 826375) Maybe there was no brother of Rama exactly like Bharata, but there have been such Bharatas at any rate in India and that is why Tulsidas could conceive one.
('14', 392, 5, 21, 826532) It is to the Bharata depicted in the Ramayana that Bharatvarsha 3
('14', 392, 6, 22, 826598) pays homage.
('14', 392, 6, 23, 826611) We need not make ourselves unhappy in the least if, because of our offering satyagraha, Phoenix should turn desolate and go to waste.
('14', 392, 6, 24, 826745) In settled conditions, we should take to agriculture.
('14', 392, 6, 25, 826799) When conditions are unsettled, we may beg or labour, or starve.
('14', 392, 6, 26, 826863) We should have unshakeable faith that nothing that is done is ever done in vain.
('14', 392, 6, 27, 826944) This is a law which has no exception.
('14', 392, 6, 28, 826982) If circumstances arise again, we may resume agriculture.
('14', 392, 6, 29, 827039) If not, we need not worry.
('14', 392, 6, 30, 827066) Agriculture is not the end but only a means.
('14', 392, 6, 31, 827111) The end is, from the lower point of view, service of the people and, from the higher point of view, moksha.
('14', 392, 6, 32, 827219) One of the means for achieving both is agriculture.
('14', 392, 6, 33, 827271) When it hinders us
('14', 392, 7, 34, 827290) 1 Gandhiji left Rangoon on March 26, 1915. 2 It has not been possible to ascertain the exact significance of this paragraph 3 India
('14', 393, 0, 1, 827422) 394 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 393, 1, 2, 827464) from attaining the end, we should abandon it.
('14', 393, 1, 3, 827510) The freedom that the Poet takes is wrong.
('14', 393, 1, 4, 827552) We should, however,bear with a man like him, in the hope that one day he willgive up indulgence of the senses.
('14', 393, 1, 5, 827663) For him, our company is all to the good.
('14', 393, 1, 6, 827704) We should make things as easy for him as we can.
('14', 393, 1, 7, 827753) We need not apply to others the rule we apply to the Poet.
('14', 393, 1, 8, 827812) That is, we need not have the same rule for all in such matters.
('14', 393, 1, 9, 827877) Even the Poet may not cross the bounds, however.
('14', 393, 1, 10, 827926) It is because of the respected Gokhale that we keep using the name “ ‘Phoenix’ Institution”.
('14', 393, 1, 11, 828019) He gave this name to our institution in order that everyone, himself included, may recognize the meaning immediately.
('14', 393, 1, 12, 828137) Most of the aims of Phoenix are the aims of our institution here.
('14', 393, 1, 13, 828203) He understood the aims of Phoenix and so gave that name.
('14', 393, 1, 14, 828260) We need not keep it for ever.
('14', 393, 1, 15, 828290) We will look for another name after we have settled down somewhere.
('14', 393, 1, 16, 828358) I shall preserve the dresses and hand them over to you.
('14', 393, 1, 17, 828414) But they will be useless when I have worn them out.
('14', 393, 1, 18, 828466) You will have, therefore, to make your selection right now.
('14', 393, 1, 19, 828526) They were good experiences I had in Rangoon.
('14', 393, 2, 20, 828571) Blessings from BAPU
('14', 393, 3, 21, 828591) From a copy of the Gujarati original: C.W. 5684. Courtesy: Narandas Gandhi

('14', 394, 5, 9, 829735) 335. SPEECH AT STUDENTS’ HALL, CALCUTTA 3
('14', 394, 6, 10, 829777) March 31, 1915
('14', 394, 7, 11, 829792) On Wednesday evening under the presidency of the Hon’ble Mr. Lyons 4 and before a stupendously large gathering at the Students’ Hall, College Square, Mr. Gandhi delivered an address, embodying advice as to the duties of young men in view of the anarchical crimes committed by some misguided youths in this country.
('14', 394, 8, 12, 830107) Though it was the command of his guru, the late Mr. Gokhale, that Mr. Gandhi, during his stay here keep his ears open but his mouth shut, he could not resist the temptation of addressing the meeting.
('14', 394, 8, 13, 830307) It was the opinion of the speaker as well as his departed guru that politics should not be a sealed book to the student community; for he saw no reason why students should not study and take part in politics.
('14', 394, 8, 14, 830516) He went the length of saying that politics should not be divorced from religion.
('14', 394, 8, 15, 830597) They would agree with him as well as their teachers, professors and theworthy chairman that literary education was of no value, if it was not able to build up a sound character.
('14', 394, 8, 16, 830775) Could it be said that the students or the public men in this country were entirely fearless?
('14', 394, 8, 17, 830868) This question engaged the speaker’s serious attention although he was in exile.
('14', 394, 8, 18, 830948) He understood what political dacoity or political assassination was.
('14', 394, 8, 19, 831017) He had given the subject his most prayerful and careful attention and he had come to the conclusion that some of the students of his country were fired no doubt with zeal in their minds and with love for their motherland, but they did not know how they should love her best.
('14', 394, 8, 20, 831292) He believed that some of them resorted to
('14', 394, 9, 21, 831334) 1 H. N. Kunzru 2 Harihar Shama, a teacher from Baroda, who joined Gandhiji in June, 1915. 3 This was published under the caption “Mr. Gandhi’s Advice to Young Bengal”, reprinted under the caption, “On Anarchical Crimes” in Speeches and Writings of Mahatma Gandhi, Natesan.
('14', 394, 9, 22, 831607) 4 P. C. Lyons
('14', 395, 0, 1, 831621) 396 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 395, 1, 2, 831663) nefarious means, because they did not work in the fear of God, but in the fear of man.
('14', 395, 1, 3, 831750) He was there to tell them that if he was for sedition, he must speak out sedition and think loudly and take the consequences.
('14', 395, 1, 4, 831876) If he did so, it would clear the atmosphere of any taint of hypocrisy.
('14', 395, 1, 5, 831947) If the student, who were the hopes of India, nay perhaps of the Empire, did not work in the fear of God, but in the fear of man, in the fear of the authorities— the Government whether it was represented by the British or an indigenous body —the results would prove disastrous to the country.
('14', 395, 1, 6, 832239) They should always keep their minds open regardless of what the consequence would be.
('14', 395, 1, 7, 832325) The youths who resorted to dacoities and assassinations were misguided youths with whom they should have absolutely no connection.
('14', 395, 1, 8, 832456) They should consider these persons as enemies to themselves and to their country.
('14', 395, 1, 9, 832538) But he did not for a moment suggest that they should hate those people.
('14', 395, 1, 10, 832610) The speaker was not a believer in Government; he would not have any Government.
('14', 395, 1, 11, 832690) He believed that that Government is the best that governs the least.
('14', 395, 1, 12, 832759) But whatever his personal views were, he must say that misguided zeal that resorted to dacoities and assassinations could not be productive of any good.
('14', 395, 1, 13, 832912) These dacoities and assassinations were absolutely a foreign growth in India.
('14', 395, 1, 14, 832990) They could not take root here and could not be a permanent institution here.
('14', 395, 1, 15, 833067) History proved that assassination had done no good.
('14', 395, 1, 16, 833119) The religion of this country, the Hindu religion, was abstention from himsa, that was to say, taking animal life.
('14', 395, 1, 17, 833233) That was he believed, the guiding principle of all religions.
('14', 395, 1, 18, 833295) The Hindu religion said that even the evil doer should not be hated.
('14', 395, 1, 19, 833364) It said that nobody had any right to kill even the evil doer.
('14', 395, 1, 20, 833426) These assassinations were a western institution and the speaker warned his hearers against these western methods and western evils.
('14', 395, 1, 21, 833558) What had they done in the western world?
('14', 395, 1, 22, 833599) If the youths imitated them and believed that they could do the slightest good to India, they were totally mistaken.
('14', 395, 1, 23, 833716) He would not discuss what Government was best for India, whether the British Government or the Government that existed before, though he believed that there was a great deal of room for improvement in the British Government.
('14', 395, 2, 24, 833941) But he would advise his young friends to be fearless, sincere and be guided by the principles of religion.
('14', 395, 2, 25, 834048) If they had a programme for the country, let them place it openly before the public.
('14', 395, 2, 26, 834133) The speaker concluded the address with an appeal to the young men present to be religious and be guided by a spirit of religion andmorality.
('14', 395, 2, 27, 834274) If they were prepared to die, the speaker was prepared to die with them.
('14', 395, 2, 28, 834347) He should 1 be ready to accept their guidance.
('14', 395, 2, 29, 834394) But if they wanted to terrorise the country, he should rise against them.
('14', 395, 3, 30, 834468) The President, in the course of an eloquent speech, eulogised the address of the evening and suggested that the young men should band themselves for the purpose of uprooting the anarchical evil from this country.
('14', 395, 3, 31, 834681) He offered a vote of thanks to Mr.
('14', 395, 4, 32, 834716) 1 The Bengalee, 1 4 1915, has “would”.
('14', 396, 0, 1, 834755) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 397
('14', 396, 1, 2, 834800) Gandhi.
('14', 396, 2, 3, 834808) Mr. Gandhi made a suitable reply and invited correspondence from the student community to which he promised to give a prompt reply.

('14', 396, 11, 18, 835430) 337. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('14', 396, 12, 19, 835464) April 8 [1915]
('14', 396, 13, 20, 835479) MY DEAR FRIEND,
('14', 396, 14, 21, 835495) I am still wandering, still seeing people and places.
('14', 396, 14, 22, 835549) Here I am almost beyond the reach of the post.
('14', 396, 14, 23, 835596) 1 I saw yesterday a little of the Himalayan scenery and I wished you could have been with me as I was wandering.
('14', 396, 14, 24, 835709) I have not seen anything grander anywhere else.
('14', 396, 14, 25, 835757) This place lies at the foot of the mountains.
('14', 396, 14, 26, 835803) It is one of the holiest places of India.
('14', 396, 14, 27, 835845) But the holiness is all but gone.
('14', 396, 14, 28, 835879) I have brought the boys here to help the pilgrims.
('14', 396, 14, 29, 835930) The air is bracing.
('14', 396, 14, 30, 835950) The Ganges you see flowing in all her grandeur.
('14', 396, 15, 31, 835998) 1 Gandhiji was in Gurukul Kangri, Hardwar on this day.
('14', 396, 15, 32, 836053) His Phoenix party had been invited to assist the volunteer corps of the Servants of India Society at the Kumbha Fair at Hardwar; vide also the following item and “Speech at Gurkul, Hardwar”, 8 4 1915.
('14', 397, 0, 1, 836254) 398 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 397, 1, 2, 836296) I have not yet decided where I am to settle down.
('14', 397, 1, 3, 836346) The question is becoming more and more complicated.
('14', 397, 1, 4, 836398) But some day it will solve itself.
('14', 397, 1, 5, 836433) ‘One step enough for me.’ I have just walked 15 miles.
('14', 397, 1, 6, 836488) This is my longest walk for months.
('14', 397, 1, 7, 836524) I do not know how it will affect me.
('14', 397, 1, 8, 836561) But you will excuse my not giving you a fuller letter.
('14', 397, 1, 9, 836616) I am not too tired but I have to go to a meeting in a few minutes.
('14', 397, 2, 10, 836683) Yours with love, OLD FRIEND

('14', 397, 4, 13, 836801) 338. SPEECH AT GURUKUL, HARDWAR
('14', 397, 5, 14, 836833) April 8, 1915
('14', 397, 6, 15, 836847) An address of welcome was presented to Mr. Gandhi by the Brahmacharis of Gurukul Kangri on 8th April when Mr. and Mrs. Gandhi visited Hardwar in connection with the Kumbhi.
('14', 397, 6, 16, 837020) Professor Mahish Charan Sinha with his band of Brahmacharis went to receive him.
('14', 397, 6, 17, 837101) Brahmachari Budhaduri read the address....
('14', 397, 7, 18, 837144) Mr. Gandhi replied: I feel indebted to Mahatmaji for his love.
('14', 397, 7, 19, 837207) I came to Hardwar only to pay my respects to Mahatma Munshiram, as Mr. Andrews has pointed out his name as one of the three great men whom I ought to see in India.
('14', 397, 8, 20, 837371) He thanked the Brahmacharis for the help they sent to their Indian brothers in Africa and felt specially grateful to the Brahmacharis and the Mahatma for the love and affection they extended towards his Phoenix boys while visiting Gurukul and felt that his pilgrimage to Gurukul was satisfactory.
('14', 397, 8, 21, 837668) He said: I am proud that Mahatmaji has called me his brother in a letter, Please pray that I may deserve his fraternity.
('14', 397, 8, 22, 837789) I have come after 28 years to my country.
('14', 397, 8, 23, 837831) I can give no advice.
('14', 397, 8, 24, 837853) I have come to seek guidance and am ready to bow down to anyone who is devoted to the service of the Motherland and I am ready to lay down my life in the service of my country and I shall no more go abroad.
('14', 397, 8, 25, 838060) One of my brothers is gone.
('14', 397, 8, 26, 838088) 1 I want guidance.
('14', 397, 8, 27, 838107) I hope the Mahatmaji will take his place and be a brother to me now.
('14', 397, 9, 28, 838176) 1 Laxmidas Gandhi
('14', 398, 0, 1, 838194) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 399
('14', 398, 1, 2, 838239) To the Brahmacharis, he said: Whatever your aim is, is the aim of all of us.
('14', 398, 1, 3, 838316) May God fulfil our mission.
('14', 398, 2, 4, 838344) Mahatma Munshiram, while welcoming him, said that he was glad to hear that he would live in India and would not go abroad like others to serve India from outside.
('14', 398, 2, 5, 838507) He hoped that Mr. Gandhi would be the beacon light of India.
('14', 398, 3, 6, 838568) The Hindu, 12 4 1915
('14', 398, 4, 7, 838589) 339. SPEECH AT ST.
('14', 398, 4, 8, 838608) STEPHEN’S COLLEGE 1
('14', 398, 5, 9, 838628) DELHI, April 13, 1915
('14', 398, 6, 10, 838650) Mr. Gandhi said he took the liberty of speaking in Hindi having ascertained previously from the Principal that the European staff of the College understood the language of the people and he was glad to know that they did.
('14', 398, 7, 11, 838872) In the course of his address he said that it would be premature for him to offer any advice in regard to Indian problems, for he had been long away from the motherland.
('14', 398, 7, 12, 839041) He needed to learn first before he spoke.
('14', 398, 7, 13, 839083) He had come to learn and hoped to live and die in India now.
('14', 398, 7, 14, 839144) Long years ago when he met his Master Mr. Gokhale, he felt he had found his guru in the sphere of politics and he had tried humbly and faithfully to follow him.
('14', 398, 7, 15, 839305) In the religious sphere he had not met with a religious guru yet.
('14', 398, 7, 16, 839371) But he must not leave people under a false impression in this respect.
('14', 398, 7, 17, 839442) His Master, Gokhale, was a deeply religious man.
('14', 398, 7, 18, 839491) Nobody worked with him in the closest contact but felt the depth of the reality of his essential religious temper.
('14', 398, 7, 19, 839606) To Mr. Gokhale God was a great reality and truth was a great reality.
('14', 398, 7, 20, 839676) This it was which explained his incessant and indefatigable labours which tried his physical powers at last.
('14', 398, 7, 21, 839785) He was a Hindu but one of the right type.
('14', 398, 7, 22, 839827) A Hindu sannyasi once came to him and made a proposal to push the Hindu political cause in a way which would suppress the Mahomedan and he pressed his proposal with many specious religious reasons.
('14', 398, 7, 23, 840025) Mr. Gokhale replied to this person in the following words: “If to be a Hindu I must do as you wish me to do, please publish it abroad that I am not a Hindu.” But Mr. Gokhale was a Hindu and his religion was fearlessness.
('14', 398, 7, 24, 840246) He had a deep belief in God, in the eternal triumph of truth.
('14', 398, 7, 25, 840308) This explained his arduous toil in mastering facts and in investigating truth.
('14', 398, 7, 26, 840387) India’s greatest need was this great fear of God—the fear of God alone and therefore no fear of man.
('14', 398, 7, 27, 840488) That was the one thing we needed.
('14', 398, 7, 28, 840522) Anarchism was
('14', 398, 8, 29, 840536) 1 This was in reply to a welcome address by Principal Rudra.
('14', 398, 8, 30, 840597) Gandhiji spoke in Hindi.
('14', 399, 0, 1, 840622) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 399, 1, 2, 840664) not necessary.
('14', 399, 1, 3, 840679) If it existed, it showed there was no fear of God.
('14', 399, 1, 4, 840730) To face evil we must stand in the strength of God and truth; and there was that ancient text on the College walls that truth, not falsehood, eternally triumphed.
('14', 399, 1, 5, 840892) Evil of any kind could not stand the searching light of truth and could only be rooted out in the strength of God through personal suffering and not through the infliction of suffering on others.
('14', 399, 1, 6, 841088) That was the secret.
('14', 399, 1, 7, 841109) Fear God, therefore, and do not fear men, and remember that ahimsa is our religion, the great gift of our rishis.
('14', 399, 1, 8, 841223) What we have got to do is to bring this religion of the Fear of God into all our lives and even into politics.
('14', 399, 1, 9, 841334) Nothing but this and the passionate love of truthwill help us.
('14', 399, 1, 10, 841397) I would exhort you therefore to obey your teachers and to be true to your College motto, to be rooted in the truth of it, so that you may worthily enter the citizenship of your motherland.”
('14', 399, 2, 11, 841587) Then thanking the students for their splendid help in the South African crisis and their hospitality and kindness to the Phoenix boys when they were the guests of the Principal, Mr. Gandhi resumed his seat amidst loud and prolonged applause.

('14', 399, 4, 14, 841873) 340. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('14', 399, 5, 15, 841907) ON THE WAY TO MADRAS, April 16 [1915]
('14', 399, 6, 16, 841945) MY DEAR FRIEND,
('14', 399, 7, 17, 841961) I am on my way to Madras.
('14', 399, 7, 18, 841987) This eternal moving is now telling on me and I am pining for rest my post too cannot be received as no one knows where I am.
('14', 399, 7, 19, 842112) I shall get letters only at Madras now.
('14', 399, 7, 20, 842152) My experiences have been rich and varied.
('14', 399, 7, 21, 842194) Some time or other I may let you have a portion of them.
('14', 399, 7, 22, 842251) This cannot be until I have settled down somewhere.
('14', 399, 7, 23, 842303) I have not yet stayed a fortnight at a stretch at any place, not even at Rangoon.
('14', 399, 7, 24, 842385) I had hoped to meet the Viceroy at Delhi but he was not there.
('14', 399, 7, 25, 842448) I have not yet been able to hit upon any method of approaching him about you.
('14', 399, 7, 26, 842526) I fear that for the time being you will have to wait there.
('14', 399, 7, 27, 842586) I am sure that you ought not to think of going to California or any other place.
('14', 399, 7, 28, 842667) I only wish you could find some occupation to steady you.
('14', 399, 7, 29, 842725) For me there is no doubt that India has a great hold on me.
('14', 399, 7, 30, 842785) Even amid the most trying circumstances, I am able to perceive the inner life.
('14', 399, 7, 31, 842864) It may be all a delusion.
('14', 399, 7, 32, 842890) But it is there.
('14', 400, 0, 1, 842907) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 401
('14', 400, 1, 2, 842952) At Hardwar, one of the holiest places in India, I felt the need to take a further step and this is what I have done.
('14', 400, 1, 3, 843069) In India I am not to take for my sustenance more than five things during 24 hours and not to eat after sunset.
('14', 400, 1, 4, 843180) Things include condiments.
('14', 400, 1, 5, 843207) Thus if I have taken today, say, bananas, dates, ground nuts, oranges and lemons, I may not take cloves or tamarind.
('14', 400, 1, 6, 843324) I still take two meals and I have to make my choice of five things for the day.
('14', 400, 1, 7, 843404) Both the vows are fairly stiff.
('14', 400, 1, 8, 843436) But they had to be taken.
('14', 400, 1, 9, 843462) The spirit was there.
('14', 400, 1, 10, 843484) The flesh will have to yield.
('14', 400, 1, 11, 843514) The vows were taken on the 10th instant.
('14', 400, 1, 12, 843555) 1 I have left the boys at Hardwar to work as volunteer nurses to pilgrims.
('14', 400, 1, 13, 843630) With me are Mrs. Gandhi and Dr. Mehta’s eldest brother.
('14', 400, 1, 14, 843686) 2 He accompanies me to curb his temper.
('14', 400, 1, 15, 843726) He is 65 years old.
('14', 400, 1, 16, 843746) He has become a pure fruitarian and avoids milk also.
('14', 400, 1, 17, 843800) He is doing very well indeed.
('14', 400, 1, 18, 843830) Needless to say we have been travelling 3rd class throughout.
('14', 400, 1, 19, 843892) At times it is most trying, involving long night journeys in crowded compartments.
('14', 400, 1, 20, 843975) Will you please give the contents of this to Miss Winterbottom and Sorabjee.
('14', 400, 1, 21, 844052) With love,
('14', 400, 2, 22, 844063) OLD FRIEND
('14', 400, 3, 23, 844074) From the original: Gandhi Kallenbach Correspondence.

('14', 400, 4, 25, 844164) 341. SPEECH ON ARRIVAL AT MADRAS
('14', 400, 5, 26, 844197) April 17, 1915
('14', 400, 6, 27, 844212) Mr. and Mrs. M. K. Gandhi arrived in Madras last Saturday evening from Hardwar by the Delhi Express.
('14', 400, 6, 28, 844313) A little disappointment was in store for the people, however.
('14', 400, 6, 29, 844375) When the train arrived, they searched all the first and second class compartments, but in vain, and they were inclined to think that Mr. Gandhi and Mrs. Gandhi had not come.
('14', 400, 6, 30, 844549) But a guard told them that Mr. and Mrs. Gandhi had come by that train and they were in a compartment at the end of the train.
('14', 400, 6, 31, 844675) A long search discovered Mr. and Mrs. Gandhi sitting in a third class compartment.
('14', 400, 6, 32, 844758) Mr. Gandhi looked thin and emaciated, a loose shirt soiled by four days of continuous travel covered his body and a pair of trousers similar in appearance covered his legs.
('14', 400, 7, 33, 844931) 1 Vide “Speech at Reception By Indian Christians, Madras”, 26 4 1915 and “Diary for 1915”, and An Autobiography, Part V, Ch. VII, p.
('14', 400, 7, 34, 845064) 310. 2 ibid
('14', 401, 0, 1, 845076) 402 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 401, 1, 2, 845118) was a rush to that compartment and the crowd was such that about a dozen policemen who had been there found themselves powerless to manage the crowd and had to leave it to shift as best it could.
('14', 401, 1, 3, 845314) .Shouts of “Long live Mr. and Mrs. Gandhi”, “Long live our hero” and “Bande Mataram” rang from the crowd.
('14', 401, 1, 4, 845420) Mr. Gandhi bowed to them in acknowledgement and was conducted to the carriage.
('14', 401, 1, 5, 845499) The students who had gathered in large numbers unyoked the horse and volunteered to drag the carriage.
('14', 401, 1, 6, 845602) The carriage was taken, dragged by the students, to the premises of Messrs Natesan & Co., Sunkurama Chetty Street, Mr. Gandhi being cheered all along the way, Mr. and Mrs. Gandhi standing in the carriage and with hands cooped [sic] acknowledging the greetings.
('14', 401, 2, 7, 845863) On arrival at Messrs Natesan & Co., where he will be stopping during his stay in Madras, Mr. Gandhi stood up in the carriage and in a loud and clear voice said that he was exceedingly thankful to them for the expression of their love to him.
('14', 401, 2, 8, 846105) He was fagged on account of the four days continuous journey and wished to be allowed to say good night.
('14', 401, 2, 9, 846210) He would, however, be free to see them during his stay here between three and five o’clock on all days and discuss questions affecting their common good.
('14', 401, 3, 10, 846364) Mr. and Mrs. Gandhi expect to stay in Madras for a fortnight.
('14', 401, 3, 11, 846426) Mr. Gandhi desires to visit the places in the South wherefrom the bulk of South African Indian settlers have been drawn in order to meet such of the passive resisters as have settled in India.

('14', 401, 5, 13, 846640) 342. LETTER TO LAZARUS
('14', 401, 6, 14, 846663) MADRAS, [After April 17, 1915] 1
('14', 401, 7, 15, 846696) MY DEAR LAZARUS,
('14', 401, 8, 16, 846713) I have your letter.
('14', 401, 8, 17, 846733) The Indian Relief Bill 2 ought to serve, as it was designed to serve, as a sound basis on which we can erect a sound structure.
('14', 401, 8, 18, 846861) I gave ample warning on my leaving South Africa that it might be differently interpreted by the Government.
('14', 401, 8, 19, 846969) In every such case we have our own remedy—legal and moral.
('14', 401, 8, 20, 847028) We may or we may not take up the legal remedy.
('14', 401, 8, 21, 847075) The moral is, and should be, always at our disposal, and that is passive resistance.
('14', 401, 8, 22, 847160) If the spirit of the settlement is not carried out and hardships are inflicted by the
('14', 401, 9, 23, 847246) 1 Gandhiji arrived in Madras on April 17, 1915; this was his first visit to the place after returning from South Africa.
('14', 401, 9, 24, 847367) 2 Vide Appendix “The Indians Relief Act”, 1914.
('14', 402, 0, 1, 847415) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 403
('14', 402, 1, 2, 847460) administration, our final remedy must be passive resistance.
('14', 402, 1, 3, 847521) I hope none of you considered that we would never have to resort to passive resistance.
('14', 402, 1, 4, 847609) All that one could hope for was that the Government had altered their spirit and that they would not lightly invite a revival of the struggle.
('14', 402, 1, 5, 847752) But this last and sovereign remedy is always at our disposal to be used whenever necessary.
('14', 402, 1, 6, 847844) Of course virtue lies in knowing when it should be used.
('14', 402, 1, 7, 847901) Generally speaking, if there is a departure from the fundamental principles which were laid down at the time of the settlement, there is sufficient cause for offering passive resistance.
('14', 402, 1, 8, 848088) You must understand the main purpose of the Relief [Bill] Let me reiterate the chief points.
('14', 402, 1, 9, 848181) First, the removal of the £3 tax: second, the reinstatement of the status of Indian wives: third, repeal of the Asiatic Act.
('14', 402, 1, 10, 848306) These three things have been obtained, I think, practically for all time.
('14', 402, 1, 11, 848380) Just administration of existing laws is a point covered by the correspondence 4 which was published immediately after the passage of the Bill, and it is there that naturally there was an uncertainty.
('14', 402, 1, 12, 848580) Our meaning of just administration may be totally different from that of the Government, and to keep the Government up to the level of our views, there must be continuous watching.
('14', 402, 1, 13, 848761) With regard to Christopher, I note what you would want me to do.
('14', 402, 1, 14, 848826) I shall try to do what I can.
('14', 402, 1, 15, 848856) I have not yet settled down.
('14', 402, 1, 16, 848885) I have just arrived in Madras in the course of my wanderings, but as soon as I settle down I shall see what can be done.
('14', 402, 1, 17, 849006) I take it that, if there is a scholarship forthcoming, he will study in India.
('14', 402, 1, 18, 849085) As to your suggestion about Indian Opinion, its sphere is narrow for want of workers.
('14', 402, 1, 19, 849171) In spite of desperate efforts we have not been able, as you are aware, to get a sufficiently large number of selfless workers.
('14', 402, 1, 20, 849298) I still feel that it cannot be worked upon any other lines.
('14', 402, 1, 21, 849358) Immediately we introduce the system of payment according to ability, it will lose all its usefulness.
('14', 402, 1, 22, 849460) Anyhow, that is not the Phoenix ideal.
('14', 402, 1, 23, 849499) You have to raise at least a few colonial born young men who would devote themselves to public cause without thought of reward, and you can make Indian Opinion a greater power than it is and you can then make it cater for colonial born Indians in the special sense you suggest.
('14', 402, 1, 24, 849777) That a sound body carries a sound mind is after all a truism, but it is to be interpreted with many qualifications.
('14', 402, 1, 25, 849893) Take the celebrated Sandow.
('14', 402, 1, 26, 849921) His is, as you would consider, one of the soundest bodies.
('14', 402, 1, 27, 849980) I am not sure that he necessarily carries a sound mind with it.
('14', 402, 1, 28, 850044) To me a
('14', 403, 0, 1, 850052) 404 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 403, 1, 2, 850094) sound body means one which bends itself to the spirit and is always a ready instrument at its service.
('14', 403, 1, 3, 850197) Such bodies are not made, in my opinion, on the football field.
('14', 403, 1, 4, 850261) They are made on cornfields and farms.
('14', 403, 1, 5, 850300) I would urge you to think this over and you will find innumerable illustrations to prove my statement.
('14', 403, 1, 6, 850403) Our colonial born Indians are carried away with this football and cricket mania.
('14', 403, 1, 7, 850484) These games may have their place under certain circumstances.
('14', 403, 1, 8, 850546) But I feel sure that for us, who are just now so fallen, they have no room.
('14', 403, 1, 9, 850622) Why do we not take the simple fact into consideration that the vast majority of mankind who are vigorous in body and mind are simple agriculturists, that they are strangers to these games, and they are the salt of the earth?
('14', 403, 1, 10, 850847) Without them your and my existence would be an impossibility, whereas you and I are totally unnecessary for their well being.
('14', 403, 1, 11, 850973) The health of both Mrs. Gandhi and myself is good.
('14', 403, 1, 12, 851024) It would have been better had we not been touring so ceaselessly as we have done.
('14', 403, 1, 13, 851106) But the holy atmosphere of India has done all that we had expected.
('14', 403, 1, 14, 851174) It is because there is something peculiar about the Indian atmosphere that I suggest so strongly to the colonial born friends that they should consider it as a matter of duty to visit India, and to visit as Indians wanting to live the purely Indian life, and not half European and half Indian.
('14', 403, 1, 15, 851468) I think I have now covered all the points you have raised.
('14', 403, 1, 16, 851527) Be good to the people of Phoenix, have patience with them.
('14', 403, 1, 17, 851586) They are doing their best, they are giving their all, they mean to render services to the motherland.
('14', 403, 1, 18, 851688) Help them to do so, criticise them by all means, but let your criticism be tempered with love of the settlement.
('14', 403, 1, 19, 851801) Please remember me to the old folks.
('14', 403, 1, 20, 851838) I should not forget you or Brian from whom I have received so much love.
('14', 403, 1, 21, 851911) Whenever you are prepared to give me your boys on my terms, I shall be ready to take them over.
('14', 403, 1, 22, 852007) The sooner you come to a decision, the better.
('14', 403, 1, 23, 852054) Else it may be too late for them.
('14', 403, 2, 24, 852088) Yours sincerely

('14', 404, 1, 2, 852209) 343. SPEECH AT GOKHALE CLUB, MADRAS
('14', 404, 2, 3, 852245) April 20, 1915
('14', 404, 3, 4, 852260) Yesterday evening, Mr. Gandhi spent about an hour and a quarter in a conversation in the home of the Servants of India Society with the members of the Gokhale Club, an association of young men started some six months ago for the study of pubic questions under the guidance of experienced elders.
('14', 404, 4, 5, 852556) Mr. Gandhi described his “Phoenix” settlement scheme 1 as one meant for the training of people for the service of the motherland.
('14', 404, 4, 6, 852686) Special attention would be paid in the settlement to the formation of character and several vernaculars would be taught in it.
('14', 404, 4, 7, 852813) In his opinion, the observance of brahmacharya was essential for all national service and would be a necessary condition for admission into the settlement.
('14', 404, 4, 8, 852969) Everyone there would be taught and required to do some manual work, preferably in connection with agriculture.
('14', 404, 4, 9, 853080) The settlement would be open to persons of both sexes, married and unmarried.
('14', 404, 4, 10, 853158) Asked if he would recommend brahmacharya and poverty as ideals to be followed by the whole country, he said he would do so without the least hesitation; only he would recognise it as a religious impossibility for a whole nation to follow them.
('14', 404, 4, 11, 853402) For conduct in life he would recommend two principles above all— love of truth and ahimsa, the latter including abstention from giving any pain to the body or to the mind and extending to all forms of life.
('14', 404, 4, 12, 853609) As to the application of passive resistance to politics, he warned his hearers that it was a very difficult weapon to use and should not be resorted to except as a last resource and in defence of the dearest interest like national honour.
('14', 404, 4, 13, 853848) He was against the use of all machinery and would use only hand made articles.
('14', 404, 5, 14, 853927) When the meeting dispersed, everyone present felt chastened by his inspiring words.
('14', 404, 6, 15, 854011) The Hindu, 21 4 1915
('14', 404, 7, 16, 854032) 1 Vide “Interview to The Madras Mail”, 22 4 1915.
('14', 405, 0, 1, 854082) 406 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 405, 1, 2, 854124) 344. LETTER TO MAGANLAL GANDHI
('14', 405, 2, 3, 854155) [GEORGETOWN, MADRAS] 1
('14', 405, 3, 4, 854178) Vaishakh Sud 7 [April 21, 1915] 2
('14', 405, 4, 5, 854212) MAGANLAL,
('14', 405, 5, 6, 854222) I learnt from Maganbhai that you had reached Gurukula.
('14', 405, 5, 7, 854277) Agricultural work is part of satyagraha.
('14', 405, 5, 8, 854318) We have deduced the necessity of agricultural work from satyagraha.
('14', 405, 5, 9, 854386) Hence the question: what should one do if it becomes necessary to give up agricultural work for the sake of satyagraha?
('14', 405, 5, 10, 854506) My purpose was to show Jamnadas that [in such a situation] agricultural work is not our chief object.
('14', 405, 5, 11, 854608) His question was: What should one do if the ruler of the place where we are living seizes our land?
('14', 405, 5, 12, 854708) Also, that if a situation arises in which one may have to attend immediately to some urgent work, the agricultural work may get neglected.
('14', 405, 5, 13, 854847) I can say much to explain this matter.
('14', 405, 5, 14, 854886) Our object always remains the same.

('14', 406, 9, 21, 856983) On behalf of my wife and myself, I am deeply grateful for the great honour that you here and Madras, and, may I say, this Presidency have done to us and the affection that has been lavished upon us in this great and enlightened—not benighted—Presidency.

('14', 410, 5, 16, 866106) 347. INTERVIEW TO “THE MADRAS MAIL” 2
('14', 410, 6, 17, 866144) April 22, 1915
('14', 410, 7, 18, 866159) Yesterday, a representative of this journal had a long and interesting talk with Mr. M. K. Gandhi, about various topics of current interest, of which the following is a summary:
('14', 410, 8, 19, 866337) Will you kindly tell me, Mr. Gandhi, what is to be your programme of work, now that your labours in South Africa have ended in a satisfactory solution of the Indian situation in that country?
('14', 410, 8, 20, 866529) For this year, of which three months have already gone, I am under instructions from Mr. Gokhale to tour round the country, study the people and institutions, and form my own conclusions before I commence any active work.
('14', 410, 8, 21, 866751) And during this period of probation, I am also to refrain from speaking on controversial topics on public platforms.
('14', 410, 8, 22, 866868) At the end of the year, I shall know definitely what the questions are to which I shall be able to devote my attention.
('14', 410, 8, 23, 866988) There is one thing, however, which it was agreed upon between Mr. Gokhale
('14', 410, 9, 24, 867062) 1 Mahatma Munshiram, an Arya Samaj leader who afterwards embraced sannyasa and adopted the name ‘Shraddhanand’ 2 This appeared under the caption, “Mr. M. K. Gandhi—His Future Work in India”.
('14', 411, 0, 1, 867253) 412 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 411, 1, 2, 867295) and myself that I should continue to do, and that was the conduct of what he called the Phoenix institution.
('14', 411, 1, 3, 867404) It was so called by Mr. Gokhale because he saw the experiment I am about to explain to you in working order partly on the Tolstoy Farm, belonging to Mr. Kallenbach, and partly at Phoenix, a wayside station on the north coast of Natal.
('14', 411, 1, 4, 867639) The experiment consists in training young men, and also women and children, for long service to the Motherland.
('14', 411, 1, 5, 867751) It is a feature of the institution that everyone should perform some form of manual labour, and as agricultural labour is the best form of manual labour, everyone is expected to work for a certain period of the day on the soil.
('14', 411, 1, 6, 867979) It is proposed also to introduce hand weaving.
('14', 411, 1, 7, 868026) All who are in the institution will also study the chief vernaculars of the country, in order that they may be able to come into contact with the masses in different parts of India without any difficulty.
('14', 411, 1, 8, 868231) For mutual intercourse, vernaculars alone will be used, the use of English being confined as far as possible to communications with British people, or those who may not understand any of the chief Indian languages.
('14', 411, 1, 9, 868446) The vow of brahmacharya and poverty will be strictly observed at the institution.
('14', 411, 1, 10, 868528) I feel that if the experiment proves a success, and there is a large response from young men, it will automatically solve many of the important problems that now puzzle or worry us.
('14', 411, 2, 11, 868710) Can you tell me something of the proposed methods of work of the institution and the nature of the service to India?
('14', 411, 2, 12, 868827) It is not possible for me to say what form the service will take.
('14', 411, 2, 13, 868893) It will largely depend upon the results of my observations during the period of probation.
('14', 411, 2, 14, 868984) At the same time, it is easy to see that an important part of the service is really included in the training itself that I have mapped out.
('14', 411, 2, 15, 869124) It ought to be easy for anyone to realize the various directions in which work may be done in this respect; but I do not propose to discuss with the public what branches of public activity are going to occupy my attention and that of my co workers, if only because of my promise to Mr. Gokhale that I would refrain from committing myself to any definite programme until I had previously studied problems in the manner mentioned.
('14', 411, 2, 16, 869553) The obligation not to dothis rests all the more heavily on me in that, I have lost my helmsman, and I am thrown entirely upon my own resources.
('14', 411, 2, 17, 869697) I, therefore, want to act with the greatest caution, and, as far as is humanly possible, to keep an open mind upon all the burning questions of the day.
('14', 412, 0, 1, 869850) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 413
('14', 412, 1, 2, 869895) Was this period of probation imposed on you by Mr. Gokhale because you had been away from India for so very many years?
('14', 412, 1, 3, 870015) Yes, that was his great argument, because I was away from India for nearly 28 years and all my ideas were formed outside India, and, therefore, a corrective in the shape of personal contact with present day conditions was, in his opinion, absolutely necessary.
('14', 412, 2, 4, 870276) Have you noticed any perceptible change in the condition of affairs in India since you last visited this country?
('14', 412, 2, 5, 870390) So far as I have been able to observe and so far as I am competent to compare things to day with things as I observed them in 1902, during my brief visit to India, I notice that there is greater eagerness amongst the younger generation to be of service to the Motherland, and that there is also great willingness to undertake work which may require a measure of self sacrifice.
('14', 412, 3, 6, 870768) Our representative then referred to the Indian question in South Africa, political agitation in India and various other topics, and gathered that Mr. Gandhi does not lay so much store by agitation for obtaining concessions from the Government as by working for the moral, material and economic regeneration of his countrymen, for he is of the opinion that once people make themselves fit by their character and capacity, the grant of privileges will follow as a matter of course—in fact, there will be no need for people to ask for concessions, and whatis granted will be no concessions, for people will have grown into them.
('14', 412, 3, 7, 871394) Mr. Gandhi implicitly believes that no agitation for political concessions will do any service to the country without reform coming from within, at the same time.
('14', 412, 3, 8, 871557) Mr. Gandhi prefers to be judged by his conduct rather than by the words he utters, words spoken under the limitations of an interview not being, in his opinion, capable of expressing all that the person interviewed might like to say on the subjects discussed.
('14', 412, 4, 9, 871817) The Madras Mail, 23 4 1915

('14', 414, 1, 2, 873964) 350. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS, MADRAS
('14', 414, 2, 3, 874007) April 23, 1915
('14', 414, 3, 4, 874022) A representative of the Associated Press interviewed Mr. Gandhi in course of which the latter referred to the splendid loyalty of British Indians in South Africa who stood on the outbreak of war by the Union Government as representing the Imperial Government.
('14', 414, 3, 5, 874282) General Botha in an appreciative letter promised to make use of their services, should the occasion arise.
('14', 414, 4, 6, 874389) Asked if any further improvement in the status of Indians was probable after the war, he said that it largely depended upon the attitude of the Imperial Government and many other considerations.
('14', 414, 5, 7, 874584) Referring to the continuation of his work in South Africa, he said that so far as legal assistance was concerned, Mr. Polak himself was practising as an attorney and was eminently fit to advise.
('14', 414, 5, 8, 874779) There were many able Indian passive resisters, he continued, who were looking after the situation, so that the problems as they rose would be fully looked after by local friends of India assisted by Mr. Polak.
('14', 414, 5, 9, 874989) The Indian Opinion voicing the passive resisters’ views was managed and controlled by Mr. West 1 and Mr. C. Gandhi 2.
('14', 414, 6, 10, 875107) Questioned as to his future work in India, he said he was touring round the country as was advised by Mr. Gokhale for study, preliminary to forming a definite plan of work in the service of the country.
('14', 414, 6, 11, 875310) He said: Meanwhile I shall also be continuing the institution which was being conducted in South Africa and which has for its object the training of young men for life long national service.
('14', 414, 6, 12, 875501) As is well known, I have already charge of several young men and boys who have followed me from South Africa and have been either passive resisters or are sons of passive resisters.
('14', 414, 7, 13, 875683) The Bengalee, 24 4 1915
('14', 414, 8, 14, 875707) 1 A. H. West, Manager of the International Printing Press, Phoenix, which published Indian Opinion 2 Chhaganlal Gandhi

('14', 415, 1, 2, 875868) 351. SPEECH AT RECEPTION BY MUSLIM LEAGUE, MADRAS
('14', 415, 2, 3, 875918) April 24, 1915
('14', 415, 3, 4, 875933) On Saturday evening, the Muslim League was At Home to Mr. and Mrs. Gandhi at Lawley Hall, Mount Road.
('14', 415, 3, 5, 876035) The refreshments being over, Mr. Yakub Hasan 1
('14', 415, 4, 6, 876082) made a short speech .
('14', 415, 4, 7, 876104) He promised on behalf of the Mussalman community co operation in any work he might undertake for the benefit of India.
('14', 415, 5, 8, 876223) Mr. Gandhi made a short reply in which he thanked them on behalf of his wife and himself for their kindness to them.
('14', 415, 5, 9, 876340) A promise had been made to him and it was an unconditional promise to co operate with him in anything he might undertake on behalf of this country.
('14', 415, 5, 10, 876488) It was one thing to promise and another thing to fulfil.
('14', 415, 5, 11, 876545) He gave them fair warning that he was most exacting to demand the discharge of obligations, especially when so voluntarily given and it might give them an uncomfortable hour when he called upon them to discharge their obligations.
('14', 415, 5, 12, 876776) In this connection, he remembered two instances of the valuable services rendered by the Mussalmans in South Africa.
('14', 415, 5, 13, 876893) One was that of Ahmed Mohamed Kachadia 2 who was a merchant.
('14', 415, 5, 14, 876954) He had not known a more stubborn man than Kachadia.
('14', 415, 5, 15, 877006) He went to jail several times for the sake of the country and his European creditors forced insolvency upon him for political reasons, but he was able to pay them 20s.
('14', 415, 5, 16, 877174) in the £.
('14', 415, 5, 17, 877184) The other instance that of Abdul Sahiba Muezzin.
('14', 415, 5, 18, 877233) His services were as valuable as any rendered by anybody else and he also forsook everything and was reduced to poverty on behalf of the mother country.
('14', 415, 5, 19, 877386) He and his family were now in the Phoenix settlement in Natal.
('14', 415, 5, 20, 877449) He again reminded them of the promise they made.
('14', 415, 6, 21, 877498) On Sunday afternoon at 2.30 p.m., the ladies of the Abeda Aikya Ananda Samajum gave an At Home at their premises in Ramaswamy Street, Manady, where an address was also presented.

('14', 416, 1, 2, 877908) 352. SPEECH AT MADRAS LAW DINNER
('14', 416, 2, 3, 877941) April 24, 1915
('14', 416, 3, 4, 877956) Under the auspices of the Madras Bar Association, the Annual Madras Law Dinner, the third of its kind, came off on Saturday evening last in the open air under bright moonlight on the extensive grounds adjoining the Moore Pavilion, People’s Park, Madras.
('14', 416, 3, 5, 878210) The Hon’ble Mr. F. H. M. Corbet, Advocate General, was in the chair....
('14', 416, 3, 6, 878282) Mr. Gandhi, who is now in Madras, and who, as a Barrister, had been invited to the Dinner, was honoured with a seat on the left of the Hon’ble the Advocate General.
('14', 416, 3, 7, 878447) The Chairman asked Mr. Gandhi to propose the toast of “The British Empire”.
('14', 416, 3, 8, 878523) .In proposing the toast of “The British Empire”, Mr. Gandhi said:
('14', 416, 4, 9, 878589) MR. CHAIRMAN, MR. LORD CHIEF JUSTICE, MY LORDS AND GENTLEMEN,
('14', 416, 5, 10, 878651) When the learned Advocate General came to me and asked me to propose this toast, I must confess that I was taken aback a little.
('14', 416, 5, 11, 878780) I don’t think he noticed it himself, but I make that confession to you.
('14', 416, 5, 12, 878852) I felt that I was invited to be present here as at one time I belonged to the profession to which you or most of you belong and as I happen to be in Madras, but that I would be allowed to remain a silent spectator of what was going on here.
('14', 416, 5, 13, 879093) But when he mentioned the thing I did not hesitate to say, “Yes, I shall be pleased to speak to this toast.” During my three months’ touring in India as also in South Africa, I have been often questioned how I, a determined opponent of modern civilization and an avowed patriot, could reconcile myself to loyalty to the British Empire of which India was such a large part, how it was possible for me to find it consistent that India and England could work together for mutual benefit.
('14', 416, 5, 14, 879578) It gives me the greatest pleasure this evening at this very great and important gathering to re declare my loyalty to this British Empire and my loyalty is based upon very selfish grounds.
('14', 416, 5, 15, 879767) As a passive resister I discovered that I could not have that free scope which I had under the British Empire.
('14', 416, 5, 16, 879878) I know that a passive resister has to make good his claim to passive resistance, no matter under what circumstances he finds himself, and I discovered that the British Empire had certain ideals with which I have fallen in love, (“Hear, hear.”) and one of those ideals is that every subject of the British Empire has the freest scope possible for his energies and efforts and whatever he thinks is due to his conscience.
('14', 416, 5, 17, 880298) I think that this is true of the British Empire as it is not true of any other Governments that we
('14', 417, 0, 1, 880397) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 417, 1, 2, 880439) (“Hear, hear.”) I feel as you have perhaps known that I am no lover of any Governmentand I have more than once said that Government is best which governs least, and I have found that it is possible for me to be governed least under the British Empire.
('14', 417, 1, 3, 880691) Hence my loyalty to the British Empire.
('14', 417, 1, 4, 880731) (Loud applause.) And may I before I sit down and ask you to drink to the prosperity of the British Empire remind you of one singular incident that happened during this campaign in far off South Africa.
('14', 417, 1, 5, 880933) General Beyers, the trusted Commander of one of the Forces of the British Empire, rose against that Empire in open rebellion.
('14', 417, 1, 6, 881059) It was only possible for him under that Empire and that Empire alone not to have himself shot on sight.
('14', 417, 1, 7, 881163) General Smuts wrote to him in a memorable letter that he himself was at one time a rebel.
('14', 417, 1, 8, 881253) He wrote to General Beyers that it was only under the British Empire that it was possible for him to save his life.
('14', 417, 1, 9, 881369) Hence my loyalty to the British Empire.
('14', 417, 1, 10, 881409) (Loud applause.)
('14', 417, 2, 11, 881426) The toast was very enthusiastically honoured.
('14', 417, 3, 12, 881472) The Hindu, 26 4 1915
('14', 417, 4, 13, 881493) 353. SPEECH AT SOCIAL SERVICE LEAGUE, MADRAS
('14', 417, 5, 14, 881538) April 25, 1915
('14', 417, 6, 15, 881553) The members of the Social Service League met Mr. Gandhi in the Ranade Hall, on Sunday (25 4 1915) last at 3.30 p.m.
('14', 417, 6, 16, 881669) Among those present were Mr. S. Sreenivasa Aiyangar, Rao Bahadur T. Vijayaraghavachariar, the Hon’ble Mr. V. S. Srinivasa Sastri, Mr. V. T. Krishnamachariar, Mr. G. A. Natesan and others.
('14', 417, 7, 17, 881857) Mr. Gandhi, who was introduced to the meeting by Mr. T. Vijayarag havachariar, said that he had already heard something of the work which the League had been doing.
('14', 417, 7, 18, 882022) He began by saying that all social work must be undertaken in a spirit of utter humility and self sacrifice and instanced Mr. Gokhale who had said that to all true pubic workers, work was its own reward.
('14', 417, 7, 19, 882226) Absence of recognition or appreciation should not in the least deter a social worker from carrying on his work strenuously and with whole hearted attention.
('14', 417, 7, 20, 882383) Whatsoever a social worker attempted to do, he must not cease his labours till he had carried it out to a successful conclusion.
('14', 417, 7, 21, 882512) He was against half hearted social service and said that such work had better not be done at all.
('14', 417, 7, 22, 882610) Asked what he would advise the members of the League to do who were only able to devote a limited time each week, Mr. Gandhi said that they should devote at least the few hours they could spare with concentrated attention.
('14', 417, 7, 23, 882833) He said that if they had the right sort of men undertaking social work, success could
('14', 418, 0, 1, 882919) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 419
('14', 418, 1, 2, 882964) certainly be hoped for.
('14', 418, 2, 3, 882988) He was unable within the time at his disposal to enter into the question of moral and religious instruction for the depressed classes, while he fully believed that it was a most important point, a true understanding of which would enable them to get to the heart of the people among whom they worked.
('14', 418, 3, 4, 883289) Asked about the policy of mingling Panchama boys with caste boys in night schools, he said that there was nothing bad in it at least in the night schools, where the time of teaching was so short, and that neither the Panchama boys nor the caste boys would be prejudicially affected in any way.
('14', 418, 3, 5, 883583) As to elementary education generally and the policy of extending that education indefinitely, he said that there was no doubt that it did a great deal of good and was an eminently desirable thing, though it was not indispensable for the sanitary betterment of the masses.
('14', 418, 3, 6, 883855) Even people without a knowledge of the 3 R’s were capable of understanding hygienic principles and capable of co operating in any proper scheme of improvement that might be devised for them.
('14', 418, 3, 7, 884046) He said that there was a great and crying need for active work in that direction....
('14', 418, 3, 8, 884131) 1 work or put into their head the notion that manual labour was degrading and said that he saw nothing wrong in a cobbler who had taken the M.A degree following that profession throughout his life.
('14', 418, 3, 9, 884329) Regarding intemperance, Mr. Gandhi said that it was an evil which it was extremely difficult to remedy and that it could be successfully overcome only by a great religious worker.
('14', 418, 3, 10, 884509) He gave a practical instance of this from the experience of a social worker in Poona.
('14', 418, 4, 11, 884595) Mr. Gandhi in closing the conversation said that for social service what was required was not money but men, men of the right sort with right sentiments, with an abiding love and charity and full of faith in their work.
('14', 418, 4, 12, 884815) If they did have such men, money would come, even unasked.
('14', 418, 4, 13, 884874) Much social work could be done without any money.
('14', 418, 4, 14, 884924) It was very difficult for an educated man to understand and appreciate exactly the feelings that prompted the masses unless he retraced his steps; and it was impossible for any man however wealthy to do any social work if he was inspired thereto not by the work itself, but by any feeling of personal ambition.
('14', 418, 4, 15, 885235) It was easier for a camel to go through the eye of a needle than for such a man to do any effective social service.
('14', 418, 5, 16, 885351) With a vote of thanks to Mr. Gandhi, the meeting terminated at 4 30 p.m.
('14', 418, 6, 17, 885424) The Hindu, 27 4 1915
('14', 418, 7, 18, 885445) 1 A few words are missing here in the source which has been damaged.

('14', 421, 5, 19, 890420) 358. SPEECH AT Y. M. C. A., MADRAS 3
('14', 421, 6, 20, 890457) April 27, 1915
('14', 421, 7, 21, 890472) MR. CHAIRMAN AND DEAR FRIENDS, Madras has wellnigh exhausted the English vocabulary in using adjectives of virtue with reference to my wife and myself and, if I may be called upon to give an opinion as to where I have been smothered with kindness, love and attention, I would have to say: it is Madras.
('14', 421, 7, 22, 890775) (Applause.) But, as I have said so often, I believe it of Madras.
('14', 421, 7, 23, 890841) So it is no wonder to me that you are lavishing all these kindnesses with unparalleled generosity, and now the worthy President of the Servants of India Society—under which Society I am going through a period of probation—has, if I may say so, capped it all.
('14', 421, 7, 24, 891100) Am I worthy of these things?
('14', 421, 7, 25, 891129) My answer from the innermost recesses of my heart is an emphatic “No”.
('14', 421, 7, 26, 891200) But I have come to India to become worthy of every adjective that you may use, and all my life will certainly be dedicated to prove worthy of them, if I am to be a worthy servant.
('14', 421, 8, 27, 891380) 1 The first four pages of the letter are not available.
('14', 421, 8, 28, 891436) 2 The month and year have been inferred from Gandhiji’s itinerary.

('14', 422, 1, 2, 891625) And so it is that you have sung that beautiful national song 1, on hearing which all of us sprang to our feet.
('14', 422, 1, 3, 891736) The poet 2 has lavished all the adjectives that he possibly could to describe Mother India.
('14', 422, 1, 4, 891828) He describes Mother India as sweet smelling, sweet speaking, fragrant, all powerful, all good, truthful, a land flowing with milk and honey, and having ripe fields, fruits and grains, and inhabited by a race of men of whom we have only a picture in the great Golden Age.
('14', 422, 1, 5, 892099) He pictures to us a land which shall embrace in its possession the whole of the world, the whole of humanity by the might or right not of physical power but of soul power.

('14', 422, 1, 8, 892599) To day I feel that these adjectives are very largely misplaced in his description of the Motherland, and it is for you and for me to make good the claim that the poet has advanced on behalf of his Motherland.
('14', 422, 2, 9, 892808) THE REAL EDUCATION
('14', 422, 3, 10, 892827) You—the students of Madras as well as students all over India— are you receiving an education which will make you worthy to realise that ideal and which will draw the best out of you, or is it an education which has become a factory for making Government employees or clerks in commercial offices?
('14', 422, 3, 11, 893125) Is the goal of the education that you are receiving that of mere employment whether in the Government departments or other departments?
('14', 422, 3, 12, 893261) If that be the goal of your education, if that is the goal that you have set before yourselves, I feel and I fear that the vision which the poet pictured for himself is far from being realised.
('14', 422, 3, 13, 893455) As you have heard me say perhaps, or as you have read, I am and I have been a determined opponent of modern civilization.

('14', 422, 3, 15, 893867) But I have been told: “How can we help it, seeing that our rulers bring that culture to our Motherland?”
