('14', 423, 1, 2, 894114) Do not make any mistake about it at all.
('14', 423, 1, 3, 894155) I do not for one moment believe that it is for any rulers to bring that culture to you unless you are prepared to accept it, and if it be that the rulers bring that culture before us, I think that we have forces within ourselves to enable us to reject .
('14', 423, 1, 4, 894409) that culture without having to reject the rulers themselves.
('14', 423, 1, 5, 894470) (Applause.) I have said on many a platform that the British race is with us.
('14', 423, 1, 6, 894547) I decline to go into the reasons why that race is with us, but I do believe that it is possible for India if she would but live up to the tradition of the sages of whom you have heard from our worthy President, to transmit a message through this great race, a message not of physical might, but a message of love.
('14', 423, 1, 7, 894861) And then, it will be your privilege to conquer the conquerors not by shedding blood but by sheer force of spiritual predominance.
('14', 423, 1, 8, 894991) When I consider what is going on today in India, I think it is necessary for us to say what our opinion is in connection with the political assassinations and political dacoities.
('14', 423, 1, 9, 895171) I feel that these are purely a foreign importation which cannot take root in this land.
('14', 423, 1, 10, 895259) But you the student world have to beware, lest mentally or morally you give one thought of approval to this kind of terrorism.
('14', 423, 1, 11, 895386) I, as a passive resister, will give you another thing very substantial for it.
('14', 423, 1, 12, 895465) Terrorise yourself; search within; by all means resist tyranny wherever you find it; by all means resist encroachment upon your liberty, but not by shedding the blood of the tyrant.
('14', 423, 1, 13, 895647) That is not what is taught by our religion.
('14', 423, 1, 14, 895691) Our religion is based upon ahimsa, which in its active form is nothing but love, love not only to your neighbours, not only to your friends but love even to those who may be your enemies.
('14', 423, 1, 15, 895879) One word more in connection with the same thing.
('14', 423, 1, 16, 895928) I think that if we were to practise truth, to practise ahimsa, we must immediately see that we also practise fearlessness.
('14', 423, 1, 17, 896051) If our rulers are doing what in our opinion is wrong, and if we feel it our duty to let them hear our advice even though it may be considered sedition, I urge you to speak sedition but at your peril.
('14', 423, 1, 18, 896251) You must be prepared to suffer the consequences.
('14', 423, 1, 19, 896300) And when you are ready to suffer the consequences and not hit below the belt, then I think you will have made good your right to have your advice heard even by the Government.
('14', 423, 2, 20, 896476) RIGHTS AND DUTIES
('14', 423, 3, 21, 896494) I ally myself with the British Government, because I believe that it is possible for me to claim equal partnership with every subject of the British Empire.
('14', 423, 3, 22, 896651) I today claim that equal partnership.
('14', 423, 3, 23, 896689) I do not
('14', 424, 0, 1, 896698) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 425
('14', 424, 1, 2, 896743) belong to a subject rate.
('14', 424, 1, 3, 896769) I do not call myself a member of a subject race.
('14', 424, 1, 4, 896818) But there is this thing: it is not for the British governors to give you; it is for you to take the thing.
('14', 424, 1, 5, 896925) I want and I can take the thing.
('14', 424, 1, 6, 896958) That I want only by discharging my obligations, Max Muller 1 has told us—we need not go to Max Muller to interpret our own religion but he says, our religion consists of the four letters “D u t y” and not the five letters “R i g h t”.
('14', 424, 1, 7, 897193) And if you believe that all that we want can grow from better discharge of our duty, then think always of your duty and fighting along those lines, you will have no fear of any man, you will fear only God.
('14', 424, 1, 8, 897399) That is the message that my master—if I may say so, your master, too—Mr. Gokhale has given to us.
('14', 424, 1, 9, 897497) What is that message then?
('14', 424, 1, 10, 897524) It is in the constitution of the Servants of India Society and that is the message by which I wish to be guided in my life.
('14', 424, 1, 11, 897648) The message is to spiritualize the political life and the political institutions of the country.
('14', 424, 1, 12, 897745) We must immediately set about realising its practice.
('14', 424, 1, 13, 897799) The students cannot be away from politics.
('14', 424, 1, 14, 897842) Politics is as essential to them as religion.
('14', 424, 1, 15, 897888) Politics cannot be divorced from religion.
('14', 424, 1, 16, 897931) Politics divorced from religion becomes debasing.
('14', 424, 1, 17, 897981) Modern culture and modern civilization are such politics.
('14', 424, 1, 18, 898039) 2 My views may not be acceptable to you, I know.
('14', 424, 1, 19, 898088) All the same I can only give you what is stirring me to my very depths.
('14', 424, 1, 20, 898160) On the authority of my experiences in South Africa, I claim that your countrymen who had notthat modern culture but who had that strength of the Rishis 3 of old, who have inherited the tapascharya 4 performed by the Rishis, without having known a single word of English literature and without knowing anything whatsoever of the present modern culture, they are able to rise to their full height.
('14', 424, 1, 21, 898556) And what has been possible for the uneducated and illiterate countrymen of ours in South Africa is ten times possible for you and for me today in this sacred land of ours.
('14', 424, 1, 22, 898728) May that be your privilege and may that be my privilege!
('14', 424, 1, 23, 898785) (Applause.)

('14', 427, 6, 7, 902493) 364. SPEECH AT RECEPTION AT MAYAVARAM 1
('14', 427, 7, 8, 902533) May 1, 1915
('14', 427, 8, 9, 902545) MR. CHAIRMAN AND FRIENDS,
('14', 427, 9, 10, 902571) I am exceedingly thankful to the people of Mayavaram for presenting this beautiful address to me on the occasion of our simply passing through your town or village whatever it may be called, on our way to places where I had hoped to see two widows of men who were shot during the struggle that went on for eight years in South Africa.
('14', 427, 9, 11, 902906) I was able to see only one and I was not able to see the other whom I hope to see before I leave this great Presidency.
('14', 427, 9, 12, 903026) It is therefore a matter of greater pleasure to me that you would not allow us to pass unnoticed even though it were simply a passing tour through Mayavaram.
('14', 427, 9, 13, 903184) But if we have appreciated or if we have received this great and warm welcome from you, may I, for the first time after my return to the sacred land, commence to make a return for the great love that has been shown to us and with your permission I shall try to do so this evening.
('14', 427, 9, 14, 903465) It was quite by accident that I had the great pleasure of receiving an address from my Panchama brethren, and there they said that they were without convenience for drinking water, they were without convenience for living supplies and they could not buy or hold land.
('14', 427, 10, 15, 903733) 1 In reply to a welcome address by Municipal Chairman at the meeting in the Victoria Town Hall, with Rao Bahadur V. K. Ramanujachariar in the chair
('14', 428, 0, 1, 903881) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 429
('14', 428, 1, 2, 903926) It was difficult for them even to approach courts.
('14', 428, 1, 3, 903977) Probably, the last is due to their fear, but a fear certainly not due to themselves and who is then responsible for this state of things?
('14', 428, 1, 4, 904115) Do we propose to perpetuate this state of things?
('14', 428, 1, 5, 904165) Is it a part of Hinduism?
('14', 428, 1, 6, 904191) I do not know; I have now to learn what Hinduism really is.
('14', 428, 1, 7, 904251) In so far as I have been able to study Hinduism outside India, I have felt that it is no part of real Hinduism to have in its hold a mass of people whom I would call “untouchables”.
('14', 428, 1, 8, 904433) If it was proved to me that this is an essential part of Hinduism, I for one would declare myself an open rebel against Hinduism itself.
('14', 428, 1, 9, 904570) (“Hear, hear.”) But I am still not convinced and I hope that up to the end of my life, I shall remain unconvinced that it is an essential part of Hinduism.
('14', 428, 1, 10, 904726) But who is responsible for this class of untouchables?
('14', 428, 1, 11, 904781) I have been told that wherever there are Brahmins, it is they who are enjoying supremacy as a matter of right, but today are they enjoying that supremacy?
('14', 428, 1, 12, 904936) If they are, then the sin will fall upon their shoulders and that is the return I am here to declare and that is the return I shall have to make for the kindness you are showing to me; often my love to my friends, relations and even to my dear wife takes devious ways.
('14', 428, 1, 13, 905205) So my return here for your kindness is to suggest a few words which you were probably not prepared to listen to and it does seem to me that it is high time for Brahmins to regain their natural prerogative.
('14', 428, 1, 14, 905411) I recall to my mind the beautiful verse in the Bhagavad Gita 1. I shall not excite the audience by reciting the verse, but give you simply a paraphrase.
('14', 428, 1, 15, 905564) “The true Brahmin is he who is equi minded towards a Pundit and a Pariah.” Are the Brahmins in Mayavaram equi minded towards the Pariah and will they tell me if they are so equi minded and, if so, will they tell me if others will not follow?
('14', 428, 1, 16, 905806) Even if they say that they are prepared to do so but others will not follow, I shall have to disbelieve them until I have revised my notions of Hinduism.
('14', 428, 1, 17, 905960) If the Brahmins themselves consider they are holding a high position by penance and austerity, then they have themselves much to learn, then they will be the people who have cursed and ruined the land.
('14', 428, 1, 18, 906162) My friend the Chairman has asked me the question whether it is true that I am at war with my leaders.
('14', 428, 1, 19, 906264) I say that I am not at war with my leaders.
('14', 428, 1, 20, 906308) I seemed to be at war with my leaders because many things I have heard seem to be inconsistent with my notions of self respect and with self respect to my motherland.
('14', 428, 1, 21, 906475) I feel that they
('14', 428, 2, 22, 906492) 1 Ch. V, v.
('14', 429, 0, 1, 906504) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 429, 1, 2, 906546) are probably not discharging the sacred trust they have taken upon their shoulders; but I am not sure I am studying or endeavouring to take wisdom from them, but I failed to take that wisdom.
('14', 429, 1, 3, 906738) It may be that I am incompetent and unfit to follow them.
('14', 429, 1, 4, 906796) So, I shall revise my ideas.
('14', 429, 1, 5, 906825) Still I am in a position to say that I seem to be at war with my leaders.
('14', 429, 1, 6, 906899) Whatever they do or whatever they say does not somehow or other appeal to me.
('14', 429, 1, 7, 906977) The major part of what they say does not seem to be appealing to me.
('14', 429, 1, 8, 907046) I find here words of welcome in the English language.
('14', 429, 1, 9, 907100) I find in the Congress programme a Resolution on Swadeshi.
('14', 429, 1, 10, 907159) If you hold that you are Swadeshi and yet print these in English, then I am not Swadeshi.
('14', 429, 1, 11, 907249) To me it seems that it is inconsistent.
('14', 429, 1, 12, 907289) I have nothing to say against the English language.
('14', 429, 1, 13, 907341) But I do say that, if you kill the vernaculars and raise the English language on the tomb of the vernaculars (“Hear, hear.”), then you are not favouring Swadeshi in the right sense of the term.
('14', 429, 1, 14, 907535) If you feel that I do not knowTamil, you should pardon me, you should excuse me and teach me and ask me to learn Tamil and by having your welcome in that beautiful language, if you translate it to me, then I should think you are performing some part of the programme.
('14', 429, 1, 15, 907803) Then only I should think I am being taught Swadeshi.
('14', 429, 1, 16, 907856) I asked when we were passing through Mayavaram whether there had been any handlooms here and whether there were handloom weavers here.
('14', 429, 1, 17, 907991) I was told that there were 50 handlooms in Mayavaram.
('14', 429, 1, 18, 908045) What were they engaged in?
('14', 429, 1, 19, 908072) They were simply engaged chiefly in preparing sarees for our women.
('14', 429, 1, 20, 908140) Then, is Swadeshi to be confined only to the women?
('14', 429, 1, 21, 908192) Is it to be only in their keeping?
('14', 429, 1, 22, 908227) I do not find that our friends, the male population, also have their stuff prepared for them in these by these weavers and through their handlooms.
('14', 429, 1, 23, 908375) (A voice: There are a thousand handlooms here.) There are, I understand, one thousand handlooms; so much the worse for the leaders!
('14', 429, 1, 24, 908507) (Loud applause.) If these one thousand handlooms are kept chiefly in attending to the wants of our women, double this supply of our handlooms and you will have all your wants supplied by your own weavers and there will be no poverty in the land.
('14', 429, 1, 25, 908753) I ask you and ask our friend the President how far he is indebted to foreign goods for his outfit and if he can tell me that he has tried his utmost and still has failed to outfit himself, or rather to fit himself out with Swadeshi clothing and therefore he has got this stuff, I shall sit at his feet and learn a lesson.
('14', 429, 1, 26, 909075) What I have been able to learn today is that it is entirely possible for me, not with any extra cost to fit myself with Swadeshi clothing.
('14', 429, 1, 27, 909214) How am I to learn, through those who move or
('14', 430, 0, 1, 909259) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 431
('14', 430, 1, 2, 909304) who are supposed to be movers in the Congress, the secret of the Resolution?
('14', 430, 1, 3, 909381) I sit at the feet of my leaders, I sit at the feet of Mayavaram people and let them reveal the mystery, give me the secret of the meaning, teach me how I should behave myself and tell me whether it is a part of Swadeshi, whether it is a part of the national movement that I should drive off those who are without dwellings, who cry for water and that I should reject the advances of those who cry for food.
('14', 430, 1, 4, 909788) These are the questions which I ask my friends here.
('14', 430, 1, 5, 909841) Since I am saying something against you, I doubt whether I shall still enjoy or retain the affection of the student population and whether I shall still retain the blessings of my leaders.
('14', 430, 1, 6, 910030) I ask you to have a large heart and give me a little corner in it.
('14', 430, 1, 7, 910097) I shall try to steal into that corner.
('14', 430, 1, 8, 910136) If you would be kind enough to teach me the wisdom, I shall learn the wisdom in all humility and in all earnestness.
('14', 430, 1, 9, 910253) I am praying for it and I am asking for it.
('14', 430, 1, 10, 910297) If you cannot teach me, I again declare myself at war with my leaders.

('14', 430, 3, 13, 910403) 365. LETTER TO A. H. WEST
('14', 430, 4, 14, 910429) May 4, 1915
('14', 430, 5, 15, 910441) MY DEAR WEST,
('14', 430, 6, 16, 910455) I will take your letter as it comes.
('14', 430, 6, 17, 910492) It is no use your qualifying as a lawyer.
('14', 430, 6, 18, 910534) It is possible you may get some guilty ones discharged on technicalities and you may get the innocent also saved from imprisonment.
('14', 430, 6, 19, 910666) But when you consider what a small percentage of the population passes through the courts, you at once see that it is no part of humanitarian work to take up law.
('14', 430, 6, 20, 910829) All that you can do, without getting the title of a lawyer you are doing.
('14', 430, 6, 21, 910903) More you do not need.
('14', 430, 6, 22, 910925) If you have leisure, read up your laws by all means as Mr. Gokhale did, though he never was a lawyer.
('14', 430, 6, 23, 911027) I am nearing the end of my first tour.
('14', 430, 6, 24, 911066) I hope then to write more regularly and to write for Indian Opinion also.
('14', 430, 6, 25, 911140) I am going through very varied experiences.
('14', 430, 6, 26, 911184) India continues to satisfy my aspirations.
('14', 430, 6, 27, 911227) I see much to dishearten me and I see much to encourage me.
('14', 430, 6, 28, 911287) We are both keeping fairly good health.
('14', 430, 6, 29, 911327) If we can settle down somewhere, we should do better.
('14', 430, 6, 30, 911381) More than this, I have not the time to say just now.
('14', 431, 0, 1, 911434) 432 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('14', 431, 2, 3, 911503) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI [PS.]

('14', 432, 1, 2, 912856) 367. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI
('14', 432, 2, 3, 912887) Vaishakh Vad 5 [May 4, 1915] 1
('14', 432, 3, 4, 912918) NARANDAS,
('14', 432, 4, 5, 912928) I shall arrive there on the 10th or perhaps the 9th.
('14', 432, 4, 6, 912981) So far as I know, Chi.
('14', 432, 4, 7, 913004) Jamnadas had joined the institution, but there may have been a misunderstanding on my part.
('14', 432, 4, 8, 913096) Jamnadas thinks that he had taken no vow.
('14', 432, 4, 9, 913138) One who does not take any vow cannot be a member, though such a one can stay as a student.
('14', 432, 4, 10, 913229) Even a student must observe the vows while he lives in the institution.
('14', 432, 4, 11, 913301) A member must observe them all his life.
('14', 432, 4, 12, 913342) Jamnadas wants to remain outside the institution and observe its rules.
('14', 432, 4, 13, 913414) It seems Harilal’s letter has had some effect on his mind.
('14', 432, 4, 14, 913473) He is hurt by the former’s allegations.
('14', 432, 4, 15, 913513) Groundnuts and dates have done most of us no harm.
('14', 432, 4, 16, 913564) By not eating more than five articles on any day, we advance in the observance of the vow of non violence, as, on that particular day at least, we spare all vegetable life excepting the articles in question.
('14', 432, 4, 17, 913772) The vow concerning [the control of] the palate will also be better observed because one would not have more than five things to enjoy for their taste.
('14', 432, 4, 18, 913923) The vow of non stealing will be conformed to because, in drawing nourishment from five articles, one would not be over eating and there would be greater economy besides.
('14', 432, 4, 19, 914093) I shall have to think much now before eating the groundnut sweet.
('14', 432, 4, 20, 914159) As it would contain three articles, I could have only two in addition.
('14', 432, 4, 21, 914230) Cardamom and similar things would also count as separate articles.
('14', 432, 4, 22, 914297) This is a difficult vow to have taken but I am getting used to it.
('14', 432, 4, 23, 914364) The mind, the dog that it still is, runs about like one seeking to extract the utmost relish from the five articles.
('14', 432, 4, 24, 914481) More you may ask me when we meet.
('14', 432, 4, 25, 914515) I shall be in Bombay for as short a time as possible.
('14', 432, 4, 26, 914569) The mind has only one thought, settling the affairs at Ahmedabad.
('14', 432, 4, 27, 914635) Inform Madhavji 2 about the date of my arrival there.
('14', 432, 5, 28, 914689) Blessings from MOHANDAS

('14', 433, 3, 4, 915056) MR. CHAIRMAN AND FRIENDS,
('14', 433, 4, 5, 915082) I do not propose to inflict a speech upon you.
('14', 433, 4, 6, 915129) I am extremely zealous of individual liberty about which we heard this morning from the eloquent lips of Mrs. Besant 2 and from Mr. Sastriar, with his matchless, merciless, severe and cold logic.
('14', 433, 4, 7, 915325) I was so zealous of your liberty that I had concocted a plot, but, unfortunately it failed.
('14', 433, 4, 8, 915417) I was not able to draw in our worthy Chairman of the Reception Committee and the present president of this Conference.
('14', 433, 4, 9, 915536) I wanted to suggest to them that for the Congresses and for the future Conferences, they might lead the way by not reading their addresses but by simply distributing their addresses for us to read.
('14', 433, 4, 10, 915734) It is an accident that this resolution 3 follows on two resolutions one with reference to my noble master Mr. Gokhale, and the other to the noble Viceroy to whom fitting tribute has been made, and I amhere to acknowledge the indebtedness that your countrymen in South Africa owe to the Viceroy.
('14', 433, 4, 11, 916029) Sir, if my wife and I are worthy of anything that has been said on this platform and on many a platform, I have repeated, and I am here to repeat, that the inspiration that we derived was from an Indian source and that was from the late Mr.Gokhale.
('14', 433, 4, 12, 916278) His life, his me ssage, his words, his methods, have been to me a guiding star, and they will still remain an important guide; and we can best revere hismemory by translating some part of his life into our own.
('14', 433, 4, 13, 916489) My life is dedicated to that, and I appeal to you, my countrymen, not to spoil
('14', 433, 5, 14, 916568) 1 At the 21st Madras Provincial Conference 2 Annie Besant (1847 1933), President of the Theosophical Society in 1907; also founder of Central Hindu College at Benares; President, Indian National Congress, 1917. She had said: “In the successful issue of the struggle in South Africa is a presage of the successful termination of the struggle for liberty on the Indian soil.
('14', 433, 5, 15, 916941) We thank him not only for what he did, but also in that what he did will strengthen the Indian nation in the future.
('14', 433, 5, 16, 917058) Mr. Gandhi’s great help to us is that of inspiration—an inspiration to self sacrifice, an inspiration to following of a great ideal, the recognition of the fact that there is no dishonour in anything that is endured for the sake of right and justice, and that a prison is no dishonour when the soul within it is free, and when prison is accepted as the price of that liberty.” 3 The resolution moved by G. A. Natesan which expressed “grateful appreciation of the enormous sacrifices....” of Gandhiji and Kasturba
('14', 434, 0, 1, 917571) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 435
('14', 434, 1, 2, 917616) us, not to isolate us in the service, not to overrate what we have done in South Africa.
('14', 434, 1, 3, 917705) Let me make this humble appeal.
('14', 434, 1, 4, 917737) Let what is done in South Africa be buried there.
('14', 434, 1, 5, 917787) Our countrymen in South Africa know well of what has been done there.

('14', 434, 1, 8, 917978) We may lose our heads and so be lost to the country.

('14', 434, 3, 11, 918165) 369. SPEECH AT STUDENTS’ MEETING, NELLORE
('14', 434, 4, 12, 918207) May 6, 1915
('14', 434, 5, 13, 918219) The address having been read and presented to Mr. Gandhi, he then thanked the students for taking such a lively part in the Conference 1 and serving as volunteers.’ He said that unless what had been said on the platform was translated into action and interest kept up, these Conferences were of no use.
('14', 434, 5, 14, 918522) A great deal was said about the encouragement of industries on the platform, but when he went into that part of the public hall, where clothes made of fly shuttle weaving and brought from Narayanavanam, Chittoor District, were exhibited and enquired of the owner how much worth of clothes he had brought, and how much of it he had sold, he found that out of Rs. 1,000 worth of clothes, he had sold only Rs. 50 or Rs. 60 worth.
('14', 434, 5, 15, 918949) The clothes were good enough, and in spite of it even the educated could not be induced to put their hands into their pockets and purchase some if only to mark their appreciation of the Swadeshi enterprise.
('14', 434, 5, 16, 919156) When such was the state of encouragement offered to local indigenous industries, there was no hope of advancement.
('14', 434, 5, 17, 919271) He exhorted the students to set a practical example, and not rest contented with merely making speeches.

('14', 437, 3, 5, 924583) 372. SPEECH AT BANGALORE 1
('14', 437, 4, 6, 924610) May 8, 1915
('14', 437, 5, 7, 924622) MY DEAR COUNTRYMEN,
('14', 437, 6, 8, 924642) Before I perform this ceremony to which you have called me, I wish to say this to you that you have given me a great opportunity or rather a privilege on this great occasion.
('14', 437, 6, 9, 924817) I saw in the recitation 2, the beautiful recitation that was given to me, that God is with them whose garment was dusty and tattered.
('14', 437, 6, 10, 924951) My thoughts immediately went to the end of my garment; I examined and found that it is not dusty and it is not tattered; it is fairly spotless and clean.
('14', 437, 6, 11, 925105) God is not in me.
('14', 437, 6, 12, 925123) There are other conditions attached; but in these conditions too I may fail; and you, my dear countrymen, may also fail; and if we do tend this well, we should not dishonour the memory of one whose portrait you have asked me to unveil this morning.
('14', 437, 6, 13, 925372) I have declared myself his disciple in the political field and I have 3 him as my Rajya Guru; and this I claim on behalf of the Indian people.
('14', 437, 6, 14, 925515) It was in 1896 that I made this declaration, and I do not regret having made the choice.
('14', 437, 6, 15, 925604) Mr. Gokhale taught me that the dream of every Indian, who claims to love his country, should be to act in the political field, should be not to glorify in language, but to spiritualise the political life of the country, and the political institutions of the country.
('14', 437, 6, 16, 925871) He inspired my life and is still inspiring [it]; and in that I wish to purify myself and spiritualise myself.
('14', 437, 6, 17, 925981) I have dedicated myself to that ideal.
('14', 437, 6, 18, 926020) I may fail, and to what extent I may fail, I call myself to that extent an unworthy disciple of my master.

('14', 447, 3, 4, 941619) 377. LETTER TO HERMANN KALLENBACH
('14', 447, 4, 5, 941653) AHMEDABAD, May 13 [1915]
('14', 447, 5, 6, 941678) MY DEAR FRIEND, Last week no letter went to you.
('14', 447, 5, 7, 941727) I miscalculated the mail day and found myself at a place from where I could not send a letter to fit in with the mail day at Bombay.
('14', 447, 5, 8, 941860) So you have changed the restaurant life for the life at Walden.
('14', 447, 5, 9, 941924) I do not mind, if it gives you some peace.
('14', 447, 5, 10, 941967) The chief thing is to occupy yourself in something useful.
('14', 447, 5, 11, 942026) It is quite clear you will not study there.
('14', 447, 5, 12, 942070) What you will do when you rejoin me remains to be seen.
('14', 447, 5, 13, 942126) I see no present chance of my 1 securing permit for you.
('14', 447, 5, 14, 942183) With the bitterness between the parties increasing, no permits will be granted.
('14', 447, 5, 15, 942263) I observe too that you are no longer meeting the Roberts.
('14', 447, 5, 16, 942321) I do hope that this forced separation will nerve you and fit you for the struggle to come.
('14', 447, 5, 17, 942412) For whilst the atmosphere here is grand, it requires all the greater effort for the perception it gives one.
('14', 447, 5, 18, 942521) I am now at a place where, for the time being at least, I shall have fixed up the Phoenix party.
('14', 447, 5, 19, 942618) We have almost arranged.
('14', 447, 5, 20, 942643) I am being given a temporary residential place, tools, etc.
('14', 447, 5, 21, 942703) The leaders here will watch me and my work and meanwhile look about for a place which will be an agricultural site.
('14', 447, 5, 22, 942819) I shall then have to think out a plan for buildings, etc.
('14', 447, 5, 23, 942877) In this you could have advised most efficiently.
('14', 447, 5, 24, 942926) However, just now I must simply do the best I can.
('14', 447, 5, 25, 942977) My health continues to be good.
('14', 447, 5, 26, 943009) The pain in the side somehow or other does not leave me entirely.
('14', 447, 5, 27, 943075) It is difficult to understand the thing.
('14', 447, 5, 28, 943116) The fruit diet continues and the restriction to five articles does not cause any trouble.
('14', 447, 5, 29, 943206) The sunset arrangement answers admirably.
('14', 447, 6, 30, 943248) 1 The source here has “you”.
('14', 447, 6, 31, 943277) 2 The reference apparently is to the vows Gandhiji took on April 9 at Hardwar; vide “Speech at Reception by Indians Christians, Madras”, 26 4 1915.

('14', 449, 4, 13, 945941) 379. LETTER TO V. S. SRINIVASA SASTRI
('14', 449, 5, 14, 945979) AHMEDABAD, May 14, 1915
('14', 449, 6, 15, 946003) DEAR MR. SHASTRIAR 1,
('14', 449, 7, 16, 946025) I want to have a quiet chat with you regarding your health.
('14', 449, 7, 17, 946085) I feel very strongly about it.
('14', 449, 7, 18, 946116) I am sure that you can by regulating your diet and taking water treatment completely cure yourself while there is yet time.
('14', 449, 7, 19, 946240) You owe it to the Society and the country to get cured when it is so easily possible to do so.
('14', 449, 7, 20, 946335) In the treatment I suggest, there need be not a day’s interruption in your public work.’ The one thing needful is to follow the cure religiously.
('14', 449, 7, 21, 946481) Prolonged treatment is not necessary to notice its results.
('14', 449, 7, 22, 946541) And here it is: 2 hip baths per day of at least 20 minutes’ duration, the baths to be taken not before the completion of three hours after a meal.
('14', 449, 7, 23, 946688) Two hours’ gentle walk in the open air morning and evening.
('14', 449, 7, 24, 946748) Only two meals per day, the last not after sunset.
('14', 449, 7, 25, 946799) Every morsel of diet must be chewed with deliberation so that it goes down the throat not as a solid mass but as a smooth thick liquid.
('14', 449, 8, 26, 946935) 1 (1869 1946), scholar, statesman; President, Servants of India Society, 1915 27
('14', 450, 0, 1, 947016) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 451
('14', 450, 1, 2, 947061) Whether you have done this or not can always be noticed in your stools.
('14', 450, 1, 3, 947133) The diet to consist of bananas, mangoes, oranges, oats, figs (fresh or dried), sultanas, grapes, lemons, tamarind, papaw, pineapple, prunes, cocoanut, groundnuts, almonds, pistachios, walnuts, olive oil, if necessary.
('14', 450, 1, 4, 947351) Only two varieties of nuts may be taken during the day.
('14', 450, 1, 5, 947407) In quantity no more than 4 ounces of both during the day.
('14', 450, 1, 6, 947465) At the commencement, i.e., for 4 days nuts may be omitted altogether and then gradually introduced.
('14', 450, 1, 7, 947565) Either lemons or tamarind may be taken.
('14', 450, 1, 8, 947605) Figs, dates and other dried fruit should be well washed and soaked for six hours before eating.
('14', 450, 1, 9, 947701) The water in which they are soaked should be drunk.
('14', 450, 1, 10, 947753) If olive oil be taken, no more than an ounce per day may be taken.
('14', 450, 1, 11, 947820) Nine, fair sized bananas should be enough per day along with the other fruits.
('14', 450, 1, 12, 947899) However, quantity may be regulated by each one for himself.
('14', 450, 1, 13, 947959) A month’s trial without a break is sure to show you that complete recovery lies in this direction and no other.
('14', 450, 1, 14, 948071) Of course, all drinks—coffee, tea, soda water, etc., and betel leaves, etc., must be eschewed during the treatment.
('14', 450, 1, 15, 948187) Later on you will go back to your old diet with variations that you may have picked up during the treatment.
('14', 450, 1, 16, 948296) Do please think of this thing seriously.
('14', 450, 1, 17, 948337) Pray remember us both to your mother and Mrs. Shastriar.
('14', 450, 2, 18, 948394) Yours sincerely M. K. GANDHI

('14', 452, 0, 1, 950373) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 453
('14', 452, 1, 2, 950418) 382. DRAFT CONSTITUTION FOR THE ASHRAM 1
('14', 452, 2, 3, 950459) [Before May 20, 1915] 2
('14', 452, 3, 4, 950483) This is only a draft printed for circulation among friends for their comments.
('14', 452, 3, 5, 950562) 3 It is not intended as a statement for the Press.
('14', 452, 4, 6, 950613) SATYAGRAHASHRAM?
('14', 452, 5, 7, 950630) DESHSEVASHRAM?
('14', 452, 5, 8, 950645) SEVAMANDIR?
('14', 452, 7, 9, 950657) The object of the Ashram is to learn how to serve the motherland one’s whole life and to serve it.
('14', 452, 8, 10, 950756) CLASSES
('14', 452, 9, 11, 950764) The Ashram consists of three classes Controllers, Novitiates and Students.
('14', 452, 10, 12, 950839) (1) CONTROLLERS
('14', 452, 11, 13, 950855) The Controllers believe that, in order to learn how to serve the country, the following observances should be enforced in their own lives and they have been trying to do so for some time.
('14', 452, 12, 14, 951043) 1. VOW OF TRUTH
('14', 452, 13, 15, 951059) It is not enough for a person under this vow that he does not ordinarily resort to untruth; such a person ought to know that no deception may be practised even for the good of the country.
('14', 452, 13, 16, 951248) One should consider the example of Prahlad in order to understand how one should behave towards elders such as parents in the interests of Truth.
('14', 452, 14, 17, 951394) 1 This was revised and published as third edition on November 7, 1915. 2 The Ashram, as stated in the third edition, was established on May 20. 3 Vide “Letter to Ranchhodlal Patwari”, 5 6 1915 and “Letter to Purushottam das Thakurdas”, 8 6 1915. 4 These sentences were replaced in the third edition by: “Some revisions have been made in this edition in the light of suggestions from friends or experience.” The revisions were as indicated in the footnotes.
('14', 452, 14, 18, 951851) 5 The third edition appeared under this title, with the following note below it: (Established) in Ahmedabad on Vaishakh Vad 6, Thursday, May 20, 1915).
('14', 453, 0, 1, 952003) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 453, 1, 2, 952045) 2. VOW OF NON VIOLENCE
('14', 453, 2, 3, 952068) It is not enough to refrain from taking the life of any living being.
('14', 453, 2, 4, 952138) He who has pledged himself to this vow may not kill eventhose whom he believes to be unjust; he may not be angry with them, he must love them; thus, he would oppose the tyranny whether of parents, governments or others, but will never kill or hurt the tyrant.
('14', 453, 2, 5, 952398) The follower of truth and non violence will offer satyagraha against tyranny and win over the tyrant by love; he will not carry out the tyrant’s will but he will suffer punishment even unto death for disobeying his will until the tyrant himself is won over.
('14', 453, 3, 6, 952656) 3. VOW OF CELIBACY
('14', 453, 4, 7, 952675) It is well nigh impossible to observe these two vows unless celibacy too is observed; and for this vow it is not enough that one does not look upon another woman with a lustful eye, one has so to control the animal passions that they will not be moved even in thought; if one is married, one will not have sexual intercourse even with one’s wife, but, regarding her as a friend, will establish with her a relationship of perfect purity.
('14', 453, 5, 8, 953112) 4. CONTROL OF THE PALATE
('14', 453, 6, 9, 953137) Until one has overcome the palate, it is difficult to observe the foregoing vows, more especially that of celibacy.
('14', 453, 6, 10, 953253) Control of the palate should therefore be treated as a separate observance by one desirous of serving the country and, believing that eating is only for sustaining the body, one should regulate and purify one’s diet day by day.
('14', 453, 6, 11, 953481) Such a person will immediately, or gradually, as he can, leave off such articles of food as may tend to stimulate animal passions.
('14', 453, 7, 12, 953612) 5. VOW OF NON STEALING
('14', 453, 8, 13, 953635) It is not enough not to steal what is commonly considered as other men’s property.
('14', 453, 8, 14, 953718) One who has pledged himself to this vow should realize that Nature provides from day to day just enough and no more for one’s daily needs by way of food and so hold it theft to use articles of food, dress, etc., which one does not really need and live accordingly.
('14', 453, 9, 15, 953983) 6. VOW OF NON POSSESSION
('14', 453, 10, 16, 954008) It is not enough not to possess and keep much, but it is
('14', 454, 0, 1, 954065) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 455
('14', 454, 1, 2, 954110) necessary not to keep anything which may not be absolutely necessary for the nourishment and protection of our body: thus, if one can do without chairs, one should do so.
('14', 454, 1, 3, 954281) He who has taken this vow will always bear this in mind and endeavour to simplify his life more and more.
('14', 454, 2, 4, 954387) SUBSIDIARY OBSERVANCES
('14', 454, 3, 5, 954410) Two other vows follow from the foregoing.
('14', 454, 4, 6, 954452) 1. VOW OF SWADESHI
('14', 454, 5, 7, 954471) The person who has taken the vow of Swadeshi will never use articles which conceivably involve violation of truth in their manufacture or on the part of their manufacturers.
('14', 454, 5, 8, 954645) It follows, for instance, that a votary of truth will not use articles manufactured in the mills of Manchester, Germany or India, for he cannot be sure that they involve no such violation of truth.
('14', 454, 5, 9, 954843) Moreover, labourers suffer much in the mills.
('14', 454, 5, 10, 954889) The generation of tremendous heat causes enormous destruction of life.
('14', 454, 5, 11, 954960) Besides, the loss of workers’ lives in the manufacture of machines and of other creatures through excessive heat is something impossible to describe.
('14', 454, 5, 12, 955110) Foreign cloth and cloth made by means of machinery are, therefore, tabooed to a votary of non violence as they involve triple violence.
('14', 454, 5, 13, 955246) Further reflection will show that the use of foreign cloth can be held to involve a breach of the vows of non stealing and non possession.
('14', 454, 5, 14, 955385) We follow custom and, for better appearance, wear foreign cloth in preference to the cloth made on our own handlooms with so little effort.
('14', 454, 5, 15, 955525) Artificial beautifying of the body is a hindrance to.
('14', 454, 5, 16, 955579) a brahmachari and so, even from the point of view of that vow, machine made cloth is taboo.
('14', 454, 5, 17, 955671) Therefore, the vow of Swadeshi requires the use of simple clothing made on simple handlooms and stitched in simple style, foreign buttons, cuts, etc., being avoided.
('14', 454, 5, 18, 955837) The same line of reasoning may be applied to all other articles.
('14', 454, 6, 19, 955902) 2. VOW OF FEARLESSNESS
('14', 454, 7, 20, 955925) He who is acted upon by fear can hardly observe the vows of truth, etc.
('14', 454, 7, 21, 955997) The Controllers will, therefore, constantly endeavour to be free from the fear of kings or society, one’s caste or family, thieves, robbers, ferocious animals such as tigers, and even of death.
('14', 454, 7, 22, 956191) One who
('14', 454, 8, 23, 956199) 1 Omitted in the third edition
('14', 455, 0, 1, 956230) 456 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 455, 1, 2, 956272) observes the vow of fearlessness will defend himself or others by truth force or soul force.
('14', 455, 2, 3, 956365) 3. VOW AGAINST UNTOUCHABILITY 1
('14', 455, 3, 4, 956397) According to Hindu religion as traditionally practised, communities such as Dhed, Bhangi, etc., known by the names of Antyaj, Pancham, Achhut and so on, are looked upon as untouchable.
('14', 455, 3, 5, 956582) Hindus belonging to other communities believe that they will be defiled it they touch a member of any of the said communities and, if anyonedoes so accidentally, he thinks that he has committed a sin.
('14', 455, 3, 6, 956783) The founders of the Ashram believe that this practice is a blot on Hindu religion.
('14', 455, 3, 7, 956866) Themselves staunch Hindus, they believe that the Hindu race will continue to add to its load of sin so long as it regards a single community as untouchable.
('14', 455, 3, 8, 957023) Some of the consequences of this practice have been terrible.
('14', 455, 3, 9, 957085) In order to be free from this sin, the Ashram inmates are under a vow to regard the untouchable communities as touchable; actually one Dhed family was staying in the Ashram, and it is still there, when the third edition of these rules was being drawn up.
('14', 455, 3, 10, 957340) It lives exactly in the same condition as others in the Ashram do.
('14', 455, 3, 11, 957407) This vow does not extend to association for purpose of eating.
('14', 455, 3, 12, 957470) All that is desired is the eradication of the evil of untouchability.
('14', 455, 4, 13, 957540) VARNASHRAM 2
('14', 455, 5, 14, 957553) The Ashram does not follow the varnashram dharma.
('14', 455, 5, 15, 957603) Where those in control of the Ashram will take the place of the pupils’ parents and where life long vows of celibacy, non hoarding, etc., are to be observed, varnashram dharma has no scope.
('14', 455, 5, 16, 957793) The Ashram inmates will be in the stage of sanyasis 3 and so it is not necessary for them to follow the rules of this dharma.
('14', 455, 5, 17, 957919) Apart from this, the Ashram has a firm belief in the varnashram dharma.
('14', 455, 5, 18, 957991) The discipline of caste seems to have done no harm to the country; on the contrary, rather.
('14', 455, 5, 19, 958083) There is no reason to believe that eating in company promotes brotherhood ever so slightly.
('14', 455, 5, 20, 958175) In order that the varnashram dharma and caste discipline might in no way be undermined, the Ashram inmates are under obligation, whenever they stir out, to subsist on
('14', 455, 6, 21, 958342) 1 This and the paragraph on Varnashram were added in the third edition.
('14', 455, 6, 22, 958414) 2 The organisation of society into four castes, each with a distinctive function, and the division of life into four stages 3 Those who, in the last stage of life have renounced the world
('14', 456, 0, 1, 958602) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 457
('14', 456, 1, 2, 958647) fruits if they cannot cook their own food.
('14', 456, 2, 3, 958690) MOTHER TONGUE
('14', 456, 3, 4, 958704) It is the belief of the Controllers that no nation or any group thereof can make real progress by abandoning its own language, they will, therefore, use their own language.
('14', 456, 3, 5, 958877) As they desire to be on terms of intimacy with their brethren from all parts of India, they will also learn the chief Indian languages; as Sanskrit is a key to Indian languages, they will learn that too.
('14', 456, 4, 6, 959081) MANUAL WORK
('14', 456, 5, 7, 959093) The Controllers believe that body labour is a duty imposed by nature upon mankind.
('14', 456, 5, 8, 959176) Such labour is the only means by which manmay sustain himself; his mental and spiritual powers should be used for the common good only.
('14', 456, 5, 9, 959312) As the vast majority in the world live on agriculture, the Controllers will always devote some part of their time to working on the land; when that is not possible, they will perform some other bodily labour.
('14', 456, 6, 10, 959521) WEAVING
('14', 456, 7, 11, 959529) The Controllers believe that one of the chief causes of poverty in the land is the virtual disappearance of spinning wheels and handlooms.
('14', 456, 7, 12, 959668) They will, therefore, make every effort to revive this industry by themselves weaving cloth on handlooms.
('14', 456, 8, 13, 959774) POLITICS
('14', 456, 9, 14, 959783) Politics, economic progress, etc., are not unconnected matters; knowing that they are all rooted in religion, the Controllers will make an effort to learn and teach politics, economics, social reform, etc., in a religious spirit and work in these fields with all the zeal that they can command.
('14', 456, 10, 15, 960078) (2) NOVITIATES
('14', 456, 11, 16, 960093) Those who are desirous of following the foregoing programme but are not able immediately to take the necessary vows may be admitted as Novitiates.
('14', 456, 11, 17, 960240) It is obligatory upon them to conform to all the observances which are followed by Controllers the while that they are in the Ashram.
('14', 456, 11, 18, 960374) They will acquire the status of Controllers when they are able to take the necessary vows for life.
('14', 457, 0, 1, 960474) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 457, 1, 2, 960516) (3) STUDENTS
('14', 457, 2, 3, 960529) 1 Any children, whether boys or girls, from four years and upwards may be admitted with the consent of their parents.
('14', 457, 3, 4, 960647) 2 Parents will have to surrender all control over their children.
('14', 457, 3, 5, 960713) 3 Children will not be permitted to visit their parents for any reason until the whole course of study is finished.
('14', 457, 3, 6, 960829) 4 Students will be taught to observe all the vows intended for the Controllers.
('14', 457, 3, 7, 960909) 5 They will receive instruction in religion, agriculture, handloom weaving and letters.
('14', 457, 3, 8, 960997) 6 Instruction in letters will be through the students’ own languages and will include History, Geography, Arithmetic, Algebra, Geometry, Economics, etc., the learning of Sanskrit, Hindi and at least one Dravidian language being obligatory.
('14', 457, 3, 9, 961237) 7 English will be taught as a second language.
('14', 457, 3, 10, 961284) 8 Urdu, Bengali Tamil, Telugu, Devnagari and Gujarati scripts will be taught to all.
('14', 457, 3, 11, 961369) 9 The Controllers believe that the whole course will be completed in ten years.
('14', 457, 3, 12, 961449) 2 Upon reaching the age of majority, students will be given the option of taking the vows or retiring from the Ashram.
('14', 457, 3, 13, 961568) This will make it possible for those to whom the programme has not commended itself to leave the Ashram.
('14', 457, 3, 14, 961673) 10 They will exercise this option at an age when they will require no assistance from their parents or guardians.
('14', 457, 3, 15, 961787) 11 Every endeavour will be made from the very beginning to see that, when they leave, they will be strong enough to have no fear what they would do for their maintenance.
('14', 457, 3, 16, 961958) 12 Grown up persons also may be admitted as students.
('14', 457, 3, 17, 962012) 13 As a rule, everyone will wear the simplest and a uniform style of dress.
('14', 457, 3, 18, 962088) 14 Food will be simple.
('14', 457, 3, 19, 962112) Chillies will be excluded altogether and generally no condiments will be used excepting salt, pepper and turmeric.
('14', 457, 3, 20, 962227) Milk, ghee and other milk products being a hindrance to a
('14', 457, 4, 21, 962285) 1 This was replaced in the third edition by: “Boys and girls under twelve years of age will not be admitted if their parents do not join at the same time.” 2 This sentence was omitted in the third edition.
('14', 458, 0, 1, 962491) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 459
('14', 458, 1, 2, 962536) celibate life and milk being often a cause of tuberculosis and having the same stimulating qualities as meat, they will be most sparingly used, if at all.
('14', 458, 1, 3, 962691) Meals will be served thrice a day and will include dried and fresh fruits in liberal quantities.
('14', 458, 1, 4, 962788) All inmates of the Ashram will be taught the general principles of hygiene.
('14', 458, 1, 5, 962864) 15 No holidays will be observed in this Ashram but, for one and a half days every week, the ordinary routine will be altered and everyone will have some time to attend to his private work.
('14', 458, 1, 6, 963053) 16 During three months in the year, those whose health permits it will be taken on a tour, on foot for the most part, of India.
('14', 458, 1, 7, 963181) 17 Nothing will be charged either from Students or Novitiates towards their monthly expenditure, but parents or the members themselves will be expected to contribute whatever they can towards the expenses of the Ashram.
('14', 458, 2, 8, 963401) MISCELLANEOUS
('14', 458, 3, 9, 963415) Administration of the Ashram will rest with a body of Controllers.
('14', 458, 3, 10, 963482) The Chief Controller will have the right to decide whom to admit and to which category.
('14', 458, 3, 11, 963570) The expenses of the Ashram are being met from moneys already received by the Chief Controller or to be received from friends who may have some faith in the Ashram.
('14', 458, 3, 12, 963734) The Ashram is accommodated in two houses on the banks of the Sabarmati, Ahmedabad, on the road to Sarakhej across the Ellis Bridge.
('14', 458, 3, 13, 963866) It is expected that in a few months, about 250 acres of land will be acquired in the vicinity of Ahmedabad and the Ashram located thereon.
('14', 458, 4, 14, 964005) A REQUEST
('14', 458, 5, 15, 964015) Visitors are requested to observe all the Ashram rules during their stay there.
('14', 458, 5, 16, 964095) Every endeavour will be made to make them comfortable; but the management will be thankful to them if they bring with them their bedding and utensils for meals, as the Ashram rules permit the stocking of only a minimum of articles.
('14', 458, 5, 17, 964327) Those parents who intend sending their children to the Ashram are advised to pay a visit to the Ashram.
('14', 458, 5, 18, 964431) No boy or girl will be admitted before he or she has been duly tested.

('14', 459, 1, 2, 964544) DAILY ROUTINE 1
('14', 459, 2, 3, 964560) (l) An effort is being made to see that everyone in the Ashram gets up at 4 o’clock.
('14', 459, 2, 4, 964645) The first bell rings at 4. (2) It is obligatory on all, except those who are ill, to get up at 4.30. Everyone finishes bathing by 5. (3) 5 to 5.30: Prayers and readings from holy books.
('14', 459, 2, 5, 964831) (4) 5.30 to 7: Breakfast of fruits, such as bananas.
('14', 459, 2, 6, 964884) (5) 7 to 8.30: Manual work.
('14', 459, 2, 7, 964912) This includes drawing water, grinding, sweeping, weaving cooking, etc.
('14', 459, 2, 8, 964983) (6) 8.30 to 10: School work.
('14', 459, 2, 9, 965012) (7) 10 to 12: Meal and cleaning of utensils.
('14', 459, 2, 10, 965057) The meal consists of dal, rice, vegetables and rotlis for five days.
('14', 459, 2, 11, 965126) On two days, there are rotlis and fruits.
('14', 459, 2, 12, 965168) (8) 12 to 3: School work.
('14', 459, 2, 13, 965194) (9) 3 to 5: Work, as in the morning.
('14', 459, 2, 14, 965231) (10) 5 to 6: Meal and cleaning of utensils.
('14', 459, 2, 15, 965275) The meal mostly follows the same pattern as in the morning.
('14', 459, 2, 16, 965335) (11) 6.30 to 7: Prayers, as in the morning.
('14', 459, 2, 17, 965379) (12) 7 to 9: Study, receiving visitors, etc.
('14', 459, 3, 18, 965424) Before nine, all children go to bed.
('14', 459, 3, 19, 965461) At ten the lights are put out.
('14', 459, 3, 20, 965492) For school work, the subjects of study at present are Sanskrit, Gujarati, Tamil, Hindi and Arithmetic.
('14', 459, 3, 21, 965595) Study of History and Geography is included in that of languages.
('14', 459, 3, 22, 965660) No paid teachers or servants are employed in the Ashram.
('14', 459, 3, 23, 965717) In all, the Ashram has at present 35 inmates.
('14', 459, 3, 24, 965763) Four of them live with their families.
('14', 459, 3, 25, 965802) There are five teachers to look after teaching.
('14', 459, 3, 26, 965850) Permanent members of the Ashram include two from North India, nine from Madras Presidency and the rest are from Gujarat and Kathiawar.

('14', 460, 2, 3, 966173) AHMEDABAD, May 20 [1915] 1
('14', 460, 3, 4, 966200) DEAR MR. SHASTRIAR, I have just returned from a brief domestic visit to Rajkot to find your two letters.
('14', 460, 3, 5, 966305) If I may suggest, I think that you should respond to Sir William’s call.
('14', 460, 3, 6, 966378) Sir Pherozeshaw is likely to take the same view that Mrs. Besant does.
('14', 460, 3, 7, 966449) To me it is enough that Sir William wants you, and that you know the subject you are expected to handle.
('14', 460, 3, 8, 966554) Your credentials as President of the Society are and ought to be sufficient to give you the status and authority you will need in your mission.
('14', 460, 3, 9, 966698) And if you go, I suppose you will not need to do so for two months.
('14', 460, 3, 10, 966766) Will you not then during the time get rid of your disease so as to enable you the more effectively to do your work?
('14', 460, 3, 11, 966882) Naiker and Sundaram seem to be doing very well.
('14', 460, 3, 12, 966930) I am settling down here for the time being at any rate.
('14', 460, 4, 13, 966986) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI The pamphlet I have sent you is not the last word.

('14', 461, 2, 3, 967565) APPENDIX I
('14', 461, 3, 4, 967576) THE GREAT MARCH
('14', 461, 4, 5, 967592) [VOLKSRUST, November 8, 1913]
('14', 461, 5, 6, 967622) He [Gandhiji] left almost at once by motor to rejoin the marchers.
('14', 461, 5, 7, 967689) Thus, if there was an effort on Government’s part to put an end to the demonstration by depriving the men of their leader in the hope that they would become discouraged and abandon the attempt to reach the Rand, this effort has been completely stultified.
('14', 461, 5, 8, 967945) I shared the motor in which Messrs Kallenbach and Gandhi overtook the main body of marchers about 33 miles from Volksrust.
('14', 461, 5, 9, 968068) They were well on their way to Kromdraai Station, near Standerton, which is their halt for the day.
('14', 461, 5, 10, 968168) The narrow ribbon of road which leads to the Rand passes through beautiful grassy country, and, as the weather was pleasant, the strikers were walking easily and showed little fatigue.
('14', 461, 5, 11, 968353) They were a little beyond General Botha’s farm when the car overtook them, and there was extraordinary enthusiasm as Mr. Gandhi alighted among them.
('14', 461, 5, 12, 968502) The car had halted at Paardekraal, where Mr. Gandhi spoke some encouraging words to the women.
('14', 461, 5, 13, 968597) Old and infirm men halted there, and Mr. Gandhi left some medicines which a doctor in Newcastle had supplied.
('14', 461, 5, 14, 968707) All along the road the car passed stragglers, who lined up and saluted Mr. Gandhi, calling him “Bapoo”, or father.
('14', 461, 6, 15, 968822) THE RATIONS
('14', 461, 7, 16, 968834) Although the rations served out consist only of a pound and a half loaf of bread and an ounce of sugar per man, the marchers are cheerful and patient to an extraordinary degree.
('14', 461, 7, 17, 969012) They have the utmost confidence in Mr. Gandhi, and obey him implicitly, although as a class indentured coal miners and the like—they are totally unused to discipline unaccompanied by force.
('14', 461, 7, 18, 969202) As lieutenants, Mr. Gandhi has several young Johannesburg Indians who were prominent during the former passive resistance movement, and the mounted constables accompanying the marchers told me they had orders to arrest some of these at Kromdraai and take them in to Standerton.
('14', 461, 8, 19, 969480) Mr. Gandhi informs me that the passive resistance movement is diminishing his resources by £250 a day, and that more than the present contribution of £3,000 per month will have to be sent from India if the success of the movement is to be assured.
('14', 461, 8, 20, 969728) He has, however, no doubt at all about the response from India.
('14', 461, 8, 21, 969792) Apart from the women at Charlestown, there are communities of strikers in every affected area to be supported, and the cost of the march to the Rand is estimated at one shilling per day per man.
('14', 461, 8, 22, 969987) Volksrust bakers have received a contract for the supply of bread, which is sent on each day by rail to an appointed station.
('14', 461, 8, 23, 970113) The sugar is served out for its
('14', 462, 0, 1, 970145) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 463
('14', 462, 1, 2, 970190) sustaining properties, and amounts to about five packets a day in the aggregate.
('14', 462, 1, 3, 970271) The Indians make a hole in their loaves, into which they put their handfuls of sugar.
('14', 462, 1, 4, 970357) Each man carries a pannikin, which he fills with water as often as is possible.
('14', 462, 1, 5, 970437) The marchers had an unexpected treat at Paardekop, where last night tea was served to the full 2,000 odd of them at the expense of a local Indian storekeeper.
('14', 462, 1, 6, 970596) Mr. Gandhi impressed upon them the fact that tea was not on the regular menu.
('14', 462, 1, 7, 970674) Leaving Mr. Gandhi with the passive resisters, whose leadership to the promised land he resumed, Mr. Kallenbach and I returned to Volksrust, and passed about 13 miles from the town a further band of 100 coolies, who crossed the border this morning with as little trouble as their predecessors.
('14', 462, 1, 8, 970968) Some of those who march to Johannesburg, I learn, are men who were charged at Newcastle with breaking their indentures, and were released on their own recognisances through lack of prison accommodation.
('14', 462, 1, 9, 971171) They offered to await trial if food and shelter were provided, but this the local Magistrate refused, and so they departed to join in the march on Johannesburg.

('14', 462, 4, 12, 971371) EXTRACT FROM GENERAL BOTHA’S SPEECH 1
('14', 462, 5, 13, 971409) [NYLSTROOM, November 1, 1913]
('14', 462, 6, 14, 971439) General Botha said he was sure there was only one road to befollowed in dealing with the Asiatic question and that was the right road.
('14', 462, 6, 15, 971574) He hoped people not living in South Africa would realise that their altitude in regardto the Asiatic was not prompted by a desire to get rid of Asiatics, but wasprompted by principle.
('14', 462, 6, 16, 971758) In this country they had Coloured races to deal withand they did not want to have the position complicated any further.
('14', 462, 6, 17, 971878) Their sole aim was to keep the position pure and clean.
('14', 462, 6, 18, 971934) Today he understood the Asiatics would undertake a great march from Newcastle to Volksrust.
('14', 462, 6, 19, 972026) He hoped these people would accept better advice than they were doing today.
('14', 462, 6, 20, 972103) General Smuts had recently made a statement as to what had taken place when Mr. Gokhale was here.
('14', 462, 6, 21, 972201) Mr. Gokhale had replied and made a different explanation of what occurred.
('14', 462, 6, 22, 972276) He (General Botha) wished to state that he was present at the interview with Mr. Gokhale.
('14', 462, 6, 23, 972366) It took place in his (General Botha’s) office, and the others present were General Smuts, Mr. Fischer, and Mr. Gokhale.
('14', 462, 6, 24, 972486) He only wished to say that he agreed with and endorsed every word spoken by General Smuts in regard to that interview, and in regard to what took place.
('14', 462, 6, 25, 972639) “At any rate,” General Botha concluded, “we shall do nothing by which your rights will suffer.”

('14', 463, 3, 4, 973085) APPENDIX III
('14', 463, 4, 5, 973098) POLAK’S LETTER TO LORD AMPTHILL 1
('14', 463, 5, 6, 973132) VOLKSRUST GAOL, November 12, 1913
('14', 463, 6, 7, 973166) DEAR LORD AMPTHILL,
('14', 463, 7, 8, 973186) My present address will not surprise you after the cables that will have doubt less been sent home.
('14', 463, 7, 9, 973286) The circumstances of my arrest you will see from Indian Opinion.
('14', 463, 7, 10, 973351) The whole affair, whilst partially accidental, is really taking advantage of me on the part of the Government.
('14', 463, 7, 11, 973462) I had joined Mr. Gandhi near Greylingstad, in order to discuss a number of matters with him prior to my prospective departure for India on Friday next.
('14', 463, 7, 12, 973614) He was then marching at the head of 1500 of the £3 tax passive resisters who had entered the Transvaal to court arrest, as the Government had refused otherwise to deal with them and had left the heavy burden of feeding and otherwise maintaining them upon us.
('14', 463, 7, 13, 973873) I had received a warning from him that if I came to the Transvaal from Natal, I might be arrested.
('14', 463, 7, 14, 973972) In view of the fact that I, as an outsider, had so often counselled Indian passive resisters to challenge arrest, I felt that it would be highly dishonourable for me—an Englishman—to draw back before such a risk, and I did not hesitate to join him.
('14', 463, 7, 15, 974221) We had hardly been conversing half an hour before we were met by a police sub inspector and the Chief Immigration Officer, who arrested Mr. Gandhi on a warrant from Dundee, charging him with removing indentured Indians from Natal.
('14', 463, 7, 16, 974452) He was driven away at once, and as these hundreds of people were leaderless, did not know where their camping ground was for the night, or where they were to get their rations next day, the authorities having refused the responsibility of taking charge of them and providing for them, I had no option but to accept the
('14', 463, 8, 17, 974771) 1 A copy of this was forwarded by Lord Ampthill to the Colonial Office on December 5, along with a covering letter in which he observed, “I venture to think that the Union Government of South Africa would have done better to invite the leaders of the Indian community to confer with them instead of putting them in gaol as there can be little doubt that under Mr. Gandhi’s leadership the struggle would have been managed without disorder and with none of the injury which has since been caused.
('14', 463, 8, 18, 975266) I trust, however, that His Majesty’s Government have already suggested to the authorities in South Africa that negotiation with Mr. Gandhi affords the most likely means of arriving at a speedy solution of the difficulty.”
('14', 464, 0, 1, 975488) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 465
('14', 464, 1, 2, 975533) responsibility of leading the people to Greylingstad, where we camped on the open veld for the night, and the next day to Balfour, about 13 miles beyond.
('14', 464, 1, 3, 975687) Here the police officer and the Chief Immigration Officer asked me to discuss the situation with them.
('14', 464, 1, 4, 975790) They informed me that they were instructed to order the arrest of all the people as prohibited immigrants in the Transvaal and to deport them to Charlestown, in Natal, where they would be arrested on local charges by the Natal authorities.
('14', 464, 1, 5, 976030) They asked me to co operate with them in entraining the men so as to avoid disturbance and the intervention of the squad of police that had arrived.
('14', 464, 1, 6, 976179) I told them that, in the circumstances, I would co operate with them cordially, as they now assumed the responsibility of feeding and sheltering the people, but that, had they not given me that assurance, I was prepared to continue to march with the men until either they were arrested or I, and I offered to place myself at their disposal for arrest then if they desired to hold me.
('14', 464, 1, 7, 976563) I hey replied that they had no desire whatever to do so and thanked me for my offer of service.
('14', 464, 1, 8, 976659) Later, when the people were arrested, some of the more defiant spirits, who did not know me refused to entrain until they received the instruction from Mr. Gandhi, and carrying the mass with them, they proceeded to resume the march.
('14', 464, 1, 9, 976892) I at once stood in front of them and urged them to remember their status as passive resisters.
('14', 464, 1, 10, 976987) Eventually I prevailed upon them to follow me to the station where they all entrained peacefully.
('14', 464, 1, 11, 977085) I am sure it would have been impossible to entrain them had I not been present, and the men would probably have been goaded into violent reprisals by police tactlessness and military brutality.
('14', 464, 1, 12, 977279) I was specially thanked by the police officials in charge and also, subsequently, by the magistrate here.
('14', 464, 1, 13, 977385) As I did not know exactly what might happen at Charlestown, and in order to assist the authorities to keep order in case of need, I travelled down with the first train.
('14', 464, 1, 14, 977554) Shortly afterwards I was arrested and brought to Volksrust.
('14', 464, 1, 15, 977614) Yesterday both Mr. Kallenbach (whose name is no doubt well known to Your Lordship—he is the owner of Tolstoy Farm, where the passive resisters were maintained in the last struggle, a German by nationality, a Jew, like myself, by religion, and an architect by profession) and I were charged before the magistrate with aiding and abetting in the introduction of prohibited immigrants into the Transvaal.
('14', 464, 1, 16, 978016) A remand until tomorrow was asked for by the prosecution.
('14', 464, 1, 17, 978074) We were refused bail as we declined togive an assurance that meanwhile we would take no further part in the movement.
('14', 464, 1, 18, 978192) We are now in prison awaiting trial, and expect to be convicted tomorrow.
('14', 464, 1, 19, 978266) We shall probably get about 3 months, but whether with or without hard labour I cannot say.
('14', 464, 1, 20, 978358) We shall, of course, refuse to pay the alternative fines.
('14', 464, 2, 21, 978416) I at once wired the circumstances to the Minister of the Interior, explaining that I had intended to leave for India on Friday at Mr. Gokhale’s request, thus leaving it to him to decide whether or not to proceed with the prosecution.
('14', 464, 2, 22, 978650) He has replied that the case should go on.
('14', 464, 2, 23, 978693) I shall not, therefore, be going to India.
('14', 464, 2, 24, 978736) May I suggest that a representation on the subject may be made to the Imperial Government, pointing out
('14', 465, 0, 1, 978840) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 465, 1, 2, 978882) that, with the facts before them, the Union Government have prevented my joining Mr. Gokhale a his request in order to assist him in placing the South African Indian question fully before the Government of India.
('14', 465, 2, 3, 979095) I am sure that Your Lordship will agree that, in the circumstances in which I suddenly found myself, I could not have adopted honourably any other course of action than I did.
('14', 465, 2, 4, 979271) In any other case, such influence as I have with the Indian community would have at once disappeared.
('14', 465, 3, 5, 979373) I may add that the spread of the strike along the Coast, on the plantations, is wholly spontaneous, and indeed, strongly against our advice as we did not wish it to get beyond manageable proportions.
('14', 465, 3, 6, 979573) But the Government must now bear the responsibility.
('14', 465, 4, 7, 979626) Both Mr. Kallenbach and I are looking forward to an enviable period of repose and irresponsibility.
('14', 465, 4, 8, 979726) The strain of the last few weeks upon Mr. Gandhi especially and ourselves has been tremendous and this withdrawal from public activity for the time being will be a matter of real relief to us.
('14', 465, 4, 9, 979919) Mr. Gandhi was sentenced at Dundee yesterday to nine months hard labour, on three separate charges under the indenture law.
('14', 465, 4, 10, 980043) I am afraid that, meanwhile, until my release, Your Lordship must derive your news of the movement from Indian Opinion.
('14', 465, 5, 11, 980163) With kind regards,
('14', 465, 6, 12, 980182) Yours very truly, HY.
('14', 465, 6, 13, 980204) S. L. POLAK
('14', 465, 7, 14, 980216) Colonial Office Records: 551/52

('14', 470, 25, 39, 990049) APPENDIX VI
('14', 470, 26, 40, 990061) LORD HARDINGE’S SPEECH1
('14', 470, 27, 41, 990085) A message from Madras states that the Viceroy (Lord Hardinge), in a speech in reply to Indian addresses said the position of Indians in South Africa for some years past had received the most anxious consideration of the Raj, which was doing all in its power to ensure fair treatment.
('14', 470, 28, 42, 990369) He added: “The Union Act of which you complain has in practice the effect of putting an end to Asiatic emigration to South Africa, though it does not discriminate in so many words against Asiatics.
('14', 470, 28, 43, 990567) We, however, have succeeded in securing the privilege of entry for a limited number of educated Indians annually, and have also specially endeavoured to secure as favourable terms as possible for the Indians already
('14', 470, 29, 44, 990783) 1 This was delivered on November 24, 1913.
('14', 471, 0, 1, 990826) 472 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('14', 471, 1, 2, 990868) resident in the Union.
('14', 471, 1, 3, 990891) Our efforts have resulted in the inclusion of provisions for the right of appeal to the Court on points of law and definition of domicile in accordance with which the position of un indentured Indians is satisfactorily laid down.
('14', 471, 2, 4, 991121) “We are at present in communication with Lord Crewe regarding other restrictions in the Act to which you take exception and we trust our representations will not be resultless.
('14', 471, 2, 5, 991298) You urged retaliatory measures by the Raj, but it is not stated what particular measures are adoptable.
('14', 471, 2, 6, 991402) We forbade the emigration of indentured Indians to Natal in 1911, and the Natal planters sent a delegate to India to beg for a reconsideration of that decision.
('14', 471, 2, 7, 991563) That shows how hardly the planters were hit by the stoppage of that emigration, but I am afraid that it had little effect on South Africa as a whole, and unfortunately it is not easy to find means whereby India can make its indignation felt by those holding the reins of Government in South Africa.
('14', 471, 3, 8, 991862) “Recently your compatriots in South Africa have taken matters into their own hands, organising passive resistance to laws which they consider invidious and unjust, an opinion which we, who are watching their struggles from afar, cannot but share.
('14', 471, 3, 9, 992109) They violated those laws with a full knowledge of the penalties involved, and are ready with all courage and patience to endure the penalties.
('14', 471, 3, 10, 992252) In all this they have the deep and burning sympathy of India and also of those who, like myself, without being Indians, sympathise with the people of this country, but the most recent developments have taken a most serious turn.
('14', 471, 3, 11, 992481) We have seen the widest publicity given to allegations that passive resistance is dealt with by measures which would not be tolerated for a moment in any country claiming to be civilised.
('14', 471, 3, 12, 992669) These allegations were met by a categorical denial by the responsible Government of South Africa, though even the denial contains admissions which do not seem to me to indicate that the Government exercised a very wise discretion in some of the steps it adopted.
('14', 471, 3, 13, 992932) That is the position for the moment.
('14', 471, 3, 14, 992969) I feel that if the South African Government desires to justify itself in the eyes of India and the world, the only course open is to appoint a strong impartial committee, whereon Indian interests will be represented, to conduct the most searching inquiry, and you may rest assured that the Raj will not cease to urge these considerations on the Imperial Government.”
('14', 471, 4, 15, 993336) Indian Opinion, 3 12 1913

('14', 473, 24, 26, 995936) You will observe that Mr. Gandhi’s present attitude is less unreasonable than that which he adopted in his public utterances immediately after his liberation.
('14', 473, 24, 27, 996095) General Smuts is still considering his reply to Mr. Gandhi’s latest proposals, and I think it not improbable that he will agree to grant a personal interview as requested.
('14', 473, 24, 28, 996267) I doubt, however, whether Mr. Gandhi’s suggestions with regard to the constitution of the Commission will be found acceptable.
('14', 473, 24, 29, 996394) The addition of two members, nominated
('14', 473, 25, 30, 996433) 1 This referred to an erroneous report about the movement of a group of Indians collected at Pinetown, near Durban, on January l, the date originally announced by Gandhiji for the resumption of the march into the Transvaal.
('14', 473, 25, 31, 996657) It later transpired that the group acted in ignorance of Gandhiji’s declaration that Passive Resistance would not be resumed on New Year Day.
('14', 473, 25, 32, 996799) 2 This formed part of a despatch forwarding to the Colonial Office copies of correspondence between Gandhiji and the Minister of the Interior, and clippings from various newspapers.
('14', 474, 0, 1, 996981) VOL. 14 : 26 DECEMBER, 1913 20 MAY, 1915 475
('14', 474, 1, 2, 997026) respectively by the Indian community and by the employers of Indian labour, would destroy the judicial character of the Commission, and this would probably entail the resignation of Sir William Solomon.
('14', 474, 1, 3, 997229) The alternative proposal that the Commission should be converted into a single member Commission, consisting only of Sir William Solomon, is not open to the same objection, and neither Mr. Esselen nor Colonel Wylie would probably show any disinclination to resign their membership.
('14', 474, 1, 4, 997511) It would not, however, be easy for the Government so to reconstitute its own Commission at Mr. Gandhi’s bidding without seeming to admit that the two members whose elimination is asked for were in fact not wholly impartial.
('14', 474, 1, 5, 997735) Possibly if General Smuts and Mr. Gandhi meet, their combined ingenuity may succeed in discovering some way out of the difficulty.
('14', 474, 2, 6, 997866) On Monday last General Smuts told my Secretary in confidence that he had received a private letter from Sir William Solomon expressing regret at the bad use which Mr. Gandhi, Mr. Polak and Mr. Kallenbach had made of their liberty, and intimating that if the Commission were to be boycotted by the Indians, in whose interests it had been appointed, it was unlikely that the enquiry could prove anything but one sided.
('14', 474, 2, 7, 998283) Sir William went on to say that he had accepted appointment, much against his own personal inclinations, only from a sense of duty because it had been represented to him that by acting as Chairman he would have an opportunity of rendering a public service.
('14', 474, 2, 8, 998540) As it now seemed likely that the Commission would be unable to do any useful work, he was inclined to doubt whether there was any reason why he should continue to serve.
('14', 474, 2, 9, 998710) General Smuts said that he proposed in his reply to point out the distinction between abstention by the Indians from giving evidence and a renewal of passive resistance, strikes and lawlessness.
('14', 474, 2, 10, 998905) If recourse were again had to disorder, the question whether the enquiry should be proceeded with might arise.
('14', 474, 2, 11, 999016) If, however, the Indians confined themselves simply to a policy of abstention from giving evidence, the Commission would still be able to hear official and other European witnesses upon the incidents of the strike and the allegations of ill treatment, and to consider the general question of grievances from the documentary material which could be laid before it by the Government.
('14', 474, 2, 12, 999398) It was desirable, moreover, that the official witness who was being sent by the Government of India should be afforded an opportunity of being heard.
('14', 474, 2, 13, 999548) General Smuts seemed to hope that these arguments would induce Sir William Solomon to continue to serve.
('14', 474, 2, 14, 999653) He was evidently apprehensive lest Mr. Gandhi should be enabled to enhance his prestige by the personal triumph of breaking up a Government Commission of whose constitution he happened to disapprove.
